HEADLINE: Editors' Note

 BODY:
A front-page article on Nov. 30 described signs that the American economy may be recovering. It quoted business people and economists who were beginning to see signs of improvement. 
 The headline in some editions referred to "the Clinton Recovery," and the first sentence referred to "the Clinton expansion," as did the headline in other editions. Although the article reported suggestions that part of the recovery was due to a psychological reaction to the election of Bill Clinton, most of the statistical evidence of improvement predated the election, and should have been more directly linked to the Bush Administration.

HEADLINE: Clinton Warns That Predictions of Economic Upturn Might Be Premature

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
As he prepared to announce his economic team later this week, President-elect Bill Clinton emerged from days of virtual seclusion today to warn that predictions of an economic upturn might be premature.
On a stop in Chicago on his way from Little Rock, Ark., to the capital, Mr. Clinton emphasized to students at Wilbur Wright Community College, a vocational school, that his economic prescriptions were still essential. 
 "We may or may not be coming out of our recession; there are some good indicators that we are," Mr. Clinton told about 100 students at the school in a working-class neighborhood on Chicago's northwest side. "But the long-term problems are there, and that is what I have to address."
 
Sounding Like a Professor
 Aides described Mr. Clinton's visit to Chicago as a political payback to a state that solidly supported his candidacy and from which he drew several top campaign aides.
Moving his hands in a wave motion to describe the economic peaks and valleys in what amounted to a sometimes-dull lecture, Mr. Clinton sounded more like an economics professor than the next President. Questions from a dozen members of the audience did little to liven the discourse.
Nonetheless, his cautionary words seemed intended to lower expectations and signal that he planned to emphasize long-term remedies rather than a short-term stimulus for the economy.
In his first round of announcements, Mr. Clinton is expected to name Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas as Treasury Secretary and announce other top economic appointees as well. In addition, aides say he was narrowing his list for Secretary of State to Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and Warren M. Christopher, the transition director.
Another person said to be under consideration for a top position in the economics area is Franklin D. Raines, vice chairman of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the Government-sponsored private corporation known as Fannie Mae. Mr. Raines is now in charge of the Clinton transition team studying the operations of various Federal agencies that deal with the economy.
The 43-year-old former Rhodes Scholar is one of the few blacks being talked about for a high-level economics post, perhaps at the Treasury or the Office of the United States Trade Representative.
 
Meets New House Members
 Addressing students at the racially mixed trade school, Mr. Clinton repeated a refrain from his campaign: that nothing was more important than overhauling the nation's health-care system.
"If I could wave a magic wand tomorrow and do one thing for this economy," Mr. Clinton said, "I would bring health costs in line with inflation and provide a basic package for everybody because eight years from now that would free more money for people to invest in their children's education, for business to invest in the plants and the production and the jobs of the future and any other thing we could do."
After arriving this evening in Washington for his second visit here since Election Day, Mr. Clinton attended a bipartisan reception for newly elected House members at the Library of Congress and spoke by satellite to a meeting of the South Carolina Democratic Party. Mr. Clinton lost the state in November, but its former Governor, Richard W. Riley, is heading the effort to recruit appointments below the Cabinet level.
Mr. Clinton also attended a private dinner in the Georgetown home of Katharine Graham, chairwoman of The Washington Post Company.
The guest list included both present and former Government officials, journalists and members of Mr. Clinton's transition team.
Hillary Clinton wore her hair in a French twist with pearls on the top, which represented a substantial change in her appearance from what millions saw during the campaign. She was flanked at dinner by the financier Warren Buffett and Donald E. Graham, publisher of The Post.
In her toast, Mrs. Graham remarked that the first President she had met was Calvin Coolidge. She said of the gathering in her mansion, "These occasions have value. They create relationships beyond the office."
Mr. Clinton said, "Washington is a better place than most Americans think it is."
In his toast, he remarked that nations' capitals have often been places of intrigue and calculation, and he added that political leaders should "calculate less what is best for all of us" and instead more "what is best for all of those who sent us here."
Other guests included Senators Nunn, Edward M. Kennedy, , John D. Rockefeller 4th, William S. Cohen and George J. Mitchell; Mr. Christopher and Vernon E. Jordan, the leaders of the transition team; Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore; Tom Johnson, president of of CNN; Franklyn G. Jenifer, president of Howard University; Ken Burns, the television documentary maker; David McCullough, the historian and author of the new biography of Harry S. Truman; Richard M. Helms, the former Director of Central Intelligence, and Robert S. McNamara, the former Defense Secretary.
 
Easy Questions
 Though he is having private meetings here with transition officials and others, Mr. Clinton's two-day trip was a respite from days of being closeted in the Governor's Mansion in Little Rock interviewing prospective appointments and meeting with his closest advisers. Those advisers say he has been practically obsessed with filling his Cabinet.
 
Easy Questions
 His appearance in Chicago gave the public its first taste of what the President-elect's aides say will be several forums in which ordinary people can ask Mr. Clinton questions. The format, a carry-over from the campaign, is viewed as a way for Mr. Clinton to appear in touch with Americans while avoiding often-tougher questions from reporters.
In addition to his failure to attack President Bush, Mr. Clinton's oratory today differed from the campaign in that he offered few uplifting words as he gave a detailed analysis of the economy and state of American education.
Mr. Clinton has an even busier agenda for Tuesday, when he will spend most of the day meeting with lawmakers on Capitol Hill. He will pay a courtesy call on Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, who will administer the oath to him.
The Supreme Court announced today that Vice President-elect Al Gore would be sworn in by former Justice Thurgood Marshall; Justice Marshall's son, Thurgood Jr., was a top Gore aide during the campaign.

HEADLINE: Staunch Conservative Wins G.O.P. Post in House

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
In a victory by conservatives over the moderate wing of the party, House Republicans today selected as their third-ranking leader Representative Dick Armey, a blunt-talking Texan with a penchant for bashing liberal Democrats and promoting supply-side economics.
Mr. Armey's 88-to-84 victory was too narrow to signify a definitive direction for Republicans in the post-election rebuilding period, even in the House where as an overwhelmed minority they are little more than a debating team. But it is one more indication that Republicans do not interpret the defeat of President Bush as a sign that they should retreat from conservative positions on issues like taxes and abortion. 
 The Democrats, for their part, re-elected Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, who both ran unopposed. Mr. Foley added a fourth chief deputy whip, appointing Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a leading member of the Hispanic caucus who is frequently mentioned as a possible Cabinet appointee.
 
Appropriations Head Is Ousted
 The Democratic leadership ousted Representative Jamie L. Whitten of Mississippi as chairman of the Appropriations Committee after 14 years at its helm. Mr. Whitten, 82 years old and in poor health, was replaced by Representative William H. Natcher of Kentucky, 83.
Emerging from the closed-door meeting, Mr. Whitten told reporters: "I just talked from the heart. I expressed my regret that they had failed to continue me in that position."
Mr. Armey, who represents a district in suburban Dallas-Fort Worth, defeated Representative Jerry Lewis of California, who sought re-election as chairman of the Republican Conference, a position from which he reinforced the centrist leadership of Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the minority leader.
Mr. Armey's challenge was supported by the No. 2 Republican in the House, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the confrontational minority whip who has privately told members that he hopes to run for leader if Mr. Michel decides to retire rather than seek re-election in 1994.
Mr. Michel, who will turn 70 in March, was not challenged for his leadership post this year, but he may be becoming more isolated in his party caucus. While Mr. Michel has always taken a conciliatory approach to Democratic leaders, Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Armey can be expected to carve sharp distinctions between the two parties.
 
Strategy of Confrontation
 "I see confrontation as a tool," Mr. Armey told reporters after his victory. He has long nurtured the image of an outsider, starting when he arrived here eight years ago and lived out of his office as a demonstration of his frugality and scorn for the trappings of power. "My heart is in Texas," he said today, "not with the Washington establishment."
Mr. Armey, who has a Ph.D. in economics, is best known as a polemicist for conservative causes. But he also demonstrated the ability to construct legislative coalitions when in the late 1980's he successfully pushed for the establishment of an independent commission to review closings of military bases, so decisions would be based on merit and not the seniority of representatives.
Mr. Armey's narrow victory was made possible by the 47 Republican freshmen, who were attracted to his call for term limits and slashes in Congressional perquisites. Representative-elect Martin R. Hoke of Ohio said 30 to 35 freshmen voted for Mr. Armey, demonstrating their ability to unite their votes to help guide the party.
"It's ideas that reshaped the Republican Party 12 years ago and a lack of ideas that undid the party the last four years," Mr. Hoke said. "Armey is ideas driven and Lewis is politics driven."
Representative-elect Ernest J. Istook of Oklahoma said Mr. Armey's victory demonstrated that "the majority of Republican members agree we need an aggressive tack to highlight the differences between Republicans and Democrats on taxes, spending and overregulation."
Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, a conservative who straddles the Michel and Gingrich wings, won election unopposed as chairman of the House Republican Policy Committee, the fourth-ranking leadership position.
The Republicans are expected to solidify the conservative hold on the leadership on Tuesday by re-electing Representative Bill McCollum of Florida as Republican Conference vice chairman over the challenge of Representative Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut, a supporter of abortion rights.
With most of the leadership elections out of the way, the caucuses are turning their attention to formulating positions on overhauling House rules. The Republicans are expected to call for sweeping changes, including term limits for committee chairmen.
But the Democrats control the votes, and they will do little more than tinker with rules that consolidate their control of the chamber. But they are expected to grant delegates from the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and the United States' three territories the right to vote on the House floor on nearly all substantive matters except final passage of legislation.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Dick Armey of Texas at a news conference after he was voted chairman of the House Republican Conference. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: MOZAMBIQUE FORCE PROPOSED AT U.N.

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali asked United Nations members today to send a peacekeeping force of up to 10,000 troops and civilians to prepare free elections in Mozambique.
The request was made as the member countries owe the United Nations a total of more than $500 million for unpaid bills for other peacekeeping operations. 
 Less than a week ago the Security Council also authorized the United States to lead a large military force into Somalia to restore order there and assure the distribution of relief supplies. In the last year the United Nations has dispatched substantial forces to Cambodia and the Balkans, and a peacekeeping mission in Mozambique would raise to 13 the number of such operations under way.
In a report to the Security Council, the Secretary General recommended that "very substantial resources" should be made available, "especially on the military side," to help Mozambique carry out an agreement ending 14 years of civil war. President Joaquim Chissano's Government negotiated the accord last fall with the Renamo resistance movement.
 
$2.6 Billion for Peacekeeping
 Mr. Boutros-Ghali gave no estimate of the cost of the force, which he recommended should have 7,000 soldiers and more than 1,200 civilian electoral and administrative officers. But officials said the cost would run into hundreds of millions of dollars.
The force would also increase the number of deployed United Nations troops, from more than 50,000 to 60,000, and increase the annual peacekeeping budget, which is expected to total $2.6 billion this year. That sum is almost a third of all the money the United Nations has spent on peacekeeping since 1948.
A Mozambique operation thus seems certain to worsen the financial crisis that the United Nations is facing because of the continuing refusals of many countries, including the United States and Russia, to pay their full shares of its costs. At the end of last month member countries owed a total of $642.5 million in unpaid dues for past and present peacekeeping operations, with the United States $290 million in the red and the Russian federation $115.4 million. Adding arrears to the regular budget, the United Nations is owed $1.2 billion by its members, with the United States and the Russian federation at $410 million each.
 
Protection of Corridors
 The Mozambique force would oversee the demobilization of the armed forces of both factions, the organization of free and fair elections and the eventual formation of an army that would include soldiers from both factions. The force would also take over the protection of the four vital transportation corridors across Mozambique to landlocked countries in Central Africa. Malawian and Zimbabwean troops now guard the routes.
Officially, the elections are supposed to be held within a year of the signing of the accord last October. But Mr. Boutros-Ghali made clear today that he would not proceed until both sides had fully complied with the military aspects of the accord and could not thus challenge the outcome with force.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
CONSOLIDATION PLAN FOR CUNY
The Chancellor of the City University of New York is pressing for an overhaul of the 19-campus system that would eliminate or consolidate some academic programs so the university could improve and expand others. The consolidation is intended to transform CUNY from a collection of autonomous campuses into an integrated university system with a shared faculty and one strong leader, the chancellor said. A1.
 
DISENCHANTMENT OVER FERNANDEZ'S BOOK
New York City Schools Chancellor Fernandez has backed away from the most scornful statements in his new autobiography as members of the Board of Education who will vote on renewing his contract began voicing deepening disenchantment. A1.
 

ANOTHER $1 MILLION FOR STEIN
City Council President Andrew J. Stein has raised another $1 million for his planned mayoral campaign next year, increasing the total he has taken in so far to nearly $4 million for what promises to be a bitter and costly campaign. B3.
 
STANDOFF WITH UNION AT THE NEWS
The root of Mortimer B. Zuckerman's current problems in trying to take over The Daily News go back to a 114-day newspaper strike 30 years ago. Then, it was Local 6 of the International Typographers Union that shut down the industry. Now, Local 6 is at the center of another dispute. But this time, the once-great labor power appears to be virtually without leverage or support from any other union. News analysis, B3.
 
HOMELESS MAN COMPETENT TO STAND TRIAL
A crack-addicted, homeless veteran who residents of West 96th Street say has terrorized them has been found competent by a judge to stand trial on a charge of criminal mischief for scraping a car with a knife. B3.
 
REGION
 
REFINANCING FOR TRENTON
The Florio administration has unveiled a $1.6 billion bond refinancing and new debt plan that would take advantage of lower interest rates to pump more than $900 million into New Jersey's state coffers over the next three years. But the gain comes at the expense of higher bond payments later. B6.
 
SENTENCING IN CHURCH BURGLARIES
A reclusive 47-year-old church organist, who confessed to stealing religious articles from more than 500 churches and synagogues in the Northeast, has been sentenced to between 4 and 14 years in prison for burglarizing two churches on Long Island. B6.
 
RULING IN GLEN RIDGE CASE
The judge in the Glen Ridge sex assault trial has rejected a defense motion for dismissal of all charges against four former football teammates accused of assaulting a mildly retarded woman in March 1989. But at the same time, Judge R. Benjamin Cohen ruled that the defense lawyers were clearly entitled to receive some documents that they argued last week had been improperly withheld from them by the prosecutors. B6.

HEADLINE: Bush and Yeltsin in Talks to Gain A-Arms Accord

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia have begun personal negotiations by telephone and letter in the last week in an effort to resolve differences that threaten a major nuclear arms reduction agreement that the two announced in June, the White House said today.
Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Mr. Bush spoke by telephone to Mr. Yeltsin on Sunday about the differences, which negotiators at lower levels in the Moscow Government had raised this year. 
 Discussions between Acting Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger and the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, have so far failed to reach a final accord, Mr. Fitzwater said.
 
Officials to Meet in Sweden
 Mr. Eagleburger and Mr. Kozyrev are expected to resume their talks this weekend at a meeting in Stockholm of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Yeltsin announced the accord, which would reduce the stocks of nuclear missiles on both sides by one-third to one-half, at a Washington summit meeting on June 17. But since then the Russians, with their economy faltering, have made proposals on technical issues intended to reduce the cost of compliance. These have raised concerns on the American side about how the agreement can be verified, said a White House official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
"The two Presidents, when they met last June, thought they had worked out this agreement, and then we sat down and finally worked it out in technical language and forwarded it to the Russians," that official said. "They came back, finally, with some new proposals and differences that raised more problems than they solved."
Asked whether the differences were serious, the official replied, "To experts they are."
Mr. Bush first called Mr. Yeltsin about problems with the treaty over the Thanksgiving weekend, and the President has also sent the Russian leader "a couple of letters" about the talks, Mr. Fitzwater said.
 
Russia Seeks to Save Money
 The agreement's major feature is a pledge by the Russians to abolish all their land-based multiple-warhead missiles. Many of the differences that are now under discussion involve an apparent desire by the Russians to save money by converting some multiple-warhead systems to single-warhead ones, rather than destroying them outright.
Some American officials fear that those changes would allow Russia to secretly rebuild its nuclear force later.
For example, the Russians agreed in June to destroy the all 150 SS-18 multiple-warhead missiles remaining on their territory, but they had not specifically agreed to destroy the silos in which they are stored, as is customary in such treaties.
Moscow has now proposed to store single-warhead missiles in those silos, but American experts are balking at the suggestion.
The Russians also wish to revise the June agreement to allow them to preserve all 170 of their multiple-warhead SS-19 missiles by removing five of their six warheads, effectively making them single-warhead weapons.
The United States worries that the warheads could be secretly re-mounted on the missiles later without inspectors being aware of the change.
The two sides also disagree over whether the final accord should explicitly mention in its preamble the 1970 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, and the Russians are seeking to place new limits on the American flexibility to covert conventionally armed B-1 bombers to carry nuclear weapons.
 
No Bush-Yeltsin Meeting Is Set
 Asked today about reports that the two leaders might meet in Alaska before President Bush leaves office to sign a final accord, Mr. Fitzwater said neither side had scheduled any such session. But should an agreement be reached, another aide said, "I don't think anyone's ruling it out."

HEADLINE: A Door Opening Wide for the Poor

 BODY:
The City University of New York began in 1847 as a free academy for young men of poor and immigrant families who normally did not have access to other universities and colleges in the city.
Since then, CUNY has become one of the largest universities in the country. It has graduated 11 Nobel Prize winners and more corporate leaders than any other university system, based on a ranking by Standard and Poor's. 
 In 1870, Hunter College, an institution to educate young women to become teachers, was added. And in 1930 and 1937, Brooklyn and Queens Colleges joined what was to become known as the Big Four cornerstones of the City University system.
In 1947, New York Technical College became the city's first two-year institution, foreshadowing the later creation of nearly a dozen community colleges two decades later.
In a pivotal change in 1961, the relatively autonomous colleges were unified under a single chancellor. That year also marked the beginning of the Ph.D. programs at CUNY.
Nine years later, CUNY initiated its open-enrollment program, under which all high school graduates were guaranteed enrollment. The result was that CUNY became the third-largest university in the country, behind the State University of New York and the California State University system, with more than 200,000 students. In the 1970's, several more community colleges were created, causing CUNY's enrollment to grow to 250,000.
But the economic crisis that hit the city in 1976 caused CUNY to run out of operating money and close its doors for two weeks. A result was that the system was forced to end 129 years of free tuition. Another result was that its fiscal governance was largely transferred to the state.

HEADLINE: EUROPEANS FACING BATTLE OF BUDGET

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Instead of providing an occasion to repair tattered dreams of regional unity, a summit meeting of European Community leaders this week may well result in a new rift over an issue that deeply concerns all 12 member countries: who pays for and who benefits from the community budget.
The summit's agenda is already weighed down by seemingly more crucial problems -- the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Denmark's rejection of the treaty on European unity, French objections to a community farm trade agreement with the United States and applications for new membership in the community. 
 But behind the headlines, that perennial source of trouble -- money -- is threatening to dominate the meeting in Edinburgh, Scotland, this Friday and Saturday. The demands of poorer members for greater community assistance are likely to be confronted by the reluctance of the richer nations to pay out more.
Last week, Prime Minister John Major of Britain, chairman of the summit meeting, traveled the region trying to sell his proposed compromise on the budget dispute. "Insufficient," said Spain's Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez. "Disappointing," said Portugal's Prime Minister, Anibal Cavaco Silva.
 
Threat by 'Poor Four'
 Arguing that their partners are committed to helping them reach the community's average living standards, the so-called "poor four" -- Ireland, Greece, Spain and Portugal -- have now threatened to delay progress on other questions if they are rebuffed in Edinburgh.
Further, they contend that without additional help they stand no chance of taking part in the community's plan to create a single currency by 1999. Fears of a "two-speed Europe" would then be realized, they say, and the idea of economic unity would be undermined.
In response, the richer governments, led by Germany, Britain and France, have pleaded that they are constrained from greater generosity by economic recessions. Long the principal benefactor of the "poor four," Bonn has added that its new priority must be to develop former East Germany.
The fact that community finance ministers will attend the Edinburgh summit meeting is itself confirmation that the budget is shaping up to be a major issue of contention. And while seemingly an internal matter, the outcome of the debate is being awaited anxiously by more than just the 12 participating nations.
The "poor four" have specifically warned that they will block negotiations with new applicants for community membership until the budget question is resolved to their satisfaction. Austria, Sweden, Finland and Switzerland have already asked to join, and the plan has been for negotiations to start early next year.
Switzerland is now unlikely to pursue these negotiations after Swiss voters on Sunday rejected the country's participation in the planned single market with community members.
 
East Europeans Watching
 Some Eastern European countries that aspire to eventual membership as a way of advancing economically view the budget debate as a crucial gauge of the community's mood. If richer members are reluctant to help their current poorer partners, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia cannot hope for early entry into the community.
The money squabble has proved so divisive that community leaders postponed addressing it at their last two summit meetings. Since it relates to planned increases in the community's budget starting Jan. 1, 1993, however, a solution can no longer be put off.
All member states contribute to the budget, and therefore it must win the approval of all of them. Of the 12, however, only Germany, Britain, France and the Netherlands pay in more than they subsequently receive. This year, 58 percent of the budget has been spent on farming subsidies, while 30 percent has gone to helping backward regions or countries.
The poorer nations have the president of the community's executive commission, Jacques Delors, as their main ally. After paring down more ambitious targets, he has proposed raising the budget from 1.2 percent to 1.32 percent of the community's combined gross national product by 1999.
 
Budget Increase Seen
 Although the increase in monetary terms will depend on economic growth rates, the commission anticipates a budget increase from $75.5 billion this year to around $106 billion by 1999. A so-called Cohesion Fund, created specifically to finance development projects in the "poor four," would also grow, from $7.4 billion to $18.5 billion.
In contrast, the British compromise, already dismissed by Mr. Delors as "a serious political mistake," would have the budget grow to just 1.25 percent of the combined G.N.P., or an estimated $98.7 billion, by 1999, with the Cohesion Fund limited to $15 billion.
The passion being stirred by these numbers reflects the pain being inflicted throughout the region by this year's sudden economic slowdown.
Last week, Mr. Delors's commission estimated growth in the community at perhaps 1.5 percent next year. It forecast that average unemployment would remain over 11 percent until at least 1996. In almost every country, governments are cutting spending and becoming more unpopular, raising the risk of being turned out by voters.

HEADLINE: U.S. Lures Dominicans, Too, to the Cruel Sea

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Re public, Dec. 5

 BODY:
After failing to persuade relatives in New York to take her in, losing money on a counterfeit visa that was never delivered, and prostituting herself in the hope of finding an American willing to marry her long enough that she could emigrate legally, Josefina Archibald was down to what for many Dominicans represents the final hope.
In the dark of a seedy merengue bar in a run-down quarter of this sprawling capital recently, Miss Archibald, a 19-year-old mother of one whose education ended in junior high school, handed over to a man named Carlos the equivalent of $150. It represented one-half payment for a risky trip in a small boat that she expects to take her to Puerto Rico early next month. 
 "I want to help my family and I want nice things for my son, but the only thing for me here is prostitution," she said, explaining her decision to risk losing hard-won money yet again to racketeers, or even worse drowning at sea. "For a young person like me, reaching your country is the only way out."
While the chaotic exodus of boat people from neighboring Haiti has often received intense attention from the United States in the last year, Dominican and American authorities say that aspiring emigrants from this country like Miss Archibald are part of a quieter wave that over time may be every bit as large, if less dramatic, than the outflow from Haiti.
Their estimates vary, but officials of the United States Border Patrol and Dominican authorities say that year in and year out 10,000 to 20,000 people set out from coastal towns in the eastern part of this country into the dangerous currents of the 90-mile-wide Mona Passage hoping to reach Puerto Rico.
Officials say the emigrants run the gamut from the scantly educated, like Miss Archibald, to young professionals made desperate by a shortage of opportunity here even for those with university degrees.
Since the coup in Haiti in September 1991, about 40,000 Haitians have been intercepted by the United States Coast Guard trying to make the 500-mile trip to southern Florida. Three-quarters of those Haitians were returned to their country.
Last year, Dominican authorities, who acknowledge the true figure may be much higher, say that at least 1,200 people drowned at sea or simply disappeared as a result of these clandestine voyages, which are sold as 24-hour trips but often last much longer because of difficult sea conditions.
"It's a wonder that a lot of these boats make it five miles off shore they are built so cheaply," said Gary Labbe, a United States Border Patrol official in Puerto Rico, describing the 30-foot yawls. The boats are typically loaded with 50 or more passengers and powered with nothing larger than a 25-horsepower outboard motor.
Dominican authorities are burdened with a 30 percent unemployment rate and demands on their surveillance resources that range from an increase in drug shipments from South America to a long border with an even poorer neighbor, Haiti. Despite the loss of life from the exodus, they say there is little they can do to stop or even slow the outflow of their citizens.
Currently, people caught attempting the voyage or those returned from Puerto Rico are fined the equivalent of about $4 for leaving the country illegally, a small fraction of the $300 to $500 fee charged for a place on a boat. Officials say that proposed laws that would allow prosecution of boat runners for attempted murder and would increase penalties on people seeking to flee have been repeatedly defeated in the Congress because of fears of alienating voters desperate to leave the country. Others say corruption links many legislators to the rings that organize the traffic.
"It is well known that many of these groups are working hand in hand with lawmakers," said Eugenio Cabral, executive director of the Defensa Civil, which overseas many refugee matters. "There have even been cases where people have been caught engaging in this traffic when legislators have used their influence to help get them off."

HEADLINE: The Push and Pull Over Taxes

SERIES: Tax Politics -- First of four articles.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The 12 years of Republican reign seem, looking back, like a constant political war over taxes, a war that will almost certainly continue next year after Bill Clinton becomes President.
Year after year, ignoring the counsel of economists and business executives that the wisest tax code is a stable and predictable one, the laws were changed in important ways. It happened in 1981, 1982, 1983, 1984, 1986, 1988, 1989 and 1990, more frequent and detailed changes in taxes than ever before in American history, and another new law would have been adopted this year if President Bush had not cast a veto.
 
Change and More Change
 Income tax rates were slashed, cut again and then increased slightly. Tax breaks to encourage business investment and personal savings were widened, then repealed. A surtax on the elderly to pay the cost of catastrophic illnesses was approved in 1987 and retracted in 1988. Social Security, Medicare and gasoline taxes went up. Corporate taxes fell. 
 Hundreds of billions of dollars of tax liability was shifted around among individuals and companies. Over these years, tax policy was a pervasive issue in every Presidential election.
Except for the very rich and the very poor, the overall tax burden of Americans is about the same as it was a dozen years ago.
A family of three at the center of the income spectrum paid 19.8 percent of its earnings in Federal taxes in 1980, the year before Ronald Reagan became President. Next year, according to calculations by the Congressional Budget Office, such a family (with an income between about $29,000 and $42,000) will owe, on average, 19.5 percent.
Put another way, as a fraction of the economy, the amount of Federal, state and local taxes collected has remained almost constant. It was 27.8 percent of gross domestic product in 1980 and 28 percent last year.
But the fact that overall tax burdens remained rather stable masks the extent to which constant changes in the law forced people and companies to alter the way they saved and spent and invested their money. First, for instance, people were induced to invest in commercial real estate; then that carrot was withdrawn. One year savings accounts were tax free; the next year they were not. Deductions for medical expenses and sales taxes went by the boards.
 
Affecting Daily Life
 Tax policy, in short, became not only a driving force in the nation's politics, but in the way people ran their lives day to day.
And despite all the turmoil, politicians seem to feel just as strongly today that the tax system needs to be revamped as they did in 1980.
In this year's election, President Bush stressed the Republican dogma that Americans in general and rich people in particular are taxed too much for the good of the economy. President-elect Clinton campaigned on the familiar Democratic theme that the tax system is unfair -- too generous to the wealthy and too burdensome to the middle class.
Since Mr. Clinton won and since his Democratic allies in Congress seem disposed to give him the tax-policy changes he wants, in general if not in every particular, shots of Gucci Gulch -- the corridors of Capitol Hill so known because that is where the tax lobbyists lurk in their tasseled loafers -- will doubtless be staples on television news programs once again.
Mr. Clinton says he wants to raise income taxes on the wealthy, revive tax breaks for businesses to induce them to invest in machinery and equipment, crack down on tax avoidance by foreign companies doing business in the United States and give a modest tax cut to middle-class taxpayers.
As the Clinton proposals are debated, these questions will form the backdrop: Did the Republicans actually cut taxes or merely shift them around? Is the tax system more or less fair than it used to be? Are Americans taxed less than people in other countries? What are the flaws in the American tax system?
And finally, is Mr. Clinton offering the right tax medicine for the economy and the country?
 
Reagan's First Term
Increases Needed After Deep Cuts
 The main theme of Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign in 1980 was that Government was too big and taxes were too high. Adopting the view known as supply-side economics, he held that lower taxes on individuals and businesses would improve the economy by increasing work effort, savings, investment and production. Some of his advisers even maintained that economic growth spurred by reduced taxes would increase the Government's revenue.
Democrats in Congress, intimidated by Mr. Reagan's popularity and enticed by a seemingly pain-free approach to financing the Government, not only sided with the President but managed to one-up him with their generosity. The result was the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981, the deepest tax cut in American history.
Businesses were allowed to write off the cost of their equipment much faster than the equipment actually deteriorated, a procedure known as accelerated depreciation. Along with the existing investment tax credit, this became the basis for many tax shelters.
Individuals got a 23 percent tax cut over three years, and the top rate paid by the wealthiest taxpayers was lowered to 50 percent from 70 percent. The rate on capital gains, the profits from investments, fell to 20 percent from 28. Breaks were devised for savings accounts, retirement accounts and two-earner families. Estate taxes were eliminated for many wealthy taxpayers.
And most important, in the view of C. Eugene Steuerle, a top tax official under Mr. Reagan and the author of a new book, "The Tax Decade," the law was written so that rates and exemptions would be adjusted automatically each year for inflation, meaning the Government would no longer collect more revenue just because prices and wages went up.
The new tax law had hardly been signed before many Administration officials and legislators realized they had acted irresponsibly. As a consequence, big tax increases were enacted in 1982 and 1984 to offset some of the lost revenue. Social Security taxes were raised substantially in 1983 to put the shaky retirement system back on sound footing.
 
Tax Reform
Broad Overhaul Limits Deductions
 By 1984, the tax system was a mess. Many of the nation's largest and most profitable corporations took such advantage of legal loopholes that they paid no taxes whatsoever. People with similar incomes paid vastly different amounts in taxes, and many wealthy individuals sought out tax shelters rather than productive investments.
After his re-election, Mr. Reagan gave what he called tax reform his highest legislative priority. And leading Democrats like Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, realizing that they too could gain political mileage, joined Mr. Reagan as allies.
The road was a long and tortuous one, and countless lawmakers, lobbyists and bureaucrats fell by the wayside. But in October 1986, President Reagan had signed the Tax Reform Act, the most comprehensive overhaul of the country's tax structure since World War II.
The foundation of the legislation was a sharp reduction in income tax rates and the elimination or restriction of hundreds of deductions, exemptions and other tax breaks.
The top tax rate on individuals, 70 percent when Mr. Reagan became President, was lowered to 28 percent, and the maximum corporate rate was reduced to 34 percent from 46 percent.
Among the familiar deductions that were scrapped or limited were those for state and local sales taxes, individual retirement accounts, consumer interest payments, medical expenses, union dues and business meals. Tax shelters were essentially abolished, as was a special rate for capital gains.
Banks, insurance companies, real estate interests, oil and gas producers and smokestack industries lost valuable tax write-offs. The taxes of nearly every household and business were affected. It was one of the most monumental pieces of legislation in American history.
 
Bush's Struggle
'Read My Lips' And Capital Gains
 George Bush never bought into tax reform. As Vice President, he did little work on behalf of the Reagan measure and tried unsuccessfully behind the scenes to preserve tax advantages for the oil and gas industry.
In his 1988 campaign, Mr. Bush's tax policy was stated in one memorable sentence, "Read my lips: no new taxes." As President, the one tax matter that seemed to engage him was the treatment of capital gains. He wasted considerable political muscle trying unsuccessfully to lower the rate on investment profits, which are enjoyed mostly by the wealthiest taxpayers.
Mr. Bush and the Democrats jockeyed for position in 1989, but by the next year they were at each other's throats over taxes as they tried to strike a deal to lower the budget deficit.
Time and again, Mr. Bush took a firm stand, only to waver. In the end, the President suffered a miserable defeat. His advocacy of a reduced capital gains rate enabled his Democratic opponents to portray him as a patron of fat cats. And by signing a tax increase, he reneged on his central campaign promise.
The 1990 law raised taxes on wealthy people by lifting the top rate to 31 percent from 28 percent and by restricting some of their deductions and exemptions. It also removed millions of the poorest Americans from the tax rolls altogether.
But the main effect was political. The struggle over the budget deal underscored Mr. Bush's indecisiveness on domestic issues. Then, and again with his veto of the tax bill this year, the President seemed more concerned with the affluent than with ordinary taxpayers. In many respects, this portended his political downfall.
 
The Effects
Shuffle Puts More In Deepest Pockets
 One popular misconception is that the Republican tax cuts caused the crippling Federal budget deficit, now approaching $300 billion a year. The fact is, the large deficit resulted because the Government vastly increased what it spent each year, while tax revenues changed little.
In terms of tax policy, the Reagan and Bush Administrations succeeded mainly in shifting around the kind of taxes Americans pay. Payroll taxes for Social Security have risen steeply. Income taxes have fallen, and taxes on corporate profits are way down.
While most Americans basically broke even, the wealthiest enjoyed something of a windfall.
Economists at the Congressional Budget Office have calculated that the richest 1 percent of taxpayers -- families earning more than about $200,000 annually -- owe 9 percent less in taxes each year, on average, than they would have if the laws had remained unchanged.
That amounts to an average tax reduction for these affluent taxpayers of around $16,000 -- enough, say, for a handsome new car or a year's tuition at a fine university.
Whether this is fair depends on one's perspective.
Robert S. McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a research center with ties to organized labor, asserted in an interview that it was quite unfair. "Rich people," he said, "are way undertaxed based on what they can afford, what they used to pay and what they would pay in other countries."
But others hold that the entire economy would be weakened and that everyone would suffer if the rich were taxed more. Norman B. Ture, a developer of tax policy under President Reagan and now the president of a research organization called the Institute for Research on the Economics of Taxation, said the wealthy were "the most productive people in the country." He added, "Tax them more, and if you think that will have no effect on their behavior, then you have to assume they are very peculiar human beings."
The wealthy now pay a higher proportion of total taxes than they did in 1980. But their share of total income has grown even more than their share of the tax burden.
 
A Global Perspective
Seeking Solutions To System's Flaws
 The Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, an association of the world's industrial nations, calculates that taxes in the United States are lower than they are in this country's main economic competitors -- slightly lower than taxes in Japan and considerably lower than those in Europe.
This is one of the strongest arguments used by economists who hold that Americans are undertaxed. But the O.E.C.D. figures can be misleading. For instance, the health care system in Europe is financed by taxes. In the United States, medical costs are borne mostly by private insurance paid by employers. The tax statistics do not reflect this difference and others.
"People in the United States are taxed less, it's pretty clear, but how much less is very hard to measure," said Timothy M. Smeeding, an economist at Syracuse University who studies the comparative economies of different countries.
Whatever the comparison with other countries, economists across the political scale agree that several aspects of the American tax system are badly flawed.
One is that the system encourages consumption and discourages saving. Another is that it gives real estate an advantage over other investments. A third is that the tax treatment is more favorable if companies borrow money than if they raise capital by issuing stock.
But while the economists agree on the problems, no consensus exists on the solutions.
Some economists want to tax consumption instead of income, but that would be a boon to rich people who can afford to spend a smaller proportion of what they earn. Some want to phase out or otherwise restrict deductions for mortgage interest to put real estate on an equal footing with other investments, but that would cause an upheaval in the housing market. Some would abolish the corporate profits tax or eliminate the tax on dividends so that the money is not taxed twice, but that would cost the Government much more revenue than it can afford to lose.
 
Clintonomics
Economists Shun Tax-Cutting Plan
 Mr. Clinton's tax policy is still under development, but he seems to have approached the matter from a political perspective rather than an economic or theoretical one.
He would be hard-pressed, for instance, to find a prominent economist, Republican or Democrat, who favors his campaign promise to give Americans making less than $80,000 a tax cut of a few hundred dollars a year.
"I hope he changes his mind about the middle-class tax cut," said Henry Aaron, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution and a strong supporter of the President-elect. "The last thing this nation needs right now is a large tax cut for any group."
But Mr. Clinton insists that raising the taxes of the wealthy and cutting the taxes of the middle class is not only fair but necessary.
"The American people," he said at a news conference last month, "will be much more willing to accept the argument that all have to sacrifice and contribute over the long run if they believe we're starting from a fair tax system, and I don't believe we are today."
With that in mind, he has said he wants to raise the top tax rate on families earning more than about $200,000 a year to 36 percent from 31 percent. He wants to impose a surtax on incomes of more than $1 million and to stiffen the minimum tax owed by wealthy individuals who have big deductions or considerable tax-free income.
As for businesses, Mr. Clinton said in the campaign that he could raise $45 billion over four years with tougher enforcement of tax laws on foreign companies that do business in the United States. But since the election, some of his economic advisers have acknowledged that they may be able to raise only a fraction of that amount.
More attention has been given to his proposals for an investment tax credit to businesses to help stimulate the economy. Mr. Clinton has not said how large the tax break should be, which investments should be covered, which industries should benefit or whether the credit should be permanent or temporary.
Those matters are likely to be the subject of fierce lobbying and debate, one more skirmish in the continuing political war over taxes.


GRAPHIC: The nominal tax rates published by the Government tell little about what taxpayers actually pay, thanks to the tax code's many deductions, exclusions, allowances, credits and surcharges, and varying rates applied to different parts of a family's total income.
Charts/Graphs: "Effective Tax Rates"
 Effective rates solve the problem by taking a family's ultimate tax bill and treating it as if it were a simple percentage of the family's adjusted income. ("Family" includes families of one person -- a single taxpayer with no dependents.)
 In the chart, the population is divided into give groups of equal numbers of people, called quintiles, based on adjusted family income. Each quintile includes 45 million people for 1980 and 51.4 million for 1993.
 A family is assigned to a quintile based on how its income compares with incomes of other families of the same size. For example, a one-person family in the middle quintile in 1993 would earn between $18,333 and $27,126, but a two-person family in the same quintile would earn between $24,459 and $34,712.
 The graphs track percentages of all Federal taxes, Federal individual income tax, Social Security and similar taxes paid by all taxpayers, the five quintiles alluded to above, and the richest one percent of families. (Source: Congressional Budget Office) (pg. D15)
 
"Piece of the Action"
 The total tax burden on the economy -- measured by comparing tax receipts to the gross domestic product -- grew steadily from the mid-1950's until 1969, but has remained roughly stable since then.
 The makeup of the tax take has changed greatly over the years. Federal taxes on corporate profits now account for much less of the total, and Social Security and similar taxes much more than they did in the 1950's. State and local individual income taxes have also grown substantially.
 The graph tracks total tax receipts (from Federal individual income taxes, Social Security and similar taxes, Federal corporate profits taxes, other Federal taxes, state and local individual income taxes, and other state and local taxes) as a percentage of gross domestic product. The years for which the data is shown are 1946, 1960, 1969, 1975, 1981, and 1991. (Source: C. Eugene Steuerle, "The Tax Decade" [Urban Institute Press]) (pg. D15)

HEADLINE: Jack Carlson, 59, Budget Specialist And Ex-U.S. Aide

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

 BODY:
Jack Carlson, an economist, budget specialist and leading economic spokesman for American business interests, died yesterday in Suburban Hospital in Potomac, Md. He was 59 years old and lived in Potomac.
His family said he had died of a heart attack. 
 Mr. Carlson served as Assistant Secretary of Interior for Energy and Minerals under President Gerald R. Ford in 1976. Before that, he was assistant director of the Office of Management and Budget under President Richard M. Nixon, and a staff member of the Council of Economic Advisers during the Nixon and Johnson Administrations.
After leaving the Government in 1976, Mr. Carson ran unsuccessfully against Senator Orin G. Hatch in a Republican primary in Utah. He later served as head of the National Association of Realtors and the American Association of Retired Persons.
Born in 1933 in Salt Lake City, Mr. Carlson received a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard University before beginning his career in Government service.
In recent years, Mr. Carlson was chairman of the Center for Educational Competitiveness and co-director of the National Commission on Executive Compensation, where he supported the policy of linking executive compensation to company performance.
Mr. Carlson is survived by his wife, Renee; three daughters, Catherine Candland, of Greenwich, Conn., Christine Point of Wilmington, N.C., and Diane Robinson of Pelham, N.Y.; four sons, Steven, of Pelham, John of Bethesda, Md., David of Zurich, and Paul, of Potomac, and 14 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Trenton Seeks Guarantees For College

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Assembly Republicans today proposed a $75 million bond act to finance a package of education bills highlighted by guaranteed financial aid for New Jersey high school graduates attending college or vocational school in the state.
To qualify, all students would have to do is successfully complete 12 semester hours at an accredited college in the state -- regardless of their families' financial status or whether the school is public or private. Education experts said there was no precedent for a state making such an offer. 
 Voters must approve the proposed bond act and the Assembly Speaker, Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, said he would try to push the bills through the Legislature in time to place the measure on the ballot next November. If passed by the voters, the target date for the program to begin would be January 1994.
Among the unanswered questions today was whether the bond act would raise enough money to provide loans for all those who might want them. It was also unclear how the state could enforce repayment of the loans in a way that would keep the aid fund solvent; Federal student loan programs have been plagued by defaults.
Assemblyman Thomas S. Smith, one of the legislators sponsoring the four-bill package, described it as "a clear departure from the past."
"We are implicitly saying that New Jersey young people have a right to an education beyond the high school level," he said.
The maximum amount of the loans per year could not exceed the annual tuition at Rutgers University, now $3,254 a year. The state would pay the tuition directly to the school.
Students would be required to sign a contract that specified that upon graduation, they would repay the loan through payroll deduction or by direct payment if they are self-employed at a rate of $2,000 a year, or 10 percent of their salary, whichever amount is greater.
Students would make one extra year of payments after the loan is repaid. So for each student the service charge would be either $2,000 or 10 percent of their salary, whichever is greater. All money would be redeposited into the college tuition loan fund, Mr. Wolfe said.
 
'Bad Idea,' Expert Says
 One legislator described the plan as "a mom and apple pie" issue that legislators would be hard-pressed to oppose. But the political payoff could create fiscal complications down the road. By looking to a bond act to finance the plan, the Legislature risks opening the way for a host of other bonds to pay for projects that traditionally had been paid for through appropriations.
Morton Owens Schapiro, chairman of the Economics Department at the University of Southern California and a national expert on higher education finance, called the New Jersey proposal a "bad idea."
"It is the last thing we need right now," he said. "When you combine the fact that public colleges and universities are hurting for money and that wealthier kids are going to public colleges and universities in increasing numbers, it is natural to conclude that what should be done is to ask students who can afford it to pay a larger proportion of costs."
Mr. Schapiro said he knew of no other state tuition plan in which any student, regardless of financial status, was eligible.
"The fact that they are not capping it, seems to me, that it is a political bill, not an economic one," said Mr. Schapiro, who grew up in Union, N.J.
The ranking Democrat on the Assembly Education Committee, Assemblyman Joseph Charles Jr., attacked the Republican plan as riddled with legal, financial and social shortcomings, and timed to "set the political agenda" for next year's elections.
"This bonding proposal is a politically crafty way of attempting to provide aid for upper-income families," Mr. Charles said. "This proposal fails to target the middle-class people who need the aid the most. These stipends should not be open-ended."
 
$10 Million Reading Program
 Sponsors of the legislation said they had not actually projected how many students would be eligible for the program, but they said it might require issuing more bonds if the demand outstripped the financing.
Mr. Haytaian and the three freshman legislators who joined him at today's news conference -- Assemblywoman Priscilla B. Anderson and Assemblymen Smith and David W. Wolfe -- described the package as landmark legislation to combat illiteracy, to improve student achievement and to make it possible for everyone to afford a post-secondary education.
One bill in the four-bill package would establish the $75 million bond act and the other three would appropriate the money. In addition to $45 million for college tuition loans and $20 million for vocational school loans, the plan calls for a $10 million reading tutorial program for the third through the seventh grades.
The vocational tuition loan bill, co-sponsored by Assemblyman Paul DiGaetano, is similar to the proposed college program. The Republicans said there are 60,000 students currently enrolled in 200 trade schools in New Jersey.
The final bill in the package, sponsored by Ms. Anderson, would establish through the State Department of Education a reading tutorial program for third to seventh grade students.
Retired teachers would be enlisted to staff the program, which would be offered to public schools, but not required, Ms. Anderson said. The teachers would be paid the state minimum wage of $5.05 an hour.
Of the three programs, the tutorial plan is the only one that is not self-perpetuating. For the program to continue beyond the four years envisioned in the Anderson bill it would require another bond issue or an appropriation.
Mr. Florio, a Democrat, said he had not seen the Republican proposals and he declined to comment on them.
Mr. Haytaian's support of the package of bills means they are likely to move swiftly through the Assembly and to have strong support in the Senate. With a 58-to-22 majority in the Assembly and a 27-to-13 advantage in the Senate, the Republicans can with or without Mr. Florio's support get the plan onto the ballot.

HEADLINE: Credit Markets;
Reports of Clinton Nominees Ease Fears of Bond Traders

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market rallied yesterday as it absorbed the names mentioned over the weekend for important economic appointments in the Clinton Administration. The price of the 30-year bond was up almost half a point, and prices of Treasury notes rose across the board.
Traders and analysts said they were encouraged by the expected choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Finance Committee, as Secretary of the Treasury, and the consideration of other potential appointees like Representative Leon E. Panetta, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, as director of the Office of Management and Budget. 
 But the market might have reacted more strongly, these analysts said, with the appointment of another candidate on President-elect Bill Clinton's short list: Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve.
"I don't think these guys are market movers," Charles Liberman, managing director of financial markets research at Chemical Securities, said of the potential appointees. "But in the absence of the Volcker choice, these other guys are acceptable."
From Bill Clinton's point of view, the expected appointments could not have come at a better time in the bond market. As reflected in the rally on Friday and yesterday, there is a new feeling that the spending and tax program Mr. Clinton has promised to stimulate the economy is now less threatening to the bond market.
At the same time, the employment data released on Friday showed that the economy, while growing, was not moving ahead as fast as many in the market feared.
Together, these themes weave a positive background for the market as the end of the year draws near. But some analysts, like Mr. Liberman, assert that investors and traders have gone too far if they are assuming there will be only a small fiscal stimulus program, or none at all.
Some analysts say they think the stronger than expected growth means that Mr. Clinton can propose a much smaller fiscal stimulus program. This means there is less risk of overstimulating the economy and igniting inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments. In addition, a smaller package means the Federal budget deficit will not grow as much in the next year or two, allowing the new President to concentrate more on deficit reduction.
 
 
Higher Rates Unlikely
 At the same time, the fact that the economy is not moving ahead too fast means that the Federal Reserve is unlikely to raise interest rates soon and that inflation is not moving higher. The hold on interest rates is good for shorter Treasury maturities and the hold on inflation is good for the 30-year bond and longer-term notes.
"The Fed is not going to tighten, and the deficit is not going to be let loose," said Neal M. Soss, chief economist for the First Boston Corporation. "That is a pretty good background for the market."
This background has allowed the price of the 30-year bond to jump a point and 7/32 point in two trading days. In late trading yesterday, the Treasury's 30-year bond was offered at a price of 1024/32 , up 14/32 , to yield 7.44 percent. That was down from 7.48 percent on Friday and 7.55 percent on Thursday. Friday was the first time since Oct. 14 that the yield had dipped below 7.50 percent.
Prices and yields move in opposite directions. Rising prices add to the value of bonds and notes while reducing the yields. When yields rise, the value of the security declines.
 
 
Note Prices Also Rise
 The prices of Treasury notes were also up yesterday, although, like the price of the 30-year bond, they fell from their intraday highs at the end of the trading day. The price of the 10-year note was up 8/32 to yield 6.77 percent, down from 6.81 percent on Friday and 6.89 percent on Thursday. The price of the two-year note was up 3/32 to yield 4.62 percent, down from 4.69 percent on Friday and 4.77 percent on Thursday.
The discount rates on Treasury bills also fell, but some analysts said that the results in the Treasury auction of three-month and six-month bills was a little disappointing, given the recent rally. The average discount rate on the three-month bill was 3.29 percent, down from 3.31 percent last week, and the average yield on the six-month bill was 3.37 percent. down from 3.46 percent last week.
Until Friday, many analysts had said they thought the jump in discount rates on Treasury bills and the rise in yields on short-term Treasury notes had been overdone. They argued that investors, traders and speculators had assumed that the economy was growing quite fast and had bet that the Federal Reserve would have to raise interest rates soon.
But when the market began to rally after Friday's moderate employment report, a lot of traders who had sold notes short, betting prices would fall, had to buy them to cover their positions, adding to the force of the rally.
Mr. Soss of First Boston now wonders if the rally in the shorter end of the market will be as overdone as the decline. "They were oversold, so now presumably they will rally until they are overbought," he said.
 
 
Still Expects Stimulus
 Mr. Liberman of Chemical Securities said he was not ready to believe that Mr. Clinton would have only a very small fiscal stimulus program, or none. Citing comments from Clinton aides, he said the President-elect believed he had won because President Bush was mismanaging the economy.
"So he is going to be sure to provide enough stimulus, so as the economy improves he can claim credit," he said.
It was difficult, traders said, to determine yesterday how much of the rally reflected approval of Mr. Clinton's apparent choices for important economic posts. Mr. Soss said, "The good economic backdrop allows you to treat all news in a midly favorable fashion."
William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president of Daiwa Securities, said it was difficult to tell because so many customers who are big buyers had already closed their books for the year.
"No matter what happens, they are not going to do anything, and that's the real money," he said. "So you'll have to wait until next year."

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Town Sees Small Gain In Big Fight

BYLINE: By John T. McQuiston

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I.

 BODY:
THE last decade has been hard on this historic village, once the center of commerce and industry on Long Island. As shoppers abandoned Hempstead's downtown and retailers moved out, crime, especially drug dealing, increased.
But over the weekend, for a few hours at least, the street corners were "virtually free of crime." 
 It took a six-month police investigation and a drug sweep that rounded up 104 low-level dealers to bring about the change, but officials here are saying it is a start.
"Little by little we're drying up the street corners," Mayor James Garner said yesterday. "And we hope to make Hempstead a safer place for citizens to live and raise their families."
Hempstead is the oldest village in Nassau County and is at the county's center. At the turn of the century it was the hub of commercial activity on Long Island. Even as things began to change in the 1980's, Hempstead's population continued to grow. From 1980 to 1990, it rose from 40,404 to 49,453, up 22.4 percent, making it among the fastest growing communities in the New York region.
White middle-class residents were moving out and gradually Hempstead went from a virtually all-white community to one in which whites are a minority. Between 1980 and 1990, the black population of the village increased to 32,033, from 29,088, while people speaking Spanish grew to 9,454, from 3,445. Whites declined to 15,550, from 16,010.
"It's the only village on Long Island with a racial mix like this," Mayor Garner said.
At the same time, the number of poor people was rapidly increasing. As of 1990, 12.5 percent of the village's residents were living below the poverty line, one of Long Island's highest concentrations of poor people.
Crime rose, and the downtown area developed a reputation as being unsafe. With malls luring away shoppers, the downtown was deserted by major retailers, the latest being Abraham & Straus, which moved in October to the nearby Roosevelt Shopping Center in Garden City. It had occupied what was once the largest suburban department store in the nation.
Drug dealing is now the Police Department's biggest concern, said James Russo, the chief of police.
He said that the arrests in the five-day sweep begun last Tuesday night had cleared the village of drug dealers and left the streets "virtually free of crime" by Sunday night.
Many of the dealers, he said, were repeat offenders who hang out primarily near housing projects on Terrace Avenue, South Franklin Street and Arbemarle Avenue. Two of the suspects were 15 years old.
The arrests ended a six-month investigation, said Joseph Burruano, the county prosecutor in charge of the burglary and narcotics unit. He said the defendants were selling crack and cocaine, ranging in price from $20 to $100, to undercover officers.
Mr. Burruano said efforts were under way to expand the fight against drugs from the street level in Hempstead up the ladder to the middle-level distributors and major suppliers, a battle he acknowledged "would take much time and effort."
Chief Russo said that the sweep was the eighth in the last few years and that more than 1,000 street-level drug pushers had been arrested.
Of those charged over the weekend, nearly all the suspects were from Hempstead. Most were young and unemployed, said Chief Russo.
They were charged with criminal sale of a controlled substance in the third degree, a class "B" felony, punishable by up to 25 years in prison upon conviction.
But Mr. Burruano said he expected the "vast majority" with no previous convictions to serve between 60 days and 6 months, while those with previous convictions would serve between 4 1/2 and 9 years in prison.
Chief Russo said he thought the punishment was not severe enough and was among the reasons why many repeat offenders were arrested in the latest sweep.
But he said he was not discouraged. "We just have to keep locking them up," he said.

With him, from left, were Richard Fiero, Nassau County chief of detectives; Joseph Burruano, county prosecutor in charge of the narcotics unit, and James Russo, the chief of police, standing. HEADLINE: Florio Presents Proposal To Restructure State Debt

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The Florio administration unveiled today a $1.6 billion bond refinancing and new debt plan that would capitalize on lower interest rates to pump more than $900 million into New Jersey's state coffers over the next three years, but at the expense of higher bond payments later.
The bond restructuring plan would allow the state to refinance $700 million in existing bonds and issue an additional $900 million in bonds without voter approval. 
 The State Treasurer, Samuel F. Crane, said the plan would allow New Jersey to take advantage of lower interest rates for both the refinanced bonds and the new ones.
Under the plan, the state would be acting like a homeowner who takes advantage of low interest rates to refinance an existing mortgage, thus lowering his monthly payments, and then takes out a second mortgage, which supplies extra cash. But in this case, the second loan is used mostly to pay interest on the first loan.
The money from the new bonds would be used to pay the state's debt service for three years, thus releasing the money normally used for that purpose to meet other needs.
 
Call for Quick Approval
 The tradeoff is that after the three-year period the state's annual bond payments will be $87 million higher for 17 years. In other words, the state will pay nearly $1.5 billion to use the $900 million for three years.
But Mr. Crane told the Legislature's Joint Budget Oversight Committee that the new borrowing would be necessary within a few years anyway, and borrowing now will allow the state to take advantage of low interest rates rather than running the risk that rates will rise.
He asked the committee to approve the plan quickly, but both Republicans and Democrats complained that they were being pressured into precipitous action. John Lynch of New Brunswick, the Democratic minority leader in the Senate, said, "I am always concerned when I hear that we have something magnificent but it has to be done yesterday."
"What we will be doing," he said, "is increasing by 12.5 percent the amount of bond debt."
Mr. Crane said he wanted the plan approved immediately so he could get the new financing in place "before Christmas week." Doing so, he said, would allow the state to avoid a $50 million debt payment in January.
However, the committee, dominated by Republicans, recessed so its staff could study the proposal in detail. No time was set for a decision.
Mr. Crane said the debt refinancing and new borrowing would allow the state to accelerate capital construction projects that he said would create 17,000 jobs. Though a formal program has not been drawn up, he said, a broad range of projects, including schools and colleges, hospitals, libraries, veterans' homes and similar projects, would be considered.
The funds freed through the use of new bond money to pay debt service would initially increase the state's unappropriated surplus -- that is, it would be set aside for emergencies. The unappropriated surplus is now only $31 million, which both Mr. Crane and Wall Street's credit rating analysts consider far too low.
 
Fiscal Weatherizing
 The low surplus was cited as the major reason that Moody's Investors Service slightly lowered the state's bond rating, a measure of its credit worthiness, earlier this year.
Mr. Crane said that if the plan is approved, the state would be able to add $235 million to the surplus.
Over the two fiscal years from July 1993 through June 1995, he said, the new financing would also allow the state to deposit $100 million in its "Rainy Day Fund," which was created last year to deal with emergencies created by budget shortfalls. The remaining money freed by borrowing the $900 million to pay debt service, about $565 million, would go to capital construction projects.
The state's ability to issue the $900 million in new general obligation bonds without the referendum that would normally be required, Mr. Crane said, results from the Refunding Bond Act of 1985, which gave the state broader authority to refinance bonds to take advantage of favorable interest rates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
T.W.A. Pact On Pensions Is Reached

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Carl C. Icahn virtually wrote the final chapter in an era in aviation history and to his involvement with financially troubled Trans World Airlines yesterday by reaching an agreement with the Government to support the airline's pension funds.
If approved by the bankruptcy court, the agreement with the Pension Guarantee Benefit Corporation will allow the airline to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law protection from creditors. It could also enable Mr. Icahn, a major figure in high-stakes corporate takeovers, to bow out of the airline with little financial damage. 
 The agreement, calling for Mr. Icahn to put up $200 million in cash to keep the airline operating, will be submitted to bankruptcy court Jan. 12, and Mr. Icahn will relinquish control of the carrier upon final approval, expected in about 30 days. The reorganized airline, whose future remains precarious, will be owned 55 percent by its unsecured creditors and the remainder by its 22,700 employees.
At a news conference in Washington yesterday, Robin Wilson, a member of T.W.A.'s two-man management committee, said, "T.W.A. will be a very competitive carrier -- not just in costs but in aggressive pursuit of revenue gains as well." The other committee member is Glenn R. Zander.
But analysts were not as optimistic. "T.W.A.'s future will clearly depend on the general state of the airline industry, including an economic recovery which will hopefully fuel the resumption of traffic growth," Julius Maldutis of Salomon Brothers said. "Its future will be beyond its control."
The agreement also calls for Mr. Icahn to provide about $80 million in minimum financing and to guarantee a total of $240 million payable over eight years to support the airline's existing pension plans in the event of a T.W.A. failure. The carrier earlier had pledged a note of $300 million to the plans, secured by its international routes and Kansas City maintenance base.
Last week, Aviation Daily, an industry publication, reported that T.W.A., supported by its unions and creditors, had undertaken a lobbying effort to win the pension corporation's blessing of the settlement. It said the effort was supported by Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican, and Senator John Danforth, the Missouri Republican.
While one airline analyst, who would not comment for the record, said Mr. Icahn appeared to have gotten off relatively easily, other analysts disagree.
"I think everybody got off well," Paul Karos of First Boston said.
Mr. Icahn also sounded pleased. "They have low costs and a good balance sheet," he said, referring to the airline.
The expected departure of Mr. Icahn will also remove from the industry one of the last of the individual investors who put up their money in an effort to imprint their personalities on the industry.

(Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Buying Surge Sends Dow Up by 18.65

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Stocks were swept higher by a wave of buying yesterday as investors appeared more upbeat about corporate earnings and less worried that President-elect Bill Clinton's economic stimulus package would fire up inflation.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed 18.65 points higher at 3,307.33. Advancing issues led decliners, 1,210 to 673, on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume was 220.1 million shares, compared with 235 million on Friday. 
 The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.93 points to a new high of 666.53. It was the eighth record close in nine sessions for the index.
Also setting new highs was the New York Stock Exchange composite index, which rose 1.59 points, to 239.36, and the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, which gained 3.25 to close at 435.31. The American Stock Exchange index lost 0.59, to 394.36.
"It's a continuation of what happened last week," said Bob Antolini, head of over-the-counter trading at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Investors view secondary stocks as strong performers in a slow economic recovery and benefiting from tax policies of the incoming Clinton Administration.
Analysts said gains in the Dow component American Express contributed to the rise in the blue-chip barometer. American Express ended up 1 1/2, to 24 7/8, on a heavy volume of 8.9 million shares on reports that James D. Robinson 3d, company chairman, is stepping down after more than 15 years at the helm. Some analysts said strong gains in the bond market also buoyed stocks. Shares in Rayonier Timberlands L.P. plummeted 2 1/2, to 37. The Connecticut-based timber partnership said it did not know why its share price fell.
American Dental Laser soared 4 1/8, to 9 3/4, topping the Nasdaq net gainers list. The company said the Food and Drug Administration decided Friday to allow it to begin marketing a new dental device. Microsoft rose 1 5/8, to 93 3/8, and Intel rose 1/4, to 79.
