HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Two Ad-Spending Forecasts Debate Amount of Growth

BYLINE: By Adam Bryant

 BODY:
BY the time 1992 is over, advertising spending in the United States will have risen 4.5 percent over 1991, a leading industry researcher said yesterday.
To a degree, an increase over 1991 was relatively easy to achieve, since the drop in ad spending last year marked the first such drop in 30 years. 
 And even though the estimate for 1992 by Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and director of forecasting for McCann-Erickson U.S.A., represents a cut of half a percentage point from his last estimate in June, he still spoke hopefully that the long-troubled economy was improving and would buoy the fortunes of the advertising industry. "I think the worst is over," he said at the opening session of the 20th annual Paine Webber media conference in Manhattan. "Optimism will gradually take hold."
Mr. Coen's track record as forecaster suggests he prefers to err on the side of optimism, but the revised 4.5 percent increase in ad spending for 1992, which is projected to total $132.1 billion, marks the second time he has slashed his estimate. A year ago, he projected that 1992 ad spending would grow 6.2 percent over 1991. In June, he cut his estimate to 5 percent.
According to Mr. Coen, local advertising continued to lag behind spending on national advertising this year. Newspapers and Yellow Pages have fared poorly because of the softness in classified and retail advertising. Mr. Coen said gains are likely next year because of the recent low levels in these categories.
Mr. Coen said that while his projections for advertising and economic growth proved overly optimistic through much of 1992, ad spending is now expanding faster than the economy. The gross domestic product grew at 3.9 percent in the third quarter, a rate well above many economists' projections.
For 1993, Mr. Coen predicted that United States advertising spending would grow by 6.9 percent, to $141.2 billion. If that estimate proves accurate, it would mark the first time since 1987 that United States advertising growth significantly outpaced economic growth.
One reason for the rosy prediction is that marketers are expected to turn increasingly to advertising, rather than coupons or other trade promotions, because more confident consumers will need to be lured less with promotions. Such predictions for 1993 are also noteworthy because those gains must come on top of the increased ad spending this year for the Winter and Summer Olympic Games.
Mr. Coen projected a 5.9 percent rise in ad spending worldwide in 1992, and another 5.9 percent gain worldwide in 1993.
After Mr. Coen made his semiannual forecast at the conference, which continues this week at the McGraw-Hill Building in midtown Manhattan, John Perriss, chairman and chief executive of the Zenith Media Worldwide subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., presented less optimistic predictions.
He estimated that United States ad spending would grow a meager six-tenths of 1 percent this year, compared with a previous forecast of 1.2 percent growth. He also revised his forecast slightly upward for 1993 major media spending in North America to 3.2 percent growth compared with a July prediction of 3 percent.
"There will be steady improvement but no great bounce-back until economic conditions improve," Mr. Perriss said.
Mr. Perriss estimated that worldwide advertising would grow 4 percent in 1992 over 1991, and he also predicted a "very modest recovery" in 1993, an increase of 3.2 percent expected for the United States and 5.3 percent for worldwide advertising growth. The Asia/Pacific market continues to be yoked by Japan's economic difficulties, Mr. Perriss said. In Europe, the market is being hurt by declining demand as well as large increases in media supply.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls and Gold Gains, But Trading Volume Is Light

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday in extremely thin trading on the world's currency markets.
Gold prices rose slightly after falling overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $336.10 an ounce, up 40 cents from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose 40 cents an ounce, to a late bid of $336.00. 
 Analysts said that the dollar sold off overnight in foreign markets and that the selling continued when trading shifted to the United States.
"The dollar fell like a rock," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with IDEA, an advisory firm. "Thin market conditions exacerbated fund managers' selling of dollars."
Much attention focused on the Swiss franc, which rose despite the Sunday rejection by Swiss voters of a proposal to affiliate with the European Community. The market seemed to conclude that Switzerland's "relative isolation from the community is a good thing," Mr. Chandler said.
Traders said that any fresh data on the United States economy was expected to confirm that the recovery was finally on track. No extreme reactions are expected in the market.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to close at 124.87 Japanese yen, from 124.63 yen at the Friday close. Later, in London, it fell to 124.40 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 123.75 yen, down from 124.93 yen on Friday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5875, from $1.5585 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.5980 to buy 1, compared with $1.5593 of Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Friday rates, included: 1.5563 German marks, down from 1.5925; 1.3935 Swiss francs down from 1.4280; 5.3025 French francs, down from 5.4140; 1,374.50 Italian lire, down from 1,397.00, and 1.2727 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2776.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with the late Friday rates, included: 1.5680 German marks, down from 1.5950; 1.3995 Swiss francs, down from 1.4315; 5.3640 French francs, down from 5.4225.
Gold fell in London to a late bid of $334.75 an ounce, from $335.65 late Friday. In Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $334.80 from $335.60.

HEADLINE: Retailers' Holiday Optimism

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The nation's retail chains said yesterday that they expected stronger Christmas sales this year, but they warned that it would be a long time before consumers resumed spending the way they did before the recession.
The National Retail Federation, meeting in New York, predicted growth of 5 to 6 percent in Christmas sales, up from 1 to 2 percent a year ago. Rising consumer confidence and colder weather are helping this year's gains, the group said. 
 Adjusting for inflation, Christmas sales will be up 3.5 percent at stores open a year or more, the group said.
But some retailers warned that times had changed, and that the American economy had entered an era characterized by layoffs among big employers like the auto and military industries.
"Today's consumer is cautious and will not change," Joseph Antonini, the chairman of the Kmart Corporation, said in a speech to the federation.
"I see 2 to 3 to 4 percent growth for the next several years," he said, speaking of the industry over all. "The reason for that is the jobs situation. I do not see a robust rebound in the economy."
Mr. Antonini said that holiday sales at Kmart's stores open more than a year would be up 4 to 5 percent and that the chain's total sales would rise 9 to 10 percent for the season.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Baseball Owners Vote to Reopen Labor Talks

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 7

 BODY:
By the slimmest of majorities, 15-13, the major league baseball owners voted today to reopen negotiations on the collective bargaining agreement with the players, instantly creating speculation that the absence of a new agreement could jeopardize the beginning of the 1993 season.
Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor executive, played down the likelihood of a lockout, saying that "everybody wants to see no disruption in baseball" and disclosing that the owners without dissent raised from a simple majority (15) to a three-fourths vote (21) the authorization required for a lockout. 
 Ravitch, one baseball official said, worked hard to get the necessary majority. One of his primary sales pitches was that the reopener and lockout were separate issues. He apparently succeeded in convincing some of the wavering owners of that view, though others said it was naive.
In the weeks leading up to today's vote, various owners had described the position of the group as sharply, and evenly, divided. Today's vote, conducted in a secret ballot, underscored that assessment and left some question about the support Ravitch will have as he tries to negotiate a change in the way that the clubs pay players.
"I think the owners will stand behind me 100 percent as I try to achieve our bargaining objectives," Ravitch said at a news conference. But he added: "Sure, it would be an easier negotiation if all 28 owners were of one mind. I can't deny that."
 
Fehr Says He Wasn't Notified
 Donald Fehr, head of the players' union, said he had not received a call from Ravitch or anyone else affiliated with the clubs notifying him of their decision.
Asked about the possible significance of the bare majority, he said: "I don't treat it with any particular significance. I have said for a long time that Ravitch is their man. They have asked him to fix the problem and he would get as many votes as he needed."
Speaking of Ravitch's stance on baseball labor matters, Fehr said, "People he allied with during the summer are people who would be viewed as hard-liners." Fehr didn't identify any owners, but he was clearly referring to Bud Selig of the Milwaukee Brewers and Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox.
In late May and early June, Selig, Reinsdorf and Ravitch tried to get Fay Vincent, who was then commissioner, to relinquish his authority in labor relations. Vincent refused, but the effort mushroomed into a move to oust him, and the owners opposed to him succeeded in forcing him to resign.
 
Owners Concerned by Escalation
 The labor contract that emerged from the owners' 1990 lockout expires Dec. 31, 1993. But either side had the right to reopen the contract by this Friday. The players, who have prospered handsomely the past 16 years under free agency and salary arbitration, had no reason to reopen.
The owners, taking a doom-and-gloom view of the game's future economy, want to change the salary system so that they can halt the escalation of salaries and have greater control over them. When negotiations begin, Ravitch will propose a system under which players will receive a share of the clubs' revenue and that will, in effect, place a cap on salaries.
Ravitch also has proposed that clubs extend their own sharing of revenue, and many of the clubs that voted against the reopener also oppose that plan.
Asked if he recommended that the owners vote to reopen, Ravitch said, "I told them if they wanted to have the option to affect the 1994 season, they had to reopen the contract in some fashion. There was concern among owners if you don't start talking now, you can't affect the economics of the 1994 season. You'd have to live with the economics of the current system."
Concern existed, too, Ravitch said, about the possibility of an interruption of the 1993 season. Some owners opposed a reopener for that reason.
"It's fair to say there are a lot of owners concerned about the technical risk that baseball won't be played in 1993," Ravitch said. "But I think they were reassured by the fact that there isn't anybody who wants to see baseball not played in 1993. There was not a single owner in the room who advocated that there be a lockout or that any decision be made about a lockout at this time."
The clubs, their labor expert said, do not seek a confrontation.
"We would like to move toward some change in the player-compensation system," Ravitch said, "because we don't think the current system works as well as other systems might. We want to do it quietly and constructively. I don't ask the union to give up any legal options they have; certainly the owners don't."
 
Fehr Sees 'Confrontation Possible'
 Fehr countered that "the mere fact this step was taken makes a confrontation possible when it otherwise wouldn't have been."
Fehr noted the string of off-field issues that have occupied baseball the past year -- the Japanese-led purchase of the Seattle Mariners, National League realignment, the initial and then the successful move against Vincent, sale of the San Francisco Giants, Marge Schott -- calling it a period of unusual turmoil and "a little more than plain meanness."
"For all the talk of partnership," he said, "it was interesting that our views were not solicited on any of these issues. I would have thought this was a year that people would have gone out of their way to make sure there wasn't a confrontation. Obviously, that hasn't happened and it's regrettable."
Ravitch said he doesn't plan to seek a vote for a lockout, adding: "I have made no effort to seek support for a lockout. I have never asked any owner to vote for it and I have no plans to do so now."
But he said: "I won't guarantee anything. I'll guarantee only that discussions will begin in good faith with the intention of proceeding to produce results without confrontation."
Baseball has never had a labor negotiation without a confrontation. Four strikes and three lockouts have punctuated talks for new agreements.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
CUSTOMERS PROTEST NEW PLAN FOR MUTUAL BENEFIT LIFE

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
A newly revised rehabilitation plan for the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company drew fire from a group of more than 500,000 people who have retirement savings invested with the seized Newark-based insurer. The Association of Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Contract Holders, said yesterday that the plan worked out by New Jersey and New York regulators favored contracts backed by state guarantee funds. 
 A group of insurance companies, including Prudential Insurance and Metropolitan Life, has agreed to guarantee contracts that are not backed by the states, but the minimum interest rate they pledged was lower than the minimum guaranteed by the states. The customers' group, whose members represent more than 80 percent of the $5.2 billion in retirement savings at stake in Mutual Benefit Life's rehabilitation, said the revised plan strayed from an agreement state regulators, insurance companies and customers had earlier worked out.

HEADLINE: SCIENCE WATCH;
More Mathematicians

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
American educational institutions continue to award doctorates in mathematics at a near record rate, but more than half the recipients are foreigners, and employment prospects for the new mathematicians are distinctly uncertain.
A survey conducted by the American Mathematical Society and the Mathematical Association of America reported that in the 1991-92 academic year, 1,050 Ph.D. degrees in mathematics were awarded, one of the highest numbers on record. Women, historically underrepresented in mathematics, did especially well; some 24 percent of the new doctors in mathematics were women. The median starting salaries for Ph.D. mathematics teachers also favored women, according to the survey. New male teachers can expect starting salaries of $34,000, while the starting salaries of women in comparable jobs average $34,900. 
 Only 42 percent of the new doctorates were granted to United States citizens, continuing a trend that has characterized American mathematical education during the last five years.
The growing participation of women in higher mathematics has not been matched by an increase in the number of black and Hispanic mathematicians. Of the 1,050 Ph.D. degrees in math granted during the year, only six went to American blacks and five to Hispanic people.
Another discouraging aspect of the survey was its findings on employment prospects. By late September, 13 percent of the new doctors of mathematics were still looking for jobs, a rate lower only than the record 14 percent in 1975.
This has created a paradox, in which on one hand mathematicians believe the United States is badly undersupplied with mathematicians, while on the other, mathematicians are having trouble finding jobs.
"The effect of economic conditions on higher education is felt strongly by the mathematics community," said Donald E. McClure of Brown University, author of the report on the survey. Pressures on the job market, he said, "limit the opportunities of new doctorates.
"At the same time," he added, "the number of students within the U.S. coming from our own undergraduate institutions and pursuing the Ph.D. does not nearly meet this country's overall demand for highly trained mathematical scientists."

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Firing Culture

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
After years of feeding on strawberries, cream and honey, or tons of money if you'd rather not be poetic about it, corporate executives are suddenly getting fired. Mr. Stempel of General Motors was the most spectacular instance of their new vulnerability. Now Mr. Robinson of American Express is said to be getting the boot.
Note that I don't dare breathe the names of these boardroom commanders without calling them "Mister." Such is the awe that corporate giants inspire in those bred to think of them as an elite class. "Corporate statesmen," they were called in the Eisenhower years. One was invited to kowtow. Now they get fired. 
 This is a big development in American firing. Until now, corporate giants were as unfireable as government workers and tenured college professors. Firing a corporate statesman can be done, apparently, only by his board of directors. It is a private operation carried out by a handful of boardroom big shots who have known each other for years.
Whatever the reason for a corporation's board to give the pink slip to its C.E.O., you can bet your gold fillings it has nothing to do with the reason you'd like to fire the guy.
If, for instance, you owned one of those multitudes of General Motors pickup trucks with the dangerously exposed gasoline tanks, you might enjoy telling Mr. Stempel to clear out his desk and pick up his farewell check at the pay window.
Never mind that those trucks were produced under the administration of Mr. Stempel's predecessor, Mr. Smith, who has since overseen his own retirement on a pension exceeding $1 million a year. You might be sufficiently hot-headed about your dangerous truck to drop the "Mister" and say, "Don't talk a retired Smith to me. What's Stempel done about my truck since taking over? Nothing. Stempel must go."
Boards of directors doubtless wish their companies wouldn't sell you dangerous merchandise. They are not merchants of death, nor heartless, nor totally indifferent to their customers' safety.
Still, if the profit margin is expanding, rather than fire their corporate giant they are more likely to approve his latest application for another pay rise after asking if there isn't something he can do, by the way, about the nasty gasoline-tank situation in his trucks.
How different this is from the traditional method of firing baseball managers and football coaches. Fans of the New York Giants football team, for example, are responding to the team's unsuccessful season by demanding the coach be fired. The sports pages and all history suggest he will be.
In contrast to the indifference a discontented Chevrolet buyer may expect after demanding that General Motors fire its president, a discontented Giants fan demanding Coach Handley's head seems to receive a sympathetic hearing from the authorities.
Actually, of course, all but the most dim-witted fan realizes he is merely acting out the traditional fan's role in a traditional firing ritual. The obvious remedy for an unsuccessful team is to fire the players, or at least the more incompetent among them, and hire better ones.
Sports fans know this. They also know just as surely that team owners will not do so. For one thing it would cost a great deal of money, which the owners might not have or which they might prefer to spend on Caribbean real estate if they did have it.
Moreover, it usually takes several years to replace losing players with winning players. Fans know this too and so are content to have the coach fired. Team owners, happy to be so easily forgiven for marketing an inferior product, contentedly play their role in the charade by firing the coach.
Hiring a new coach is the economically sound, though athletically absurd, solution for a losing-team problem, since coaches -- and, in baseball, managers -- work for even less money than mediocre, which is to say unwinning, athletes. The beauty part is that coaches and managers accept the rules of the charade and expect to be fired periodically, just as Mafia men accept, as part of their job, the probability that they will have to spend a percentage of their lives in prison.
The lesson here is that if you hope to fire the people you think need firing you must get a seat on the corporate board or own the team.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

LENGTH: 1397 words

HEADLINE: Clinton Expected to Name Woman Attorney General

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton is moving to name the first woman to serve as Attorney General, and transition aides in Washington and Arkansas said today that he was considering four candidates.
The finalists, three judges and a Washington lawyer active in public-interest causes, are emblematic of the women who entered law schools in small numbers in the 1950's and 1960's and then rose to the top of their profession. 
 The candidates are Judge Patricia M. Wald of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit; Judge Amalya L. Kearse of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in Manhattan; Judge Judith S. Kaye of the New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, and Brooksley E. Born, a partner at the Washington firm of Arnold & Porter. All are accomplished legal scholars and considered liberals to varying degrees.
A person with knowledge of the appointment process said Mr. Clinton had also made his choices for two major economic positions, subject to background checks: Representative Leon E. Panetta as director of the Office of Management and Budget and Robert E. Rubin as economic security adviser.
Mr. Panetta, a California Democrat, heads the House Budget Committee, and Mr. Clinton is expected to highlight the post of budget director in his first round of appointments, to be announced Thursday and Friday.
 
Meeting With Women
 Mr. Rubin is co-chairman of the banking investment firm of Goldman Sachs & Company. Mr. Clinton is creating the post of economic security adviser, and its responsibilities have yet to be defined.
The decision to focus on female candidates for Attorney General followed a meeting in Washington last week in which top Clinton aides, including Vernon E. Jordan, the transition chairman, conferred with the leaders of about a half-dozen women's rights groups. According to those at the meeting, the representatives from the groups called on Mr. Clinton select a woman for one of what is sometimes referred to as the "big four" Cabinet posts: Treasury, State, Defense and Justice.
One transition official said the meeting was not confrontational because the Clinton team was receptive to the idea that a woman be chosen for one of those four positions. The official said the Justice Department provided the greatest opportunity to fulfill that notion because of the large pool of accomplished female lawyers.
All four candidates have been interviewed by top transition officials, two of them last weekend in Little Rock, Ark.
It is unclear what role was played by Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary, a prominent lawyer who is active in many of the same causes as some of the candidates. Some Clinton aides suggested that however influential Mrs. Clinton might have been, she and her husband were uneasy about people believing that she had significant influence in such issues.
 
A Carter Appointee
 The tentative decision to focus on four women to head the Justice Department means that Mr. Jordan, once referred to in newspaper accounts as a candidate for Attorney General, is not under serious consideration.
Judge Wald is, by some accounts, the slight favorite of transition officials. At 64, she is also the oldest of the four. She was appointed to the bench by President Jimmy Carter in 1979 after serving as Assistant Attorney General for Legislative Affairs.
After graduating from Yale Law School in 1951, she began work for a Washington law firm but soon took 10 years off to rear five children, managing at the same time to write a book urging reform of the bail laws and other scholarly articles.
She returned to practicing law in the early 1960's by joining a neighborhood legal-services offices. Over the next several years she worked for a variety of public-interest legal causes, including the Center for Law and Social Policy, which brought test cases in consumer and health areas, and the Mental Health Project. She has written extensively on issues like children's rights.
 
A Black and a New Yorker
 Judge Wald has told friends that she is interested in the job, but the peculiar judicial pension laws mean that she would forfeit all her pension interest accrued over 13 years if she left the bench now. If she served another two years as judge, she would receive her full salary as a pension. Transition officials said pension questions might not prove an obstacle.
Judge Kearse, also named to the bench by President Carter, is the first woman and the second black lawyer to serve on the Second Circuit, the first black being Thurgood Marshall. She is a native of Vauxhall, N.J. In addition to being an accomplished corporate lawyer with a Wall Street firm before she went on the bench, she is one of the nation's top contract bridge players and has written several books on the game.
Judge Kearse, 55, has also been mentioned in news accounts as a likely nominee for the Supreme Court in the Clinton Administration.
 
Candidate for State Post
 Similarly, Judge Kaye of New York's top state court has been thought of as a potential nominee to the Supreme Court. She is also a candidate to become chief judge of the state Court of Appeals, succeeding Judge Sol Wachtler, who resigned last month after being arrested on charges of extortion.
After graduating from Barnard College, Ms. Kaye became a society writer for The Hudson Dispatch newspaper in New Jersey. She has said that she thought she was given that job because it was considered women's work and that that motivated her to enroll in New York University Law school at night.
Judge Kaye, 54, became the first women to the state's highest court when she was appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in 1983.
 
Trailblazer at Stanford
 The fourth candidate, Ms. Born, has combined an active private practice with interest in children's issues, legal services and bar association activities. Ms. Born, 52, graduated at the top of her class at the Stanford University Law School and was the first woman to head the Stanford Law Review.
During the first few years of the Reagan Administration, she was the chairman of the American Bar Association's committee that evaluates nominees to the Federal bench. She is the only woman ever to hold that position.
She was also a pioneer in that she was named a partner at Arnold & Porter at a time when she insisted on working part-time to allow her to spend more time with her children, who are now grown.
She is also a founding member of the Women's Legal Defense Fund and is chairwoman of the National Women's Law Center.
Transition officials said they had not even begun to consider candidates for another important Justice Department position, Solicitor General, the person who argues the Federal Government's cases before the Supreme Court.
 
Transportation Secretary
 In other Cabinet positions, the list of finalists for Transportation Secretary is said by Democratic and transition office sources to include a former Democratic Governor of Michigan, the brother of Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago, and a Democratic Congressional leader.
James J. Blanchard, 41, who was Governor of Michigan from 1983 to 1991, is considered the top candidate, several of the sources said, all on the condition that they not be identified.
Mr. Blanchard, a lawyer and business consultant in Washington and Michigan, is a friend of Mr. Clinton and has been serving as an informal adviser in the transition to the President-elect and former Gov. Richard W. Riley of South Carolina, who is heading the transition team's search for appointees to sub-Cabinet posts.
William Daley, son and brother of Chicago Mayors, is also reported to be a finalist for Transportation Secretary. Mr. Daley, 43, is president of the Amalgamated Bank of Chicago.
Two Westerners who are members of minorities are also being considered: Representative Norman Y. Mineta of California and Henry G. Cisneros, former Mayor of San Antonio.
Mr. Mineta is an 18-year Congressman from San Jose, Calif. His family lost its insurance business and home during the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II.
Mr. Cisneros is considered a candidate for several Cabinet positions, but it is also regarded as a possibility that Gov. Ann W. Richards will appoint him to the Senate seat that will be vacated if Lloyd Bentsen is nominated to be Treasury Secretary.

HEADLINE: Educator's $960,000 Payment Prompts Outrage

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
This fall, at 62, Edward J. Murphy, an influential administrator and superintendent of a special school district on Long Island, received the highest retirement award in the history of New York State -- $960,000.
Now, as state officials scramble to recoup the payment, they say the retirement award threatens to undermine not only the public's attitude toward Dr. Murphy's 42-year career, but its support for ever increasing taxes to pay for public education. 
 Yesterday, the State Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, said the payment was excessive and possibly illegal, and he moved to suspend the seven-member board that awarded the payment. He also moved to recover the money.
"Such payment is grossly excessive in a time when the state and local districts are facing serious fiscal constraints," he said.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has been sparring with Long Island school officials for years over state aid reductions and spiraling local property taxes, issued a statement saying, "Instead of raising real-estate taxes and demanding more and more taxpayers' money from Albany, all school districts must finally admit the truth and subject themselves -- if not to severe discipline -- at least to reasonableness."
The payment was made after Dr. Murphy, the head of a district that provides services like vocational training and special education to 18 local school districts, put in his retirement papers on Sept. 30.
Just like many of the superintendents of the 40 other similar districts across the state, he received a salary of $43,499 from the State Education Department as well as additional pay from the local school districts. In Dr. Murphy's case, the supplemental pay was about $175,000 a year, bringing his total annual compensation to about $220,000.
This made him the highest paid education official in New York State, receiving far more than Mr. Sobol's $131,000 and the $195,000 paid to New York City's School Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, according to the State Education Department.
And as the retirement paperwork made its way through the education bureaucracy in Albany, state officials were stunned to discover some of the details of Dr. Murphy's contract with the Suffolk No. 3 Board of Cooperative Educational Services. Dr. Murphy had received a $960,000 payment, which included a $115,000 in "termination pay" and pay for 800 unused sick and vacation days at a rate of $1,040 a day. The Education Department said the package was the highest of its kind ever awarded in the state.
Among the terms of his contract, Dr. Murphy received up to 90 paid vacation days a year, when most state employees typically receive 15 to 20, said Christopher Carpenter, a spokesman for the Education Department.
And while regular state employees can receive pay for only the first 30 days of vacation, and get little or no benefit from unused sick days, Dr. Murphy was permitted to carry it all forward to his retirement.
Some state officials believe that the board was willing to approve the contract to keep Dr. Murphy from retiring. The retirement package was reported yesterday in Newsday.
Dr. Murphy did not return several telephone messages left on a tape machine at his home in Syosset. Asked about the award, Joseph F. Singleton, the deputy superintendent of the district, said the board had done nothing wrong.
 
'Nothing Illegal'
 "I respect the Commissioner highly, but the fact is that this board has done nothing illegal and has not violated any regulations of the Commissioner," Mr. Singleton said. Because the extra pay came from the school districts, rather than the state, "there is no need to return anything," he said.
But he declined to respond in detail until he received an order to show cause, which is expected to be issued by Mr. Sobol today. Before Mr. Sobol acted, the local board issued a statement, according to The Associated Press, saying that "the board believes that his compensation was appropriate for Dr. Murphy's consistently outstanding performance."
State officials said that in addition to the $960,000 payment, Dr. Murphy received about $50,000 for working the three months from July through his retirement in September.
Under the usual retirement rules, Dr. Murphy would be eligible for a pension of about $150,000 a year, according to Robert DeLuca, a spokesman for the State Retirement System. But if the $960,000 payment is eventually counted toward his retirement, it could double the pension to about $300,000 a year.
 
Pension Calculations
 Usually pensions are calculated on the average of a person's final three years of regular salary. However, in some cases pensions are based on the final five years of salary and whatever other compensation is awarded. Pensions are financed through a state pension plan into which school districts contribute.
Lawyers for the State Education Department reviewed the award and said there were several grounds for challenging it, Mr. Carpenter said. He said that while local boards had the authority to award additional pay, it was not clear whether they had the authority to pay for additional unused vacation days.
The Suffolk cooperative services board covers 18 school districts in the towns of Huntington Babylon and Smithtown, and has a reptutation for being among the most innovative in the state.
Alice F. Willet, the executive director of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association, said that Dr. Murphy was "excellent, outstanding" and innovative. But the dispute over his retirement package, she said, "is going to have a detrimental impact upon our future legislative lobbying with the state."
"It is distressing when this comes at a time of economic hardship on Long Island," she said.
 
'Nothing Is Business as Usual'
 Last year, Dr. Murphy was among the scores of school officials who complained bitterly about what they saw as disastrous cuts in state aid that were disproportionately aimed at relatively wealthy Long Island school districts.
"This is a year when nothing is business as usual," he said at the time, addressing the impact of layoffs and tax increases. State officials said yesterday that despite the hardships, Dr. Murphy had received a $10,000 annual raise at the start of the new school year.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO SOMALIA;
Americans Will Find Somalia Full Of Arms Provided by Superpowers

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The American marines who landed in Somalia tonight have entered a country that is awash in weapons, many of them Soviet-made but also including American arms supplied to the African country by Washington in the 1980's.
Moscow was the principal weapons supplier to Somalia during the 1970's, and Soviet and Eastern European arms have continued to flow into the country in recent years from Libya and have been smuggled in from neighboring Ethiopia, current and former American officials say. 
 The results are readily apparent on the streets of Mogadishu, where clan members are seen with AK-47's, Soviet-made machine guns and even an occasional Soviet armored personnel carrier.
But while much of the weaponry is of Soviet origin, the American-led force will also face American arms. According to an internal Pentagon report, Washington provided $35 million in "lethal assistance" to the old Government of President Mohammed Siad Barre from 1981 to 1989. Among the American weapons are 4,800 rifles, 3,672 grenades, 482 TOW anti-tank missiles, 24 armored personnel carriers, 18 155-millimeter howitzers, 6,032 artillery shells, 75 81-millimeter mortars and 144 land mines.
 
Few Somali Heavy Weapons
 The Somalis' weapons are no match for American firepower. The Somalis have relatively few heavy weapons like tanks, and the absence of spare parts and maintenance problems have taken a toll. The Pentagon does not expect the Somali clans to mount a determined resistance to the American force.
But there are so many weapons and they are so widely dispersed that there are potential threats to the American troops everywhere. Even a few shots from a sniper or undetected mines could result in American casualties.
"The problem at the present time is not heavy weapons," said Paul B. Henze, a Rand Corporation analyst and former aide to Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser. "The problem is an enormous quantity of small arms, total disorder and young men whose way of life is to rob, steal and shoot."
Mr. Henze predicted that the Somalis "will not take on a convoy of marines, but there is no way of controlling that many people with guns."
The flood of arms in the Horn of Africa is a legacy of the cold war and of tensions between Somalia and Ethiopia. During the 1970's, Ethiopia and Somalia fought a war over the Ogaden region of Ethiopia. From 1961 to 1974, Somalia imported more than $210 million worth of arms, primarily from Moscow or Eastern European nations, according to Mr. Henze.
After Somalia invaded Ethiopia in 1977, the Soviets shifted their support to the Marxist Government in Ethiopia. After Moscow switched sides, Washington's ally, the Shah of Iran, provided Somalia with weapons, as did Egypt and other Arab nations. Washington's supply of arms to the Siad Barre Government from 1981 to 1989, was at a lower rate than Moscow's earlier flow.
According to an American official, after the United States stopped supplying weapons, Eastern bloc arms were provided by Libya. When the Siad Barre Government fell in 1991, armories were looted and the arms divided up by rival clans.
The overthrow of the Ethiopian Government of Mengistu Haile Mariam in 1991 also unleashed a new supply of arms in the Horn of Africa. With poorly patrolled borders, the region has a thriving black market in weapons.
It is unclear how many weapons in Somalia are in working order. But when the American Embassy personnel were rescued from Mogadishu by a Marine force in January 1991, Somalis were menacing the Embassy with shoulder-fired SA-7 surface-to-air missiles. The Americans also detected radar signals for SA-2 and SA-3 surface-to-air missiles during that operation.
Even if maintenance problems and a healthy fear of the marines mean that the heavier weapons are not much of a threat, disarming the entire country would be a herculean chore.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO SOMALIA;
U.S. Orders Relief Workers Indoors for 48 Hours

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Relief workers have been advised by the United States military to stay indoors for at least the first 48 hours after the arrival of American troops in the Somali capital, but many relief officials are concerned that the interruption will last longer, gravely affecting hundreds of thousands of hungry people.
A 48-hour hiatus is not expected to have a great effect on the delivery of aid, at least in Mogadishu, which has received more food and health care than any other area. 
 The International Committee of the Red Cross, which has brought more food to more people in famine-torn Somalia during the past year than any other organization, has stocked two days' worth of food in its 600 kitchens. Their Somali workers have agreed to continue business as usual, feeding 1.2 million people in the Mogadishu area.
The situation is more critical where the famine is worst. In Baidoa, a major feeding center, Somali workers for one relief agency refused to go to work until the United States troops arrived.
But for the aid agencies, the key issue is whether the troops can quickly provide security for their operations, a function now performed by hundreds of paid Somali guards.
Safety, respect and power in Mogadishu are secured by machine guns. But United States military officials have told relief agencies that the troops would respond to armed Somalis as aggressors.
The Red Cross has ordered its guards to stay off the streets. But relief officials have not been able to figure out what to do with the guards.
"Do we allow them to keep their guns?" asked Rick Grant, a spokesman for CARE, "or do we take their guns from them to prevent accidental shootings from the Americans, which then opens them up to be shot by other Somalis? I don't want to be the one to ask my guard for his gun."
Other problems have surfaced for relief agencies.
In the past 24 hours, the value of the Somali shilling has risen sharply. A dollar now buys only 2,000 shillings, down from 3,200, creating a small financial crisis for CARE. The 900 guards at the port, for example, usually cost the equivalent of $5,000 a day, Mr. Grant said. But with the new exchange rate, the cost is closer to $8,000.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

METRO DIGEST
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
FEW SURPRISES IN HOSPITAL REPORT
A panel commissioned to investigate New York City's sprawling public hospital system identifies weaknesses that have already been pointed out and endorses changes that have already been made. The blueprint for caring for the health of New Yorkers supports the direction chosen by the Dinkins administration and suggests moderate changes. But it stops short of recommending the sweeping changes hoped for by some critics. B2.
 
HASIDIM MAY COOPERATE IN INQUIRY
After more than a week of virtual silence, several Hasidim may step forward to offer prosecutors information about events surrounding the beating of a homeless black man by a group of Hasidim in Crown Heights last week, the lawyer for the rabbinical student charged in the case said. Their testimony could prove an important development in a case fraught with political dangers whatever its outcome. Without any new witnesses, the prosecution would have to rely largely on the testimony of the beaten man, Ralph Nimmons, who has a long arrest record. B3.

HEADLINE: Foe of Slovak Leader Asking For U.S. Aid for New Nation

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
A leader of the opposition in Slovakia, which is to become an independent republic in three weeks, said today that the United States should assist his country regardless of the relatively authoritarian character of its current Government.
In an interview, the opposition leader, Ivan Miklos, deputy chairman of the Civic Democratic Union party in Bratislava, said, "Isolation would be punishment more for democratic forces than for the Government." 
 Under Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar, a nationalist who gained power in elections in June on a platform of separation from Czechoslovakia, Slovakia is to acquire sovereignty on Jan. 1.
Mr. Miklos, a 32-year-old economist who was Minister of Privatization in the previous coalition Government, said he and other members of the opposition were concerned that Slovakia, the poorer part of Czechoslovakia, would soon slide into economic despair.
"Czechoslovakia had a chance at prosperity," Mr. Miklos said. "Now only the Czechs have that chance. Slovakia has lost that chance. The kind of help from Western countries that I have in mind would keep Slovakia out of isolation, and it would help to keep democrats alive."
Mr. Miklos said he was conveying this message to Congress, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and private foundations.
Since he assumed power in the summer, Prime Minister Meciar has stifled efforts to establish a free press in Slovakia, has denied funds to a university created by the political opposition in the city of Trnava, and has slowed plans for reforming the economic system inherited from the Communist era that ended three years ago.
Despite his opposition to Mr. Meciar, Mr. Miklos said a prudent Western policy toward Slovakia would be to support stability.
"Otherwise you would create a demand for a more totalitarian regime," he said. "Better a little help when it is needed than massive efforts later to deal with a catastrophe."
United States policy toward the two parts of Czechoslovakia is aimed at treating them "as much as possible on a basis of parity," an Administration official said today. Until now, American assistance has been aimed principally at helping Czech and Slovak enterprises obtain financial assistance and converting military industries to civilian purposes.
"If we treat Slovakia as a second-class citizen, they'll end up that way," the official said, adding that the Meciar Government would be judged on its merits in human rights, treatment of minorities and creation of democratic institutions.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Despite Good News, Clinton Says, Economic Ills Remain

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton, fearful that recent optimistic economic reports could blunt public pressure for change, cautioned today that hard times were probably not over and that painful long-term economic reforms were still required.
In a speech before newspaper managers, in meetings with Congressional leaders and again at a news conference, Mr. Clinton repeated the theme he has been sounding more and more in recent days: that the public should not reduce pressure on Congress for sweeping changes because of optimistic interpretations of recent economic data. 
 "There is a lot of talk in the atmosphere today of people saying, 'Well, you know, maybe you don't need to do anything about this economy because the unemployment rate is going down, and housing starts are up, and everything's just hunky-dory,' " Mr. Clinton said at a news conference with Democratic Congressional leaders.
That is not the case, he insisted, adding, "We are nowhere near to knowing that this short-term recession is, in fact, over." Indeed, although the unemployment rate did drop in November, to 7.2 percent from 7.4 percent, the latest figure for housing starts showed a 1.1 percent decline in October.
Even if the economy is improving, Mr. Clinton added, long-term changes to improve productivity and competitiveness are essential. "There must be a very strong multiyear deficit reduction plan submitted at the same time I submit this coming year's budget, and that's what I'm going to do," he said.
Mr. Clinton also used his second visit to Washington since the election to prepare the public for the prospect that he may have to spend more time on foreign policy than he had intended. If he does not come to grips with problems around the world before they erupt into full-blown crises, he said, "I might have to spend all my time on foreign policy, and I don't want that to happen."
 
Underlying Problems
 For the last two days Mr. Clinton has used his public appearances to reinforce his argument that figures showing an improvement in the unemployment rate and the strongest quarterly growth in the gross domestic product in four years do not reflect the underlying problems still plaguing the American economy.
Aides said his comments are part of an effort by Mr. Clinton to blunt "if it ain't broke don't fix it" arguments as well as to signal the public that he has not forgotten why he was elected.
Even if the economy is rebounding from its recent depths, Mr. Clinton said at a meeting of Gannett newspaper managers today, "Maybe that changes what you do in the short run, but there are certain fundamental long-term challenges, that I believe I was elected to address, which have caused great difficulty for most Americans and have caused great difficulty for our country."
He later added in his Congressional news conference, "I based my whole campaign on my absolute conviction that the fundamental economic problems of this country are long-term problems that have been 20 years in the making."
To underscore that point, Mr. Clinton held up a chart provided by Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland, meant to show that increases in American productivity and job growth this year have not matched those following earlier economic slumps.
It is such long-term problems, he said, that "have led us to the situation now where most people are working longer hours than they were 20 years ago for lower wages in real dollars than they were making 10 years ago because of uncompetitive situations in the United States with regard to education and training, investment in new technologies, energy, dealing with the deficit and dealing with the health care issue."
 
Focus on the Rich
 Mr. Clinton said that such long-term problems can be cured only with tough long-term medicine, but, as in the campaign, he stopped short of detailing what sacrifices the middle classes might have to make, focusing instead on those who earn more than $200,000 a year.
Next week he will hold a conference on the economy in Little Rock, Ark., to which more than 250 business leaders and economists have been invited to discuss exactly how to put in place his proposals for improving productivity and competitiveness and reducing the deficit.
On foreign policy, Mr. Clinton also seemed to be trying to prepare the public to expect that events in Somalia and other areas will force him to direct his attention overseas, despite his campaign promise to focus on the economy like a "laser beam."
He said he appreciated President Bush's desire to withdraw American troops from Somalia by Inauguration Day on Jan. 20, but added, "We believe that this mission has merit and that an artificial timetable cannot be imposed upon it."
Mr. Clinton said that the crucial question in determining the length of United States involvement in Somalia is whether American troops will be needed to maintain order after the food situation is stabilized so that the government can be rebuilt, or whether that mission will be handled by a multinational force.
"I don't think anyone knows the final answer to that," he said.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton left open the possibility that his Administration might have to step up American involvement in Bosnia.
Mr. Clinton said he would not rule out a more aggressive involvement there, but stopped short of promising to commit troops. His aides have argued that there is much more the United States could do in Bosnia -- from tightening the arms embargo on Serbia to selective air strikes against Serbian artillery positions -- that would make a difference without putting American soldiers in harm's way.
"I'm quite concerned about what is likely to happen there -- the increase in violence, the impending loss of life," Mr. Clinton said. But he added that he understood why President Bush and other officials "do not wish to make a commitment of ground forces of the United States."

HEADLINE: MISSION TO SOMALIA;
Somali Clans Planning Last Grab for Advantage

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The competing clans that have ravaged this country spent the day today plotting attacks to wring the last bit of military advantage over their foes before the arrival of American forces, which are expected to put a damper on much of the fighting.
The faction under Gen. Mohamed Farah Aidid, which controls southern Mogadishu and most of the southern part of this dogleg-shaped country, was making plans to swoop into the famine-hit town of Bardera and oust the forces of Gen. Mohammed Siad Hersi Morgan. General Morgan, a son-in-law of former President Mohammed Siad Barre, wanted to ride into Kismayu, the southern port city, and fight General Aidid. 
 "We are afraid that if the Americans come they may say stop the fighting," said Abdullah Ahmed Shire, an adviser to General Aidid, after being asked about the planned offensive against Bardera. "We must be rid of these people because they are the remnants of the Marehan of Siad Barre."
 
Deep Clan Animosity
 The offensive has been delayed, reportedly because General Aidid's fighters are stuck in mud some 30 miles east of Bardera. But Mr. Shire's passion against the Marehan, the sub-clan of Mr. Siad Barre, whose 21-year dictatorship ended in 1991, illustrates the ferocity the clan fissures here.
The clan divisions have overcome other factors that would seem to make Somalia an unlikely candidate for civil war.
Unlike virtually any other country on the African continent, everyone speaks the same language. The Sunni version of Islam is embraced by more than 90 percent of the people, and almost everyone does the same thing: raises and sells cattle and camels.
 
A Nation's Collapse
 Yet almost 30 years after independence from the British and the Italians, Somalia has become riven by internecine clan politics backed by armories of cold war weapons to the point that it has ceased to exist as a nation.
"One can scarcely think of a significant domestic or foreign development in Somali politics since independence that was not influenced to a large degree by an underlying clan consideration," David D. Laitin and Said S. Samatar wrote in "Somalia, Nation in Search of a State." "Ethnicity remains the paramount factor."
The intense clan competition poses the greatest potential threat to the American-led military operation to protect the delivery of food and other humanitarian aid to the country if the Americans are seen to favor some groups over others. Somalis will defend their honor if they feel that it is being impugned.
"It is going to take a very enlightened group of officers working with the local people," said Stephen Tomlin, the director of the International Medical Corps, a Los Angeles-based agency, who has been here for more than a year and narrowly missed being killed by a bullet aimed at his head by an angry security guard. "Life for outsiders is very frustrating. You have to drink lots of tea and talk lots of hours at all levels. This is not the American way."
The Somali resilience in tough environmental conditions and their warrior tradition impressed the Europeans who started to colonize Somalia in the last century.
"It is wonderful how little we have yet managed to impress the Somalis with respect of our superior power," wrote J. W. C. Kirk, the British consul in Zanzibar, as the British started to make inroads into northern Somalia in the 1880's.
Significantly for the Americans, these characteristics persist.
Six major clan families account for the vast majority of Somalia's 4.5 million to 6 million people: the Darod, the Hawiye, the Isaak, the Dir, the Rahanwayn and the Digil. Within these clan-families are sub-clans and sub-sub-clans. Mr. Barre was a Darod who belonged to the Marehan sub-clan. During most of his 21 years of rule, the non-Marehans viewed all political and economic decisions as disenfranchising them, a belief that has driven many of the clans who were on the outs during Mr. Barre's rule to claim a larger share of the spoils left behind, and to fight when the other groups resisted.
The Hawiyes have emerged strongest from the fighting. Mohammed Ali Mahdi, who controls the north side of Mogadishu and little else, and General Aidid are Hawiyes. But Mr. Ali Mahdi is from the Abgal sub-clan, whose members managed to become a merchant class and consider this city theirs. General Aidid is a Habir Gidir from a village in central-western Somalia near the Ethiopian border.
Humanitarian agencies, contracting out the transport of large amounts of food assistance, say they must be constantly aware of clan allegiances and be as inclusive as possible when hiring staff.
But people of the Hawiye clan say physical characteristics give no sign to which sub-clan someone belongs to and that except for the inflection on some letters it is almost impossible to tell whether one of their clansmen is a Habir Gidir or an Abgal.
Even further distinctions exist, and aid agencies must be careful to spread their hiring of guards according to a careful calculation based on the relative power of the various groups. For example, the Habir Gidir includes four sub-sub-clans, and the International Committee of the Red Cross employs members of the two strongest of these sub-sub-clans for transport services.

HEADLINE: A.M.A. OPPOSES CAP ON MEDICAL COSTS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
In a rebuff to President-elect Bill Clinton, the American Medical Association today rejected the idea of an overall national limit on health care spending. But the doctors said they were willing to consider other ways of restraining costs.
At a meeting in Nashville, the association's House of Delegates approved a resolution saying the A.M.A. "strongly opposes a national ceiling on health-care spending." 
 Mr. Clinton proposed such limits in the campaign to try to slow medical prices, which have been rising about twice as fast as other consumer prices. His staff is now trying to translate his proposal into legislation.
But the American Medical Association asserted that national limits on health spending could undermine health care, inhibit progress and interfere with patients' freedom.
Another possible reason for the A.M.A. stance, one not mentioned in the resolution, is financial self-interest. A national ceiling on health spending could lead to stringent new limits on doctors' fees, economists say.
 
Doctors' Incomes
 Dr. Nancy W. Dickey, a trustee of the association, said doctors' incomes were not a factor. "We take this stance on behalf of our patients," Dr. Dickey said in a telephone interview. "The capping of health-care expenditures is far less of a concern to me as a physician than to my patients."
In the campaign, Mr. Clinton said repeatedly that he wanted to limit public and private spending on health care. In September, his idea was endorsed by the American College of Physicians, the largest medical specialty group in the United States, which has 77,000 members, who specialize in internal medicine.
Dr. John R. Ball, executive vice president of the American College of Physicians, expressed disappointment with the A.M.A., saying it had rejected the concept of a national health budget without offering specific alternatives.
"Health-care reform begins with cost control, and cost control begins with the commitment to living under a budget," Dr. Ball said. "The American people, the President-elect and leading members of Congress understand that." But the American Medical Association, which has 290,000 members, or 43 percent of the nation's doctors, said today that such limits would lead to a burdensome new system of regulation. The A.M.A. resolution was approved by voice vote.
Dr. Dickey of the A.M.A. said the association wanted to slow the growth of health spending by encouraging "market forces and economic competition," by discouraging malpractice lawsuits and by slashing administrative costs.
The A.M.A. also restored a policy today saying it was unethical for doctors to send patients to clinics in which the doctors have invested.
The policy, initially adopted in December 1991, strongly discourages doctors from referring patients to clinics, laboratories, diagnostic imaging centers and other businesses in which the doctors have a financial interest.
In June, the association softened the policy and said that such referrals could be ethical in some cases, if patients were informed of the doctors' financial interests.
Leaders of the A.M.A. decided to fight for the strict ethics policy. The policy says there is a potential conflict of interest whenever doctors send patients to medical businesses in which the doctors have a financial interest. Studies show that such referrals often raise costs to consumers.

HEADLINE: New York State Crosses the Hudson in Search of Taxes

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
As 3,000 New Yorkers who went shopping in New Jersey last weekend will soon discover, strangers were snooping around their cars: New York officials intent upon making them pay the sales tax they owe.
James W. Wetzler, State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, sent four employees into parking lots across the Hudson River to write down the license numbers of cars with New York plates. 
 People whose names are coughed up by the computers will soon get polite letters telling them that they might just owe money to New York. About 600 other New Yorkers whose cars were spotted at shopping centers in Pennsylvania will receive similar letters.
"We're not sending anyone a bill," Mr. Wetzler said. "We're educating people about their tax responsibility so they won't be surprised if down the road they do get a bill from us for the sales tax owed on expensive items purchased out of state."
 
Does Anyone Comply?
 New Yorkers who shop out of state and bring their purchases back to New York are legally supposed to pay New York the difference between the sales tax in the other state and that in New York. Hardly anyone does so, however.
Mr. Wetzler is concerned that a tax change in New Jersey might be enticing New Yorkers to cross the Hudson to beat New York City's 8 1/4 percent sales tax. He has been especially unhappy about an advertisement for Ikea, the home-furnishings retailer that touted the "whopping" tax savings that Manhattanites could get at its store in Elizabeth.
Not surprisingly, news of Mr. Wetzler's license-plate caper was not well received yesterday in the Ikea parking lot.
"First of all, I have a right to spend my own money where ever I want," said Donna Currington, a 33-year-old nurse from the Bronx. "This is a time we all have to be careful with a dollar, and this stuff about the tax folks chasing after us is not going to deter me."
Another shopper, Lisen Sundgren, 26, an actress from Greenwich Village, said: "That sure sounds like Big Brother to me. I thought we put something like that all behind us with Russia giving up."
Since April 1, when New York's fiscal year began, 1,648 New Yorkers voluntarily paid nearly $1.7 million in sales tax for out-of-state purchases.
Karl Felsen, a spokesman for the Department of Taxation and Finance, said much of that was for purchases abroad. A probable reason that figure is as high as it is, he said, is publicity about New York's crackdown on such purchases. The state began combing United States Customs Service records two years ago.
"More and more people are paying" the sales tax on purchases in other states," Mr. Felsen said.
"But it is still an infinitesimally tiny portion of the total," he said. "We're still chipping away at it, but the real hope is Federal legislation" that would require retailers in one state to collect sales taxes owed to other states.
Mr. Felsen said the license-plate missions in New Jersey and Pennsylvania were the first time his department had sent people to monitor cars in parking lots. Since the early 1980's, New York has uncovered tax evaders mainly as a result of information-exchange agreements with other states. "In essence, those states audit their retailers and send names of New Yorker customers to us and we do the same in return," he said.
For years, New Yorkers have shopped for clothing in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, lured in part by the fact that those states levy no sales tax on clothing. Now, New York has changed strategies, provoked by the Ikea ads publicizing an expansion of a sales-tax break available in urban enterprise zones in New Jersey. As of Nov. 27, New Jersey began permitting retailers in parts of Elizabeth, Jersey City, Kearny and Orange to charge a 3 percent sales tax on purchases instead of the state's usual 6 percent rate. The tax break had already been in effect in six other economically depressed areas.
 
Ikea Defends Itself
 While Ikea insists it was not breaking any law, Mr. Wetzler accused the company of encouraging tax evasion. Acting on his request, the New York State Attorney General and the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs are examining whether the ads were misleading or illegal.
"We don't want to have a problem with the State of New York," said Pamela S. Diaconis, an Ikea spokeswoman. She added that Ikea intends to post signs in its Elizabeth store to inform out-of-state customers that they may have to pay additional taxes in their state.
Mr. Wetzler wants to do more. He is threatening to subpoena records from retailers in the New Jersey urban enterprise zones as well as charge-card companies and trucking companies that deliver their goods to New York to track down tax evaders. He said that Leslie A. Thompson, Director of the New Jersey Taxation Division, agreed to cooperate yesterday.
 
'Our Main Concern'
 "Our main concern at the moment is to point out to our taxpayers what their tax liabilities are in the hope they will comply voluntarily," Mr. Wetzler said. "In the event that fails, we'll engage in whatever enforcement efforts we deem to be cost effective."
Those caught would have to pay the tax, along with penalties and interest, which are explained in the mailing.
That was not a popular idea in the Ikea parking lot last evening.
"That's the most ridiculous thing I ever heard," said Lisa Halgren, 32, a financial manager for a Manhattan corporation. "I work hard. I pay taxes. And if I want to save a little money that's my business and no one else's."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Municipal Bonds Rise

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The prices of actively traded municipal bonds rose about 1/4 point yesterday as investors moved to buy ahead of what could be a rally at the beginning of next year. The demand was good enough that several new issues were repriced to lower yields.
Some of the buying, traders said, was in anticipation of the drop-off in new issuance that usually comes at the end of December and the begining of January, a factor that could push prices higher. 
 In addition, there will be a huge amount of cash available at the beginning of next year from semiannual interest payments on outstanding municipal bonds, and because $9 billion or more in bonds are expected to be redeemed on Jan. 1. As investors with this cash look for new investments, prices could be pushed higher.
Dave Johnson, manager of tax-exempt mutual funds at Van Kampen Merritt in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., said there has been buying of municipal bonds by several of the new funds that have come to the market recently. The fact that there will be little supply at the beginning of next year and a lot of available cash makes the issues coming out now attractive to both new funds and individuals, he said, as they try to buy ahead of a January rally.
Peter B. Coffin, senior vice president at Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston, another mutual fund manager, said that these factors, and the threat of a tax increase next year, ought to help municipal bonds outperform the Treasury market in January.
The success of yesterday's sale of the general purpose revenue bonds issued by New York's Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority reflected the demand in the market yesterday. The issue, with Bear, Stearns & Company as the underwriter, was repriced at the end of the day to lower the yields from what was originally offered because demand was so strong.
The $655.75 million issue was the largest of the day. Of the total, $633.16 million are in noncallable series Y bonds. The remaining $22.59 million is in series Z bonds.
The series Y serial bonds were repriced to yield 4.70 percent in 1998, 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, below the initial pricing in the morning. The bonds due in 2008 were repriced to yield 6 percent, five basis points lower. At the top Federal tax rate of 31 percent, the bonds have a taxable equivalent yield of 6.81 percent for the 1998 maturity and 8.70 percent for the 2008 maturity.
The term bonds due in 2012 have a coupon of 6 percent and were repriced to yield 6.14 percent, six basis points less than the initial pricing. This is equivalent to 8.90 percent on a taxable bond. The term bond due in 2017 was repriced to yield 6.16 percent, four basis points lower, with a taxable equivalent yield of 8.93 percent. The bond due in 2018 was repriced to yield 6.27 percent, three basis points lower, with a taxable equivalent yield of 9.09 percent.
The issue is rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard Poor's.
At least three other smaller issues, including $47.2 million in New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation taxable service contract bonds, were repriced to lower yields.
 
Treasury market
 Prices of the 30-year bond and Treasury notes moved higher in light trading yesterday as the recent rally continued. But there were some comments from President-elect Clinton that could confuse traders and speculators just as they seem to be becoming more comfortable with the incoming Administration.
The price of the 30-year bond was up 6/32 , to 102 10/32 , to yield 7.43 percent, down from 7.44 Monday. The yield is the lowest since Oct. 6. The 10-year note was up 12/32 , to yield 6.71 percent, down from 6.77 percent the day before and the lowest since Oct. 29.
In comments in a morning speech in Washington, Mr. Clinton spoke about where the Federal deficit would be in four years.
"I think you can reasonably expect the budget deficit to be substantially smaller than it is today," he said, "both in absolute dollars and as a percentage of national income."
Traders and analysts like such comments because they point to a concern about the Federal budget dificit.
But in the afternoon, Mr. Clinton made comments that might have disturbed traders. He said he was not sure the recession was over, which could indicate that he would stilll propose a significant fiscal stimulus program, something that the bond market is worried about. It is the belief that the recent signs of stronger economic growth will mean a smaller fiscal stimulus package that is behind much of the recent rally.
"There is no evidence that we're really coming out of this in a traditional sense," Mr. Clinton told reporters after a day of meetings with leaders and rank-and-file Democrats in Congress.
"So we are nowhere near knowing if this short-term recession that has gone on agonizingly long is over."
One bond trader said that the comment yesterday reminded him that Mr. Clinton would still propose enough of a fiscal stimulus program to make it clear to the country that he had gotten the economy moving again. For bondholders, that might be too much because of the threat of overstimulating growth, which would force interest rates higher and could nudge the rate of inflation out of its very comfortable 2 percent to 3 percent range.

HEADLINE: Yields Flat On C.D.'s for Week Ahead

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Average yields on money market accounts and certificates of deposit at most banks in New York and around the country are virtually unchanged for the seven days beginning today, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
Analysts said rates were unlikely to change much until President-elect Bill Clinton's inauguration next month. "Every time a new positive economic indicator pops up, it lessens the possibility of strong Government intervention to stimulate the economy," said Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Monitor. "And that tends to hold rates down."
 
Treasury Bills Down
 Moreover, the average discount rate on short-term Treasury bills dropped Monday at the weekly auction, reversing direction after eight consecutive weeks of increases. 
 The auction is often viewed as an indicator of how banks might adjust their rates on savings. But analysts said they did not expect further declines in three-month bills, which slipped 2 basis points, to 3.29 percent, and six-month bills, which were down 9 basis points, to 3.37 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
Average Fall of One Basis Point
 Combined yield averages for money market accounts at commercial and savings banks in the New York area were down one basis point, to 2.74 percent. Three-month C.D.'s were unchanged at 2.87 percent and six-month C.D.'s remained at 3.02 percent.
The largest changes this week are at the Bank of Tokyo Trust, which lowered the average yield on its six-month C.D. by 28 basis points, to 2.77 percent and its yield on three-month C.D.'s by 31 basis points, to 2.74 percent. But its money market yield was unchanged at 2.38 percent.
Home Savings of America lowered its money market yield by one-tenth of a percentage point, to 2.84 percent.
Outside New York, average yields on six-month C.D.'s at 20 large banks rose 2 basis points, to 3.01 percent, while money market yields held steady at 2.68 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Up by 14.85 as Stocks Extend Rally

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Wall Street stocks extended their rally yesterday as investors, apparently encouraged by the economic outlook, pumped more cash into the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 14.85 points to close at 3,322.18, with 234.3 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Advancing issues led decliners, 1,026 to 817. 
 The Nasdaq composite index rose 0.59 point to a new high of 667.12, its ninth record closing high in 10 sessions, but advancing shares beat losers by only a narrow margin.
Chris McLellan, head of trading at Robertson, Stephens & Company, said the tight range between gainers and losers led him to believe the over-the-counter market could be in for a deep correction.
"It's a very scary market," Mr. McLellan said. "The generals are marching but the soldiers aren't following."
Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and New York Stock Exchange index also set new highs. "People want to get their cash to work before the year ends," said Ron Doran, director of institutional trading at C. L. King & Associates.
Analysts said the market's strong upside momentum outweighed early profit taking. "You've really got mood, momentum and money flow," said Alan Ackerman at Reich & Company.
Traders said the market was focusing on Washington, awaiting President-elect Bill Clinton's decisions on Cabinet posts and approach to fostering economic growth.
"Everyone is looking for a signal from Washington on Clinton appointments in order to gauge what his policy will be," said Jim Benning, a trader at BT Brokerage.
Recent signs of economic improvement have convinced investors that Mr. Clinton may be able to revise his plans for a substantial fiscal stimulus package and instead focus on lowering the nation's huge budget deficit.
"All his remarks are that we're going to do something with the deficit, which is our primary problem," said Dick Stein, a vice president at MKI Securities.
In Washington, Mr. Clinton said there was no real evidence the economic recession was over or that the first hopeful signs of recovery matched those usually seen after previous recessions.
Mr. Clinton made clear that he intended to pursue economic stimulus programs, which focus on jobs creation and investment, while simultaneously pursuing long-term deficit reduction goals.
Analysts said investors will be focusing on inflation data later this week to confirm recent signs of the economic recovery.
"There should be some caution out there," Mr. Doran said. "I'm surprised that we didn't have a little more profit taking."
Among the standout stocks, a first- day issue, the First Colony Corporation, topped the Big Board's most active list, closing at 30 1/8 after making its debut at 28. The company sells individual life insurance and annuity products throughout the United States.
International Business Machines fell 1/2, to 65 3/8, despite its announcement of new software products that promote the use of big mainframe computers as a central feature of personal-computer networks.
Capital Cities/ABC surged 15 3/4, to 478 1/2, after the broadcasting and publishing company said it was financially capable of and interested in making a major acquisition costing as much as $8 billion.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 1.68 points to a new high of 436.99. The American Stock Exchange index rose 0.29, to 394.65.
