HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Company Promises a No-Effort TV-Rating Device

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

 BODY:
Seeking again to compete with A. C. Nielsen in the national ratings business, the Arbitron Company announced yesterday that it was developing a high-technology device for keeping track of television and radio audiences.
The device, which would take advantage of the latest military technology, would be worn by viewers, beeper-style. It would keep tabs on what its wearers are watching and listening to by "reading" an inaudible code etched into a program's sound track. 
 Arbitron's so-called pocket people meter -- still far from actual tests -- is the latest entry in the competition to devise a ratings system that can provide highly detailed information for advertisers and programmers but is effort free for viewers. Arbitron would not say how much it was spending to develop the system.
At a news conference in Manhattan yesterday, Ken Wollenberg, Arbitron's executive vice president for sales and marketing, told reporters that the "pocket people meter" would "require practically no effort on the part of the respondent." But some network executives, whose backing is crucial to Arbitron's efforts, immediately criticized the system as too demanding.
"The need exists for a better measurement," said Nicholas Schiavone, NBC's vice president for media and marketing. "So nothing should be dismissed out of hand." But because participants would have to carry the device wherever they went, "their proposal is not for a 'passive people meter,' he said. "The device requires an extraordinary level of cooperation, and in fact, it is very active."
Arbitron is working with a Canadian television industry cooperative, the BBM Bureau of Measurement, to develop the device. The Martin Marietta Corporation, the military contracting company, and Intellisys Automation, an engineering firm, are working on the design.
The plans call for the system to be tested in two media markets by late 1994. But Arbitron executives said that as of yet they had no clients for the new system and that they would not introduce the service unless clients materialized.
National television ratings, which determine how some $15 billion in advertising money is spent, are currently provided by Nielsen, using its own version of the "people meter."
 
Pushing the Button
 Each member of Nielsen's 4,000 sample households is given a personal control button and is supposed to press the button whenever he or she watches television. The networks complain that the system underrates audience numbers because many viewers -- particularly the much-sought-after younger viewers -- grow tired of punching in and out.
Nielsen, a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, and Arbitron compete to provide local television ratings to stations and advertisers in regional media markets. Both companies use a combination of metered television sets and hand-written viewer diaries to assemble these ratings. Arbitron, a unit of the Ceridian Corporation, also provides ratings to 260 local radio markets based on the distinctly low-tech diaries.
Arbitron executives said one advantage of its new "pocket people meter" was that it would record whatever its wearer was watching on television or listening to on the radio, whether he was at home, at work or on the road.
 
Cooperation Needed
 But for the system to be effective, virtually every radio and television station would have to agree to imbed the code in its transmissions. The codes would be combinations of very narrow frequencies that would either be added or subtracted from the sound track, producing no audible change.
"Arbitron is assuming that everyone in the industry will cooperate," Jack Loftus, a spokesman for Nielsen, said. "Good luck."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await a Meeting in Germany

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended narrowly mixed yesterday in light trading as the currency markets awaited a meeting of Germany's central bank.
Gold prices fell. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $335.40 a troy ounce, down 70 cents from Monday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell 75 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $335.25. 
 Analysts said there was little news to affect trading, with the market marking time ahead of tomorrow's meeting of a policy-setting committee of the Bundesbank, at which the German bank could take action on interest rates.
On Monday, the dollar fell sharply against the German mark as well as against other currencies. Analysts said thin trading volume had exaggerated the decline.
Raja Ramachandran, an analyst with Thomson Financial, said the dollar appeared to stabilize yesterday when it reached a technical support level against the mark.
In Tokyo yesterday, the dollar closed at 123.83 yen, down 1.04 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 123.95 yen. In New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 123.75 yen, unchanged from late Monday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5975, from $1.5875 late Monday. In New York, one pound cost $1.59975, more expensive than $1.5980 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.5562 German marks, down from 1.5563; 1.3945 Swiss francs, up from 1.3935; 5.3065 French francs, up from 5.3025; 1,367.50 Italian lire, down from 1,374.50, and 1.27225 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2727.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $335.65 a troy ounce, from $334.75 late Monday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $335.25, from $334.80 late Monday.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: Dips, but Not Much Dancing;
Holiday Party Indicator Is Finally Pointing Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Sober-minded people look to things like unemployment numbers for clues to the economy's health. But that may be much too rational. For the real story, scrutinize the menu of the office holiday party.
Do you see Champagne and caviar followed by prime rib? Recession's days are numbered. Or is there a bulletin-board request for potluck casseroles -- or no party at all? Times are still rocky. 
 Well, this indicator leads upward. After several years of penny pinching, many companies are putting on slightly more lavish affairs this year, according to a survey of 100 companies by a New York-based executive search firm, Battalia Winston International.
"Companies are more optimistic about the economy," said Dale Winston, president of Battalia Winston. "Most seem to believe that the downturn can't get worse." Many companies "feel a bit more positive about spending for Christmas parties," he added.
Mr. Winston views the office party as "a fun economic barometer."
Of the 100 companies surveyed by the firm, 87 said they were giving parties this year, compared with 82 last year. Forty-eight of the parties will be held in the evening, compared with 16 in 1991. And 26 companies are planning luncheons, which are less expensive, down from 66 last year.
But the ostentatious soirees of the 1980's are out of fashion, even for companies that can afford them. Nighttime dinner dances have given way to luncheons or cocktails. Companies that used to rent out an entire restaurant for an evening are having sandwiches or hors d'oeuvres brought in. Spouses are no longer invited at some companies.
"No business now, especially in the last few years, wants to appear to be wasting money," said Steven Hart, who heads the catering department at Zabar's delicatessen in Manhattan. The days are gone, he said, when companies can get "big fancy catering concerns to come in and do outlandish parties."

HEADLINE: This Season, Bottom Line Is on Top

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Although sale signs that promise 25 percent off are as ubiquitous as ever in stores this holiday season, retailers are dusting off and playing up time-honored techniques for snaring shoppers -- techniques that take less of a bite out of the bottom line.
The usual seasonal niceties are in place -- the holly boughs, the carols ringing from store sound systems and the extended shopping hours. But there are some distinct additions over Christmases past. Some retailers have set up makeshift coat checkrooms to relieve weary shoppers of wraps and packages; others are wrapping and delivering gifts free of charge. 
 Of course, most are offering their customers some kind of price break, from the plain vanilla $19.99 special on blue jeans at Macy's to the exclusive after-hours cocktail party Cartier is holding for big spenders, who get a 10 percent discount on anything they buy.
"Everyone has some hook out to get people to buy," said Walter F. Loeb, a retail consultant.
But Mr. Loeb and other longtime observers of the seasonal frenzy that overtakes retailers say the promotions this year are far less likely to have a negative impact on profits. Unlike the last three holiday seasons, when anxiety-ridden retailers started cut-rate Christmas sales a few days after Halloween, merchants this year have so far resisted rampant price slashing.
At Kmart stores on the day after Thanksgiving, for example, customers lined up before the 7 A.M. opening in hopes of getting one of the 19-inch color televisions that would go on sale for $199 only until 11 A.M. The limited-time sale has little effect on the company's profit margins and makes the stores more efficient by evening out traffic patterns.
Bloomingdale's is selling a number of once-in-a-lifetime experiences like a walk-on part for one night in a Broadway play or a ride over New York City in the Goodyear blimp. The money will go to the Victim Services Agency, a not-for-profit organization that helps finance programs for battered women, abused children and other victims.
Bloomingdale's will also cash a personal check worth up to $50 for holders of its charge cards and package its customers' presents in elegant star-spangled gold-and-black boxes that are available at cash registers at no extra charge.
Eddie Bauer, the chain of outdoor wear and sporting goods stores based in Redmond, Wash., is giving shoppers a gift in lieu of a discount. Every customer who spends $100 or more in its stores receives a prettily packaged box filled with popcorn, trail mix and three ounces of smoked salmon worth about $20.
At Macy's and other stores, shoppers may check their coats. Neiman Marcus is shipping merchandise ordered from its Christmas book by Federal Express at no additional charge to normal shipping and handling fees. Talbots is giving away gift wrap.
With the exception of free Federal Express delivery, none of these niceties are novel. But over the last decade, many retailers replaced such touches with sales that attracted customers in droves but eroded profits. With the recession making consumers cautious spenders, stores can ill afford such shrinkage.
"The greatest promotion we have at Christmas time is wrapping our landmark building in a big red bow and posting toy soldiers out front," said Simon Critchell, the president and chief executive of Cartier U.S.A. "It's a tradition at Cartier that people remember."
 
Not Merely Window Dressing
 A recent survey of consumer attitudes about this holiday shopping season by the market research company Yankelovich Clancy Shulman affirms that opulent windows, festive ornamentation and carols are important. About 63 percent of the 706 respondents said traditional holiday decorations and music were somewhat or very important factors in making their shopping experience more enjoyable.
"Sales promotions by themselves won't make people buy anymore," said James A. Taylor, president and chief executive of Yankelovich. "There's a desire for something more."
Mr. Critchell of Cartier said it was coincidental that the party Cartier is throwing for American Express card holders who spend lots of money was scheduled amid the holiday selling madness, although he acknowledged that the date was fortuitous nonetheless.
Mr. Critchell played down the discount Cartier is offering to those who attend. "The 10 percent off is not a major strategy," he said. "It's really just a strategy to offer people a reason to come."
Retailers are especially sensitive about using price as bait this year, perhaps remembering the paper-thin profit margins that resulted from excessive markdowns in the last three holiday seasons when shoppers almost uniformly refused to buy at full price. Several have also made well-publicized commitments to reducing the number of price-based promotions they stage and do not want word of sales this season to ruin their credibility.
On the day after Thanksgiving, a public relations employee at Bloomingdale's flagship store in Manhattan was assigned to pull down the placards directing shoppers to special bargains before a television news camera crew taped the action on the main floor.
But as much as they would like to shove the subject under the carpet, most retailers are offering their customers reduced prices on certain merchandise.
"Sales have become a mainstay of Christmas," said Thomas A. Filandro, a retail analyst at Gruntal & Company. "But I do think retailers actually have held back a little bit this year on their promotional activity based on price."
Or perhaps they are just doing a better job of turning price promotions to their advantage. On three days recently, Abraham & Straus gave its charge card holders $20 back for every $100 of merchandise they charged to their A & S cards. While the promotion essentially amounts to a 20 percent discount, A & S will eventually get the money back because it is issuing $10 coupons for the rebate that will only be good at its stores.
Radio Shack is giving customers who purchase big-ticket items a 60-day break on finance charges, and even Century 21, the off-price store in Manhattan and Brooklyn, was offering shoppers coupons with their purchases.
"This year I think the innovation is far higher when it comes to gimcrackery," said Alan G. Millstein, editor of the Fashion Network Report, a newsletter. "Somebody's been reading P. T. Barnum."

HEADLINE: Daily Challenge to Be True to One's Dream

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES

 BODY:
When Donato Mancini moved into his cold-water loft in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, the idea was to stay a year, then move on to more comfortable quarters. That was in March 1980. "Almost 13 years without a hot shower," Mr. Mancini said with a rueful smile, gesturing out over his studio.
For nearly 13 years, Mr. Mancini has cooked his meals on a hot plate and an electric casserole. Each morning, he has heated water on the hot plate and taken a sponge bath. And every day, he has picked up charcoal or brush to work on drawings and paintings that pile up in his loft, most of them unsold and unseen. This has been his routine, in various locations around the city, since he left with an art degree from Pratt Institute in Brooklyn in 1970.
 
'It's Very Picturesque'
 The artist toiling away in a garret was already a cliche when Puccini wrote "La Boheme." But Mr. Mancini is the genuine article. For several years, Jock Truman, a retired New York gallery owner, put Mr. Mancini's loft on a shopping tour he organized for wealthy collectors. "He'd always stop at my place first," Mr. Mancini said. "It's very picturesque. You look at it and say, 'Yeah, this is an artist's studio.' " 
 The romance is in short supply, however, for Mr. Mancini and for the thousands of other artists in the city scrambling to get a foot on the ladder of success. New York is tough on its painters and sculptors. High rents have driven many of them from Manhattan and away from the dealers they hope to entice to their studios. Working space is scarce and often expensive, and artists who try to colonize commercial lofts can wind up spending more time fighting eviction by the city than making their art.
Even in the best of times, the expense of running a gallery means dealers think long and hard before taking on a new artist. In the current economic climate, with many galleries folding, the point of entry has narrowed even further, as dealers mount fewer exhibitions and cut back on the list of artists they represent.
Economic uncertainty has been compounded by a kind of esthetic malaise. The art world has failed to generate the kind of exciting movement that collectors embrace with open checkbooks. The boom that put painters like Julian Schnabel, David Salle and Eric Fischl in the pages of Vogue and HG has fizzled. The mood now is one of sullen apprehension, as strapped dealers, bored critics and restless artists scan the horizon for the next thing.
Yet for visual artists, New York is still the place. It's the city where careers are made, where the money, the dealers, the critics and the ideas are.
 
'The Center of the World'
 "Believe me, every month I say: 'I've got to get the hell out of here. I should be living in Florence,' " Mr. Mancini said. "But I stick it out, because New York really is the center of the world in many ways, especially if you want to be in touch with other artists, in other fields."
If nothing else, artists in New York can take solace in knowing that their struggles are a normal part of life in the city. The painter without a dealer and, for the moment, without a prayer does not necessarily count as a freak or a failure.
"There are a lot of people here living the same life you're living," said Mr. Mancini, a large, lumbering 45-year-old with a round face and a man-in-the-moon smile. A product of working-class Detroit, he still speaks with a blunt dese and dose accent, loudly and insistently, usually wagging a finger or jerking a thumb sideways for emphasis. When something strikes him as funny, he bursts into a ho-ho-ho laugh that can unexpectedly fly upward into an uncontrolled giggle.
"People forget how much understanding there is here from people on the same wavelength," he said. "You're not as isolated as you think you are."
It would be difficult, however, to find an artist more isolated than Mr. Mancini. He has chosen a medium, easel painting, that has undergone critical attack for nearly 30 years as a reactionary, bourgeois form (the art-critical term is retardataire) that has been superseded by photography, video, performance art and installation art with a sharp political edge.
Moreover, Mr. Mancini paints in a figurative style. That is, he deals in recognizable images, using an idiosyncratic visual language based on the work of Renaissance frescos, the Mexican muralists of the 1930's and Edward Hopper. He presents, in a kind of mythic narrative, the social rituals he experienced as a first-generation Italian growing up near the auto factories of Detroit, where his father worked until his death in 1972.
A characteristic painting is "Teen-Age Dance," a 6-by-14-foot triptych. On its side panels, two couples slow dance. In the central panel, throngs of teen-agers dance in a floodlighted outdoor arena, set against an ominous background in which the factories of Detroit pour smoke into a low, brooding sky.
"A lot of people are not sympathetic to the work," said Michael Walls, a SoHo dealer who has included drawings of Mr. Mancini's in two off-season group shows. "It is not part of the MOMA-endorsed official chronology of modern art, it's deliberately outside that, and people ask, How is it any different from things that were done in the 20's and 30's?"
Mr. Mancini has become used to hearing his work described as warmed-over Ashcan school, or worse, sentimental and illustrative, a short step removed from Norman Rockwell or Andrew Wyeth.
 
The Trouble With 'Tough Work'
 "I thought it was strong, memorable work, but not quite my esthetic" said Jack Tilton, a New York gallery owner, who visited Mr. Mancini's studio two years ago. "It's tough work, and in general tough work is slow to be appreciated, slow to sell, slow to make its way."
Mr. Walls said: "There's a kind of clumsiness that I haven't talked to him about: the use of these big clunky feet to anchor the figure to the ground. I'm certain that if the work were closer to a Renaissance or Beaux Arts ideal of delineating the human figure, he would have a wider audience: not among the movers and shakers and reputation makers, but among buyers."
Mr. Walls cited the fleshy, Bruegel-like figures, and "the Tiepolo-esque evocation of the Detroit skyline" approvingly. "I think it's part of what gives the work its craziness," he said. "His work is a very strange amalgamation."
That strangeness has effectively kept Mr. Mancini without a career. He has never sold enough work to make a living. To support his painting, he said, he does freelance work designing audio-visual displays. He has turned down full-time job offers to leave time for his art. He has never earned as much as $20,000 in a year from all sources of income, he said. To date, he has sold about 15 paintings and drawings. Expenses for supplies and promotional materials, including slides and transparencies of his work, postcard announcements for shows and postage, run about $3,000 a year, he said.
This year, Mr. Mancini received his first grant, for $2,000, from the Pyramid Arts Center in Rochester, as part of a regional program called "Diverse Forms," financed by the National Endowment for the Arts, the Andy Warhol Foundation and the Rockefeller Foundation.
The grant is expected to help pay expenses for a series of paintings on two Italian festival parades, the feast of St. Paulinus in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and the feast of St. Rocco in Aliquippa, Pa.
 
Home Is Where The Light Is
 Mr. Mancini lives a spartan existence. His loft measures 1,000 square feet, and about 80 percent of that is devoted to work and storage space. He has a bed, a guest bed that doubles as a couch, a small circular coffee table, a table to eat on, five chairs, two bookshelves and a homemade work table he also uses as a desk. It's the kind of furniture that the Salvation Army no longer bothers to pick up. The unwary visitor who settles into the seat of honor, a 1930's-era swivel office chair, stands a good chance of being flipped straight back to the floor.
What the studio lacks in amenities it makes up for in light, which floods in from three sides, and from a large roof section of rippled translucent plastic. The sound of pigeons scrabbling for footing overhead is a constant background noise.
On days when he is not working for an audio-visual company, or visiting museums and galleries, Mr. Mancini starts drawing or painting at about 9 in the morning, and works until 7 P.M. If he has had an unproductive day -- fretting and fussing and erasing -- he might push on after dinner and work into the early hours of the morning. He works slowly. It can take him two or three years to finish a large painting, and several months to finish a large drawing.
Mr. Mancini has had just enough success over the years -- an exhibition here, a sale to an important collector there -- to keep him from sinking into despair. A banner year was 1982, when three of his large drawings were included in a show at the Drawing Center in SoHo and a gouache version of "Teen-Age Dance" was included in a show of Brooklyn artists at the Brooklyn Museum.
Mr. Truman, who once served as director of the Betty Parsons Gallery in its heyday, attended the Drawing Center show with J. Patrick Lannan, a major collector. Mr. Lannan bought all three works for his foundation's art collection.
This was a coup for Mr. Mancini. Placing work in the right hands can be more important than the money involved in the sale, in this case $2,500 for all three drawings.
At the same time, the show was an occasion for some bitterness. The New York Times reviewed the show, yet his work went unmentioned, an oversight Mr. Mancini says he does not regard as as accidental as his drawings covered the entire main wall of the gallery. The silent treatment, he insists, is a standard art-world strategy.
"One of the maneuvers of power is they try not to attack you, because that gives you as much attention as praise does," he said. "They ignore you. They don't empower you in any way; they don't give you the satisfaction of a fight."
Nevertheless, for the next two years, Mr. Mancini rode the crest of a small wave. His work appeared in two more group shows, in Chicago and Morristown, N.J. The Brooklyn Museum invited him back. Then, nothing. It was back to the routine of putting together press kits and mailing them to galleries, freshening up the package from time to time with photographs and slides of new work.
 
Fingers Crossed; Things Improve
 Lately, things have been looking a little more hopeful. Last year, the show at Mr. Walls's gallery led to a one-man show at the Miami-Dade Community College Art Museum. A scaled-down version of the show traveled to the Bergen Museum of Art and Science this year in Paramus, N.J. The $2,000 grant has buoyed Mr. Mancini's spirits. But a one-man show at Mr. Walls's gallery still eludes him.
Mr. Mancini, despite the frustrations of 27 years, remains philosophical about his art and his career. He defines his goals modestly. Success, he says, would mean earning enough money to paint full time.
"I didn't start doing this work gearing it toward my career; I did it after seeing my father in his casket," he said. "That's when I decided to commit myself to it totally, no turning back, although now I can see that I've given up a lot."
Mr. Mancini could probably find a city where the critical climate is more sympathetic, where he could be a larger fish in a smaller pond. But the idea doesn't appeal to him.
"Part of the thing is to do what you like and in the place you like," he said. "That's New York. This is the place where the lottery is being conducted. It gives you the dream, the hope that tomorrow maybe things will happen."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Bonds and the Giants Come to an Agreement

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 8

 BODY:
The two most controversial and economically significant issues that have developed at baseball's winter meetings -- the Barry Bonds contract and the owners' reopening of the collective bargaining agreement -- have turned on the uncompleted sale of the San Francisco Giants.
The incoming owners finally resolved their problem with the Bonds contract today, completing the six-year, $43.75 million deal by agreeing not to make Bob Lurie, the outgoing owner, liable for the contract if the new group does not gain approval. 
 The Peter Magowan group is virtually assured of approval in the next few weeks, but it won't come in time to prevent the major league club owners from reopening the collective bargaining agreement.
Lurie was the Giants' owner Monday when the clubs voted, 15-13, to reopen the labor contract. Lurie, another owner said, voted for the reopener. The Magowan group, said a person familiar with its thinking, would have voted against the reopener.
 
Not Sticking Around
 With the reversal of that one vote, the outcome would have been 14-14, and the owners could not have reopened. They needed a simple majority, and they got that with Lurie's vote. Lurie, of course, won't be around when the possible consequences -- a lockout or a strike -- occur.
"Bob Lurie still owns the club," Bud Selig, chairman of the executive council, said. "He's sitting in the room representing the San Francisco Giants. The person who owns the business that day votes for the business."
The Magowan group had enough problems resolving the Bonds mess. Agreement on the financial terms of the $7,291,667-a-year contract was reached at about 7 o'clock Saturday evening. It took another three days to figure out how to take care of Lurie's stance that he would not accept the contract if the buying group were not approved.
"If we are not approved," Magowan said at a news conference, "Mr. Lurie has the right to decide if Barry Bonds is a member of the Giants. If he winds up with the team, he will not be responsible for Barry Bonds's contract. I don't want to get into any of the details about how that satisfaction was arranged."
 
Then What?
 But people around the Giants said that under the agreement if the Magowan group were not approved and Lurie did not want to keep Bonds at that price, he would become a free agent for a brief period.
If he signed with another team for less than $43.75 million, the McGowan group would make up the difference.
The final Bonds agreement was announced at 4:10 P.M., 44 hours after Bonds and his entourage left the Cochran Room of the Galt House Hotel, the news conference they thought they were attending having been canceled.
When they left Sunday evening, they exited through the kitchen. This time they marched single file along the wall of the room, Bonds leading the way. In line were Dennis Gilbert, Bonds's agent; Bobby Bonds, Barry's father; three of Gilbert's aides; Larry Baer, the Giants' executive vice president; Bob Quinn, the general manager, and Magowan.
"We're making a commitment, a big commitment to our fans and the entire California community," Magowan said.
Bonds, a two-time National League most valuable player, who lived in San Francisco when his father played for the Giants, said he couldn't "say how excited I am to have the opportunity to go back home."
 
Emotional Moment
 As part of the deal, his father will be the Giants' hitting coach, and the son said, "I always wanted to be able to share something with my father." Then, when he talked about receiving permission from Willie Mays, his godfather, to wear Mays's retired No. 24, he broke down.
He shed no tears over the contract. It will pay him a $2.5 million signing bonus and salaries of $4 million, $4.75 million, $7.75 million, $8 million, $8.25 million and $8.5 million. No one ever has received as high a salary as he will get in his last four years. Furthermore, if he is the league most valuable player, he will gain bonuses of $100,000 for the first time, $250,000 the second time, $750,000 the third time and $1 million the fourth time.
Bonds also shed no tears over leaving the Pittsburgh Pirates, although he has said he enjoyed playing for the team and living in the city.
The Pirates won't even get compensation of two choices in next June's amateur draft for losing Bonds.
 
Question of Oversight
 If the agreement had been final Sunday evening, the Pirates would have received the compensation. But it wasn't, and the Pirates didn't offer Bonds salary arbitration by Monday's deadline, thus forgoing their right to compensation.
Asked if not offering arbitration was an oversight, Ted Simmons, the Pirates' general manager, said it was not.
"What happens if he accepts?" Simmons said, thinking of the money it could have cost the Pirates. "That would have been awful for us."

HEADLINE: BILL'S LIST;
A New Foreign Policy for a New Era

SERIES: Bill's List: An occasional series commenting on ideas and issues facing the new Clinton Administration.

BYLINE: By Roger Morris; Roger Morris, who served on the National Security Council staff under Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard Nixon, is writing a book on the early days of the Clinton Presidency.

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M.

 BODY:
As Bill Clinton prepares for inauguration, his Presidency already seems haunted by the great issue he pointedly avoided in the campaign -- national security and foreign policy. History will judge the Bush Administration's missed opportunities and neglect of a revolutionary world as an almost epic blunder, leaving a legacy of contradiction and hazard.
Unless the new Administration develops a coherent view of a transformed world and of America's new international interest, role and purpose, there will be no more than a marginal, politically arbitrary reapportionment of huge national security budgets, which are now largely wasted on cold war vestiges yet are essential to finance domestic revival and deficit reduction. The same capricious politics are likely to raid non-military international spending or exploit trade tensions for short-run advantage, all with insidious effect. 
 Without a new foreign policy for a new era, Bill Clinton will forfeit command over budgets, bureaucracies and ultimately his own Presidency.
When he enters the Oval Office, he will find waiting a radically altered world. As old industrial and imperial orders collapse, America's power remains pre-eminent, though its leadership must be earned. Amid kaleidoscopic change and turmoil, the world is free of Great Power rivalries and has unprecedented opportunity for cooperation and peace, yet faces unparalleled challenges in the spread of weapons, ecological damage, festering poverty, vast migrations and separatist violence.
Much as George Bush failed to grasp that changing world, it has overtaken as well the conventional foreign policy aspirants to whom whom Mr. Clinton might have resorted and whose national security nostrums and habits of mind are now anachronistic.
Bill Clinton must marshal a new democratic foreign policy, one as bold and relevant as Harry S. Truman's 1947 summons to a peacetime America to contain Soviet expansion. Like Truman, Mr. Clinton is "present at the creation" of a new epoch in world affairs -- and the next half-century hangs in the balance.
Mr. Clinton's equivalent to deterring the Soviets is to seize the fleeting chance for post-cold-war demilitarization while also checking the plague of weapons proliferation and sectarian chaos that threatens any comity of nations. Since the U.S. cannot -- should not -- dominate in that effort, national security dictates a sustained commitment to a genuinely cooperative, collective international security system.
The foundation of that policy would be a peacekeeping force, drawn proportionately from U.N. member states and more than twice the size of the Desert Storm coalition, with the strength to stop any aggression or genocide. Europe, Japan and Russia would play and pay their fair shares. Contributing only its own portion, America, no more the primary world policeman, might safely, and within Mr. Clinton's term, see the return and reduction of its overseas forces to mainly territorial defense; it will also see the reconversion of its economy to a long-earned peace and nonmilitary prosperity.
The following steps toward collective security should be as compelling as those taken to deter the Soviets:
When the principal threat to peace is nationalist aggression or national disintegration, where a new global compact depends on common action in defense of the weakest, tragedies such as Bosnia and Somalia are the real Munichs, the ominous dominoes, of our era.
Seeing the new pragmatism of principle, the U.S. should immediately work to forge a system of collective action to redress such outrages -- action far more shared and purposeful than President Bush's 11th-hour U.S.-dominated expedition in the Somali famine.
Mr. Clinton should recognize the complexity of such intervention, external culpability in tragedies such as Somalia and the dangers of neo-imperial aggrandizement. Much of the new turmoil requires sustained peacekeeping, just as the cold war required U.S. staying power.
But he should understand, too, the Holocaust's enduring lesson -- that sovereignty in a seamless new world no longer allows a regime to destroy its own citizens with impunity or indifference, and that a truly peaceful planet must outlaw aggression within borders as well as across them.
Practically, as well as morally, the larger stake of collective security -- and the insidious precedent of impotence and appeasement -- would clearly justify the world's prudent military commitment after the most serious diplomacy failed.
Because the stability and participation of Russia are essential to that collective security, the U.S. should urgently mount all the aid necessary to bridge economic hardship and save post-Soviet democracy.
No Presidential policy would have more urgency -- or more riding on it -- than the necessity to prevent another Russian tragedy. Washington should take the initiative to forge ahead of the Russians in nuclear disarmament (already stalled in fresh suspicions), beginning with a long-term test ban, the renunciation of some $30 billion in needless new weapons in the wake of the George Bush-Boris Yeltsin arms agreement in June and eventual reduction of U.S. strategic weapons to an adequate minimum of 250 to 500 warheads.
In his first year, Mr. Clinton should place nonproliferation and disarmament on top of the international agenda; bring a prompt, exemplary end to our own $36 billion-a-year trade in conventional weapons (with reconversion provision for affected industries); begin an all-out collective effort to demilitarize worldwide by agreements with poorer nations to forgive debt in return for substantial conversion of military sectors to peaceful development along with strict inspection of arms reductions, and use all means to bring about a nuclear-free, demilitarized Middle East with renewed Arab-Israeli peace talks.
Where foreign policy merges most visibly with the domestic agenda, Mr. Clinton should seize a similar chance for needed change in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the North American Free Trade Agreement with Mexico. His policy should be to renegotiate, as necessary, America's international economic future, reversing George Bush's readiness to allow supranational trade agreements to erode U.S. labor and environmental standards. We should not avoid a trade war, Mr. Clinton should announce, only to inflict a class war on American and foreign workers, fought with high-tech sweatshops and symbolized by gruesomely polluted border towns.
Soon Mr. Clinton should meet with major trading partners, including Japan, the Pacific Rim, Europe and Latin America, to advance a straightforward new policy: America will settle for neither belligerent blocs nor politely masked inequity but rather will seek an equitable, politically sustainable world commerce of shared sacrifice, responsibility and opportunity for capital and labor. Since no nation is more important in the new U.S. policy than Japan, a mutually sensitive and systematic reduction of the $100 billion U.S. trade deficit would be the primary goal and crucible of U.S.-Japanese relations.
Not least, Mr. Clinton should convene a conference of rich and poor nations to strike a new bargain of ideals and self-interest in international development. Just as he visited a struggling neighborhood in Washington, showing he would be a concerned citizen of the capital, he should be the first U.S. chief executive in a generation to demonstrate an authentic sensibility toward the struggling nations.
No one's future is secure, he should explain, when four or five billion people in the world are left in smoking slums on the outskirts of hope. America cannot simply deal with domestic needs and then later turn to the world's anguish; either we begin anew to heal both or it may well not matter for our grandchildren if we make ourselves prosperous.
As another principle of new policy, the U.S. should become a leader -- and no longer a scofflaw or laggard -- in international environmental action, including energy conservation, meaningful reduction of carbon dioxide, stricter emission controls, hazardous-waste clean-up, responsible population policy, resource replenishment and myriad other measures to meet the danger of ecological disaster.
Washington should foster a new representative world organization to oversee and plan, decades ahead, common environmental policy and management of resources, just as GATT has been charged with orchestrating trade. For details, President Clinton should look to Vice President Al Gore, whose book "Earth in the Balance: Healing the Global Environment" is a blueprint for environmental security.
Finally, Mr. Clinton should come to grips with the most formidable challenge of all: ignoring the stale foreign policy Establishment and circumventing the permanent regime of bureaucrats, whose civil service ranks are deeply penetrated by Reagan-Bush loyalists.
Just as Truman's postwar internationalism could not be conducted by the old isolationists of a bygone era, the post-cold-war Clinton policy will survive only with new ways and new people, beyond old establishments and ex-officials. A centerpiece of the new diplomacy could be sophisticated conflict resolution, with assisted negotiation and mediation of the kind so successful under private auspices with the World Bank, among Nicaraguan factions and in Middle East water issues.
Preventing conflicts rather than reacting to crisis, creating forums for dialogue and joint problem-solving, acknowledging the legitimacy of all interests, understanding historical and psychological dynamics at work, building long-term relationships of collaboration -- these new techniques would apply to many international flash points.
For such innovation -- much less his emphasis on collective peacekeeping, humane international economics and environmentalism -- Mr. Clinton will find neither skill nor commitment among the cold-war veterans jockeying for jobs.
He must reach for a fresh generation of thinkers and doers -- for a new-world visionary, manager and practiced negotiator as Secretary of State; a Secretary of Defense versed in economic reconversion and internationalized security; a U.N. ambassador of stature to match the post's unparalleled new importance; policy-makers on international economics and the environment of ministerial rank and worldwide distinction for their mastery of the issues; a new Director of Central Intelligence with the mettle to turn a rogue relic into a relevant public servant, and a national security adviser of original intellect and old-fashioned humility, embodying America's new creativity yet modesty about its place on the planet.
In the end, the most important change should be in the President. He should believe in his own newcomer's genius, knowing that the new foreign policy is not sorcery, that he need not apprentice to the past. He should trust his own decency and intelligence in world affairs and a new democratization of foreign policy.
The President would have to choose decisively between conventionality, with its all too predictable outcome, and a new community of nations, joined by America and led by its example as never before. We can only hope that for Bill Clinton this would be no choice at all.

HEADLINE: Books, Books and More Books: Clinton an Omnivorous Reader

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
If there is still considerable uncertainty about the changes President-elect Bill Clinton intends to make after his inauguration on Jan. 20, at least one is now virtually carved in mahogany: there will be more bookshelves in the White House.
After Barbara Bush gave Hillary Clinton a tour of the private quarters at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue last month, Mrs. Clinton exclaimed to her friends here: "There aren't enough bookshelves!" She vowed to correct the situation. 
 The change will be perfectly in character. The Clintons added bookshelves to the Governor's Mansion here in Little Rock in 1979 after they moved in. When compelled to vacate, they constructed bookshelves in the house they bought on Midland Avenue; and when they returned to the mansion in 1983, they added more bookshelves.
The Clintons read books of all sorts, from Churchill to Clancy and from Lincoln to Ludlum. And that is the most striking feature of a cultural profile of the first-family-to-be pieced together in recent days from the recollections of longtime friends and associates.
In addition to his bibliophilia, the President-elect loves to sing, calls himself a movie addict and once in his youth considered becoming a professional jazz musician. Mrs. Clinton, who jokes with friends about her inability to carry a tune, prefers classical music to pop.
 
Other Bookish Presidents
 Of course, bookishness and other cultural interests are no index to success in politics. In fact, most political leaders prefer oral briefings to reading at length for themselves, and at least one, Adlai E. Stevenson, was seriously wounded by being caricatured as an egghead. But in modern times, such interests put Mr. Clinton in the company of, say, Woodrow Wilson, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S. Truman and John F. Kennedy.
Ann McCoy, administrator of the Governor's Mansion, said that the Clintons' private library on the second floor, together with about a dozen still unopened book boxes in the attic, numbered about 4,500 volumes.
Deborah Sale, a senior adviser who has known Mr. Clinton since their high school days in Hot Springs, said that during the campaign, when a voter asked Mr. Clinton whether it was true that he had read 300 books in one year, he replied with a laugh: "That was in 1982 when I didn't have much else to do." Mr. Clinton had been defeated the previous year in his campaign for re-election.
Carolyn Staley, Mr. Clinton's next-door neighbor when he lived in Hot Springs and a close friend, said he would read at least four or five books a week.
Carol Allin, who ran the now-defunct Capitol Book Store here for 11 years, said Mr. Clinton used to browse in her shop about once a month and "never left without an armful of books." Such avid reading habits make Mr. Clinton seem positively erudite compared to George Bush, who appeared to freeze when asked on television in 1984 to name a book he had recently read. Eventually, Mr. Bush mentioned a 22-year-old best seller, "The Guns of August," by Barbara Tuchman.
A Current Favorite:
Thoughts of a Stoic Last summer, Dee Dee Myers, Mr. Clinton's chief spokeswoman, caused a stir -- and aroused some skepticism -- when she reported that her boss's current favorite was the "Meditations" of Marcus Aurelius, which he reread every year or two.
The "Meditations" are not much of a reach for a present-day politician. Marcus Aurelius was a second-century Roman emperor whose victories were mostly undone (among other things, his conquering troops brought home a plague), and who consoled himself with the mind-over-matter Stoicism exemplified by statements like, "Do not think yourself hurt and you remain unhurt."
Another favorite of the Governor's, his aides say, is the Colombian novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez's challenging "One Hundred Years of Solitude," a fantasy that conjures a phantasmagorical Latin America.
Mr. Clinton also reads books and periodicals in German, a skill he acquired as an undergraduate at Georgetown University, said BetsyWright, his former chief of staff. The President-elect has been sending his daughter, Chelsea, to a German-speaking summer camp in Minnesota for the last four or five years, she said, and he makes a point of spending time conversing with her in German.
From Pop to Plato,
Many Books at Once
Rather than concentrate on one book at a time, aides say, Mr. Clinton usually reads several simultaneously, gulping down literary caviar and pretzels with the same enthusiasm. A typical load of books in the bag of reading material he travels with would include the latest Walter Mosley murder mystery, a biography of Lincoln or Churchill, a pop futurology selection like "Megatrends," a serious treatise on world economics like "Head to Head," by Lester Thurow, and a collection of Plato's Dialogues.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton appears to be almost obsessive about his cultural intake. Beverly Lindsey, a former director of the Arkansas Arts Council and a close Clinton friend, said that last week the President-elect and a group of friends watched "High Noon." Afterward, she said, he told the group it was the 19th time he had seen the movie, and then began describing the other occasions.
Ms. Wright said that Mr. Clinton had a prodigious memory for characters, actors, directors, situations and punchlines in books and movies.
Mrs. Lindsey acknowledged that much of the President-elect's reading was what she and her husband called "grocery store trash" like the technothrillers of Tom Clancy and Robert Ludlum.
Mrs. Clinton, Mrs. Lindsey said, is a more consistently serious reader, devoting herself to law journals and recently Chaim Potok's 1967 best seller, "The Chosen."
A Fanatical Worker
Of Crosswords
Aides who travel with Mr. Clinton also describe him as a crossword puzzle addict who works the puzzles out with a pen rather than a pencil and completes them in record time.
Eli Segal, Mr. Clinton's chief financial adviser, said that he took Mr. Clinton to the New York office of Games Magazine, a crossword puzzle bimonthly he publishes, and had the editor clock Mr. Clinton in working out one of the toughest puzzles.
"He completed it in seven minutes," Mr. Segal said. "That's championship time."
Not everyone who knows Mr. Clinton is captivated by his reputation as a book person. Paul Greenberg, the editorial page editor of The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, said that Mr. Clinton regarded all culture as "ornamental rather than influential."
Responding to the reports of Mr. Clinton's enthusiasm for Marcus Aurelius, Mr. Greenberg wrote that it was about as plausible as "the news that Richard Nixon had taken up Zen." Mr. Greenberg added that "Clintonized culture" is little more than an exploitation of the arts for political purposes.
Ms. Wright, the former Clinton chief of staff, challenged that view. "His reading," she said, "is part of a lifelong quest for knowledge. He gains it from books and from people. He never stops."
Mr. Greenberg is correct in at least one respect. All politicians exploit the arts as naturally as they kiss babies, and Mr. Clinton is no exception.
Some Music for You
And You and You
For example, at each of his inaugural celebrations as Governor, Mr. Clinton meticulously selected the music to be performed throughout the day, making sure that the program included black gospel singing, a Pentacostal hymn, a Baptist hymn, jazz, pop, rock, symphonic and operatic selections and, always, his favorite Bach choral, "Jesu, Joy of Man's Desiring."
Partly, his aides insist, that is a sincere expression of the President-elect's love of music and ecclectic taste. Ms. Staley tells how startled she was one day in her youth to hear applause after practicing a Bach fugue on the piano in her home. Bill Clinton had heard her playing, slipped into her livingroom, listened quietly and then burst into applause.
That love of music is also evident when Cathie Buford, a former member of the Governor's staff, tells how exhilarated Mr. Clinton would be after participating in the annual all-night gospel sing in McNeil, Ark., and after singing in the choir of his church, the Immanuel Baptist Church in Little Rock. (Hillary and Chelsea Clinton, being members of the more reserved First United Methodist Church, infrequently attend these events.)
Nevertheless, it cannot be denied that the musical programs for Mr. Clinton's past inaugural festivities have been stitched together craftily, using music as a medium for reaching out to various political constituencies.
Mr. and Mrs. Clinton also collect porcelain, fine examples of which they were shown during several trade-promoting trips to the Far East. Arkansas sells more than $80 million a year in poultry to Japan, Malaysia, South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong. The Clintons are no doubt motivated by an appreciation of the artistry of these objects. Did they, perhaps, suddenly fall in love with a seductively gleaming teapot? Or did they begin to collect in order to flatter their hosts? To foster trade? Probably, the Clintons themselves would find it hard to sort out the answers.
Compassionate Tour
Of an Art Museum
Those who know Mr. Clinton best agree with Ms. Wright that he is attracted to books and the arts as a means of acquiring knowledge and satisfying an all-but-insatiable craving for mental stimulation. For example, David Leopoulos, a boyhood friend, recalled a guided tour of the Tate Gallery in London that Mr. Clinton gave him in the spring of 1970.
Mr. Leopoulos was then in the Army, stationed in Italy, and feeling distraught over the death of his mother, who had been murdered back home. Mr. Clinton, studying at Oxford, invited him to London to take his mind off of his grief.
"I had never heard of the Tate Gallery," Mr. Leopoulos recalled, "but he took me there from the station and began lecturing on the different paintings, the artists and what was going on politically at the time each work was painted that might have influenced it. I couldn't keep my mind on everything he was saying, but his knowledge was amazing."
Mr. Leopoulos said he had asked Mr. Clinton how he had learned so much, and the future President had replied: "Well, since I'm here in England, I felt I should expose myself to what's around."

LENGTH: 991 words

HEADLINE: 7 Found Dead in a Virginia Coal Mine

BYLINE: By SABRA CHARTRAND, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORTON, Va., Dec. 9

 BODY:
Two and a half days after an explosion rocked South Mountain Mine No. 3 here, hopes that eight miners had survived the blast ended late tonight when grim officials announced they had found the bodies of seven of the men.
United States Assistant Secretary of Labor Bill Tattersall said the miners "apparently died in their work stations" and "did not survive the blast."
He said rescue workers found "seven of the eight bodies," but were unable to locate the last body or remove any of the dead from the mine because of dangerously high levels of methane gas. 
 Sheriff's deputies at the mine site boarded school buses where frightened family members had huddled for days to deliver the devastating news. Many of the relatives collapsed, hugging one another and rocking and crying in each others' arms.
Among the victims were Claude and Palmer Sturgill, brothers whose family first began working in the mines in the 1930's. For over 50 years Sturgill men blasted and drilled, opening solid rock deep in the Appalachains to haul out coal.
Over the decades, a young father died in a mine blast, a cousin was crippled by an earth scraper, and the countless dangerous jobs deep in the shafts left many of the clan injured.
Yet, few knew the dangers of mining coal better than the Sturgills. Like everyone else here, and like people in other hard-scrabble Appalachian towns, the Sturgills also knew that only mining paid a living wage in an area where work itself is scarce and they felt lucky to be earning $14 an hour doing the backbreaking job.
Between them, Claude Sturgill, 49, and his brother Palmer, 44, had eight children. In the cold, snowy days since the explosion on Monday morning, Claude's youngest son, 13-year-old Lee, camped with the rest of his family in a tent at the base of the hillside mine.
"Dad liked the money but he didn't feel safe in the mine and he wanted to find something else," the boy said earlier today. "But he couldn't. Just about everybody in my family works in the coal mines."
 
Losses of Two Kinds
 And now, eight of the 38 employees of the No. 3 mine are dead. The other workers, home at the time of the blast, are out of a job, perhaps permanently. And while there is little comparison between the two blows, people here know that in a place where few have life insurance, pensions or nest eggs, where new mines rarely open and existing ones are turning increasingly to mechanization and where unemployment is already in the double digits, the loss of 38 jobs is devastating, too.
While rescue workers, government investigators and officials from the South Mountain Coal Company, which owns the mine, have not determined the cause of Monday's explosion, all say that high levels of naturally occuring methane gas usually cause such disasters.
Norma Bowman, a Sturgill cousin, spent two and half days in her family's vigil, but never held out much hope.
"This is part of the work, the hazard of the job," she said earlier today. "Those boys all knew the risk. But they didn't have any choice."
 
Pulling Together
 Norton and the surrounding towns are the sorts of places where people rally to help one another faster than any Government agency can react. As soon as word of the explosion spread, townspeople rushed to the trapped men's relatives with blankets, clothes, food and spiritual support.
"This is small area," Mrs. Bowman said. "Everybody is kin to everybody else, and everyone pulls together.
Outside the Sturgill clan's tent, volunteers offered pizza and fried chicken to rescue workers and relatives. Others passed out stocking caps and mittens, while a Salvation Army canteen truck gave away hot coffee and food. In a nearby tent, the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company hooked up telephones for the families.
"An accident like this reminds everybody that there's no such things as an overpaid coal miner," said Jerry Gray, a local lawyer who once was part-owner of a mine but who now earns a living suing mine companies for property owners or miners.
 
Few Alternatives Available
 "If you drive down Main Street, you'll see it's a dying town," Mr. Gray said of Norton, whose population is under 5,000. "We've got high unemployment. They're mining more coal now than ever with fewer men. It's still a single-employer economy, and there will not be other mines opening up for these miners to work in."
Jackie Barnete, another Sturgill cousin, knows well how hard it is to find work outside the mines. He was disabled in a mine accident in 1988 and has not been able to find a job since.
"My Daddy had 37 years in the mines," Mr. Barnete said. "I was in and out of the mines for five years. The pay is good, even in a non-union mine. But I don't get any compensation, and now my wife has to support me and our kids."
Though the focus here was clearly on the fate of the trapped men, there was also worry about what would happen to the miners who had lost their jobs.
"As far as the company taking care of the other miners, that's doubtful," said Howard Campbell, a former South Mountain employee. "They're just out of a job and will have to apply for unemployment."
This lack of security and alternatives saddens, and angers, nearly everyone in small mining communities like Norton. "America wants a cheap product, but they don't realize this kind of cost goes into it," said the Rev. Wayne Harrison, pastor of the First Baptist Church. "But the people in the coal fields are very aware of what goes into it."
Even as he waited this afternoon for word of his father and uncle, Lee Sturgill and his older brother Chris both said they would still welcome work in a mine.
"I'd sure think about it if they offered me a good job," said 25-year-old Chris Sturgill, who now works for a heavy-machine company here.
Lee said: "My Dad doesn't want me to work in the mines He says coal is going to run out in this area pretty soon. But what else is there?"

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
CLINTON TO LEAD TALKS ON ECONOMY

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark, Dec. 9

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton will personally serve as the moderator for 12 hours of nationally televised talks on the economy here next week, to be attended by about 300 business men and women ranging from a South Dakota flower seller to the presidents of Xerox and Apple Computers.
What was originally conceived as a gathering of 25 to 30 business leaders to help form economic policy has ballooned into a full-blown spectacle, with 300 corporate executives, small-business people and economists now invited to take part in the two-day conference. It will be held in the city's largest auditorium and televised live on C-SPAN, with large chunks also being broadcast by CNN and the three major television networks. 
 Aides to the President-elect said he would personally serve as chairman and moderator of the event, which will be broken up during the two days into seven subject areas, ranging from trade to training to how to deal with the debt and the deficit. Mr. Clinton's aides said the different chapter headings of his campaign agenda book, "Putting People First," would serve as the basic outline for the conference.
 
Format for Discussion
 During each of the discussion segments, a different group of 30 of the invited guests will sit around a central table, with the others remaining in the audience. One member of the core group will be charged with presenting a paper on the subject, and then Mr. Clinton will throw open the discussion for all to participate.
Seated alongside the President-elect will be the incoming Administration's top economic advisers, whose selection is to be formally announced Thursday: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, whom Mr. Clinton is expected to nominate for Secretary of the Treasury; Representative Leon E. Panetta, a California Democrat who now heads the House Budget Committee and is the choice for director of Mr. Clinton's Office of Management and Budget, and Robert E. Rubin, co-chairman of Goldman Sachs & Company, who will be the head of a new economic advisory group.
Mr. Clinton has decided to rename that group, transition aides said today, dropping the name Economic Security Council and leaning toward the name National Economic Council. The Economic Security Council name was dropped, they said, because Mr. Clinton's aides feared that American trading partners would find it provocative and almost military in tone.
In addition to naming his top economic aides, Mr. Clinton this week is interviewing other prospective appointees. He has summoned to Little Rock for interviews two candidates to replace Carla A. Hills as United States Trade Representative: Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., who was Deputy Trade Representative in the Reagan Administration and who could provide Mr. Clinton the taste of Republicanism that the President-elect has hinted might be in his Cabinet, and Dr. Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley.
 
Mushrooming of Event
 Participants in the conference were invited from all 50 states, and Clinton aides said that while many of their top donors wanted to be on the list, some had to be shunted aside to make room for a smattering of Republicans. The conference has ballooned in size partly because of the number of people agitating to attend and in part because Mr. Clinton has simply kept adding names.
Those invited include John H. Bryan, chairman of Sarah Lee Corporation; Michael Walsh, chairman of Tenneco Inc.; Sheryl L. Handler, founder of the Thinking Machines Corporation; Gordon E. Moore, chairman of Intel Corporation; John Sculley, chairman of Apple Computer Inc.; Paul A. Allaire, chairman of the Xerox Corporation; John A. Young, president of the Hewlett Packard Company, and Alvin J. Boutte, of the Independence Bank of Chicago, a prominent black banker.
There will also be representatives from all three major American automobile manufacturers, although not their chairmen. Thomas Donahue, the secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and Lynn R. Williams, head of the United Steelworkers of America, will be on hand.
And so will Cathleen Piper, owner of the Piper Flower Shop in Yankton, S.D. "I'm a little intimidated," Ms. Piper said. "I may be the smallest, but I have the same problems as the big corporations: I worry about health care for my employees, transportation costs, environmental issues that affect rural America and pay for workers. I am delighted that Clinton would take the time to listen to ordinary Americans before he takes the big steps."
The thrust of the discussions will be remarks by Mr. Clinton and the other participants detailing how they think the economy got to its present state and how best to get out of it. There will be a closing news conference but no final document of recommendations.
"The process itself will be the product," said Mickey Kantor, a member of the Clinton transition board who is organizing the conference. "It will be a defining moment. We will have everyone's attention, and therefore the whole nation will have a chance to connect to what is the most important issue: how to improve the economy."

HEADLINE: Dow Up 1.63, but Secondary Shares Fall

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks posted minor gains yesterday but secondary shares fell after the Nasdaq composite index hit its ninth record close in the 10 sessions on Tuesday.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 1.63 points at 3,323.81, with 230.1 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 In the broader market, losers outpaced gainers 1,121 to 734.
The Nasdaq composite index ended 3.20 points lower at 663.92, down from Tuesday's record close.
"We're due for a little pause; there's no problem there," said Dick Gunter, senior vice president at Wedbush Morgan.
A late influx of buying lifted the blue chips, which had drifted lower earlier in the session. Earlier, the Dow was depressed by losses in key large-capitalization issues and airlines.
"Stocks have reached our short- to intermediate-term targets," said A. C. Moore, an analyst at Argus Investment Management. "We wouldn't be surprised to see the market pull back at this point. I think stocks are at a high level here."
The Federal Reserve's survey of the economy in its so-called beige book found that many manufacturers and retailers were seeing a pickup in activity in most regions of the country. Inflation is low or nil, the report said, confirming other economic data.
Despite the market's broad advance, some traders see more room for gains.
"I think stocks are still the best place to be right now," said Alice Sadlo of McDonald & Company. "I'd try to jump back in if prices got lower."
Traders said the leap in the price of the first-day issue Fresh Choice Inc., which operates restaurants in Northern California, was a sign that investors were still eager to put money into the market. Fresh Choice closed at 24 1/2, up from its initial pricing at 13.
"There's a tremendous amount of cash out there chasing the new issues," said Brian Finnerty, senior vice president at Unterberg Harris.
The Limited topped the most active list on the Big Board, closing down 7/8, to 26 3/4. It was among 11 specialty retailers downgraded by Merrill Lynch.
International Business Machines slumped 2 3/4, to 62 5/8, on speculation that it will make more announcements about restructuring, including additional staff cuts and a possible dividend cut. Standard & Poor's also said it was reviewing the computer giant's debt ratings.
Microsoft shed 1/2, to 92, and Apple Computer fell 1/2, to 57 5/8.
Valence Technology gained 4 3/8, to 25 3/8, after it announced a $100 million deal to sell its solid polymer batteries to Motorola Inc. Amgen fell 2 1/4, to 72 3/4. Prudential cut its rating on the company to hold from buy.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks lost 1.34 points, to 435.65. The American Stock Exchange index fell 1.67, to 392.98.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.80, to 239.44. The average share was down 12 cents.

HEADLINE: U.S. Still Holds Haitians With H.I.V. in Cuba

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Despite warnings of a potential "public health disaster," the Government is still holding more than 200 Haitian refugees infected with the virus that causes AIDS at Guantanamo Naval Base in Cuba.
Officials of the Justice Department, which created a special camp for the infected refugees last spring, said it would remain in place until the incoming Clinton Administration decided what to do with them. 
 In letters, memorandums and discussions since the spring, Federal health officials have told the Justice Department that the detention camp was dangerous because people especially vulnerable to diseases like tuberculosis were confined in close quarters.
More than 270 Haitian men, women and children have been held at Guantanamo for more than six months, and some for more than a year. They live in makeshift buildings, sleeping on cots and using portable toilets.
The death of one infant from pneumonia after the baby and its mother were evacuated from the camp, and two attempted suicides inside the camp, have been recorded so far, and doctors fear that more health problems may arise.
"It is common sense I think to realize that concentrating people known to have an infection that causes immunosuprression in a tent city is a potential public health disaster," Dr. Paul V. Effler, an official of the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, wrote in a memo sent to the Justice Department.
"We have growing public health concerns" about the camp, Dr. James O. Mason, Assistant Secretary for Health and chief of the Public Health Service, wrote to the Justice Department last spring. "Housing so many immunosuppressed individuals in close proximity to one another in a camp environment presents substantial risks for infection and potential for uncontrolled, sustained transmission of infectious diseases, both to the H.I.V.-infected persons as well as their families and the health care and other personnel who may share their environment. An epidemic of otherwise easily controllable infectious agents could be a major problem in this environment."
Dr. Mason said the solution was the rapid processing of the refugees' claims and closing of the camp.
But the Justice Department halted all processing of claims because of a two legal disputes: whether people infected with H.I.V. should be allowed to enter the United States, and whether the refugees have a right to come to this country to have their claims heard.
Some 15,000 Haitians have entered the United States since last year's coup, but 274 Haitians remain in legal limbo on Cuba. Many others were sent back to Haiti.
Paul Cappuccio, an associate deputy attorney general, said that it was now clear that the easiest thing to have done would have been to avoid testing the immigrants for H.I.V., and simply treat their claims as those of other Haitians, who must prove under immigration law that they fear political persecution in order to be granted asylum in the United States.
"Though everybody involved in the process thought it would be simpler not to test them for H.I.V., no one in the Administration was comfortable with remaining ignorant," he said. "The Government is just not comfortable turning a deliberate blind eye to the infection, given that there is a statute which states that we must consider this."
The Justice Department had fought for the statute because officials said people infected with H.I.V. would be a social and economic burden if permitted to enter this country. Such restrictions do not apply to people with other illnesses that can be more expensive to treat, like cancer.
President-elect Bill Clinton has said he will end the ban on immigrants infected with H.I.V.
Public Health officials have maintained that AIDS is not a significant hazard from immigrants because it is not spread by casual contact and because the United States, with a million people believed to be infected, already has far more people with H.I.V. than any country from which migrants might come.

HEADLINE: American Vows Millions to Ex-Soviet Science

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 9

 BODY:
An American financier with a philanthropic specialty in post-Communist transitions announced today that he would give $100 million over the next two years in direct research grants to keep former Soviet scientists working in a time of economic crisis.
The pledge by the American, George Soros, is by far the largest gift, government or private, received so far for the support of fundamental science in Russia, Boris Saltykov, Minister of Science and Technology, said at a news conference here today. 
 "What Mr. Soros has done is an extraordinarily generous act and a private statement of his faith in this country," said James Collins, the acting chief of mission at the United States Embassy. "I certainly think he has given the U.S. Government a standard to live by."
Mr. Soros has already distributed $100 million throughout the former Communist countries of Central and Eastern Europe over the last five years as part of a broad effort to help build open, democratic societies.
Mr. Soros said the size of his latest grant was dictated by the crisis facing the once-powerful Soviet scientific establishment, and by his desire to set an example for Western governments and financial institutions.
"The thinking behind it is that there were some real values in the natural sciences in the former Soviet Union which are of world standard," he said in a telephone interview from Washington. "To lose them because of economic difficulties would be really a loss for mankind."
Mr. Soros has argued that now is the time for Western aid to be distributed in new, focused and imaginative ways. "This is a demonstration of what can be done," he said.
The salary of the average junior research scientist is now less than 5,000 rubles a month, while full professors make between 6,000 and 7,000 rubles a month. With the official exchange rate now at 419 rubles to the dollar, individual grants of $600 can go far, Russian scientists said today.
The grant from the Soros Foundation will be used to create the International Science Foundation for the Former Soviet Union, which will be based in Moscow and will provide money for research, equipment and scientific institutions in Russia and other former Soviet republics. The first $6 million will be disbursed as "emergency" grants early next year, while $85 million will be ready for distribution by mid-1993, after the foundation sets up for the review of grant applications. The remaining $9 million will cover operating costs.
Mr. Saltykov emphasized that research scientists would be able to apply for the grants directly, bypassing the traditional institutes and academies that until now have controlled the flow of research money.
This approach is certain to shake up the scientific establishment in Russia, which Mr. Soros said is one of his goals. "We are targeting the creative people," he said. "It will undoubtedly lead to a shift in power away from the administrators to the professionals."
Mr. Soros, a Hungarian-born financial expert who has made a fortune in investment funds, said the growth in his own business has allowed him to step up the level of philanthropic activities. "I was looking for a megaproject that would make a bigger impact," he said.
Several other Western institutions have come to the aid of Russian science, which is now suffering from severe budget cutbacks, an outflow of talent abroad and paralyzing uncertainties about the future. Scientists have watched their salaries fall behind inflation and their institutes cut back on personnel. To get their books and articles published, they often have to find sponsors themselves, as publishers seek more lucrative titles.
"Go into any bookstore to the science section, you will see stacks of books on astrology," said Aleksandr Levin, a professor of quantum chemistry. "Russian science needs some serious, focused help now. Science is not like canned goods that you put on a shelf and pick up again five years later. Science is a system which if it is not supported, will die."

HEADLINE: Chip Indicator Posts 3d Rise

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Orders and shipments for chips in the United States market both gained in November, and the semiconductor industry's leading indicator rose for the third time in three months, a trade group reported today.
The Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.13 for the three-month period that ended in November, up from a revised figure of 1.11 in October and from 1.07 in September. The ratio compares orders with shipments. A ratio above 1 indicates rising demand. 
 At $1.90 billion, three-month orders for November were up 5.6 percent from $1.80 billion for the three-month period ended in October and 42.0 percent higher than the comparable figure for one year ago, which was $1.34 billion. Three-month average shipments for November totaled $1.68 billion, up 3.9 percent from October's figure of $1.62 billion. At $1.66 billion, actual United States market shipments for the month of November were up 7.5 percent from October's $1.55 billion.
