HEADLINE: Incentives Help Retain A Company In Suffolk

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Defying the trend of companies leaving the New York metropolitan area for the South and the West, a Long Island company announced yesterday that it was closing a factory in California and adding hundreds of jobs in Suffolk County.
But it took a package of $12 million in grants, low-interest loans and other financial incentives from New York State and Suffolk to persuade it not to leave. 
 The company, Symbol Technologies, is a major manufacturer of computerized devices for reading the bar codes used in stores, warehouses and inventory control systems. Although it has been based in Suffolk since it was founded in 1973, it said its rapid growth in recent years had forced it to look at alternative sites in other states.
Describing the deal to keep Symbol in Suffolk as a major victory, state officials said it would reinforce Long Island's role as a center of technologically advanced manufacturing at a time when it has been buffeted by layoffs and business failures.
 
"A New Era'
 "Firms like Symbol will help the Empire State inaugurate a new era of national leadership in advanced technology," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said in a formal statement.
Symbol, which employs 850 people at its headquarters and a nearby plant in Bohemia, said it would close a plant in Costa Mesa, Calif., which it acquired in 1988, and consolidate all its operations in Suffolk County. It said it would hire 300 workers next year and 600 more by the end of 1996, bringing its total employment on Long Island to 1,750.
In addition to expanding its work force, the company said it would spend $30 million to $50 million to build a new headquarters in the Town of Islip.
"This is the first good news we've had about manufacturing on the Island in years," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Since 1986, he said, manufacturing employment on Long Island has plummeted by more than 30 percent, from 180,000 to 124,000, largely because of the shrinkage of military industry activity.
 
Effect of Economy
 Analysts said a company like Symbol, which relies heavily on engineering and computer skills among its workers, is a particularly important prize for Suffolk now because it is bound to employ some of those laid off by military contractors.
For its part, Symbol said part of the appeal of Long Island was its surplus of high-technology workers. "If the Long Island economy were still at the hot pace of the early 1980's, our decision might have turned out differently," said Nancy Tully, a spokeswoman for the company.
She said several states had aggressively courted Symbol with offers of financial incentives, among them Delaware and Maryland. Although the company gave little consideration to leaving Long Island for California, she said proposals from other states were considered because Symbol officials wanted to consolidate all their manufacturing and executive functions, and needed more space than it now has in Bohemia.
What clinched the deal, said officials of the company and the Cuomo administration, was New York State's incentive package. It will provide provide Symbol with $6.6 million in grants and low-interest loans for construction, equipment and job training, $2 million in subsidies for electrical power and road improvements that are to cost $1.2 million.
Suffolk County will provide the company with $2.2 million in property tax abatements.
The incentive package "creates the kind of positive business environment in which high-technology companies can flourish," said Jerome Swartz, a Long Island electrical engineer who founded Symbol in his Stony Brook garage in 1973, and is now the company's chairman.
 
Decades of Losses
 New York State officials said Symbol's decision to expand on Long Island was particularly good news because it comes after decades of job losses and manufacturing relocations to the South and Mexico.
A recent example was announcement a year ago that the General Motors Corporation would close its assembly plant in North Tarrytown, eliminating 3,400 jobs by 1995, and transfer the same assembly operations to Georgia.
The incentives offered to Symbol were similar to those provided many companies that the state has attracted from elsewhere, or persuaded to remain in their New York offices and plants. In a much larger package, the state won agreement from the Union Carbide Corporation to consolidate its Industrial Gases Division in Tonawanda in 1990, but only after providing the company with low-interest loans, grants and other inducements worth $34 million.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A package of state grants and other financial incentives has been offered to help keep Symbol Technologies in New York State. Employees worked on bar code scanners at the company's plant in Bohemia, L.I. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Rally Wall St. Hardly Noticed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
It has happened quietly, without the flash and drama that made Wall Street what it was in the 1980's. But over the course of the last three months, stock prices have moved to record highs.
The relative lack of attention to the latest bull market may be because of the relatively poor performance of the 30 issues that make up the most famous and widely watched index of stock market performance, the Dow Jones industrial average. At 3,323.81, the Dow is up 4.89 percent this year, but still well below the record 3,413.21 it reached on June 1. 
 But broader, more representative indexes, like the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks and the Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter issues, have never been higher.
 
Surprise on Wall Street
 The current rally, which began in early October, has confounded some of Wall Street's ablest professionals.
But it is a run-up that has been sparked and sustained by growing optimism about the economy, which is seen as improving, inflation, which is not viewed as a threat, and the potential of the incoming Clinton Administration. And it has been fed by a steady inflow of new money, much of it invested by mutual funds. Much of that, in turn, has been moving into small stocks.
"The run has surprised us," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers. "But we don't see any argument that says the market is cheap. That makes us cautious. But we were cautious when the S.& P 500 index was at 400 back in early October. Now it is at 436. We have missed the whole rally."
Perhaps the most important reason to explain why the run-up in stock prices has gone largely unnoticed or under-reported is that small investors, not big money managers, are fueling it.
"What has made it difficult for interpreters of this bull market is that it is a different marginal buyer that is moving into stocks," said Laszlo Birinyi, who heads Birinyi & Associates, a stock research firm.
"For years and years the public sold stocks. Now they are coming back."
According to data compiled by Mr. Birinyi, pension plans, which bought an average of $3.5 billion worth of stock each quarter, every quarter, from 1982 through 1989, have cut those purchases in half.
On the other hand, mutual funds, which purchased an average of $14 billion worth of stock each quarter in the 1980's, have been buying at a $40 billion- a-quarter clip in the current decade.
"During the 1980's, people who trade odd lots were net buyers on less than 1 percent of all trading days," Mr. Birinyi added. "This year, that odd-lotter has been a net buyer more than 50 percent of the time." Odd-lot trades are stock tranactions of fewer than 100 shares.
A. Marshall Acuff, chief equity strategist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said that "it became apparent by August that cash positions at mutual funds had begun to grow. The money was available, and those cash levels were maintained through October. And anecdotally, I hear from some funds they are struggling to get that money to work."
Confronted with the lowest interest rates in two decades, individuals have been shifting out of money market funds and maturing certificates of deposit and into stock and bond funds all year.
But analysts said that investor behavior changed somewhat this fall, and that Bill Clinton's election had a good bit to do with it.
Michael J. Hines, a senior vice president in marketing at Fidelity Investments, said discussions with focus groups of potential investors earlier this year were strikingly similar to ones held four years earlier.
"What we are seeing is very reminiscent to what happened in 1988," Mr. Hines said. "What people were doing then and did again this year was wait until they saw what happened in the election. This year the idea of change inherent in Clinton's victory was viewed as a very positive thing."
After the election, a monthly poll of investor attitudes conducted for Fidelity by the University of Michigan jumped 11 points in November, to its highest level since the early spring of 1991, Mr. Hines said.
In addition to the jump in confidence, analysts said newspaper articles noting that smaller companies tend to do better under Democrats appear to have contributed to the rise in the Nasdaq's composite index in recent months.
"A couple of headline-grabbing articles haven't hurt," said Chip Morris, an investment analyst for the $1.5 billion New Horizons Fund at T. Rowe Price Associates.
"In addition to that, this year it looks like the U.S. economy is recovering, while markets overseas are declining. That means you are seeing a rotation out of big companies who make a substantial part of their profits overseas and into companies who are more U.S.-centric."
The rise in the Nasdaq composite index has been impressive since October, but the recent run-up in prices of smaller companies is merely a continuation of a run that began at the end of September 1990.
Since then, the Dow has risen by 35 percent. The Nasdaq, by contrast, has risen by more than 90 percent.
 
Still a Bargain
 Analysts have also played a big role in touching off the rush to small stocks. Despite their appreciation in price, compared with their price-earnings ratio of the larger companies that make up the Standard & Poor's 500 index, small stocks remain comparatively cheap.
"I still think small stocks are underpriced," said Charles Clough, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch & Company.
That said, few analysts were willing to predict the current rally would go much further in the near term. Indeed, stock prices moved generally lower yesterday, and the Nasdaq index tumbled.
"The market looks toppy now," said Byron Wien, chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "We are closer to the end than the beginning.
"But if you look at where we were at the beginning of the year, attitudes have shifted 180 degrees."
 
Europe Loses Its Sheen
 
 
At the start of the year, Mr. Wien recalled, Europe was the place to invest. Pessimism about the United States was rife.
"Now, we are coming out of recession, we have a leader who seems to be doing everything right and Europe's prospects have faded," he said of the President-elect.
Mr. Acuff at Smith Barney said the current run could last through December and up to Inauguration Day.
"This is sort of play time," he said. "The market keeps moving toward the inauguration as a benchmark. Then the hopes and expectations will be tested. After that, whatever people are looking or hoping for may not happen fast enough to sustain prices."

HEADLINE: Grim to Giddy: Dining Out Is In

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
The mood these days at the Four Seasons, one of New York's landmark restaurants, is positively giddy. In the evening, the restaurant's clubby Grill Room now welcomes a capacity crowd of around 140 guests a night, who order from a new, lower-priced prix fixe menu, instead of the lonely 6 to 10 who dined there earlier in the year. Reservations in the soaring Pool Room have also risen by about 10 percent in the last month.
"Everything had been in a decline or flat," said Alex Von Bidder, the general manager. "Then it just exploded." 
 After five years of layoffs and belt-tightening in the finance, law, publishing, retailing and advertising industries that sharply reduced the need and desire to dine out, restaurants from the most casual to the most exalted appear busy again. Many restaurants enjoying new success, like the Four Seasons, have taken to heart the lessons of the lean years, offering a less expensive menu and a more informal atmosphere.
"The grim mood of the past two or three years seems to be sliding away," said Tom Margittai, an owner of the Four Seasons, who estimated that his restaurant had lost 30 percent of its customers since the beginning of the recession. "We now see signs of better business, and people seem to be in a more spending mood. It's great to get the customers back in the door."
Since 1988, except for a few dozen perennial hot spots, New York restaurants had to shift gears to adjust to the economic decline. As passionate as many chefs and owners had been about their food and wines, they had to become hard-nosed business people, focusing more on attracting and keeping diners and on finding creative ways to control costs.
Many restaurants that were struggling a year ago report that business has improved and that more people are dining out. Joe Baum, managing partner of the Rainbow Room, said reservations for New Year's Eve, at $375 a person, were significantly ahead of last year's. "People are now rewarding themselves, " he added. "They're not as self-conscious about spending money."
 
More Orders, Pricier Wines
 The American Express Company and Visa U.S.A. have registered an increase in the use of their credit cards for dining out. Purveyors of fine foods say they have more orders on their books and are more confident that their invoices will be paid. Restaurants and hotels say more private parties are being scheduled.
Marc Sarrazin, owner of De Bragga & Spitler, a meat wholesaler in lower Manhattan, said his business was up 15 to 20 percent over last year. At the Gotham Bar and Grill, Scott Carney, the general manager, said that in the last couple of months people have been buying more expensive wines; the nightly average has been as much as $44 a bottle, up from $32 or so. And even in restaurants that were prospering despite hard times, like Aureole, reservations have been coming in for those hard-to-fill shoulder periods, around 6 P.M. and after 9:30 P.M.
The improvement began to take hold this summer, say those who regularly take the pulse of the restaurant business in New York, and it seems to have quickened appreciably since the Presidential election.
Around the country, restaurants are generally doing better. There are some problematic pockets, notably in Los Angeles, which has still not recovered from the combined effect of the riots in May and the summer's earthquakes. But in Atlanta, which is looking forward to the Super Bowl in 1994 and the Summer Olympics in 1996, the restaurant scene is flourishing, attracting chefs like Jean-Louis Palladin of Washington and Jean Banchet from Chicago.
Considering other bright economic indicators, like the drop in the jobless rate, it may have been inevitable that more people would start making reservations for dinner instead of buying Lean Cuisine. But helping to fuel the restaurant habit in New York was a promotional device that had a far more dynamic effect on business than originally intended.
The gimmick, lunch for $19.92, offered by about 100 restaurants during the week of the Democratic National Convention in July, was conceived by city officials and restaurateurs as a courtesy, mainly to the delegates and visiting journalists. It proved so effective in generating business that more than half of the participants retained the program through Labor Day and even beyond. A number of them have even added special dinner menus for $24.92.
"We're getting a hell of a lot of credit for something we did not anticipate," said Tim Zagat, president of the Zagat Survey Restaurant Guide, who helped organize the effort. "It proved to be a boon for the entire industry."
By encouraging droves of new customers to feel welcome in pricey restaurants like San Domenico or La Caravelle, the promotion helped fill and energize dining rooms that were once as sparsely visited as a fourth-run movie theater on a Monday afternoon.
 
A Lesson Is Learned
 "We have been able to bring in new traffic," said Tony May, owner of San Domenico, on Central Park South, where the promotion has been continued. "I was very stubborn about lowering prices, but I learned a lesson. Besides, once they come into the restaurant, they don't all order the prix fixe menu." Mr. May added that while his average check has decreased about 20 percent during the promotion, his gross sales have grown about 30 percent.
Nationwide, there has been a 1.8 percent growth in revenues in sit-down restaurants this year, according to the United States Department of Commerce. That is still far below the 6.9 percent growth in 1987, but up from the meager six-tenths of 1 percent in 1991.
"We're anticipating a slightly greater upturn for 1993," said Ron Paul, president of Technomic, a research and consulting firm in Chicago that analyzes these figures regularly. "We're actually more bullish now than we were in September."
Patricia Duffy, the vice president and general manager of the restaurant and entertainment industry for American Express, was optimistic. "We're now seeing a stabilization and growth mode in the industry," she said, "and that's a statement I would not have made a year ago." The number of transactions using the American Express card has increased over last year, but the company won't say by how much.
Thomas C. Edwards, the vice president for travel and entertainment marketing for Visa U.S.A., said that so far this year, card usage for dining has increased more than 10 percent over that of last year, when charges were more than $10 billion. He attributed this increase to improved business, as well as his company's aggressive marketing of the Visa card, which costs restaurateurs less to accept than does American Express.
 
Signs of Growth
 In New York, where the number of permits issued for restuarants by the Health Department has not varied significantly over the last five years, there are signs of growth for the 1993 fiscal year, which began on July 1. From July 1 through Nov. 21, the department reported issuing 8,963 permits, compared with a typical year's total of around 11,700.
And Mr. Zagat's latest guide lists 45 restaurants that have closed in 1992, compared with 57 the year before. It also showed 145 new restaurants this year, compared with 112 in 1991. "That really surprised me," he said.
The list of notable, largely informal newcomers this season includes Brasserie des Theatres, Becco, Banana Cafe, Follonico, Ariel & Michael and One Fifth Avenue, a new restaurant in a familiar location.
In addition, two of New York's leading chefs have new ventures. Jean-Georges Vongerichten of Jo Jo is poised to open Vong, a Thai restaurant, and Daniel Boulud, the former chef of Le Cirque, is scheduled to open a new venture on the Upper East Side early next year.
 
Successful but Closing
 A restaurant can fail or close for reasons not directly related to the economic climate or the amount of business it is doing. For example, Barry and Susan Wine will turn out the lights at the highly regarded Quilted Giraffe on Dec. 31, a decision influenced by the fact that the Sony Corporation, the restaurant's new landlord, is doing major reconstruction. The Wines would have had to close at least temporarily anyway, and this way they obtained a profitable settlement.
"Our business has been up tremendously since late August," said Mr. Wine, who also participated in the $19.92 promotion. "It was sluggish before that."
Still, sometimes the sheer weight of expenses incurred in the high-rolling 1980's can haunt a restaurant right into the grave. Mondrian, on East 59th Street, was one such casualty. It is still on the market for the original rent of $30,000 a month. "When the bank drops it to $20,000 there will be a taker," said Warren Newcorn, the executive vice president of the Winick Realty Corporation in Manhattan, a company that specializes in retail leasing.
Mr. Newcorn said that these days, most landlords are willing to make deals. "Rents are more affordable, a lot of new places are opening, and there are fewer spaces available now," he said. "Our business is up 30 percent over last year."
While landlords are more flexible, restaurateurs appear to have learned a hard lesson. Like investment firms and law offices, restaurants have emerged from the crucible of the late-1980's with a new, leaner management style. "You have to be very careful with costs and overhead," said David Liederman, who revised the menu at Broadway Grill to meet these goals and is now trying to reopen Chez Louis, which he closed in a rent dispute last year.
Steven Wils, the president of Harry Wils & Company, which supplies dairy products and specialty foods to restaurants, said that at the start of the year many of his customers were still ordering lower-quality ingredients to save money. "Not now," he said. "They're still very price-conscious, but they won't compromise on quality. They're bargaining hard."
 
A Demanding Public
 Chefs also say that today the dining public is more demanding and knowledgeable. As a result, the jobs restaurants are doing, especially when it comes to service, have improved strikingly.
Malcolm M. Knapp, president of the food-service-consulting firm in Manhattan that bears his name, compared the restaurant business today to the art market. "The speculators have been squeezed out and the real collectors are back," he said.
Mr. Knapp said he believed that since financial businesses had cut back and stabilized, they would start spending again. He also suggested that since New Yorkers voted heavily for Bill Clinton, the mood is especially buoyant here.
Ariane Daguin, co-owner of D'Artagnan, which supplies game and foie gras to restaurants, agreed. "Since November it has been good news all the way," she said. "We were hurt badly last year." Then, $70,000 in invoices were not paid, she continued but added, "I don't expect that to happen now."
For the most part, however, the optimism is hesitant. For example, while the reservation book at Le Bernardin, the plush French seafood restaurant in midtown where business has slipped since 1990, is full this month, Gilbert LeCoze, an owner, said, "Business is now about the same as last year, and I think it will be another year before things will be better."
December can always be counted on to be the busiest month of the year. As Ms. Daguin said: "People don't go out of business in December. They go out in January and that's when we'll really know." Or will we?
Mr. Paul, the Chicago consultant, said he expected restaurant sales to collapse in January, but he took a longer view. "December is great," he said, "and January is traditionally a terrible month. We all know that. The real question now is how many places will still be in good shape by the time April rolls around."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Four Seasons restaurant is enjoying new success by offering a less expensive menu and a more informal atmosphere. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times) (pg. B9)

HEADLINE: Bid Is Weighed to Make Sales Tax Rise Permanent in Suffolk

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Dec. 9

 BODY:
As Suffolk County lawmakers gave final approval today to a 5.8 percent increase in the property tax rate for 1993, Republican leaders raised the idea of making a temporary one-cent increase in the county sales tax into a permanent levy.
The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, noting that the temporary sales tax increase was due to expire at the end of 1993, said he planned to ask state lawmakers to make most, if not all, of the tax increase permanent. The additional penny on the dollar generates $120 million a year. 
 Donald R. Blydenburgh, a Republican and presiding officer of the County Legislature, proposed that the sales tax issue be decided in a public referendum next November, when all 18 county legislators are up for re-election.
 
'The Major Issue'
 "Taxes will be the major issue, and the voters should have the chance to tell their lawmakers what to do," Mr. Blydenburgh said.
Meanwhile, the County Legislature this afternoon gave unanimous approval to next year's property tax rate, which will show up in tax bills that should arrive in the mail along with New Year's greetings. The increase will help to balance the county's $1.5 billion 1993 budget. For the average homeowner, the tax bill will rise by $37, to $677, county officials estimated.
Although the sales tax issue was not on the official agenda for today's meeting, the debate began in private among lawmakers, wary that their comments now could come back to haunt them next November.
The temporary sales tax increase was approved by the State Legislature in half-penny increments over the last two years as a way of balancing the county budget, paying back loans and providing additional funds for the Nassau County Police Department. The sales tax now totals 8.5 percent in the county.
Both half-penny increases are to expire on Dec. 31, 1993, and both state and county legislators would have to approve any increase.
Mr. Gaffney first mentioned making all or part of the sales tax increase permanent during talks last week with financial analysts from Moody's Investors Service before it reaffirmed Suffolk's Baa1 bond rating, which is two grades above junk-bond status.
In a statement issued to the county by Moody's, analysts noted that Suffolk had taken "important steps toward restoring the county's financial position." But the analysts noted that Suffolk was still faced with a "significant challenge" in 1993.
Mr. Gaffney said he was hopeful that the state and county legislatures would vote to keep at least three-quarters of the sales tax increase to help pay for the growing number of mandated state and Federal programs. He said the portion of the sales tax revenues being used to retire a one-time borrowing of $35 million to help cover a 1990 budget deficit could be allowed to expire.
Paul Sabatino, legal adviser to the Suffolk Legislature, said the sales tax question "could not be discussed in a vacuum." He suggested that the legislators may have to link it to another issue -- relief from mandated state and Federal programs.
He said economic circumstances might also determine whether the continuing revenues from the sales tax extension would be needed.
"If the economy picks up, we would all benefit," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on Expectations Of Stronger U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against major currencies yesterday amid perceptions that the United States economy was improving. Gold prices fell.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $333.60 an ounce, down $1.80 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $1.50, to a late price of $333.75. 
 Zlatko Glamuzina, chief currency dealer at Banco di Sicilia, said the dollar was a double beneficiary of bad international news and good domestic news.
The market likes President-elect Bill Clinton's reported choices for various economic posts and it likes the improving economy, even though the improvement is slow, he said.
And, he said, the market is skittish about political and economic troubles worldwide: the Hong Kong financial markets are troubled, the German economy is skidding, the British economy is in recession and Japan's markets are roiling.
"The only place the international money can go is the United States," whether it is in dollars, Treasury securities or the stock market, Mr. Glamuzina said. "You will get ahead in the short term."
In New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 124.05 Japanese yen, up from 123.75 yen late Tuesday. Overnight in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 123.85 yen, up 0.02 yen from Tuesday's close. The dollar closed at 123.95 yen in London.
In New York, a British pound cost $1.5660, down from $1.59975 late Tuesday. In London, the pound was quoted at $1.5695, down from $1.5975 late Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5725 German marks, up from 1.5562; 1.4105 Swiss francs, up from 1.3945; 5.3665 French francs, up from 5.3065; 1,393.00 Italian lire, up from 1,367.50, and 1.27305 Canadian dollars, up from 1.27225.
The price of gold fell $1.65 in London to $334.00 an ounce. In Zurich, gold fell $1.45, to $333.80. In Hong Kong, gold lost $2.16 to close at $334.58.
On the Commodity Exchange, silver closed at $3.688 an ounce, down from $3.739 late Tuesday. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $3.72 an ounce, down from Tuesday's $3.77.

HEADLINE: Fed Survey Finds an Upturn, but an Uneven One

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The economy is improving modestly but unevenly across the country, with retailers expressing optimism about the holiday season, the Federal Reserve said today.
In its periodic assessment of the state of the economy, the central bank said almost all regions were experiencing "a slight to moderate pickup in some or all sectors of the economy" while noting specifically that California was doing worse than other states. 
 The report, the latest in a string of favorable economic news, could reduce the pressures on President-elect Bill Clinton to give the economy a quick jolt with short-term economic stimulus measures. As he maneuvers to make sure that the public and Congress still back his call for long-term economic changes, Mr. Clinton has been saying over and over again that the economy remains in unsatisfactory shape. .
The report, known as the beige book, stated that sales for existing and new single-family homes were up throughout the nation. It added that manufacturing was increasing in just half the nation, with factories in New York and California continuing to face soft demand. Continuing cutbacks in military production remain a "notable drag on the recovery in some regions," the report said.
The latest beige book was noticeably more optimistic than the one issued five weeks ago. It is based on information gathered by the nation's 12 Federal Reserve District Banks before Dec. 1.
The central bank's chief policy-making committee, the Federal Open Market Committee, will discuss the report's conclusions when it meets to assess monetary policy on Dec. 22.
 
No Rate Action Seen
 "The report paints a positive picture, but you're also left with the impression that the recovery is subpar and is struggling to get off the ground," said Hugh Johnson, chief economist with the First Albany Corporation, a New York-based brokerage firm. "Still, I don't think, based on this report, that there is enough weakness in the economy to push the Fed to ease policy another notch."
In interviews last week, several Fed officials said they were so pleased with the low inflation and the pickup in growth that they saw no need to raise or lower short-term interest rates in the near future.
The beige book stated that "little to no general inflationary pressure is reported," although it noted that high factory operating rates were expected to lead to higher prices for steel and construction materials.
David W. Mullins Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, said in an interview last week: "We've made a lot of progress on inflation. The outlook for the future suggests further progress."
The report was most optimistic about the outlook for retailing and housing.
"Except in California, retailers reportedly expect 1992 holiday sales gains to be better than last year's," the report said. It noted that the Federal Reserve Bank in Chicago said retailers in the region expected "the best performance in eight years" this holiday season, while the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said the sense among retailers was for a gain, but "nothing spectacular."
Construction and real estate, the report said, "tell a tale of two markets, with improvements in the residential sector, but continued stagnation on the commercial side."
 
A Problem Area
 In New England, the commercial real estate market "is very slow and shows no sign of recovery," the report said, noting that office vacancy rates continued to hover stubbornly near 20 percent.
For New York and New Jersey, home builders reported some modest improvement and office leasing activity rose strongly in midtown Manhattan, up 23 percent in the first nine months of this year from the level a year earlier. In downtown Manhattan, however, the pace of leasing activity has been flat.
According to the report, nonfarm employment has continued to decline in New York and New Jersey, although the rate of job losses has slowed. It noted that the Grumman Corporation planned to cut 500 more jobs on Long Island by the end of March, while the Miller Brewing Company will cut 180 jobs in upstate New York early next year.
The bleakest part of the report concerned California. "Cutbacks continue in aerospace and defense-related manufacturing, retail sales are sluggish and the state's fiscal condition has worsened," the report said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Tax-Exempt Yields Plunge; Taxables Post Slight Rise

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt money market funds were down sharply this week because of increased demand and a tightening supply of short-term municipal securities, according to the most recent survey by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report, the newsletter that tracks money-market mutual funds.
But taxable money market fund yields rose slightly, the newsletter said. 
 The steep drop in tax-exempt yields followed a slight rise in the previous week. Still, assets increased $3.2 billion in the latest week, to a total of $101.1 billion. Analysts said corporations and other large institutional investors moved into the money funds to have a source of ready cash for mid-December corporate tax bills. Individuals moved into the funds to reduce tax exposure after taking gains in stocks and bonds.
The average number of days left to maturity of securities held in fund portfolios was unchanged from last week, at 62 days.
The seven-day average compounded tax-exempt yield was down 11 basis points, to 2.10, with the simple yield down 10 basis points, to 2.08 percent. IBC/Donoghue's statisticians calculate that over the course of 30 days, the average compounded yield is 2.18 percent, down 4 basis points, with the simple yield at 2.16 percent, also down 4 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Making no assumption for state taxes, the taxable equivalent of the seven-day compounded yield this week for investors in a 28 percent tax bracket comes to 2.92 percent and to 3.04 percent for those in a 31 percent bracket.
From its survey of tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, IBC/Donoghue's said the Strong Municipal Money Market fund distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management was still outperforming the others, yielding 2.74 percent this week, down 11 basis points from last week's 2.85.
Among taxable money market funds, the average seven-day compounded and simple yields were both up 2 basis points, to 2.83 percent and 2.79 percent, respectively.
Assets of taxable funds were up $7.7 billion, to a total of $483.6 billion. About $6 billion of the increase came from funds open only to institutional investors, like pension funds and corporations, probably to prepare for tax payments, said Mary Sue Hoban, acting editor of the newsletter, based in Ashland, Mass. The remainder came from investors who took gains in other markets and want to remain liquid through the end of the year, she said.
IBC/Donoghue's analysts said the average days left to maturity of the funds' securities slipped to 60, from 62.
This week, bank money market accounts, which compete with the funds, had an average yield of 2.77 percent.

HEADLINE: Dole Expects Income Drop

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WESTLAKE VILLAGE, Calif., Dec. 9

 BODY:
The Dole Food Company said today that this year's earnings will plummet to $15 million from $134 million in 1991, citing tough times in the banana business, charges for accounting changes and restructuring costs.
Dole's shares lost $1.125, to $28.875, on the New York Stock Exchange after news of the company's earnings estimate. 
 "Dole's earnings are being reduced primarily by lower worldwide prices for bananas and lower market demand caused by a major global recession," David H. Murdock, chairman and chief executive officer, said.
It also forecast that its fourth-quarter earnings will sink to $4 million from $29 million a year earlier, adding that this "is primarily attributable to reduced prices in the company's banana operations."
The company said the fourth-quarter results will reflect a $12 million after-tax insurance recovery relating to the 1991 Costa Rican earthquake and a charge of $27 million to cover severance and other costs associated with a cost-cutting program. The cost- cutting program involves job reductions and plant consolidations, the company said. Dole said it would take a one-time charge of $50 million and a retroactive adjustment to prior earnings of $32 million to comply with new accounting rules covering future retiree medical benefits.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Free Agents Remain Anything but Free

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 9

 BODY:
In a frenzy unprecedented in the 17-year history of free agency, clubs have signed 35 free agents in three days to contracts worth $225 million.
After 10 free agents signed on Monday and 16 on Tuesday, nine more signed today. Greg Maddux, the latest pitcher to spurn the Yankees, led the third-day parade, agreeing to a five-year, $28 million deal with the Atlanta Braves tonight. Among the free agents who joined him, Andre Dawson marched to Boston for two years and $9.3 million; Todd Worrell to Los Angeles for three years and $9.5 million; Mike Moore to Detroit for three years and $10 million, and Randy Myers to the Chicago Cubs for three years and $11 million. 
 The recent rash of signings brought to 64 the number of free agents who have signed new contracts. That total, too, is unprecedented for this date.
In 1989, 43 free agents had signed by Dec. 9. That was the previous highest number for this period. But the average number signed by this date in the first 16 years was 18.
The signing splurge struck particularly hard this week. The previous record number of free agents signed in a three-day period was 22. Those deals were made during the winter meetings in 1989. In the entire week of the meetings last year, a seven-day period from Saturday through Friday, only 13 free agents were signed.
 
A One-Day Record
 The 16 who reached agreement on new deals Tuesday were more than that entire week and were a one-day high for the 17 years since free agency began after the 1976 season. The previous one-day high was 13 last Dec. 19.
The number of free-agent signings, though, has not been the only significant development. The amount of money clubs have agreed to give the players also is astounding.
The richest contract, of course, is the $43.75 million gift the San Francisco Giants presented to Barry Bonds on Tuesday in a not-so-neatly wrapped package. Just a couple of hours later, the Kansas City Royals twisted David Cone's arm until he accepted a $9 million signing bonus to be paid this month. Cone hadn't even bought a lottery ticket.
And the series of signings hasn't even included Mark McGwire, Ruben Sierra and Jimmy Key.
Bud Selig, chairman of the executive council, whose Milwaukee Brewers lost Paul Molitor in the economic spree, was asked today about the development.
"Every club must do what they do," he said, speaking in unfamiliar thoughts for him. "Every club has the right to make business decisions. One of the problems we have in this industry is we have a group of clubs in association that have widely divergent characteristics. It's hard for some people to understand what others are doing."
But then he added, "It only points up why we need a different system."
The record three-day frenzy comes just days after baseball's economic study committee submitted its report to the 28 clubs and the Players Association. Although one of the four members dissented, the report paints a dire picture of the game's economy and recommends a new system in which clubs would share a greater proportion of their revenue and would pay players with a percentage of their revenue.
Furthermore, most of the money the clubs have committed themselves to spending in these new contracts will come from post-1993 revenues. Next season is the last of the national television contracts -- clubs will receive $401 million in 1993 -- and baseball and television people have predicted that income will plunge drastically.
The players wonder how accurate those projections can be when the clubs are agreeing to such mammoth contracts. The salaries and signing bonuses in the 35 contracts that have been signed in these three days total $225,335,000. The 48 guaranteed contracts that free agents have agreed to in the entire signing period are worth $365.3 million.
And those totals don't include the four-year, $24 million contract signed Tuesday by Seattle Mariners center fielder Ken Griffey Jr., who has had only four years in the major leagues, two years short of free agency eligibility. The Mariners apparently don't expect salaries to fall in the next few years; otherwise, why would they agree to pay Griffey $7 million each in 1995 and '96?
The Oakland Athletics, on the other hand, vowed to slash their payroll this winter, and they already have lost Moore and Dave Stewart as free agents and also could lose McGwire, not to mention Sierra, although they figure to sign one of the hitters.
The Braves tempered their signing of Maddux by immediately trading pitcher Charlie Leibrandt to Texas, thus freeing his $2.5 million salary to use for Maddux's signing bonus. But the Braves also will pay Maddux a $5 million salary next year, followed by salaries of $3.5 million, $5 million and $6 million each of the last two years.
Stewart jumped to the Toronto Blue Jays with a two-year, $8.5 contract Tuesday night. Moore reached agreement with the Tigers late today on a deal that will pay him a $1 million signing bonus and a $3 million salary each year for three years.
The Tigers, with a new owner, have joined other recently purchased clubs in spending sprees their previous owners did not make. The Mariners, the Giants and the Houston Astros also are in that nouveau spending clique.
Seventeen of the 28 clubs have signed the three-day wonders, some limiting themselves to low-paid players. The Blue Jays, looking to win another pennant, have not been one of the meager spenders. Stewart, Molitor and Joe Carter have cost them $41 million.
The Dodgers, like the Athletics, want to reduce their payroll, but they needed a closer in their bullpen so they gave Worrell a $1.25 million signing bonus and salaries of $2 million each of the first two years and $4.25 million the third. The Cubs signed Myers to be their closer for a $1 million signing bonus and salaries of $3.25 million each of the first two years and $3.5 million the third.
The Cubs, however, didn't want to spend to retain Dawson so the 38-year-old outfielder went to the Red Sox for a $350,000 signing bonus and salaries of $4.7 million and $4.25 million.
Other free agents who signed today were outfielder Milt Thompson, Philadelphia, 2 years, $2.75 million; pitcher Jim Deshaies, Minnesota, 1 year, $1 million; pitcher Kelly Downs, Oakland, 2 years, $1.3 million, and outfielder Dave Martinez, Giants, 2 years, $2.2 million.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: December 11, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 2179 words

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: A Cabinet Begins to Take Shape;
CLINTON TEAM TAKES SHAPE WITH BENTSEN AND 4 OTHERS NAMED TO ECONOMIC POSTS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 10

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton began to give shape to his Cabinet today with the appointment of an economic team of old hands from Washington and Wall Street to help him fulfill his campaign promise of fundamental economic change.
The distinctly mainstream array of advisers that Mr. Clinton introduced at the old Arkansas State House, led by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas as Treasury Secretary, seemed intended to mobilize lawmakers and executives behind his economic program, and to signal that the Clinton Administration will be as serious about reducing the deficit as about any new spending programs.
 
Diversity in Jobs
 Along with Senator Bentsen, Mr. Clinton named Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, as director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget, M. Alice Rivlin, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, as Mr. Panetta's deputy, Roger C. Altman, an investment banker, as Deputy Treasury Secretary, and Robert E. Rubin, the co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, as senior economic adviser. 
 As he spoke, Mr. Clinton was preparing to name a more diverse group to other top Administration jobs. On Friday, Clinton aides say, he will name Carol M. Browner, a former assistant to Vice President-elect Al Gore and currently Secretary of Environmental Regulation in Florida, as head of the Environmental Protection Agency.
The choice of Ms. Browner was something of a surprise. Earlier in the week, aides said the top candidate was Madeline Kunin, a former Vermont governor. But now they say that Mr. Clinton chose to let Mr. Gore take the lead in appointing environmental officials.
In addition, the Clinton aides say he will name Donna Shalala, chancellor of the University of Wisconsin and former head of Hunter College in New York City, as Secretary of Health and Human Services.
 
Looking at Foreign Affairs
 And they say he will name Laura D'Andrea Tyson, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, to head the Council of Economic Advisers, and Robert B. Reich, a political scientist at Harvard University, as Secretary of Labor.
Mr. Clinton is also said to have all but formally decided to name former Mayor Henry Cisneros of San Antonio as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Senator Timothy E. Wirth of Colorado, who retired this year, as Secretary of Energy, and former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona, a 1988 Democratic Presidential contender, as Secretary of the Interior.
In light of the crisis in Somalia and other pressing foreign affairs problems that have recently come to the fore, the President-elect is vigorously trying to narrow his choices for Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense and national security adviser, aides said.
Mr. Clinton's transition director, Warren M. Christopher; Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, remain high on Mr. Clinton's short list for the State Department, the aides said, but he keeps pressing for more names as well.
Asked today about General Powell, Mr. Clinton said: "I certainly think he is qualified to be Secretary of State." But he added with a smile, "I'll tell you who I am considering for that position when I announce my appointment for Secretary of State."
Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, has been asked to consider the post of Ambassador to the United Nations, but has not responded, members of the transition staff said.
At today's news conference, Mr. Clinton seemed intent on focusing exclusively on his core economic advisers and on economic issues.
"Our nation faces two deficits, a budget deficit and an investment deficit," Mr. Clinton said as he introduced his first Cabinet appointments. "I am going to work my heart out with these people to construct a strong, long-term plan for economic growth, for jobs, for incomes, and to reduce our national debt."
As he promised during the campaign, Mr. Clinton also created a new post in the White House -- a senior economic adviser to coordinate foreign and domestic policy through a new National Economic Council. Mr. Clinton named Mr. Rubin to that post, which carries the same rank as the national security adviser. The new council is intended to coordinate foreign and domestic economic strategies in much the same way as the National Security Council does in diplomatic and security affairs.
The choice of Mr. Altman, a friend of Mr. Clinton from their days at Georgetown University, as Deputy Treasury Secretary, may prove to be delicate issue for a President who campaigned on saving jobs and fending off foreign encroachments on American markets an industries. He is vice chairman of the Blackstone Group, an investment bank specializing in international mergers and acquisitions. Like many companies of its type, the Blackstone Group has aggressively solicited business abroad, and several years ago ran a a full-page advertisement in a Japanese newspaper offering its services to Japanese companies interested in taking over American companies.
Over all, Mr. Clinton has chosen a team of Wall Street and Congressional veterans, known more for parliamentary skills and business experience than for economic innovation. While the words change and innovation were the hallmarks of Mr. Clinton's campaign oratory, the appointees, aside from Mr. Bentsen, are probably stronger advocates of deficit-reduction than big new spending programs.
As a Clinton adviser said: "The message to Wall Street was steady as she goes, nothing different or innovative to worry about. This is the establishment here, all people very concerned about the deficit. I think Bill feels that with regard to economic policy, he can be his own top adviser. He knows what he wants to do and these people will be good at implementing it."
 
His Own Top Adviser
 Mr. Clinton said as much when he told reporters, "I will be the chief economic adviser in my Administration and I would take responsibility for addressing both the short and long-term economic challenges facing us."
As always, though, Mr. Clinton offered no specifics about painful measures he might offer to American taxpayers to pay for his programs.
Mr. Clinton said he wanted his economic team in place in time to help oversee the economic conference he has called for Monday and Tuesday in Little Rock, which will bring together about 300 business executives from around the country to discuss the state of the economy and how best to revive it.
The economic program Mr. Clinton's team will be asked to put into effect, as it currently shapes up, looks like some version of the outline he gave during the campaign: tax increases for Americans making more than $200,000 a year, tax reductions for the middle class, an investment tax credit for businesses creating jobs and $20 billion in new spending on roads, bridges, highways and high-technology transportation and communications systems.
Mr. Clinton promised all of that plus halving the budget deficit within four years.
The first challenge for the group will be deciding in the coming weeks whether the economy is rebounding enough now or whether it needs an extra dose of economic stimulus. Then, if more stimulus is needed, how should it be squared with a credible program to reduce the deficit.
As if reflecting some advance agreement, each of the new appointees included lines in their opening statements clearly intended to play down expectations for a quick fix.
"The American people realize that these challenges did not develop overnight and won't be fixed overnight," Mr. Bentsen said.
"The structural economic problems facing this country are deep-seated and can't be solved overnight," Mr. Altman said.
"There remain some deep and fundamental problems in the economy," Representative Panetta said.
Mr. Bentsen, Mr. Rubin and Mr. Altman, are all millionaires, and Mr. Rubin in particular has been a big donor to the Democratic Party for years. Mr. Clinton was asked, but did not answer, why he was turning to such Washington insiders, for his top economic advisers.
When Mr. Bentsen, who was known for granting more than a few large tax breaks for special interest business lobbies as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, was asked to respond to this question he sidestepped it. "I have heard all those stories about my being an insider," he said. "Let me tell you I felt like an outsider for 12 years, and I'm tired of the gridlock."
 
Defining Jobs
 One of the points that was not resolved in the news conference was exactly what Mr. Rubin will do, and how his role as economic coordinator will be meshed with the Secretary of the Treasury, who has historically served in that function.
Under President Bush, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady was the head of the Economic Policy Council, a body that was abolished about a year ago and drew wide criticism for producing little in the way of policy initiatives.
Trying to explain it, Mr. Clinton said: "First of all the Secretary of the Treasury will be the principal economic spokesperson for the Administration after the President. Mr. Rubin's job will be to coordinate, facilitate and provide some direction to the deliberations of our economic council. It will be a larger group than the National Security Council because it will include some others like Commerce, Labor, Energy, and it is a very important job. But in the end I will make the ultimate decisions and be the ultimate arbiter.
"Because we want to bring in more people in a systematic way and reconcile what these departments are doing so they can reinforce and energize one another. I decided I needed someone on the domestic side to be that sort of coordinator and facilitator, but these departments will each stand on their own bottoms and the Treasury will still be the place where the President's economic views are spoken for."
 
Old Hands for Clinton's New Economic Team
President-elect Bill Clinton turned to the center of the economic and political specturm with his choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, at right, as Treasury Secretary and Representative Leon E. Panetta as Director of the Office of Management and Budget, the top two economic jobs, and by naming Robert E. Rubin to the new post of senior senior economic adviser, Alice M. Rivlin as deputy budget director and Roger C. Altman as deputy Treasury Secretary. The choice of centrists could be important at a time when economists and politicians on the left and the right are arguing that the budget deficit is of secondary importance and when the number at the center willing to advocate the bitter medicine needed to lower the deficit seems to be shrinking.
 
Roger C. Altman -- Vice chairman of the Blackstone Group, a New York investment bank who was a student at Georgetown University with Mr. Clinton in the 1960's...46...Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance in the Carter Administration and played a role in the rescues of the Chrysler Corporation and New York City...is among those who say that any financial stimulus to the sluggish economy must be applied with caution so as not to aggravate the Federal budget dificit or disturb the financial markets.
 
Alice M. Rivlin -- Economist...61...first director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1975 to 1983, where she earned considerable respect for professional and nonpartisan economic forecasts, options and analysis...former president of the American Economics Association...now an economist at the Brookings Institution and visiting professor of public policy at George Mason University...has long sounded the alarm over the huge budget deficits...in a recent book she called for for a shift from Washington and to the state capitals of programs like job training and public works, a sharp contrast to Mr. Clinton's position that his foremost responsibility as President is to promote economic growth and job creation..
 
Rep. Leon E. Panetta -- Democrat of California...54...elected to the House in 1976...chairman of the House Budget Committee since 1989...started as a Republican and switched parties in 1971...was a leading architect of the 1990 budget agreement aimed at reducing the deficit and has defended it against spending proposals, including those of many Democrats, that would pierce the agreement's limits...this year he drafted a long-term deficit-reduction plan calling for deep spending cuts and tax increases to pay for any new spending programs.
 
Robert E. Rubin -- Co-chairman and 26-year veteran of the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs and Company...54...has a reputation as a good manager who absorbs diverse opinions and then focuses on building consensus...not a particular ideologue, but many believe he would bring a willingness to balance concern about the financial markets with concern about economic and political needs...long-time Democratic fund-raiser who helped raise millions of dollars to finance the Democratic National Convention in July.

PUB-DATE: December 11, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1109 words

HEADLINE: The Transition: An Eye Toward Wall Street and Capitol Hill;
Promises Before Policies

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
With the choices he announced today, President-elect Bill Clinton indicated that the main responsibility of the top economic policy officials in his Administration would be not so much to develop new policy as to get his campaign promises enacted quickly.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen and Representative Leon E. Panetta have mastered tax and budget policy like few others in public life. The high regard with which they are held by their peers in Congress should prove invaluable to Mr. Clinton, who says he is determined to break the deadlock between the White House and Capitol. 
 Their intelligence and political skill aside, neither Mr. Bentsen nor Mr. Panetta has concentrated on developing views about preparing for the economy of the 21st century. Similarly, Robert E. Rubin, the investment banker who is to be the chief economics coordinator in the White House, is said to be a smart and efficient manager, and is not known as someone who offers new ideas about the economy.
 
Painful Measures Ahead
 Mr. Clinton apparently felt he did not need philosophers right away but sought the special talent of two accomplished politicians and a highly successful Wall Street investor to win approval of the painful measures necessary to lower the budget deficit.
The President-elect has already formulated a detailed plan involving higher taxes on the wealthy, a tax cut for the middle class, an investment tax credit for business and new spending on public works projects, and he has vowed to push this package through Congress in his first 100 days in office. That does not leave much room for further policy development for a while.
Mr. Clinton almost said as much at his news conference today. He said he had chosen Mr. Bentsen to be Treasury Secretary because of the Senator's "stature, dignity and respect." He said he had picked Mr. Panetta to be budget director to win "swift and effective implementation of our economic plan."
But if he succeeds at the outset, Mr. Clinton presumably will then begin to "chart a new course in the world economy," as he promised in his election campaign. How, for example, can American industries compete better with those of Europe and Japan? How should schools and job-training programs be improved? What steps will be needed in the next decade to prepare for a time early in the next century when the country has a much higher ratio of retired people to workers than it does now?
Mr. Clinton addressed such matters in broad brush during the campaign, but Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Panetta, perhaps because of their legislative responsibilities, have tended to look at economic issues more narrowly.
Mr. Bentsen's foremost initiative in the last few years has been to advocate a tax break to encourage upper-income taxpayers to save money. Whatever the merits of the Texan's proposal, no one thinks it would result in a fundamental change in the economy.
Mr. Panetta is one of the few lawmakers who have consistently argued that most Americans should pay higher taxes and relinquish Government benefits to lower the Federal budget deficit. But the California Congressman has rarely addressed the longer range question of what should be done once the deficit problem is licked.
 
In Line for Labor
 The economic philosopher among the Clinton insiders is Robert B. Reich, the head of the economics transition team. Mr. Reich (it is pronounced Reish) was not included in the first round of announcements today, but Clinton aides say he will be named Secretary of Labor. Mr. Reich, by virtue of being a close friend of Mr. Clinton, will probably be an influential force in the new Administration.
As Mr. Clinton selects people for top jobs in other areas where his campaign promises were less explicit and action less urgent than on the economy, he will be looking more for people he considers capable of developing broad approaches to policy questions -- visionaries, some of his advisers say.
That will be especially important in foreign affairs, where Mr. Clinton is on less familiar ground than he is with economic issues and where he will have the chance like no other President since Harry S. Truman to establish policies reflecting a completely changed world.
Boldness will also be needed in health care, where Mr. Clinton has promised to revamp the current system so that costs are controlled and everyone can get affordable insurance.
 
Turning to the Familiar
 But today, the spotlight was not on foreign policy or the medical system but on the economic choices and on the particular views, talents and liabilities of the people Mr. Clinton is putting into the top jobs.
George Bush, whose own background is in business, relied for economic counsel largely on advisers with a business perspective like Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, Richard G. Darman, the budget director, and John H. Sununu, his first chief of staff.
Similarly, Mr. Bentsen, Mr. Panetta and Mr. Rubin are, like Mr. Clinton, lawyers, although none have practiced law for years. By picking Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Panetta for the top two economic jobs, and by naming Mr. Rubin, Alice M. Rivlin and Roger C. Altman to other important positions, Mr. Clinton turned to the center of the economic and political spectrum.
 
A Shrinking Center
 That could be important at a time when economists and politicians on the left and the right are arguing that the budget deficit is of secondary importance and when the number at the center willing to advocate the bitter medicine needed to lower the deficit seems to be shrinking.
The new line-up of advisers may dispel the notion held in some circles here and on Wall Street that Mr. Clinton is not completely committed to reducing the deficit, a view that developed because the President-elect has never said specifically what sacrifices he would ask Americans to make. But today's announcement will do little to reassure critics who hoped Mr. Clinton would look beyond Washington and Wall Street for his economic advice.
Mr. Bentsen has such stature as his party's Vice-Presidential nominee in 1988 and as the chairman of the most important committee in the Senate that he is almost certain to restore to the Treasury the influence the Department had when John B. Connally was Treasury Secretary in the Nixon Administration and when James A. Baker 3d held the post in Ronald Reagan's second term. Mr. Clinton made it clear at his news conference this afternoon that Mr. Bentsen would be his chief lieutenant on economic matters.
In the Bush Administration, Mr. Brady, whose political experience was limited, was generally overshadowed by Mr. Darman and others.

HEADLINE: Across the U.S., Immigrants Find the Land of Resentment

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
On her way home from school recently, a Chinese immigrant girl was attacked by other teen-agers who spray-painted her face black. She and her guidance counselors at the Seward Park High School in lower Manhattan were horrified, but they were not shocked. Attacks on newly arrived immigrants are a routine occurrence at their school, they said.
Similarly, a Salvadoran dishwasher, assaulted and robbed recently on his way into a money-transfer agency in Hempstead, L.I., was frightened but not surprised by the message of his assailants, who were black: "You steal our jobs, we steal your money." Tensions had been building between the entrenched black community and the Central American newcomers to the town. 
 And on Staten Island, when a group of junior high school students repeatedly vandalized the house of Indian immigrants, smashing windows and splattering blue paint on the facade, the final message, chalked on the driveway, was sadly predictable to the family. "Indians go home," it said. "Leave or die."
Across the country, immigrants say they are feeling the brunt of a growing and complex hostility, the same kind of antagonism that has cropped up periodically in United States history. As their numbers increase sharply and the recession lingers, immigrants find themselves the target of a mix of social anxieties: economic tension, free-floating anger seeking an outlet and the volatile ethnic discord plaguing many cities. And because most new immigrants are not white, there are racial overtones to the friction.
Even in New York, which proudly defines itself as a haven for immigrants, the "gorgeous mosaic" of diverse populations, as Mayor David N. Dinkins calls it, has its chips. Some New Yorkers, particularly those down on their luck, seem to resent the presence of so many immigrants, as if the American dream were in danger of becoming the exclusive province of newcomers.
"Unfortunately, immigrant-bashing is no longer an unpopular activity," said Dennis deLeon, the city's Human Rights Commissioner. "I sense that immigrants are being scapegoated for a lot of our problems. A certain kind of xenophobic bigotry has come out of the closet."
Most advocates for immigrants stress, however, that the United States remains markedly tolerant compared with those Western European nations now grappling with surging hostility and violence toward foreigners. And while they acknowledge that the historically explosive mix of record numbers of immigrants and a weak economy has generated undeniable frictions, immigration experts do not anticipate a return to the vehement nativism that followed World War I, or the overt hatred of the 1890's.
Most of the present antagonism is expressed in words, not violent acts, and most of the words are not reported to the authorities, immigrants and their advocates say. Rosa Perales, an immigrant from Mexico who sells flowers at an intersection in the Bronx, said drivers routinely spit at her and tell her to return to her country. And Sarah Benyaminova, a Russian refugee, said the antagonism she encountered while waiting in line at a bank in Queens last week was typical.
"I was staying in the line and we had some brief discussion about the candidate who became President," said Ms. Benyaminova, who runs the Russian Educational Bilingual and Cultural Association. "The lady who was standing behind me said, 'You better shut up because you came to this country and everything was given you for free.' I said: 'Oh, yeah? I'm working very hard from dawn to dawn. Could you point me out where I could get all this free lunch?' "
It is difficult to quantify anti-immigrant sentiment. New York City's police statistics on bias complaints do not even have a separate category for bias against immigrants. And the line between xenophobia and ethnic or racial hatred is a blurry one. Was the Seward Park High School student attacked because she was Asian or because she was a vulnerable newcomer? (Probably for both reasons.)
Further, most immigrants, and particularly illegal immigrants, do not make official complaints. For instance, M. K. Srinivasan, New York bureau chief for The Indian-American Magazine, told of a Sikh friend who said he was followed off a New York City bus recently by teen-agers who forcibly removed his turban and set it on fire. But he did not call the police because he was new to the country from India and feared they would be unreceptive.
Many advocates for immigrants believe that resentment toward immigrants built gradually in the late 1980's as the economy began to falter and as immigration reached its highest level since the early part of the century.
 
In U.S., Some Sticks, More Harsh Words
 This year as many as a million new refugees and immigrants, will enter the United States. And, if patterns from the 1980's hold, about 15 percent will settle in the New York metropolitan area. Nationally, a majority are from Mexico and Asian countries; in New York, the majority hails from the Caribbean and Latin America.
"It is not a coincidence that as the immigrant pool has darkened, hostility has grown," said Rolando T. Acosta, New York City's First Deputy Commissioner of Human Rights.
Across the country, there are a few extreme examples of anti-immigrant hostility. In Houston, for instance, two skinheads stomped a 15-year-old Vietnamese boy, Hung Truong, to death in late 1990. One of the assailants -- convicted of involuntary manslaughter while his partner was convicted of murder -- testified that Mr. Truong, dying, cried out: "God forgive me for coming to this country. I'm so sorry."
But some experts wonder whether the current problem is being exaggerated, whether some advocates for immigrants, shaken by the events in Germany and the nativist oratory of some American political candidates, have become hypersensitive to prejudicial slights that have always existed.
 
Nativism Used In Political Campaigns
 Nonetheless, in the last year and a half, political candidates, lobbyists, academics and writers who oppose current levels of immigration have capitalized on the frustration of some Americans. They have not advocated violence. "It was more a climate of hostility that was being created," said Frank Sharry, executive director of the National Immigration, Refugee and Citizenship Forum.
Two politicians, Patrick Buchanan and David Duke, made nativism a key element of their campaigns, with a particular concern that new immigrants would "dilute," as Mr. Buchanan said, the country's European character. Then this summer, a spate of magazine articles raised questions about the value of immigrants to American society -- questions rarely voiced publicly in this land of immigrants.
The articles not only explored the idea of restricting immigration but of placing a moratorium on new immigrants, who were blamed for displacing Americans from jobs, draining scarce Government resources, and even worsening the smog in Los Angeles.
The riots in Los Angeles and Washington Heights, during which immigrants were denounced for inciting violence, provided further fodder for such antagonism. Advocates for immigrants steeled themselves for a public battle during the fall Presidential race.
"We were quite concerned that the anti-immigrant drum would beat so loudly that it might create a tide of xenophobia," said Mr. Sharry, whose organization collected scores of examples in a "Nativism Watch" last spring and summer.
But after the party conventions, even after the Republican Party plank called for "a barrier" -- a wall or trench -- along the border with Mexico, the issue faded. Immigration was scarcely mentioned by either George Bush or Bill Clinton. Those favoring a freeze on immigration were, however, not discouraged. "We assume that this last year has been just the beginning of a wave, and in the year to come, the justifiable backlash will solidify," said Dan Stein, executive director of the Federation for American Immigration Reform, a Washington-based group that supports a three-year freeze on most immigration.
In the metropolitan region, advocates for immigrants trace the first stirrings of a heightened antagonism to the 1986 law that created sanctions on employers who hire illegal immigrants.
"The sanctions became an excuse for people to discriminate under the cover of meeting their legal obligations," said Elizabeth Aivars, director of the New York City's Office of Immigrant Affairs.
For some New Yorkers, the employer sanctions seemed to validate their anxieties that low-paid immigrants had been stealing their jobs after all, advocates for immigrants said. And the recession only heightened those fears.
"At times, we feel like the community would just as soon put out a 'Not Welcome' mat," said Cecilia Moran, director of the Center for Central American Refugees in Hempstead, L.I. "Some people are jealous, I guess, that we are finding and keeping work."
Occasionally immigrants are willing to fight back, especially as a group. In New York City, three Egyptian elevator operators at the Museum Tower condominium filed a discrimination complaint after years of being harassed by a supervisor who called them "camel jockeys" and threatened to have them sent back to Egypt.
An administrative law judge, Linda A. Stagno, found they were subjected to a consistent barrage of slurs, awarded them $10,000 each in damages.
Similarly, several Hispanic immigrant cleaning women working nights at office buildings in Manhattan won damages after complaining that they were pressured to have sex by supervisors who threatened them with deportation.
But some immigrants, tired of being harassed, try to accommodate their offenders. Navpreet Satara, a 27-year-old immigrant from New Dehli, now avoids conflicts by wearing a baseball cap instead of a turban to cover his hair when he goes out on the town or to the beach. He is sick of being called "Ayatollah," "Saddam Hussein" or "Hare Krishna," he said.
A couple of years ago, when he was a graduate student at Temple University in Philadelphia, he arrived late at a college basketball game and as he was crossing the court to the bleachers a spectator rose and shouted, "Ali Baba." Then the entire crowd rose to their feet and chanted "Ali Baba, Ali Baba," he said.
"There is a lot of ignorance, I guess, and insecurity about all these people who come to America and hold onto their identity with pride," Mr. Satara said.
 
In New York City, A Different Climate
 Unlike in California, where mainstream politicians of both parties have blamed immigrants for the state's economic woes, it remains virtually taboo for public figures in New York to question the value of immigrants in society. There is usually an instant uproar.
For example, Hazel N. Dukes, the New York State president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was quickly pushed to issue an apology when she remarked in a radio interview in 1990 that black men have lost jobs to immigrants who do not speak English.
Similarly, in 1991, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, executive minister of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, appeared on the WABC-TV program "Tiempo" and suggested stopping "the influx of people into this city," adding "if it must come to this nation, send it elsewhere." But outrage began to build immediately, and Mr. Butts was quick to praise immigrants in opinion columns for El Diario and The Carib News.
And when City Councilman Jerome X. O'Donovan of Staten Island wrote the city's Office of Immigrant Affairs to suggest that the Immigration and Naturalization Service be asked to "identify and/or deport illegal aliens" who were a "strain on the economy," Mr. Dinkins sent a stern letter in response, remarking that all immigrants were a part of his "gorgeous mosaic."
Compared with other large city governments, the Dinkins administration takes an unusually strong advocacy position for immigrants, which many immigrants say sets a tone for public debate and prevents some confrontrations from escalating. For example, when residents of Woodside, Queens, complained about the immigrant laborers who hang out in their streets waiting for daily jobs, the city's Human Rights Commission found a church parking lot for their pickup point and made T-shirts for them saying "Trabajadores Unidos," or United Workers.
But public officials in New Jersey have not been so quick to defend immigrants, advocates for immigrants say. Responding to public outrage that illegal immigrants were allowed to obtain driver's licenses, the New Jersey Legislature is moving to forbid them licenses. The New Jersey Legislature also recently eliminated general assistance benefits -- $140 a month plus some medical benefits -- to illegal immigrants.
In response to antagonism, most immigrants choose to avoid confrontation at all costs.
"What can you do if the Americans laugh at you on the subway or look at you like you're an animal or insult you?" said Jonathan Lee, a Vietnamese refugee and caseworker at the New York Association for New Americans. "You must keep quiet and get away from them fast."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The tension between entrenched minorities and newcomers is nearly as old as the country, but immigrants to the United States find the hostility particularly sharp in times of economic distress. In an effort to fit in and avoid conflict, Navpreet Satara often sheds his turban and dons a baseball cap when he leaves his midtown leather-coat exporting business. "There is a lot of ignorance," he said. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times) (pg. B4)
