HEADLINE: Budget Option Would Raise Gas Tax in '96

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The New Jersey Legislature and the Florio administration are studying a proposal to divert hundreds of millions of dollars from the state's Transportation Trust Fund over the next five years to balance the budget. The plan would require a 4.5-cent increase in the gasoline tax in 1996.
The proposal is the latest in a series of moves to divert money to the general fund to meet budget shortfalls without appearing to raise taxes, by tapping the bonding authority of various funds. 
 Under the plan, during the budget year that ends on June 30, 1993, the Legislature would reduce the state's appropriation to the Transportation Trust Fund by $176 million, cutting it from $331 million to $155 million.
That money would go into a surplus category and could be used to finance a growing list of supplemental appropriations bills passed by the Legislature to repair a budget that is increasingly out of balance. As much as $150 million is needed to meet a shortfall in the Medicaid budget, $20 million for corrections and another $20 million for general assistance.
 
Fund Would Need Help Sooner
 In the budget year that begins on July 1, 1993, the plan calls for reducing the appropriation for the Transportation Trust Fund from $331 million to $175 million and diverting $156 million to the general fund.
The reduced appropriations would mean that the Transportation Trust Fund, set up in 1984 to provide the state's share of capital transportation projects' costs, would have to be replenished sooner than expected.
Since the fund is supported by a 2.5-cents-a-gallon gasoline tax, the tax would have to be increased much earlier than anticipated.
The original trust fund plan called for consistent state appropriations of $331 million each year, and no increase in the gasoline tax was anticipated until 1998, when an increase of 3 cents was planned.
 
43 Percent State Tax Rise
 Under the alternative now being discussed, an increase would be necessary in 1996, and it would be larger, raising the tax to 7 cents a gallon.
The total state gasoline tax, including the trust fund part, is 10.5 cents a gallon and would rise to 15 cents a gallon under the latest proposal, a 43 percent increase.
The plan being considered by Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat, and the Republican leaders in the Legislature is similar to a proposal by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to take $516 million from a transportation fund to balance New York State's 1993-94 budget.
New Jersey has turned to such proposals repeatedly in the last year to avoid politically unpalatable tax increases. Earlier this week, the Florio administration unveiled a bond refinancing plan that the State Treasurer, Samuel F. Crane, said would take advantage of lower interest rates, but would also allow the state to pay some of its debts by borrowing more money through bonds to pay the annual debt on existing bonds.

HEADLINE: Lithuania Seeks a Niche in High Technology

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

DATELINE: VILNIUS, Lithuania

 BODY:
Under the eyes of Russia's 107th Division and beset by countless other unwelcome remnants of the Soviet era, Lithuanian scientists, engineers and would-be business leaders are gambling on advanced technology to gain entrance to the industrialized world.
Once a major supplier of specialized military and industrial technology to the Soviet Union, Lithuania has lost most of its traditional Soviet-bloc markets while being forced to pay skyrocketing prices for oil, natural gas and other essentials. 
 For scientists formerly under the wing of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and its amply funded institutes, the change has been particularly hard. Many must hold second and third jobs to survive, and laboratories have obtained little or no new equipment during the two years of independence.
"The American Chemical Society at present is sending us all its journals free, which is a tremendous help," said Algirdas Vaskelis, director of the Lithuanian Institute of Chemistry. "But most scientists here are not so lucky."
In a sprawling industrial compound on the outskirts of Vilnius, built in the 1960's by the Soviet military establishment and still partly occupied by the Russian Army, Lithuanian administrators and scientists are designing computer components, developing new compounds for chemical research and preparing to undercut Japan in the production of high-quality medical instruments.
It is a painful process. Hallways are kept dark to save electricity, and even in five-story buildings many of the elevators have long ceased to run.
But despite all this, some voices for change exude optimism, and some very advanced research is in progress.
Viktoris V. Vasilionkaitis, a physician who directs the Lithuanian branch of Soveta-Baltica, a joint venture of Lithuanian, Polish and Italian partners, has published many papers on cardiovascular disease in Western medical journals. He is preparing to make and sell a range of clinical instruments, including heart catheters, clinical pumps and machines to administer medication automatically.
"We have a well-educated and skilled population in Lithuania," he said, "and wages here are low. Even by paying employees double the national average, we feel we can make and sell high-quality pumps costing only one-third what the Japanese sell them for." The average wage is equivalent to $30 a month.
The Government has provided money to Dr. Vasilionkaitis's enterprise and granted it two years' freedom from taxes. "By then, we'll be swimming or we shall have sunk," he said.
The most dramatic success story has been at Fermentas, a biotechnology enterprise founded by Arvidas Janulaitis.
Dr. Janulaitis and his colleagues, who began in 1975 by giving their products free to fellow scientists, now run a business earning $500,000 a year and employing 110 people, including 20 scientists.
Their products are restriction enzymes and related substances, which are used, for example, to develop pharmaceutical products or isolate the genetic material that enables certain bacteria to break down and metabolize oil spills.
The Fermentas group has explored many natural enzymes, including rare soil bacteria found in nearby fields, and now offers one of the larest selections of biological-engineering compounds in the world. Fermentas sells some products through an American company, New England Biolabs, a branch of A.T.&T. Bell Laboratories.
Viginius Siksnys, a senior chemist at Fermentas, said that the company's equipment was relatively simple and cheap, but that its products, mostly derived from bacterial cultures, were valuable.
Holding up a plastic vial the size of a thimble, he pointed to its contents -- a few drops that looked like pure water. "Could you guess that we sell this one for $240, and that many scientists are eager to buy it?" he said.
"I think a lot of Lithuanian enterprises now starting out will have a hard time at first, but I think we'll pull through, individually and as a nation," he added.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: Man in the News -- Lloyd Millard Bentsen Jr.;
Insider for the Treasury

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Lloyd Bentsen is almost everything Bill Clinton is not. He is a multimillionaire, languid and almost aloof, calm and not intensely driven. He got his political start proclaiming his record as a decorated bomber pilot.
Even their respective morning running routines reflect the basic symbolic difference between them. The President-elect jogs on the streets. The Secretary of the Treasury-designate stays indoors, on a treadmill. 
 As the consummate Senate insider, beloved of lobbyists, whom he once charged $10,000 in contributions for a monthly breakfast meeting (canceled after protests), the 71-year-old chairman of the Senate Finance Committee represents a lot of the things Bill Clinton ran against.
But as an expert Senate deal-broker who knows the tax laws thoroughly and is respected by almost all Senators regardless of party, he also represents Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to end the logjam and get things accomplished in Washington. The last tax bill he handled had Senate Republicans joining him in an unsuccessful campaign to get President Bush not to veto the bill.
 
Selection by Dukakis
 The same dignified mien that helps Mr. Bentsen "to command the respect of Wall Street," as Mr. Clinton said today, appealed to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in 1988, when he chose him to run for Vice President.
And the combination of his appearance, his record and his demolition of Dan Quayle that year in a Vice-Presidential debate when he said, "I knew Jack Kennedy; you're no Jack Kennedy," led many of his friends to urge him to seek the Democratic nomination this year. But like many politicians better known than Mr. Clinton, he declined to run against a President whose popularity had soared in 1991.
He acknowledged in an interview this March, when Mr. Clinton was struggling, that he often wondered if he had made the right decision. He was tempted to jump in, and speculated about what might happen if no candidate reached the convention in New York with a majority of the delegates.
But he never seemed as excited about a race as his friends were. Plainly comfortable in the Senate, he would shift political conversations to a pending piece of legislation and say, "That's what I hired on to do."
 
Defender of Oil Interests
 The Texans who sent him to the Senate four times, starting in 1970, have found him a reliable defender of such specific state interests as the oil and gas industry and international trade, including the pending North American Free Trade Agreement, which is expected to improve the economy of border areas near the Rio Grande, where he was born in Mission, Tex., on Feb. 11, 1921.
But Mr. Bentsen has also been a central supporter of tax preferences of real estate, an industry important not merely to Texas, and an unrelenting advocate of greatly expanding access to tax-free Individual Retirement Accounts.
Like any Finance Committee chairman, he has never had trouble raising lots of campaign money. He has something of a reputation for being tolerant of lobbyists' pleadings. But with a narrowly balanced committee of 11 Democrats and 9 Republicans, assembling a majority usually requires matching favors and senators.
Nor is the work finished in committee. Tax bills, its main body of work, usually confront scores or hundreds of amendments on the Senate floor, and then a conference with the House. His counterpart there, Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, called the Texan "a man of great integrity who has a strong sense of pride," and said, "I think he'll be a good Treasury Secretary."
They have shared a reluctance to get out front on national health care without having their party united behind them. Some critics see Mr. Bentsen in particular as having been too committed to step-by-step changes.
And while he tried today to silence the "insider" accusation by saying he had felt like an "outsider" during 12 years of Republican Administrations when Democratic plans to fight crime, overhaul election laws and create jobs were vetoed, he is not one of the Senate's foremost partisans.
Not only do his two Republican predecessors, Bob Dole of Kansas and Bob Packwood of Oregon, praise his fairness, but Mr. Dole also recalled defending the Democrat during his 1982 campaign. The Kansan was in Texas to appear for Representative James Collins, Mr. Bentsen's Republican challenger.
"They had me set up to call him a raging liberal," Mr. Dole recalled. "But I told them that's not the case."
Then in 1992, with Mr. Bentsen's permission, Senator Dole used a friendly quotation from the Texan in one of his campaign advertisements.
 
Early Years in House
 Mr. Bentsen has really had two Congressional careers. The first lasted from 1948 through 1955, when he served in the House. He had been elected to a district on the Rio Grande after winning a Distinguished Flying Cross as a B-24 pilot in Europe. That exploit figured heavily in his campaign literature, he recalled, which was closely copied from a flier used by a former Naval officer in a 1946 Massachusetts race, John F. Kennedy. Where Kennedy had used a P.T. boat's silhouette, Mr. Bentsen used a bomber's, but the language was closely copied.
In those years, Representative Lloyd Millard Bentsen Jr. was known for opposing the poll tax and for proposing to use the atomic bomb against North Korea, a view he has long since recanted, with some embarrassment these days.
He left the House, somewhat bored and eager to make money on his own, though his father was a wealthy land-trader. He had earned a law degree at the University of Texas in 1942, but went into the insurance business, with his father's financing.
He spent 15 years there, leaving Lincoln Consolidated to run against a liberal Democratic incumbent, Ralph Yarborough, in 1970.
It was a bitter campaign. Mr. Bentsen used television commercials that showed disorder outside the 1968 Democratic National Convention and seemed to hold Mr. Yarborough responsible. He defeated Mr. Yarborough, and then defeated Representative George Bush, the Republican. Blood feuds characterized Texas politics even more in those days than they do now. The liberals worshiped Mr. Yarborough and disdained Mr. Bensten for many years as a "Tory Democrat" who was concerned about the establishment, though they gave him credit for never race-baiting, and for looking out for the interests of black and Hispanic Texans.
But in 1988, when he was chosen to run for Vice President, Mr. Bentsen resigned from two Houston clubs because of their membership policies. But he rejoined them after the election. His press secretary, Jack DeVore, said on Wednesday that Mr. Bentsen had concluded that the River Oaks Club and the Ramada Club did not discriminate. Officials at both clubs refused to discuss their membership policies today.
Mr. Bentsen and his wife, the former Beryl Ann Longino, who is known as "B.A." live in an apartment in the Embassy area of Washington. They were married in 1943 in Lufkin, Tex. They have three grown children who live in Texas, Lloyd M. Bentsen 3d, Lan Bentsen and Tina Bentsen Smith.
Mr. Bentsen has been known occasionally to exit from parties by hoisting his wife over his shoulder and carrying her out. But last year he broke one of her ribs doing that and has said he has given up the practice.
John White, a former Democratic national chairman and a close friend of Mr. Bentsen for more than 40 years, today recalled recently declining an invitation to the movies with the Bentsens because he had already seen the film. He said Mr. Bentsen told him the next day "B.A. said you'll never cut it in this town if you turn down a chance to do a movie with the chairman of the Finance Committee just because you've seen it."
Mr. White got the message. "I'll go to a movie with the Secretary of the Treasury," he said today, "even if I've seen it 10 times."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fell 0.2% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
In the best monthly inflation report since January, prices received by producers of finished goods fell two-tenths of 1 percent in November as energy and food unwound earlier increases, the Labor Department reported today.
At the same time, the department disclosed that first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell for the eighth time in 10 weeks, achieving the lowest level on a four-week average since the latest recession -- still not officially declared over -- began in July 1990. 
 Both reports were somewhat better than expected, even allowing for the fact that the Thanksgiving holiday was a major factor in the lower jobless claims.
 
 
Praise for the Data
 "It's the best of all possible worlds," Robert T. McGee, economist for Tokai Bank in New York, said. "We've got low inflation and an improving labor market."
The relative price stability for finished goods was matched by those at the intermediate and crude levels, both sectors also posting two-tenths of 1 percent declines for November. Nor was there anything very worrisome in the so-called core rate for finished goods, which excludes the erratic food and energy components. This edged up one-tenth of 1 percent last month after easing that amount in October and stood just 2 percent above the level for November 1991.
The encouraging price figures were seen by analysts as providing some additional leeway for the incoming Clinton Administration to pep up the economy with fiscal medicine that otherwise would risk unpleasant inflationary side effects. The Federal Reserve is also likely to be reassured, though most analysts believe that the central bank will make no change in monetary policy when its Open Market Committee conducts its final 1992 meeting just before Christmas.
"There's no inflation in the pipeline at all," David W. Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, said.
Friday's report on consumer prices is expected to be almost as good as today's but is likely to show some increase because it, unlike the producer price indexes, includes health care and other services as well as imported goods.
 Finished energy goods dropped 1.5 percent at the producer level last month as prices for gasoline and residential electricity turned down after October jumps. Heating oil dropped 11.8 percent, far more than October's 1 percent decline. Partly offsetting these, however, was a 2.2 percent rise for residential natural gas that was bigger than in October.
In food, which posted a five-tenths of 1 percent overall decline, the main factor was a 33.2 percent plunge for fresh and dry vegetables that followed a 27 percent October surge. Among the most dramatic tumbles were 67.4 percent for cucumbers, 59.1 percent for lettuce and 46.7 percent for radishes.
Beef and veal turned down following an October rise, but eggs turned up sharply. Fruit and melon prices rose considerably more than in October, the report showed.
Elsewhere, passenger cars climbed 1 percent after falling 2.3 percent in October while tobacco products and prescription drugs partly reversed October rises.
Among goods at the intermediate stage, like a bolt of cloth, a 1 percent decline in energy helped push the index lower. Durable factory materials, however, fell much less than in October while prices of foods and feeds turned up in November following an October decline.
Hot rolled steel bars and flat glass edged up while copper and copper and brass mill shapes fell less rapidly. Aluminum mill shapes, lead, plywood and primary aluminum all declined.
Nondurable factory materials edged down one-tenth of 1 percent with declines paced by paperboard, processed yarns, plastic resins and gray fabrics. Basic organic chemicals, however, rose considerably.
 
 
Construction Materials
 After showing no change in October, construction materials rose two-tenths of 1 percent on increases for softwood lumber and for millwork, concrete and plastic products.
Over all, intermediate materials excluding food and energy were unchanged last month, the third in a row without any price increase.
For crude goods, slaughter broilers rose 4.9 percent following a 26.7 percent October jump, but raw cotton rose seven-tenths of 1 percent after an 11.8 percent October plunge.
Crude goods excluding food and energy fell nine-tenths of 1 percent compared with a 1.3 percent decline in October.
Today's report was "really a superb result," Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist for Morgan Stanley, said, noting a further ratcheting downward of prices since summer. "There's just no price pressure out there."

HEADLINE: For Crown Hts. Figure, a Life on Streets

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
Ralph Nimmons is missing. But for the 25-year-old man at the center of the Crown Heights beating case, that is nothing new.
Mr. Nimmons, whose absence has threatened the grand jury investigation into his beating by Hasidim, has long drifted on the streets into and out of sight, his wife, Debbie, said the day he was beaten. Jobless and unable to support his family, he makes money by foraging for discarded clothing, bottles and cans, visiting his wife's home in Queens occasionally to change his clothing and then leaving again for days. 
 "Basically, he was a hustler in the streets," but not a burglar, said Mrs. Nimmons, who was introduced to him over the phone by a friend while he was in jail at the Rikers Island complex. "Whatever he could sell he would sell."
According to Mrs. Nimmons, her husband has often made his living off the streets, even as a youth helping his single mother, who reared him and two younger brothers in Brooklyn. His mother died when he was 16.
The Nimmonses were married on May 25, 1990, after knowing each other for about five months. Their romance was not conventional, Mrs. Nimmons said. She first met him while he was on Rikers Island after a friend of hers, also on Rikers, introduced them over the telephone. She became interested in the stranger on the other end of the line. "It was like a blind date," she said.
After they married, Mr. Nimmons moved in with her and her four children at her mother's two-family house in South Jamaica, Queens.
 
He Couldn't Find Work
 He had trouble finding work, she said, and bounced around from one job to another: a handyman for a beauty salon, selling clothing as a street vendor, passing out fliers and working with a construction crew in Brooklyn.
In May he was jailed for violation of parole and was released in October, Mrs. Nimmons said. Unemployed, Mr. Nimmons began living on the streets, in part because he felt he couldn't provide for his family the "way he wanted to."
Mrs. Nimmons, a certified medical assistant, wound up providing for the family.
Mr. Nimmons has a record of six convictions on charges including robbery, burglary, weapons possession and use of drug paraphernalia, according to a city law-enforcement official.
Hasidic leaders point to that arrest record as support for their claim that several Hasidic men only tried to detain Mr. Nimmons after he had been caught trying to break into a rabbinical school behind the Lubavitch headquarters.
Mrs. Nimmons said her husband has told her that on the night he was beaten he was simply scrounging behind the Lubavitch headquarters for discarded clothes to sell.

HEADLINE: University Seeks a Laboratory-Marketplace Link

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The president of the University of California today proposed the creation of a for-profit corporation to help bridge the gap between the laboratory and marketplace for technology developed by university researchers.
Under the proposal, the university's Board of Regents would control a 51 percent stake in the for-profit company. The remaining shares would be sold to corporate and individual investors. The university would contribute technology, and money would come from foundation grants, gifts and outside investors. 
 The university is also asking the State of California to give up its 25 percent share of the university's fees from patents and licenses so it could be applied to the corporation.
Although a handful of other universities have taken similar steps in recent years through the creation of venture capital funds, university officials said the corporation would be the first of its kind dedicated to such early stage technology. Experts on the development and transfer of technology say the move redefines the traditional role of the university.
"The university is sort of the ground on which two large public policy issues collide," said Gary W. Matkin, an associate dean at the University of California's continuing education program, University of California Extension, and author of "Technology Transfer and the University." "One calls for the university to be more involved in the economic life of the state, while the other wants it to maintain its objective stance and not be pulled into the marketplace."
 
Proposal Discussed for 3 Years
 The university president, Jack W. Peltason, presented the proposal to the regents as the centerpiece of a set of initiatives intended to help invigorate the state's lackluster economy.
University officials have discussed the possibility of such a program for at least three years, but today's proposal was made just weeks after a group of state lawmakers sent a letter to Mr. Peltason asking him to consider steps the nine-campus university system could take to exert a greater influence on the economic life of California.
"I am launching an effort to more effectively deploy the brainpower of this university in direct service of the people of California," Mr. Peltason said. "We have a responsibility to put the knowledge of our faculty to work for society."
Officials say the university has at least 160 patented processes or products that promise significant public benefit. These have not been commercialized because traditional sources of financing consider them in too early a stage of development. A central purpose of the corporation would be to provide financing to develop a commercial prototype that could then be picked up by industry.
For instance, university researchers have developed a way to remove cholesterol from milk without affecting the taste or consistency. Before a company will spend the money for the rights to that process, it wants to know if it will work in its factory, not just in a university laboratory. To do that takes time and money that most investors are not willing to risk.
Through the proposal made today, university officials said they expect income from patent fees and royalties to increase to $222 million a year by 2001, up from a projected $26.9 million this year.
Officials said they hope the corporation would be in place by March 1993. A companion not-for-profit corporation would also be created to handle the logistics of the university's patent and licensing activities. The proposal must still travel through a set of committees before returning to the regents for a final vote.
Some faculty members in the past have expressed their fear that a pursuit of profits will compromise the university's mission of teaching and research. Others, though, are frustrated by the delays they see in turning their research into real products that could benefit the public.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: An Eye Toward Wall Street and Capitol Hill;
Clinton's Budget Office Will Differ From Bush's in Both Style and Substance

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The Office of Management and Budget may remain an army of bean counters with eye shades under Leon E. Panetta and Alice M. Rivlin, President-elect Bill Clinton's choices as budget director and deputy budget director. But it will be a far different place than it was under the current budget director, Richard G. Darman.
For all his talk about the evils of the Federal deficit, Mr. Darman presided over years of record deficits. Mr. Panetta and Ms. Rivlin are known as deficit hawks. Indeed, during the campaign each criticized Mr. Clinton's budget plan as not being tough enough on the string of $300 billion deficits projected for the years ahead. 
 Mr. Darman is known as much for his arrogance as for his brilliance, and he spent much of his time browbeating Democrats in Congress.
Mr. Panetta, a Democratic Representative from California, is expected to play the friendly shepherd, nudging and cajoling former colleagues to enact Mr. Clinton's potpourri of tax cuts, tax increases and new spending programs.
 
'Tremendously Strong Team'
 Budget directors usually eclipse their deputies, but Mr. Clinton's aides say that Mr. Panetta and Ms. Rivlin will divide the labor. Ms. Rivlin, a respected economist who was the first director of the Congressional Budget Office, the legislative counterpart of the executive branch's O.M.B., will do a lot of the technical work, while Mr. Panetta, chairman of the House Budget Committee, does the heavy political lifting.
"It's a tremendously strong team," said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office. "You have two people strongly committed to deficit reduction, two people who are extremely knowledgeable on the details of the Federal budget, one who brings economic expertise and an academic perspective and another who brings the political dimension."
The primary charge of the Office of Management and Budget is shaping the Federal budget. It reviews requests for spending from Federal agencies and works with them in developing programs that will be reflected in the budget request the President sends to Congress. It also seeks to hold down their costs and tries to make the bureaucracy more efficient.
Under President Jimmy Carter, the O.M.B. started reviewing Federal rules and pressured agencies not to overregulate. It performed this task aggressively under President Ronald Reagan, when David Stockman and then James C. Miller 3d were budget directors, and far less vigorously under President Bush, during Mr. Darman's tenure.
One thing seems clear: Mr. Panetta will play a less important role in policymaking than Mr. Darman, who through his forcefulness and the absence of other strong voices on budget issues became the Bush Administration's most powerful voice in economic policymaking. With his strong views and extraordinary command of budget details, Mr. Darman turned the agency into a potent force that reached into every nook of the Government.
Asserting that President Bush stood on the sidelines when it came to the economy, Mr. Clinton has promised to be the first-string quarterback on economic policy. Mr. Panetta will be one of the backs, called on to carry the ball through the House and Senate. And unlike Mr. Darman, he is expected to bounce ideas off key members of Congress before the President's policies are set in concrete.
"Leon is well liked by virtually everybody on the Hill," said Mr. Reischauer. "He can push and cajole his former colleagues as Dick Darman never could."
 
Human Lightning Rods
 Still, there are plenty of areas where the Panetta-Rivlin team could soon find themselves in hot water.
Since the "M" in O.M.B. stands for managing the budget and the bureaucracy, Mr. Panetta and Ms. Rivlin may have to shoulder the burden of implementing Mr. Clinton's campaign pledge to cut administrative expenses by 3 percent a year and to cut 100,000 of the 3 million Federal workers.
Mr. Panetta and Ms. Rivlin have long urged deeper cuts in mandatory entitlement programs like Medicare, and that could quickly make them lightning rods for Congressional ire. And because many interest groups are eager to get a larger piece of the pie with the Democrats back in power, Mr. Panetta will probably have to slam the door on some old friends.
Four years as Budget Committee chairman seem to have prepared Mr. Panetta for this role. He once boasted it was an "enforcement committee."
The Monterey native is also frugal in his private life. He shared a tiny townhouse in Washington with four other Congressmen, and he uses frequent-flyer miles for much of his official travel.
Mr. Panetta, 54, was a Republican in his youth and worked for former Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York. He reportedly became a Democrat after President Richard M. Nixon dismissed him for being too vigorous as head of the Federal civil rights office. He was elected to the House 16 years ago.
This year, he led the campaign against a balanced budget amendment, calling it a gimmick that did not require members to make tough decisions to slash he deficit.
Ms. Rivlin, 61, showed a liberal bent for greater social spending while holding several positions in the Johnson Administration, but she showed she could be a solid, neutral economist as head of the Congressional Budget Office from 1975 to 1983.
A Radcliffe graduate, she is a fellow at the Brookings Institution and teaches economics at George Mason University.
Her recent book, "Reviving the American Dream," (Brookings Institution, 1992) conflicts with some of Mr. Clinton's philosophy in urging that states be given responsibility for managing and financing economic development programs, like job training and transportation spending. The book calls for a consumption tax, suggesting that revenues should be shared by Washington and state governments.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Norway Lets Crown Float, Adding to Strains in Europe

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Norway today abandoned its long battle to maintain the value of its currency and allowed the crown to float, putting new strains on Europe's monetary system.
Norway's decision came as leaders of the European Community prepared to gather for a two-day summit meeting in Scotland, starting on Friday, at which they will try to salvage their plans for greater political and economic cooperation, including the creation of a single currency. 
 Norway is not a member of the community, but has applied to join and was voluntarily keeping the crown at a semi-fixed rate against Europe's leading currencies. In recent weeks, it has sharply raised interest rates and used central bank reserves to buy crowns in attempts to bolster the currency's value.
With the Government no longer defending it, the crown's value immediately fell about 5 percent today.
 
 
Pressure From German Rates
 For months, high German interest rates have made the mark a more attractive investment than the currencies of nations with lower rates, creating greater demand for the German currency. The strength of the mark has pushed the relative values of most other European currencies to their lower allowable limits under the community's monetary system, encouraging investors to sell them.
Since September, Britain and Italy have left the community's monetary system after speculative onslaughts against their currencies, and Spain and Portugal have been forced to devalue theirs. Sweden and Finland, which, like Norway, had informally linked their currencies to the monetary system, have also allowed their currencies to fall in value.
In a signal that the strains on the European Exchange Rate Mechanism will not ease soon, Germany's central bank said today that it had decided not to lower interest rates.
Analysts said there was almost certain to be renewed pressure on weaker European currencies like the Irish pound. Denmark, the only Scandinavian nation that has not devalued its currency, will also face additional pressure in the markets, they said.
Analysts said that if progress is not made toward patching up rifts between the member nations at the European summit meeting, being held in Edinburgh, speculators may once again doubt the community's resolve to defend the currency system. In that case, they said, there may be a new round of market turmoil.
In other trading today, the United States dollar was mixed against leading currencies, rising against the German mark and falling against the yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 1.5795 marks, from 1.5725 late Wednesday, and it was quoted at 123.70 Japanese yen, down from 124.05 late Wednesday. A British pound cost $1.5540, down from $1.5660 late Wednesday.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $334.10 an ounce, up 50 cents. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $333.90, up 15 cents.

HEADLINE: California Moves to Revitalize San Francisco Bay

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10

 BODY:
After years of dispute, the state of California moved today to repair one of the worst environmental calamities in the American West: the degradation of San Francisco Bay and its estuary, which supplies drinking water to 20 million urban Californians and irrigation for millions of acres of farms.
The State Water Resources Control Board in Sacramento ordered a series of new pumping rules and water standards for the pivotal region, which is the very heart of California, spurting water across the state through massive aortic pumps. 
 The more fresh water is pumped out, the more sea water flows in to the estuary. The region's environmental decline has paralleled the great growth of California over the last generation. The salinity brought on by overpumping has not only threatened drinking water supplies but has also pushed fish species to the brink of extinction.
The board's decision goes into effect after a 45-day period for public comment. It can be challenged in court, which it apparently will be.
 
Politically Sensitive
 Given the continuing drought that grips the West, the plan is politically sensitive, since it will likely mean less water for farms, cities and industry throughout most of California. Any change in the way delta water is allocated will have economic and social effects on the furthest reaches of this state of more than 30 million residents.
The plan envisions a reduction in the amount of water taken from the delta, depending on rainfall, that will range from 800,000 acre-feet of water in average years to 1.9 million acre-feet in very dry years. In recent years, the amount of water pumped out has ranged from about 5 million to 9 million acre-feet. (An acre-foot is about 326,000 gallons, or about enough to supply two typical households for a year.)
Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, ordered the plan after an earlier one offered last year was rejected as inadequate by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency. The Federal agency had warned that it would impose its own plan if the state did not act soon to correct its violations of the Federal Clean Water Act, from excess salt that is killing fish and contaminating drinking water.
The Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta estuary, a marshy region larger than Rhode Island that feeds into San Francisco Bay, is the source of drinking water for two-thirds of California. Melting snows in the high Sierra turn into great rivers that empty into the delta. At its southern end, great pumps reverse the flow of the rivers and shunt the water into a system of reservoirs, canals and aqueducts that supply seven million acres of farmland and cities to the south and west.
 
Delicate Balancing Act
 The standards imposed today, therefore, were a balancing act. "The board is confident the standards included in this decision will successfully answer Governor Wilson's call for immediate delta protective measures while insuring a water supply sufficient for the many Californians who depend on the delta for domestic, agricultural and industrial water use," said W. Don Maughan, the chairman, who retired Dec. 1.
Environmentalists like David Behar and Gary Bobker of the Bay Institute, a watch-dog group that monitors environmental problems of the San Francisco Bay, welcomed the move as a first step.
Gregory A. Thomas, president of the Natural Heritage Institute, a San Francisco nonprofit law firm that represents groups trying to preserve the delta, said the new guidelines appear to address many of the organization's concerns. "It looks like the right set of targets," Mr. Thomas said. "Whether it's enough to make a difference for the species at risk, we are going to have to make a technical evaluation of the numbers and see."
Farm interests warned it would further damage agricultural production.
"This is just another element in increasing the uncertainty of water management in California," said Jason E. Peltier, manager of the Sacramento-based Central Valley Project Association, which represents irrigation districts that serve farmers. "This draft report clearly puts the protection of the environment at the expense of human uses."
The pumping has had devastating effects on the fish that once flourished in the bay, the delta and its tributary rivers, particularly the now endangered winter-run chinook salmon. The salmon spawns in the upper reaches of the Sacramento River north of San Francisco but many of the young are now sucked south by the pumps and killed. Striped bass, once plentiful in the bay, are also scare now, as is the Delta smelt, soon to be listed as endangered by the Federal Government.
A major question over the years has been how much salt should be Suisun Bay, where the delta feeds into the San Francisco Bay.
 
Longterm Remedy Sought
 The new standards are meant to apply for up to five years while a longer-term remedy is devised. They apply mainly to the two huge water systems that divert water from the delta, the federally run Central Valley Project and the State Water Project. The main elements are:
*Pumping will be reduced in the late winter, spring and summer, when fish are migrating, and increased in the late fall and early winter, when they are less vulnerable. Reverse flows in the western part of the delta will be limited.
*Water users will be asked to release short flows of water, called "pulses," into the rivers at certain times to help the migration of young salmon and striped bass.
*New fees will be imposed on large irrigation districts to raise up to $60 million. The money will pay for such wildlife habitats as gravel beds for fish spawning and temporary hatcheries.
*New conservation requirements will be imposed on urban users.
*The Central Valley Project, criticized for delivering too much water for farmers during drought, will be required to use more conservative methods to predict the amount of water available.
The debate over what to do about San Francisco Bay and the delta is almost two decades old, and it has brought to the surface all the tensions that are California: North vs. South, farmer vs. city, environmentalists vs. industry. Demands on it have reached the breaking point with the state's huge population increase, more than 25 percent since the 1980 census.
The water board first tackled the problem in 1978, but its plan was rejected by the state courts in 1986 as inadequate. It tried again in 1988 with a plan that would have drastically limited exports to populous and politically powerful Southern California, but that collapsed under political assault.

HEADLINE: At the Bar

BYLINE: By David Margolick

 BODY:
There are not many memorable moments in his 25 years in the Manhattan Surrogate's Court that Nathaniel Weiss has failed to record. Whether art experts were testifying in the Estate of Mark Rothko, or Al Pacino was testifying in the Estate of Lee Strasberg, or 15 workers were disrupting Estate of J. Seward Johnson, Mr. Weiss, his fingers dancing over the keyboard of his trusty stenograph, got it down.
Last May, however, something occurred that even Mr. Weiss missed documenting. In a cost-cutting measure, Matthew Crosson, chief administrator of New York's courts, replaced Mr. Weiss and 36 other court reporters in the state's Surrogates Courts with tape recorders. 
 Mr. Crosson, it is true, merely transferred Mr. Weiss and his colleagues to other local courts. But they face a far more implacable foe in New York's Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, who last month labeled stenographic reporting "an anachronism" and called for jettisoning it.
Court reporters, their views seconded by many judges and lawyers, argue that electronic recording is unreliable, cumbersome, and more costly. They note, too, that most of them, Mr. Weiss included, now use computers to transcribe their notes. But for court reporters seeking to defend their craft and preserve their jobs, Mr. Weiss himself is perhaps the best exhibit of all. For half a century, through a combination of erudition, wisdom, curiosity, conscientiousness and an insatiable love of words, he has given judges, lawyers and litigants what is by common consensus a most consistent and reliable recapitulation of reality.
Mr. Weiss is one of those increasingly rare reporters who need not spell out Brobdignagian or epimenorrhea or in pari passu phonetically until he can look them up in a dictionary. Better than just about anyone, he manages the increasingly difficult task of capturing and clarifying what decreasingly articulate lawyers and witnesses seem to say.
He is a nimble practitioner of linguistic triage, choosing what matters most when lawyers, judges and witnesses speak at once. He can understand mumbles, the jargons of various professions, the thickest Ukrainian accent. He knows whether laughter or tears or screams or italics belong in the record or whether they intrude on it. But his greatest attribute is his inconspicuousness.
By personality and temperament, Mr. Weiss's peers are no more given to hyperbole than he is. But to William Cohen, a 45-year veteran of the trade who works in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Weiss is "the finest court reporter in the English-speaking world." Befuddled periodically by some lawyerly malapropism or neologism or unintelligible burble, Mr. Cohen, like many others, invariably asks Mr. Weiss for help.
Perhaps because they rarely get the respect they deserve, court reporters stick together. They have their own clubs, their own publications, their own rituals and role models. Sometimes they are quite literally family; the profession is filled with siblings, husbands and wives, fathers and sons. Mr. Cohen's twin brother, Arnold, is also a renowned reporter; Mr. Weiss's son, Robert, works in Family Court.
In 1939, when the elder Mr. Weiss was still in Brooklyn College and the country did not quite realize it was out of the Depression, he saw shorthand as a route to a steady job. Three times, in 1958, 1959 and 1960, Mr. Weiss won the speed contest given by the National Shorthand Reporters Association. Twice he matched the mark for accuracy set in 1926 by one Martin Dupraw, who still transcribes part-time in Westchester County. After turning it down for years, in 1986 Mr. Weiss accepted the New York State Court Reporters Association's Louis Goldstein Memorial Award honoring contributions to court reporting.
His landmark 1963 guide to medical terminology, for instance, teaches reporters how, by understanding prefixes, suffixes and roots, they can differentiate between a colotomy, a colostomy, and a colectomy and handle an occasional jejunojejunostomy as well. His 1971 study of punctuation contains individual chapters on paragraphing, colons, semicolons, question marks and quotation marks, plus two chapters on different sorts of dashes and five chapters on commas.
The bar is a status-conscious breed, and throughout his career, Mr. Weiss has been largely overlooked -- or, on occasion, barked at -- by people who, for all their skills at bombast and legerdemain, may be nowhere near his intellectual equal. In no way has that, nor his professions' recent trials, diminished his enthusiasm.
"Anatole France said that 'children are the unrecognized geniuses of the world,' and reporters are the unrecognized human computers of the court system," Mr. Weiss said. "In their desire to economize, our critics are willing to throw away the baby with the bath water."

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: A Cabinet Begins to Take Shape;
Excerpts From Clinton's Announcement of Appointments to Economic Posts

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday in which President-elect Bill Clinton announced the appointment of Senator Lloyd Bentsen as Secretary of the Treasury and named other economic advisers, as recorded by News Transcripts Inc., a private transcription service: 
 PRESIDENT-ELECT BILL CLINTON Today, I have asked you here to announce the first members of our economic team. These people are seasoned, skilled, incredibly able and ready to work for the American people. I stress the word "team" because the success of our economic action agenda will depend not only on the talents of these people as individuals and those whom I will announce in the next few days, but also in their capacity to work together for the common good of all Americans.
They are deeply aware that we must not be the first generation of Americans to leave a worse economy to our children. And as I have said repeatedly, our nation faces two deficits, a budget deficit and an investment deficit.
I'm going to work my heart out with these people to construct a strong, long-term plan for economic growth, for jobs, for incomes, and to reduce our national debt.

 	 	 		. . .	 	My first appointment, intentionally, is the Secretary of the Treasury. In filling this post, I wanted someone who had the unique capacity to command the respect of Wall Street, which showing an unrelenting concern for the Americans who make their living on Main Street.
When Lloyd Bentsen agreed to serve as Secretary of the Treasury, it is safe to say I succeeded. In American politics when you say the words "stature, dignity, and respects," Lloyd Bentsen's name comes right to mind. I've known Senator Bentsen for many years, and, as a few of my folks know, I've had him in mind for this position for a long time, long before I was actually elected President.
I followed his work for years as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee; I know about the tax bills he tried to have written into law, which would have promoted more investment and less consumption; I know about the trade positions he's tried to convince our country to take which would have promoted more free trade but a tougher set of demand to open markets to American products.
But he, too, needs a team, and the team that will take the helm at the Treasury Department is truly exceptional, in part because of the creativity and quality of the person who will be appointed as deputy secretary of the Treasury, Roger Altman. Roger is a longtime friend of mine, a former assistant secretary of the Treasury, a preeminent investment banker. And he's been one of my closest economic advisers throughout this entire campaign.
As director of the Office of Management and Budget, Congressman Leon Panetta will bring integrity to this critical office and restore the confidence of the American people and their elected representatives that O.M.B. is shooting straight with the Congress and shooting straight with the American people, and doing its best to help us not only to have a responsible budget but to manage the massive American Government in a different and better way than ever before.
As chairman of the House Budget Committee, Leon Panetta brought a unique combination of strong leadership and superb technical skills. With Leon Panetta as O.M.B. director, I believe that agency can play the pivotal role we have to have it play in the swift and effective implementation of our economic plan.
I'm also delighted to announce that Alice Rivlin, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office and one of our nation's most respected budget experts, has agreed to serve as deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget. Together, Alice and Leon promise to be the most dynamic team in the history of O.M.B. and to restore the confidence of the Congress that the executive branch is going to be a responsible partner in making the budgets of this country.
Finally, I have asked Robert Rubin to serve as assistant to the President for economic policy and to help to coordinate and to direct our new Economic Council. I've created this new role, similar to that of the national security adviser in the present White House, because the coordination of our nation's economic policy is every bit as essential as the coordination of foreign policy to our long-term national security.
Bob Rubin has enjoyed a brilliant career at his firm, and has throughout manifested concern for the welfare of all Americans, and a special concern for the welfare of the inner city poor for whom he has worked as a member of the Cuomo Commission and in other contexts. This new Economic Council which I will chair embodies our commitment to make economic prosperity the top priority of this administration and to sharply focus on economic policy in the White House.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Today's appointments are just the first of many. In the coming days and before too long, we will have appointed the entire economic team and the remainder of the Cabinet. When we are done, the American people know that I mean business when it comes to our campaign commitment to promote a high way, high growth, strong and vital economy, not only for today's Americans, but for the future generations as well.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Can you tell us, who will be taking orders from whom -- Mr. Rubin from Mr. Bentsen, or Mr. Bentsen from Mr. Rubin? It's not quite clear what each one will be doing here.
PRESIDENT-ELECT CLINTON Well, I think it is quite clear. First of all, the Secretary of the Treasury will continue to be the principal economic spokesperson after the President for this Administration, just as it has traditionally occurred. Mr. Rubin's job will be very much like General Scowcroft's job on the national security side in this Administration. His job will be to coordinate, to facilitate and to provide some direction to the deliberations of our economic council.
It will be a larger group than the National Security Council because it will include not only these departments, but also some others which I have discussed with you before, like Commerce, Labor, Energy. And it is a very important job.
But in the end, I will make the ultimate decisions and be the ultimate arbiter when there has to be an arbiter. I think that if you go back to the campaign structure that we tried to provide, which really did defy past organizations because it was less hierarchical and more team work oriented, that's what I expect to provide here.
And I think that because we want to bring in more people in a more systematic way and reconcile what these departments are doing so they can reinforce and energy one another, I decided that I needed someone on the domestic side to be that sort of coordinator and facilitator but these departments, each will stand on their own. . . . The Treasury will still be the place where the President's economic views are spoken for after the President does it.
SENATOR LLOYD BENTSEN I've heard all these stories about my being an insider. Let me tell you, I felt like an outsider for 12 years. And I'm tired of the gridlock.
To do the things we've tried to do on campaign reform, do the things we tried to do on a tough crime bill, to do the things that we did in the last tax bill, to put economic incentives in there to create jobs, and to get this country moving again, and to see those kinds of things vetoed, I'm just delighted to see us be able to bring about the kind of change, to create those jobs now, with a Democratic President, a Democratic President like Bill Clinton.
I think you're going to see those hopes turn into reality. And to be able to pass those and put them into law is what I'm so pleased about.
And as far as the Secretary of the Treasury's job, I know you're probably looking for more maturity in that job. But I'll do what I can.
REPRESENTATIVE LEON E. PANETTA I think everyone that knows me as chairman of the Budget Committee and my work on the budget, we've been basically fighting the budgets that have been presented over the last 12 years concerned about the priorities that we part of those budgets, the failure to invest in our society, and the fact that they would ultimately produce the record deficits that they have produced.
So I've been fighting against those kinds of budgets in the time I've been in Congress, and I think the President-elect and I share a common commitment, not only to long-term deficit reduction, but to making the investments in education and health care and infrastructure and growth that this Administration has failed to make over the last few years.
Q. Governor Clinton, and also Senator Bentsen, for both of you, were you at all concerned in picking Senator Bentsen that his choice might lead to the loss of yet another Democratic Senate seat in Texas that might make your job of getting your program passed harder? And Senator Bentsen, did that play any part in your decision whether to take this position?
SENATOR BENTSEN Obviously that's something that would be of some concern to me. But the Democratic Party in Texas is in great shape and we have a very effective and attractive Governor who will be making that decision and that choice and who will play a major role in that campaign and I think the odds are just excellent that a Democrat will succeed me in that spot.
PRESIDENT-ELECT CLINTON I did give it some thought. It crossed my mind. I think that frankly the kind of leadership that has been provided in Texas by people like Ann Richards, Henry Cisneros, John Sharp, that they and many others have embodied the kind of new Democratic Party that we're trying to bring to the United States. And I think there's a good chance that Governor Richards will name someone senator who will have the confidence of the people of Texas. I thought about it. But I also thought that Senator Bentsen was the best choice for America for Treasury Secretary and I think the people of Texas will respond to that. But I don't think there's any reason to believe that the Democrats can't be highly competitive in that job.
Q. The Justice Department has decided not to appoint a special prosecutor in the Iraqgate case. Do you believe that there is a need for additional inquiries in that? And will you appoint, have your Justice Department appoint, a special prosecutor after you take office?
PRESIDENT-ELECT CLINTON I certainly think we need to know more about it than we now know. And what I intend to do is to appoint an Attorney General and then get a recommendation on it. And generically, let me make a statement, the special prosecutor law, as you know, either just did or is about to expire and I had to tell you, I think it should be reenacted. And I will support that.

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

 BREATH TESTS AIMED AT TRANSIT WORKERS
 The Transportation Department proposed new regulations that would make seven million transportation workers subject to on-the-job breath tests for alcohol and expand existing drug tests to include mass-transit workers. The program was mandated by Congress last year in response to a series of accidents involving alcohol, including a subway derailment in New York City in 1991 that killed five. A35.
NEW YORK CITY
 
 IMMIGRANTS MEET GROWING RESENTMENT 
 Across the country, immigrants say they are feeling the brunt of a growing and complex hostility. As their numbers increase sharply and the recession lingers, immigrants find themselves the target of a mix of social anxieties: economic tension, free-floating anger seeking an outlet and the volatile ethnic discord plaguing many cities. And because most new immigrants are not white, there are racial overtones to the friction. Even in New York, which proudly defines itself as a haven for immigrants, some seem to resent the presence of so many. A1.
 
 BATTLE OVER CURRICULUM ESCALATES
What began as provincial faceoff over what gets taught about homosexuality has mushroomed into a battle over the survival of the Chancellor and perhaps the way New York City governs its schools. News analysis, page A1.
Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez and the local board clash again over a curriculum. B2.
 
 UNCERTAINTY IN CROWN HEIGHTS INQUIRY
The Brooklyn District Attorney's office said that a grand jury would continue to investigate the case of a homeless black man who said he was beaten by Hasidic Jews in Crown Heights and whose lawyer says the man cannot now be found. But privately, investigators said the case would almost certainly be scrapped unless the man resurfaces and agrees to testify. B3.
Life on the street familiar to missing man. B3.
Faculty members at City College's School of Engineering voted to secede. B3.
 
 REGION
 
CAREFUL DEFENSE IN ASSAULT CASE
Defense lawyers in the Glen Ridge, N.J., sexual-assault trial cross-examined a mentally retarded woman, trying to show that the four defendants did not force her to perform sex acts four years ago. B5.
 
 NEW JERSEY CONSIDERS RAISING GAS TAX
The New Jersey Legislature and the Florio administration are studying a plan to divert hundreds of millions of dollars from the a state fund over the next five years to balance the budget. The plan would require a 4.5-cent increase in the gasoline tax in 1996. B5.
 
 AIDS PANEL TO URGE AGGRESSIVE PLAN
If New Jersey wants to slow the spread of AIDS, condoms should be available to all students beginning in the ninth grade and hypodermic needles sold over the counter, an advisory panel will tell Governor Florio on Friday. B5.
Unusual dispute over plan to export radioactive nuclear fuel from Shoreham. B6.

HEADLINE: A DuPont Family Father-Son Fight Goes to Court

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RADNOR, Pa., Dec. 10

 BODY:
Edgar Newbold Smith has spent the last seven years trying to extricate his son, an heir to the Du Pont chemical fortune, from the extremist political organization of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr.
But Mr. Smith, a securities analyst here, has little to show for his efforts, apart from his son's enmity. And now Mr. Smith is scheduled to stand trial in Alexandria, Va., on Federal charges that he conspired with cult specialists to kidnap his 36-year-old son, Lewis duPont Smith, so the son could be "deprogrammed," or freed from Mr. LaRouche's influence. 
 The discussions among Mr. Smith and the specialists were revealed to the authorities by a private investigator who had been hired to follow Mr. Smith's son. Eventually the authorities tape recorded 60 hours of conversations. If convicted, Mr. Smith and the three cult specialists could receive sentences ranging from probation to life in prison. The trial begins Monday.
Mr. Smith denies there was a kidnapping plan, but he does not deny that he had considered abduction. "It's just like my son is being held hostage by terrorists in Lebanon, with very much the same set of emotions," Mr. Smith said as he and his wife, Margaret duPont Smith, were interviewed at their home in this affluent Philadelphia suburb.
"When I think of all that's been lost, it's tragic," said Mrs. Smith, who accuses the LaRouche organization of turning her son against his parents, sister, two brothers and childhood friends, not to mention the Du PontChemical Company, which the son, a shareholder, says is run by gangsters.
 
Declared Incompetent
 The younger Mr. Smith lives with his wife, Andrea Diano-Smith, in the fashionable Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia. Both work as fund-raisers for the LaRouche organization. In 1985, after Mr. Smith gave $212,000 to Mr. LaRouche, a Pennsylvania court, at the family's request, declared him incompetent to manage his financial affairs. A Delaware bank was appointed to act as financial guardian of his $10 million inheritance.
The LaRouche organization, based in Leesburg, Va., raises money for political campaigns and publications that promote Mr. LaRouche's theories of international conspiracies and his extremist views on how to fight drug trafficking and revive the economy. Mr. LaRouche is serving a 15-year prison sentence in Minnesota. He and six of his fund-raisers were convicted in 1988 of conspiracy to defraud elderly contributors of $30 million.
Mr. Smith appeared, elegantly dressed, for a recent interview saying he would spend only 30 minutes with a member of the "corrupt media," but he wound up giving a 2 1/2-hour discourse on his family's "humiliating" efforts to control his life.
 
Writing a Book
 He also spoke at length about Mr. LaRouche's conspiracy theories, including one that links Queen Elizabeth 2d to the international drug trade. On his family, he said he would tell all in a book he is writing. Its title, he said, would be "Blood Feud: The Story That's Rocking the Richest Family in America."
Civil libertarians say the Smith case raises disturbing questions about the LaRouche organization, some of which have followed it since its founding. Is the group a destructive cult that preys on the elderly and the infirm? Or is it a political party whose zealous adherents sometimes get in legal trouble by soliciting money to publish their unconventional theories?
Civil libertarians are also raising new questions: Is it an expression of mental illness to contribute money to Mr. LaRouche? And should the Government prosecute the elder Mr. Smith for considering, but not committing, a crime?
 
'Spiral of Thought Control'
 Experts on cults are sharply divided in their opinions of the LaRouche organization, and Stefan Presser, legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Philadelphia, said civil libertarians are trying to keep an open mind.
Summing up his view of this case, Mr. Presser said: "The father doesn't like what the son is thinking and was considering imposing his own thoughts on the son. The irony is full circle now that the prosecutor is going after the father just for thinking about imposing his thoughts on the son. This is a kind of never-ending spiral of thought control that civil libertarians find intolerable."
Lawrence J. Leiser, the Assistant United States Attorney in Alexandria, Va., who is prosecuting the kidnapping charge, would not discuss the case, but he argued in recent court papers that many of these questions could not be resolved in court.
"The defendants will call their cult experts to say the LaRouche organization was a cult," Mr. Leiser wrote. "The Government will call its experts to say it was nothing more than a political organization. They will call their people to say 'deprogramming' works; we will call ours to say that it is ridiculous to suggest that you can 'deprogram' someone out of their political positions.
"We can listen to testimony that Lewis duPont Smith is incompetent and the defendants' 'purpose' was to save him as a result of that incompetence from an evil and corrupt political organization. The Government can call its experts to show that Lewis duPont Smith is not incompetent."
 
'Height of Irony'
 Mr. Leiser had summarized these thorny issues in an unsuccessful effort to exclude them from the trial and narrow the trial to legal issues surrounding the kidnapping itself.
The elder Mr. Smith's lawyer, John J. E. Markham 2d, said in court papers that it was "the height of irony" for Federal prosecutors to seek such a blanket exclusion because it was the United States Attorney in Alexandria that had prosecuted Mr. LaRouche in the first place.
Mr. Markham, in fact, is a former Assistant United States Attorney, and he was one of two prosecutors who handled the 1988 case against Mr. LaRouche. Mr. Markham has said in court papers that he will present the elder Mr. Smith as a father who was simply considering ways to rescue a mentally ill son from a criminal group and that he had come to no decision when he was arrested.
Judge Thomas S. Ellis of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia has decided to rule on the relevance of each issue as it comes up in the trial.
 
Accused of Fraud in 1989
 Charges similar to those in the 1988 criminal case against LaRouche were made in a 1989 civil suit against the younger Mr. Smith and several of his colleagues in the LaRouche organization. Lydia Baldasar, a 78-year-old widow in Northport, L.I., said in court papers that Mr. Smith and the others had defrauded her of $20,000 in cash and $50,000 in securities by telling her, in meetings, some of which lasted as long as seven hours, that her blue chip stocks were worthless and that the nation's banks and corporations were collapsing.
Ms. Baldasar said she was told that some of her money would be used to prevent the assassination of world leaders. The LaRouche organization settled the case by returning the woman's donation.
The younger Mr. Smith said he and his family had spent more than $1 million on court battles about his mental health. In the 1985 competency case, a state court held lengthy hearings before ruling, on basis of psychiatrists' testimony, that Mr. Smith was mentally ill, incompetent to manage his own financial affairs and prone to falling prey to others.
In his decision, Judge Lawrence Wood said that Mr. Smith had lost more than $100,000 in "ill advised" schemes involving silver mines and walnut trees, and that he had given $212,000 to the LaRouche organization, which, the court said, had "unusual, if not suspect, motives." The court appointed a financial guardian for Mr. Smith's $10 million trust fund and set his annual living allowance at $180,000.
The ruling was upheld in subsequent appeals, and the United States Supreme Court refused to hear the case in 1988.
 
All Plots, No Action
 In the current case involving the elder Smith, court papers do not suggest that a kidnapping was planned, only that Mr. Smith had seriously considered the idea and, his lawyer says, rejected it without committing any crime. But in transcripts of the Government's secretly recorded discussions, the consultants sound like characters in a Mickey Spillane mystery.
There is loose talk about a seductress, blackmail, sedative-laced drinks and the use of a motorcycle gang or mercenaries to kidnap the younger Smith and possibly his wife. There is talk about wrapping the unconscious son in a rug and putting him aboard the Smith family's 44-foot yacht for a voyage to a place where "bribery is king" and where the deprogramming would be tried.
Prosecutors say the defendants were ironing out the details of a kidnapping, a claim the elder Mr. Smith's lawyer disputes.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation and a Government informant secretly recorded the discussions, as well as telephone conversations, last summer and early fall.
 
Life Sentence Possible
 Whether the evidence proves a criminal kidnapping conspiracy will be up to the jury. If convicted, Mr. Smith, who is 66 years old, and the three other defendants face sentences of up to life in prison.
The other defendants are Galen G. Kelly, 45, of Esopus, N.Y., a specialist in cultic groups; Robert Point, 38, a lawyer from South Amboy, N.J., who has worked on cult cases with Mr. Kelly, and Donald L. Moore, 45, a former deputy sheriff in Loudoun County, Va., where the LaRouche organization has its headquarters.
The matter came to the authorities' attention in July, after Mr. Moore hired Doug Poppa, another former deputy sheriff from Loudoun County, to monitor the activities of the younger Mr. Smith in Philadelphia. Mr. Poppa informed the Federal Bureau of Investigation and became a paid Government informant. He later recorded his conversations with the defendants.
The younger Smith said he pities his father but expects him to be convicted. He said it would be "poetic justice" if his father was required to share a cell with Mr. LaRouche.
"He would set dad right in no time," he said.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

The Economy
Regulators said 1992 will be the most profitable year ever for the banking industry, contrary to expectations of 12 months ago. As a result, fewer institutions will fail in 1993 than expected. [D1.]
Prices received by producers of finished goods fell 0.2 percent in November as energy and food declined. It was the best monthly inflation report since January. [D2.] First-time claims for unemployment benefits fell for the eighth time in 10 weeks. [D2.]
 
Companies 
The F.C.C. is proposing to allocate a big block of frequencies for a new technology capable of simultaneously transmitting 49 channels of television and large volumes of data over the airwaves. This could ultimately result in services that are provided at much lower prices than cable television. [Page A1.]
Barry Diller will acquire a stake in QVC Network in hopes of converting the shopping network into a new cable venture that will be at the forefront in using new television technology. [D1.]
Allstate increased its estimated losses from Hurricane Andrew by more than 40 percent, to $2.5 billion. The move prompted Moody's to lower its financial strength ratings for the insurer. [D1.]
The S.E.C. filed insider-trading charges against Jonathan Sheinberg, the son of the president of MCA, in connection with Matsushita's acquisition of the entertainment industry giant. [D1.]
Imcera announced a shake-up of its top management and warned that its earnings growth might not meet expectations. The company's stock fell 14.6 percent. [D5.]
National Semiconductor's earnings disappointed Wall Street despite a one-time gain that enabled it to report its best quarter in eight years. The stock plunged almost 20 percent. [D5.]
Shoppers at Mervyn's stores may receive vouchers worth nearly $6 million because of a settlement of a lawsuit that contended that the retailer had violated a California privacy statute. [D5.]
Rockefeller Center Properties will cut its quarterly dividend because of Manhattan's "unfavorable real estate climate." [D5.]
Frequent fliers are being invited to bid mileage in an auction of 40 unusual travel experiences offered by Continental Airlines. [D5.]
BMW was reprimanded by the New York State Attorney General for advertisements that he called misleading. [D17.]
The National Hockey League voted to expand with a team in Anaheim, Calif., to be owned by Disney and a Miami team to be owned by the chairman of Blockbuster Entertainment. [B7.]
 
Markets
The stock market retreated despite positive economic news. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been up 47.28 points in the four preceding sessions, fell 11.62 points, to 3,312.19. [D6.]
New municipal bond issues will set a record this year in terms of dollar value, the Public Securities Association said. The bonds are expected to total 36 percent more than in 1991. [D13.]
Norway allowed the crown to float, abandoning a long battle and putting new strains on Europe's monetary system. [D14.]
Soybean futures rallied to their highest levels since July. [D14.]
 
 Today's Columns
The preferred stock of T.W.A. has almost quadrupled amid rumors that Lee Iacocca may join the company, but the shares are soon likely to be worthless. Kurt Eichenwald: Market Place. [D6.]
If Lee Iacocca were a brand, he would rank high, among the top 200, in terms of his advertising impact. Advertising. [D17.]
