HEADLINE: Piermont Prospers From Makeover on the Hudson;
Location, Location, Woody and Mia Aid Transformation From Factories to Galleries

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PIERMONT, N.Y., Dec. 5

 BODY:
Howard Brawner vividly remembers the day in 1983 when he pointed his camera out his living-room window and captured Mia Farrow daubing on some makeup outside his family's home on Piermont Avenue.
Oddly enough, he may have recorded a pivotal moment in the comeback of this tiny Rockland County village. 
 Long an isolated, two-mill town, Piermont fell down hard in 1982 after its paper and cardboard factories shut down, eliminating about 1,000 jobs and testing the town's spirit.
Now Piermont is thriving again, having reinvented itself as a charming collection of upscale galleries, specialty shops and fine restaurants set against the serene backdrop of the Hudson and within easy reach of well-heeled consumers from New York City, Westchester County, northern New Jersey and Connecticut.
 
A Successful Rebirth
 "It went from being a depressed factory town with a dying factory to a booming village that attracts tourists," said Robert C. Samuels, president of the Piermont Civic Association. "Piermont used to be a place where some people were ashamed to say they lived. Now it has status in the real estate ads."
By formulating a new niche for its outdated main street in the era of the shopping mall, Piermont joined a growing list of communities that have been reborn as one-day destinations for shopping and dining. But where Piermont and such communities as Corning, N.Y., Oyster Bay, L.I., and Cranbury, N.J., have succeeded, just as many others have failed. And those who look for a fail-proof formula will find little agreement here about what turned things around.
When asked to tick off the reasons for Piermont's revitalization, each of its 2,163 residents seems to have a pet theory. But many first mention Ms. Farrow and Woody Allen, who came here briefly in late 1983 to film parts of "The Purple Rose of Cairo," Mr. Allen's fable about a character who steps out of a film and into the heart of a small-town waitress, played by Ms. Farrow.
Mr. Allen's production team -- which dressed up many of the vacant buildings on Piermont Avenue, the village's main street -- not only brought in a sizable crew but also attracted a flurry of tourists. All seemed to discover Piermont for the first time and many returned with family and friends.
Some of those who sensed untapped potential in Piermont, which is about 20 miles north of the George Washington Bridge, began buying and renovating dilapidated buildings on Piermont Avenue, fundamentally recasting the tone of the village's one-block downtown.
The names Armani, Ralph Lauren and Donna Karan have been stenciled in black on the front window of the old Coneys Grocery Store, which is now a resale dress shop named Abercorn Place. Nearby, the old Meyers Meat Market, the sawdust on its floor long since swept up, has been trimmed in terra cotta and converted into Hudson Valley Bazaar, which counts zucchini corers among its eclectic inventory of cooking utensils. And DeLorenzo's Shoe Repair has been reborn as Boondocks, which bills itself as "the environmental marketplace" and sells shoulder bags made from recycled inner tubes.
 
Prescience and Research
 Virtually the only establishments that predate the 1980's are the Community Market, a longtime general store that now carries squid-ink pasta opposite cans of Campbell's soup, and The Turning Point, a 16-year-old restaurant that offers live entertainment, including, on occasion, the singer Arlo Guthrie.
Piermont's success cannot, of course, be explained solely by the filming of a movie. Among other factors, people here cite the careful planning by village officials -- particularly in the mapping of a new shopping and condominium development on the old mill site -- and the prescient, grass-roots initiative of individual merchants. The village was also able to study the experience of Nyack, N.Y., a waterfront community about three miles north that had undergone a similar spruce-up several years earlier.
"In Piermont, they -- meaning the town, the individual businesses and the property owners -- identified their strengths and built on them," said Peter Mosbacher, executive director of the New York Main Street Alliance, a nonprofit group that advises municipalities on economic development. "They have the advantage of being surrounded by wealthy communities and people with a lot of disposable income."
Not surprisingly, change has brought some new stresses to Piermont, including the overcrowding of narrow Piermont Avenue on summer afternoons by tourists who can occasionaly be a bit brusque, some say.
Mr. Brawner, the 70-year-old shutterbug who snapped Ms. Farrow, and his wife, Ruth, 67, have had to post an "Absolutely No Trespassing" sign on the side of their purple home to deter bicyclists, who tend to use the 142-year-old house as a bike rack.
 
'We Still Say Hello'
 "Everyone is friendly, but I couldn't tell you the last name of one person who lives across the street" said Mrs. Brawner, who has lived on Piermont Avenue since she was 3 and has watched as young professionals have slowly replaced working-class families. "But we still say hello to everyone."
Nevertheless, the Brawners say that their gripes are allayed by Piermont's vitality. "I think it's nicer now than it was in earlier years," Mrs. Brawner said, to which her husband added, "I have no problem with the town at all."
While generally applauding the village government's shepherding of the transition, Mr. Samuels, of the civic association, laments the increase in rents, home prices and property taxes. A one-bedroom apartment, which might have rented for $300 a month 10 years ago, can now command $800 to $900. One home on Piermont Avenue recently sold for $425,000, village officials said.
Mr. Samuels said he wonders what will happen when people begin moving into Piermont Landing, the new condominium development that has replaced the old mills on a 35-acre peninsula jutting into the Hudson.
"We're concerned that most of the people who move into the condominiums will be wealthier than the residents who are here and have different values," he said.
But Mary Hardy, the village clerk for 23 years, defends the development, saying Piermont could not afford to let prime real estate that accounts for almost a third of the village tax base lie fallow. Ms. Hardy said the Mayor and the village board of trustees aggressively planned the conversion of the mill site, designating it as a mix of retail and residential zoning, keeping the concentration of units at a level far lower than many developers wanted.
"They really did their homework," said James Cymore, the deputy commissioner of planning for Rockland County.
The first residents are just now preparing to move into the development, built at an estimated cost of $50 million. The original developers found themselves stymied by a variety of problems including a sluggish real-estate market and a complicated review process as well as a lawsuit involving construction of the project so close to the river.
Chase Manhattan Bank took back the deed for the project rather than foreclose on it. Since then, the bank has concluded sales of 22 of the 62 condominiums that make up the development's first phase, said James R. Psaki, a Chase vice president. The units, which have been discounted 15 to 35 percent from the original prices, are being sold from $170,000 to $360,000, depending on size and location, he said.
In contrast with its earlier incarnations, Piermont has an urban sophistication now, especially with Xaviar's -- an elegant restaurant where waiters wear black tie -- and the recently opened Piermont Flywheel Gallery, a cooperative of 24 artists and sculptors.
"For me, as a European, it makes me feel very much like I'm in Europe," said Linda Majors, who was born in London and named her Piermont dress shop, Abercorn Place, after the street where she was raised. "In any given weekend, I can hear four different languages."

HEADLINE: Port Authority Budget Averts Rise in Fares

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey approved yesterday a $2.7 billion budget for 1993 that it said insures that fares on the PATH system and tolls on the authority's six bridges and tunnels will not increase for at least two years.
The budget reflects concerns that the region's economy will be stagnant for much of next year and represents the latest effort by the authority to address criticisms that its spending has been too luxurious in lean times. 
 Authority officials said the budget includes dozens of cost-control measures, ranging from eliminating 100 jobs through attrition to reducing insurance coverage for new staff members to consolidating office space. "Sacrifices have been made up and down the line," said Richard C. Leone, the authority's chairman. The current year's budget was $2.5 billion.
Because revenues from its bridges, tunnels, office buildings, marine terminals and airports have been flat, the authority had projected that by 1994 it would have a $150 million deficit that might require toll increases on its New York-New Jersey crossings, said John J. Collura, the director of management and budget.
But cutbacks and productivity improvements will enable the authority to delay increases at least until 1995, he said. The budget calls for raises for union and white-collar employees of between 3 and 4 percent. It also provides for $750 million in capital programs, including road reconstruction at Kennedy International Airport and construction of a monorail system at Newark International Airport.

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Drop

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing new claims for jobless benefits dropped by 38,000 in late November to the lowest level in more than three years, the Government said today.
The Labor Department said first-time applications for unemployment insurance totaled 324,000 in the week that ended Nov. 28, down sharply from 362,000 the previous week. 
 It was the smallest number of new claims since 323,000 were filed in the week that ended Sept. 23, 1989. Before today's report, some analysts had expected claims to fall only about 2,000.
Though part of the decline may have been due to a shorter Thanksgiving holiday work week, it represented the 10th consecutive week that claims remained below 400,000, leading analysts to believe that the unemployment situation was gradually improving.
The department reported last week that the jobless rate fell to 7.2 percent in November from 7.4 percent a month earlier and from the recent peak of 7.8 percent last June. At the same time, it said 105,000 new jobs were created last month.
The four-week moving average that smooths out the erratic weekly changes and is considered a more reliable indicator of the labor situation also fell.
The average was 361,500 in the period that ended Nov. 28, down from 369,250 a week earlier and the lowest since it reached 356,250 on July 14, 1990.
Forty-one states and territories reported declines in their weekly claims, while 12 reported increases.

HEADLINE: A Record-Breaking Year for Bank Profits

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Signaling a dramatic turnaround for the banking industry from the gloomy forecasts of just 12 months ago, Federal regulators said today that 1992 would be the most profitable year ever for the nation's banks.
As a consequence, they said, fewer institutions would fail in 1993 than had been expected, even though new regulations that go into effect next week require officials to seize weak, but solvent, institutions. 
 Officials said the industry's strong profits, $8.5 billion for the three months ended Sept. 30, reflect tougher regulations, tighter supervision and most important, the most favorable interest rate climate in decades.
 
 
Three Record Quarters
 The quarterly profits reported by the nation's 11,590 commercial banks were nearly double the industry's earnings for the comparable period last year. Having compiled three record quarterly profits in a row, the banks have earned $24.1 billion for the first nine months of the year. In 1988, the industry's best year since such records were begun during the Great Depression, the banks earned $24.9 billion.
Regulators said the industry had been plowing much of the record earnings back into reserves for bad loans and to capital that can be used as a cushion to absorb losses in worse times.
Since banks have been lending more money to the Government than to private enterprises, experts said, the industry's strongest returns have come from its growing investments in longer-term Treasury bonds, which continue to post yields of more than twice that of shorter-term Treasury bills.
Bankers have attributed the banner year to what they call the spread -- the difference between the rate they charge lenders and the rate they pay depositors -- which has been at its widest point ever as a result of the Federal Reserve Board's moves over the last year cutting interest rates to their lowest levels since the early 1960's.
While the industry still suffers from weak spots in California and New England and could suffer broader declines again if interest rates rise dramatically over the next few months, senior officials said the industry appeared to have put the worst behind it.
Bankers said the latest figures, which have indicated modest increases in loan demands, were a further indication of a rebounding economy.
"It's always easier to make money in the banking business when interest rates are lower, but the numbers also suggest a little more robust economy than most people had thought," said Daniel R. Smith, chairman of the First of America Bank Corporation, a $20 billion institution based in Kalamazoo, Mich.
But Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee, warned that the latest figures "are illusory" and that the bank profits from large spreads reflect "enormous interest-rate gouging of many Americans."
And Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn,a senior member of the Banking Committee, said the banks' heavy reliance on Treasury instruments reflected the fact that there were few other long-term investments strong enough for investing insured deposits.
 
 
'Making a Mistake'
 "Any idiot can make money by taking in money at 3 percent and lending it at 7 percent," Mr. Schumer said. "But anyone who looks at the last four quarters and thinks the banking industry is back on track is making a mistake."
Twelve months ago, regulators acknowledged that the bank insurance fund, which protects insured depositors, was about to go deeply into debt, much as the savings association insurance fund had done years earlier. This precarious condition prompted Congress to adopt the toughest banking legislation in many years.

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 11.62, to 3,312.19, In Busy Trading Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The stock market gave ground yesterday in a busy session, yielding to sellers even in the midst of positive economic news.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had been up 47.28 points in the four preceding sessions, dropped back 11.62 points, to 3,312.19. 
 Declining issues outnumbered those advancing by about 5 to 4 on the New York Stock Exchange. Big Board volume came to 240.6 million shares, compared with 230.1 million in the previous session.
Analysts said traders were cashing in on some of the market's recent gains, despite a favorable news background that depicted the economy strengthening without inflationary side effects.
 
Unemployment Claims Down
 The Labor Department reported that initial claims for state unemployment insurance dropped 38,000 in the week ended Nov. 21 to their lowest level in more than three years. The decline, which was much larger than analysts had been expecting, provided emphatic new evidence that the job market was improving.
At the same time, the department also said its Producer Price Index of finished goods dropped two-tenths of 1 percent in November, signaling an absence of inflationary pressures in the pipelines of the economy.
If trends like those continue, analysts say, President-elect Bill Clinton will have a lot of maneuvering room to direct his economic policies toward reducing the Federal deficit rather than seeking short-term stimulus for business conditions.
The market showed no pronounced reaction to the apppointments Mr. Clinton made to top economic posts in his Administration, including the choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen as Secretary of the Treasury. Analysts noted that all the names had appeared in news reports over the last several days, and presented no surprises.
National Semiconductor ranked among the volume leaders, down 2 5/8, at 10 5/8, after reporting quarterly earnings that fell short of expectations.
Imcera Group tumbled 5 3/4, to 33 3/4. The company lowered its earnings projection for its 1993 fiscal year, citing a weaker-than-expected performance by its Pitman-Moore animal health subsidiary.
International Business Machines, still buffeted by talk that fresh restructuring and cost-cutting moves might be in store at the company, dropped 7/8, to 61 3/4.
Other decliners among the blue chips included General Motors, down 3/4 at 33 1/8; American Telephone and Telegraph, down 3/8 at 48 1/2; Philip Morris, down 1 at 79 7/8; Merck, down 1/2 at 47 1/8, and Eastman Kodak, down 1/2 at 40 1/2.
Micro Warehouse, making its debut in the over-the-counter market, jumped to 23 3/4 after an initial public offering of 2.85 million shares at 18. But some of the big-name software issues in the over-the-counter market ran into selling pressure. Microsoft fell 3, to 89; Borland International 3/4, to 20 3/4, and Novell Inc., which reported higher quarterly profits, 1/4, to 30 3/4.
National City Bancorp plunged 7 1/8, to 11 7/8, while Metropolitan Financial rose 1, to 16 3/4. The two companies called off a planned merger.
The Nasdaq composite index dropped 4.99, to 658.93. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 0.59 at 392.39.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Rockefeller Center Trust to Cut Dividend

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., the real estate investment trust that holds the mortgage on Rockefeller Center, said yesterday that it would cut its fourth-quarter dividend.
The dividend, payable on Dec. 30, was cut to 25 cents a share, from 48 cents the previous quarter. The board of the trust cited the "unfavorable real estate climate in midtown Manhattan" as a main reason behind the move. 
 Rockefeller Center Properties' principal asset is a $1.3 billion participating mortgage loan that it made in 1985 to the Rockefeller Group, which is 80 percent owned by the Mitsubishi Estate Company of Japan and about 20 percent owned by various Rockefeller family trusts.
 
Many Leases Expire in 1994
 The Rockefeller Group owns buildings that account for 6.2 million square feet, most of the office space in Rockefeller Center. Although the space is about 95 percent occupied, 42 percent of it -- some 2.6 million feet -- is on leases that will expire in 1994.
"No one is afraid that Mitsubishi won't make good on its debt," said Cornelius V. Sewell, an analyst with Argus Research. Mr. Sewell has had a sell recommendation on the Rockefeller Center Properties stock since September, when the board first announced it was reviewing its dividend policy. "They are worried about rental revenues," he said.
On the new York Stock Exchange yesterdy, Rockefeller Center Properties shares gained 75 cents each, closing at $8.875.
Earnings have stayed flat at about $1 a share annually, so the new 25- cent quarterly dividend is not much higher than the 95 percent of earnings that real estate investment trusts are required by law to pay out as dividends. Rockefeller Center Properties had been paying about 190 percent of its earnings as dividends.
At the time the Rockefeller Group bought the center from the Rockefeller family, the real estate market was tight, midtown space was going for about $40 a square foot and real estate experts expected that by the 1990's, $60 a square foot would be a reasonable asking price. Now, most brokers say the Rockefeller Group will be lucky if the space goes for as high as $30.
 
'Big Bonanza' Not Materializing
 "They figured they'd reap a big bonanza when the leases rolled over in 1994," said another analyst, who insisted on anonymity and has been recommending that clients sell the stock for a year.
The problem for Rockefeller Center Properties is that the participating mortgage calls for it to receive substantial cash flow only if gross revenues of Rockefeller Center top $312 million a year, which seemed easy to reach when projections were made in 1985. But last year the gross rentals were barely $230 million.
Rockefeller Center Properties, meanwhile, structured its own debt with those terms in mind. On Jan. 1, 1995, the annual interest rate on its convertible deventures is scheduled to increase to 13 percent from 8 percent. And it has a $200 million letter of credit from Credit Suisse that is due next May. It is trying to refinance a portion of that debt.
Richard M. Scarlata, senior vice president for finance and administration at Rockefeller Center Properties, said, "It is premature to say that the debt will be called." But the trust clearly is shoring up its cash position just in case. "We no longer have the expectations of additional interest from the mortgage participation that we once had," Mr. Scarlata said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The investment trust holding the mortgage on Rockefeller Center, above, said yesterday that it would cut its fourth-quarter dividend. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Theater Is Selected for 'Angels in America'

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:
After weeks of agonizing by the playwright, feverish competition from theater owners and Kremlinology-like speculation by the theater world at large, the New York fate of Tony Kushner's two-part AIDS epic, "Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes," has finally been determined.
It was announced yesterday by Mr. Kushner and the play's producers, Jujamcyn Theaters and the Center Theater Group of Los Angeles, in association with the New York Shakespeare Festival, that the four-hour first part of the play, "Millennium Approaches," will open on April 25 at the Walter Kerr Theater on West 48th Street. The production, to be directed by George C. Wolfe, will thus bypass a previously announced Off Broadway engagement at the Joseph Papp Public Theater.
 
A Run in Los Angeles
 The second part, "Perestroika," which Mr. Kushner is still revising, is to follow at an unspecified date. The entire play recently completed a successful run at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, where the schedule included both marathon single-day performances and consecutive-night performances. The producers said the scheduling was undecided for New York. 
 Competition for the play, in the end between Jujamcyn and the Shubert Organization, was particularly striking for its vehemence and because, by virtually all accounts, a seven-hour nonmusical play on a homosexual theme is a considerable economic risk for Broadway, though the rumor mill already has it nominated for -- if not the recipient of -- a Tony Award.
Indeed, as negotiations went on, what became evident was the ever-smoldering rivalry between the upstart Jujamcyn group and the older, more powerful Shuberts. Finally the Shuberts offered Mr. Kushner one of its prime jewels, the Booth Theater, a stunning, intimate house in a desirable location on West 45th Street, which would have involved moving -- at considerable expense -- the Booth's current tenant, "Someone Who'll Watch Over Me."
"My life has been significantly shortened by the events of the last three weeks," said Rocco Landesman, Jujamcyn's president. "But I'm proud we're getting a show of this importance." Asked why the competition for the play escalated to the degree it had, he added: "To the extent any show can be, this show is news. Whatever the commercial outcome, it's going to be noticed and I think the people who are associated with it are going to be proud."
 
'He Was Very Upset'
 The final announcement, which was put off several times, came after Mr. Kushner met for two hours on Wednesday with Bernard J. Jacobs, the president of the Shubert Organization, who made a last-ditch effort to persuade Mr. Kushner to bring the play to the Booth. Obviously angry at the outcome, Mr. Jacobs declined to comment. Gordon Davidson, the artistic director of the Center Theater Group, who told Mr. Jacobs of the decision, said ruefully: "He was very upset. It's going to take a while to repair that relationship."
Mr. Davidson said the decision was difficult because both the elegantly restored Kerr and the Booth are extraordinary theaters, and equally suitable for the play. But, he said, Mr. Kushner "responded extra strongly to the Kerr."
Mr. Wolfe's acceptance of the directing job provided another discomforting development. To take the assignment, he pulled out of a commitment to the Hartford Stage Company to direct "Marisol," a play by Jose Rivera, enraging Hartford's artistic director, Mark Lamos, and its managing director. They issued a blistering statement through a spokesman, which said, in part, "We find this decision and the producers' encouragement of it reprehensible and an affront to Hartford Stage."
Mr. Wolfe responded, also through a spokesman: "I feel terrible about this. I love the play 'Marisol' and have offered to do it at a later date."
 
Fate of a Play
 "Angels in America," which had its world premiere in San Francisco last year and then a celebrated run in London, was scheduled to open at the Public Theater in February. But discussions about whether to move from Los Angeles directly to Broadway began last month after the play's enthusiastically received national press opening at the Taper. The possibility of losing "Angels in America," the centerpiece in the Public's season, had been viewed in the theater world as a potentially devastating blow. But JoAnne Akalaitis, the artistic director of the New York Shakespeare Festival, said yesterday that the festival would still be involved in the production, that festival subscribers would still be entitled to tickets at downtown prices and that she viewed the hole in the schedule as an opportunity. She said she was already talking to producers about other projects, but declined to name them.
"We have not lost the play to Broadway," Ms. Akalaitis said. "We have gained for our subscribers and community the chance to see it on Broadway. It's sort of a good deal for us, I think."
Mr. Davidson, speaking for himself and Mr. Kushner, said: "It's been difficult. We've been juggling a lot of elements, and a lot of feelings are hurt. But it comes out of the fact that so many people want to be involved."
In the wake of a particularly painful and hectic week, he added, "Now the problems begin."

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber

 BODY:

Casting Crunch for a New Rabe Play
For four years now, ever since he finished it, David Rabe has been trying to cast his four-character play "Those the River Keeps" in a way that would make it viable for a Broadway production. Now it looks as though he's about to give up, making the possible Broadway run of a major work by a major playwright a casualty of star-system economics. 
 The play is about a middle-aged man who, having married a much younger woman, is visited by a colleague from his shady past and must choose between current comfort and the allure of dangerous days gone by. The problem has been the two male leads, Phil and Sal, the casting demands of which "are very, very particular," in the words of the playwright.
"It needs two men who can play Italians in their 40's and who can act onstage," Mr. Rabe said. "You start adding in the demands of Broadway, the renown or fame they need, and the talent pool gets pretty small. There's about four people who could do it."
That assessment is actually a little bleak. Of the four Mr. Rabe named, Robert De Niro was never a realistic possibility, but Al Pacino, Danny Aiello and Harvey Keitel have all done readings of the play. Their film commitments have kept them from signing on for a minimum six-month stint on stage. Joe Mantegna and Armand Assante have also been affiliated with the project at one time or another, but the producer, James B. Freydberg, said that as Mr. Rabe made changes in the play, the role of Phil emerged as central, and "therefore it's been more difficult to match two stars in it."
Mr. Freydberg added: "At one time, Joe Mantegna did a reading with Al Pacino. At one time it looked like it was going to be Joe and Aiello, but that didn't work because Joe got a film." Mr. Assante was interested in doing the play with Mr. Aiello, he said, but then it turned out that both of them wanted the same part.
The play's one production, almost two years ago at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., featured Burt Young and Anthony LaPaglia, but because "in some fashion Sal is the alter ego of Phil," Mr. Freydberg said, the disparity in the actors' ages -- Mr. Young was 50, Mr. LaPaglia some 20 years younger -- was an obvious flaw.
Of the once-interested performers, Mr. Aiello remains so. "I wanted to come back on Broadway," Mr. Aiello said, "but getting all the ducks in a row seems like an impossible thing. So David asked me if I'd be willing to do it Off Broadway. Who the hell am I? I'm too big to do that? I said, 'If it's the right house.' "
Now the problem is that Mr. Rabe and Mr. Freydberg are looking in another direction, committing to Off Broadway but casting two younger actors in the play -- John Turturro is a name that has surfaced -- which would leave Mr. Aiello, who is somewhere north of 50, out of it.
"I think it'll happen," Mr. Freydberg said. "But I don't know when. We've got to rethink."
 
Patinkin as Marvin in 'Falsettos'
 When Michael Rupert, who has since 1981 played Marvin, the lead character in various incarnations of "Falsettos," leaves the show in January to take on the Stephen Sondheim revue at the Manhattan Theater Club, the role will be filled by Mandy Patinkin. Mr. Patinkin, a longtime friend of the show's director, James Lapine, was on a concert tour recently in Toronto, where Mr. Lapine is directing a film. The offer to take over the role, Mr. Patinkin said, was made on a street corner after a serendipitous meeting.
Mr. Patinkin said that his contract for the show was open-ended and that his only other commitments were sporadic concert performances in the spring and a likely 10-week concert tour next fall.
 
Larry Gatlin Is the New Will Rogers
 The country singer Larry Gatlin likes to tell a story about the days between the time he and his younger brothers first saw fame in the early 1970's and the time he finally quit drinking and taking drugs in 1984.
"In 1976 or 1978," he said, "when we started getting real hot, I was the cockiest young son of a buck. I was drinking a little too much vodka, and I took too many funny substances. And some of the guys at the music publishing company" -- Combine Music in Nashville -- "they thought I was too big for my britches, and they were right."
"A funny thing happened," he went on. "At Combine, there's a chalkboard in the men's room in the basement. And on it somebody wrote a sign, in big capital letters, that said, 'Will Rogers never met Larry Gatlin.' "
The story is apropos because Mr. Gatlin, who has said that his touring days with his brothers, Steve and Rudy, with whom he has recorded 23 albums, will come to an end this month, has just been named to replace Mac Davis in the title role of "Will Rogers Follies," beginning Feb. 16. He has appeared as an actor a time or two on television, but never before onstage. Mr. Davis is leaving to resume his songwriting and performing career in Los Angeles, but he'll stop in Pittsburgh and Charlotte, N.C., on his way home to stand in for a vacationing Keith Carradine in the "Will Rogers" road production.
Mr. Gatlin auditioned for the part early this year and was the first choice of the producer, Pierre Cossette, to replace the original Will on Broadway, Mr. Carradine. Mr. Cossette said he had gone to Mr. Davis because Mr. Gatlin was unavailable until January.
In the sort of confluence that makes it seem as though celebrities were all born into the same large family, Mr. Cossette also said he got the idea for casting Mr. Gatlin from the same source he got the idea to cast Marla Maples: Frank and Kathie Lee Gifford, who are friends of both Mr. Gatlin and Ms. Maples's former fiance, Donald Trump.
"It's the Gifford casting system," Mr. Cossette said, adding that Mr. Gatlin's lack of acting experience didn't trouble him at all. "What this is, more than acting, is an entertainment piece. Larry has done two shows a night, seven days a week, all of his adult life. That's what Will Rogers did all of his adult life."
The 44-year-old Mr. Gatlin, who lives in Austin, Tex., spoke from a mobile phone there, where he was furniture shopping for the apartment he just bought in Trump Tower in New York.
"I like to say Donald made me an offer I didn't understand, and I took it," Mr. Gatlin said.
He said he felt no unease about appearing as an actor. "I'm thankful for the past, for all the people we've sung for, from the little road houses to the White House -- hey, that's pretty good -- and in between, but I feel like this is the next step for Larry Gatlin. I don't think it's a big stretch from Larry Gatlin, a Texan, to Will Rogers an Oklahoman."

The show, to be directed by Gloria Muzio, opens a monthlong run on March 25. (Jerry Watson/Camera Press)

HEADLINE: Review/Photography;
Paris in Its Prime, Posing for Classic Images

BYLINE: By CHARLES HAGEN

 BODY:
Paris in all its romantic glory is the subject of a fascinating show at the Houk Friedman Gallery. Under the cumbersome title "De l'Ancien Regime aux Temps Modernes: Paris et ses Environs," the gallery has assembled a diverse and often beautiful selection of photographs of the city in its heyday. Most of the pictures in the show, which includes classics by Man Ray, Brassai, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Robert Doisneau and many others, are from the period between the two world wars, when artists and writers flocked to Paris, drawn by its atmosphere of creativity and freedom.
By the time much of the work shown here was made, the great artistic achievements that earned the city its reputation were largely in the past. French society, too, was undergoing changes, which World War II would accelerate. But the point of the show is to record not the Paris of history but the mythical city, the Paris of "La Boheme" and Balzac. 
 The fabulous nature of this view of the city is made clear by pictures like Brassai's 1931 photograph of the Pont des Arts shrouded in mist, or Georges Blanc's nighttime shots from the 1930's of the lighted fountains on the Place de la Concorde. These and other photographs depict Paris as a kind of fairy-tale city.
Perhaps it is not surprising that so many of the photographers who portrayed this imaginary Paris were themselves foreigners. Andre Kertesz, from Hungary; Brassai, from what is now Romania; Ilse Bing, from Germany; Man Ray and Berenice Abbott, from the United States: they joined countless others from all over the world in portraying this idealized Paris.
Not only were many photographers from elsewhere, but their subjects often were, too. In an elegant shot from around 1925, George Hoyningen-Huene, a former Russian aristocrat, photographed Josephine Baker, coyly hiding behind strings of pearls and a glittery strip of cloth. In Kertesz's complexly geometric "Chez Mondrian" (1926), a lithe tulip in a vase sits next to the open door of the Dutch painter's loft.
What these and homegrown masters like Cartier-Bresson and Doisneau recorded in their images of Paris was not so much a place or even a society as an attitude toward life. In this view, sophistication and pleasure, whether intellectual or sensual, were among the highest values.
While photographers in the United States in the 30's recorded the ravages of the Depression, often to promote social change, their counterparts in Paris, on the evidence of the pictures here, paid little attention to economic or political reform. Instead, romance is all. The young lovers reflected in the mirrored walls of a cafe in Brassai's photograph from 1932 are too self-absorbed, too pleased with their own beauty and stylishness, to worry much about the problems of the world.
At the heart of this mythical Paris is the implicit notion of a kind of democracy based on talent and sensuousness. Even in Brassai's picture of a well-dressed young man surrounded by half-naked women in a brothel, there is little sense of inequality or anguish. Whatever the reality may have been, here the women confront the man as equals.
In this and other pictures, the frank acknowledgment of sex is accompanied by a deep sense of romance that at times tips over into sentimentality. Perhaps no picture better captures the dizzy feeling of young love that for many people defines Paris as Doisneau's "Kiss in Front of the Hotel de Ville" (1947), in which a young couple embrace on a busy sidewalk.
As this picture demonstrates, the romantic image of Paris easily survived World War II. It persists to this day, in part thanks to photographs like these. Increasingly, though, this impossibly alluring vision has taken on a nostalgic tinge. Two photographs here by Eugene Atget suggest that this sense of a lost golden age has long been part of the myth of Paris.
In one, taken at the Parc de St. Cloud in 1901, a line of trees and statues reflected in the calm waters of a pool at dawn has a lonely but fragile elegance. And in the 1920's, near the end of his life, Atget photographed a small Greek-style temple in a wooded park. A great dark bough sags across the frame like a mournful blot on the ideals of beauty and proportion represented by the building.
For all the vibrancy and exuberance of the pictures his younger contemporaries made in the 20's and 30's, they, too, have taken on an elegaic resonance, as the joyful and impossibly sophisticated Paris they describe, whether real or imagined, has faded into the past.
"De l'Ancien Regime aux Temps Modernes: Paris et ses Environs" remains at the Houk Friedman Gallery, 1094 Madison Avenue, at 82d Street, through Dec. 31.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Detail of Brassai's "Vue Nocturne de Notre Dame et la Tour St. Jacques," at Houk Friedman. (Courtesy Houk Friedman Gallery)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: Review/Film;
Two Marines and Their Code on Trial

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
The role doesn't have to be big, but if it's good, and if the actor playing it is great, the results can be magically transforming. Witness Jack Nicholson's vicious, funny, superbly reptilian turn in Rob Reiner's entertaining "A Few Good Men," adapted by Aaron Sorkin from his hit Broadway courtroom drama.
Mr. Nicholson doesn't steal the film, which would mean that he somehow separates himself from everybody else in it. Rather, in the course of only a handful of scenes, he seems to suffuse the entire production, giving it a weight, density and point that might not otherwise be apparent. 
 The role, beautifully written, is made to Mr. Nicholson's order. It's that of Col. Nathan R. Jessep of the United States Marine Corps, a tough, bigoted Vietnam veteran, a career officer shaped by decades of cold-war politics. By chance, Jessep is stationed in that last corner of the earth where the cold war goes on as if there were no yesterday.
He's the commander of the marines stationed at the American naval base on the southwestern coast of Cuba at Guantanamo Bay, on a small bit of arid real estate protecting one of the best anchorages in the western Atlantic, a legacy of the Spanish-American War. It's there that the United States and Cuba, separated by barbed wire and command posts, have continued to co-exist through the Bay of Pigs invasion, the great missile crisis and a continuing, crippling economic embargo, in one of the strangest examples of symbiosis to be found in all of international relations.
This geographic fact becomes a central image in the film adaptation, which gracefully opens up the story of a military court-martial without allowing the tension to evaporate. There are times when the movie seems to force-feed the audience essential information, and when the audience might well wonder whether the emotional crises of the defense lawyers really are of more interest than the fates of the two men on trial.
Yet such things are built into the structure and nature of the drama, which is less about the workings of the military than about the mechanics of this particular inquiry. The story is this: in the course of what appears to be a hazing incident at Guantanamo, a Marine private has died, apparently poisoned by the rag stuffed into his throat before his mouth was taped. Two enlisted men are charged with the murder. As often happens during proceedings of this sort, the victim and the men on trial become less important than the politics surrounding the case.
The Marine Corps would like to wrap it up as quickly and efficiently as possible. To this end, a hot-shot young naval lawyer, Lieut. (j.g.) Daniel Kaffee (Tom Cruise), is assigned to the defense with the understanding that he'll persuade the defendants to accept a plea bargain. Also assigned to the defense is Lieut. Comdr. JoAnne Galloway (Demi Moore), who acts as Kaffee's conscience, eventually persuading him that there is a strong possibility that the two enlisted men were, in fact, acting on orders from their officers.
The investigation, initially undertaken by Kaffee with some reluctance, uncovers the fact that the victim, Pfc. William T. Santiago (Michael DeLorenzo), had for some time been trying to transfer out of his unit. Also, that he had ignored both the Marine Corps code and its chain of command. He had written letters to Washington offering to testify that he had witnessed an incident in which a member of his unit had arbitrarily fired on a Cuban watchtower near the base.
As the investigation continues, Kaffee and Galloway, who clearly never go to the movies, read a book or spend much time talking to career service personnel, are surprised to discover a kind of military mind that, to them, seems prehistoric. The two defendants at first behave like automatons. Pfc. Louden Downey (James Marshall) is so taciturn that he seems seriously retarded. His co-defendant and spokesman, Lance Cpl. Harold W. Dawson (Wolfgang Bodison), refuses all offers of help. He will stoically accept whatever punishment is meted out. The two men simply parrot the Marines' code of fidelity to unit, corps, God and country.
On a fact-finding trip to Guantanamo, Kaffee, Galloway and their assistant Lieut. Sam Weinberg (Kevin Pollak) have their first brush with Jessep at a scary lunch, during which the colonel cheerfully lies through his teeth. For Galloway's benefit, he also describes the special kind of high one can get when having sex with a superior officer. According to Jessep, that's one of the few benefits of an integrated service.
"A Few Good Men" doesn't pack the surprises of "Witness for the Prosecution," nor does it probe very deeply into the psyche of men who exercise the power of dictators in a society that congratulates itself on its freedoms. It's no "Full-Metal Jacket." "A Few Good Men" recalls something of "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial," though it is most troubling not for the questions it raises, but for the casual way it finally treats its two lost, utterly bewildered defendants.
The screenplay is a good one, directed with care and acted, for the most part, with terrific conviction. Among the supporting players who do exceptional work are Kiefer Sutherland, as a Marine officer who is a Jessep in the making; J. T. Walsh, as an officer fatally flawed by conscience; Kevin Bacon, who appears as the military prosecutor, and Mr. Bodison, a new young actor whose performance as the more prominent defendant gives the film its melancholy shock value.
Mr. Cruise, Ms. Moore and Mr. Pollak are perfectly adequate in less flashy roles, which, unlike the others, appear to have been constructed to keep the plot moving right along. They have to play it comparatively straight, which must be maddening when the actors around them are having such a colorful time.
Mr. Nicholson is in his own league. His Jessep is both a joy to watch because of the actor's skill, and an explanation of why the United States base at Guantanamo Bay, whatever its military value, continues to exist. "A Few Good Men" is a big commercial entertainment of unusually satisfying order.
"A Few Good Men," which has been rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), has a lot of vulgar language and some violence.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Reflections in an Unflinching Eye: C-SPAN Meets Baseball

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
It's too bad C-SPAN could not provide coverage of yesterday's United States Senate hearings into baseball's antitrust exemption the way ESPN would do it. Where was the video? The replays of inflammatory comments? The studio analysis?
We know C-SPAN merely flips the camera on and leaves it alone until the hearing ends. That's fine for an arcane hearing on Keynesian economics as it relates to Federal Reserve monetary policy. But over five or six hours of baseball testimony, a dose of Chris Berman narrating dramatic video and the career stats of the antitrust subcommittee's chairman, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, Democrat from Ohio, would have been mighty welcome. 
 We're so used to clip-filled coverage of sports that we craved video of former Commissioner Fay Vincent at Candlestick Park during the earthquake-delayed Giants-A's World Series in 1989 each time the Giants' abortive move to St. Petersburg, Fla., was mentioned. Or clips of the padlocked spring training camps during the 1990 owners' lockout of players when talk of a possible 1993 lockout came up. Or footage of Barry Bonds.
What cried out most for action yesterday was the testimony of ex-pitcher Roric Harrison, who bemoaned how baseball's exemption from antitrust laws kept him the Baltimore Orioles' chattel. He said that in one season when he pitched five shutouts in a month and finished with a 15-5 record, he was never called up from Class AAA and the Orioles would not trade him elsewhere. Surely, ESPN would have had video of him during his stints with Atlanta or Minnesota.
As for the performances: Vincent was stern, animated and occasionally witty, punctuating his words with a motion that seemed as if he was breaking off imaginary sliders; Selig (with a cheering section introduced like stars in audience of "The Ed Sullivan Show") emerged as Boy Scout-faithful, but jumpy and tense; Sen. Connie Mack, Republican from Florida, displayed a bulldog-like intensity in pursuing his anti-exemption crusade, but forgot to wear his grandpa's straw boater, and Sen. Alan Simpson, Republican from Wyoming, praised himself effusively for not exceeding his allotted speaking time and mispronounced "Kuhn" (Bowie) as "Koon."
The verbal home run of the hearings came from witness Rick Dodge, assistant city manager of St. Petersburg, who reminded the remaining senators (most of whom had left early) that Selig, who benefited when the Seattle Pilots moved to Milwaukee, and Peter O'Malley, whose father moved the Dodgers from Brooklyn to Los Angeles, both opposed the Giants' move to St. Petersburg.
If ESPN were there, Dodge's words would have been accompanied by footage of wrecking balls at Ebbets Field or the Milwaukee Braves celebrating their 1957 World Series victory, eight years before shipping off to Atlanta.
COTTON SWITCH ANYONE? When we left this saga, NBC had its first Cotton Bowl on Jan. 1 at 1 P.M. featuring Notre Dame and Texas A&M competing with CBS's Blockbuster Bowl (Penn State-Stanford) and ABC's Citrus Bowl (Ohio State-Georgia). With ratings lure Notre Dame, the Cotton would presumably act as a strong lead-in to NBC's weaker Syracuse-Colorado Fiesta Bowl at 4:30 P.M.
But why sacrifice Notre Dame so early? Why not flip-flop the Cotton and Fiesta Bowls so the Irish-enhanced Cotton Bowl would go up against ABC's Michigan-Washington Rose Bowl.
If the Fiesta featured a Pac-10 team to avoid vying head to head with the Rose Bowl's Pac-10 team, such a switch would be contractually automatic. With more viewers watching at 4:30, NBC could strategically place Notre Dame in a more crucial and competitive time slot against the ever-popular Rose Bowl.
Nothing in NBC's contracts with the Fiesta and Cotton Bowls would preclude the time switch, but it won't be done, said Kenneth Schanzer, the executive vice president of NBC Sports, who said that using Notre Dame to lead off the bowl day on network television is of primary importance and that the Rose Bowl "isn't of such great cachet" that it requires Notre Dame's presence.
John Heisler, a spokesman for Notre Dame's athletic department, said he'd heard no suggestion of a time switch. "The Cotton Bowl people were here the other day and there was no talk about anything but a kick-off at 12:05 (Central time). Our priority was not time slot, but to play against a higher-ranked team. We can't play Miami, but we are playing Texas A&M."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Say This For N.H.L.: Goofy, Eh?

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY

 BODY:
WAYNE Gretzky was once moved to describe the New Jersey Devils as a "Mickey Mouse franchise." Needless to say, the next time his Edmonton team went gliding onto the ice in the Meadowlands, he was greeted with thousands of locals wearing little black ears.
The Great One need only look southward, under his rocking chair in Los Angeles. Coming soon to an arena near Wayne is the latest in Mickey Mouse franchises. The National Hockey League, which has added three teams in the last two seasons, is making loud noises about expanding again. 
 Just yesterday, the Walt Disney Company was conditionally granted a franchise in Anaheim, Calif., hard by the concrete Matterhorn and other cultural phenomena of Disneyland and Orange County. Within the next year or two, the league also plans a franchise in the hockey hotbed of Miami, where only two nights ago 12,842 fans watched the Rangers play the Tampa Bay Lightning in a neutral-rink experiment that is by no means a success.
There are a lot of things I do not understand about this proposed expansion: how can a league that does not yet have a president, and that is still stuck somewhere back in 1948 in its administration, make a decision to keep expanding? And what makes it think the Sun Belt is ready for all these hockey teams?
I also do not understand how hockey can expand when the North American economy is still shaky. Are we to take this expansion as a major endorsement of the economic policies of President-elect Clinton?
There are other possible explanations for this extremely optimistic -- you might even say grandiose -- move. The league meeting was in Palm Beach, Fla., where the temperature was well into the 70's. The lords of hockey sat around in their tennis shorts or plaid golfing pants, and called back to their offices in Winnipeg and Boston and even in New York, where it was fixing to snow. Orange County? Miami? Looked pretty good to them.
The other explanation is that the lords of hockey have already decided to elect Gary Bettman, the slick, young whippersnapper from the National Basketball Association, to be their president. Gil Stein, the league's lawyer, has been watching the store since John (Boys Will Be Boys) Ziegler was offed last spring, but maybe it's the Bush-Clinton thing all over again. A fresh start. Youth be served.
The lords of hockey may be hoping that Bettman will know how to market Lemieux and Lindros and Gretzky the way David Stern sold Magic and Bird and Jordan in the past decade.
That may be wishful thinking, but the hockey owners are on the right trail if they go for Bettman rather than maintain the status quo. The N.H.L. is drawing players from every major hockey country in the world. It should be selling television, merchandise and even official games like the N.B.A.
This expansion mania is contingent on the new ownerships coming up with the entry fees, $50 million, the same paid by the new Tampa Bay and Ottawa teams. The Disney Company obviously feels a hockey team in Anaheim would be a good way to promote its gigantic entertainment network, and Wayne Huizenga, the owner of Blockbuster Video and the new Florida Marlins baseball team, seems to think he has some money left over for a hockey team in Miami.
The other sports are not exactly feeling expansive. Even Stern is resting for a while. Pro football is reviewing the situation. And baseball, which once talked of a nice, neat 32 teams by year 2000, is going to hold fast at next year's expansion to a highly unwieldy 28 teams.
That is, if there is a next year. Baseball is currently mired in the deepest psychological depression ever suffered by a professional league. These owners may blunder their way into a lockout in 1993 that could wreck baseball forever.
The way the baseball owners were spending money for players at the winter meetings this week, they are either lying about their financial problems or they are crazy. I cannot make up my mind.
The hockey owners never struck me as crazy. They were a sour, conservative lot who didn't understand why nine-tenths of the United States population said: "Hockey? Isn't that the sport where people punch each other around on the ice?" It is a far better sport than that, when a couple of good teams are actually trying to score goals. The owners have recently tightened their rules about fighting and stick-holding, and you can sometimes attend a game without seeing two mugs mauling each other. Does this mean hockey is ready for expansion to the Sun Belt? Has anybody checked the hockey owners for sunstroke?

SECTION: Section A; Page 38; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 450 words

HEADLINE: The Clinton Anti-Gridlock Team

 BODY:
Teamwork. Coordination. Words like these dominated President-elect Clinton's news conference yesterday because they govern his choice of five top economic officials. All five are cut from the same fiscally conservative cloth; they should have little trouble working together.
They are also smart, experienced professionals who will pack clout in Congress and on Wall Street. That's Mr. Clinton's way of telling voters: No more gridlock. 
 As expected, Mr. Clinton nominated Senator Lloyd Bentsen to be Treasury Secretary and Roger Altman, a savvy New York investment banker, as his deputy. Representative Leon Panetta, the House Budget Committee chairman, was nominated to be budget director, with Alice Rivlin, the only economist in the group, as his deputy.
Mr. Panetta and Dr. Rivlin have lobbied hard for no-tricks deficit reduction. Dr. Rivlin has the added stature, as the Congressional Budget Office's first director, of having established its reputation for first-rate, nonpartisan technical analysis.
Perhaps the most significant appointment is that of Robert Rubin, co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, the Wall Street investment bank. He will head the new White House council charged with coordinating the Administration's economic policy. His job will be to focus Mr. Clinton's attention on the economic picture, in much the way the national security adviser focuses attention on geopolitics.
The President-elect might have gone a different route -- choosing someone who had already staked out hard policy positions. Mr. Rubin, however, can be expected to play the role of honest broker. His task is to coordinate the ideas of economists at Treasury, State, the budget office and the Council of Economic Advisers and give Mr. Clinton coherent policy choices.
Yesterday's selections leave important questions unanswered. For starters, advisers like Robert Reich and Ira Magaziner, who were most closely associated with the defining themes of the Clinton campaign -- training, education and infrastructure investment -- were notably absent.
But that's no reason to suppose Mr. Clinton has abandoned his economic program. Both men could surface in other key posts. In any case, Mr. Altman and Mr. Rubin helped write his campaign agenda. And, as Mr. Clinton said yesterday, he has already defined his policies.
He will also have to refine them. It's simply impossible to cut taxes on the middle class, raise public investments by $20 billion a year and create bold new education and training programs -- all while cutting the deficit in half. What Mr. Clinton most needed was a team to identify priorities and push them through Congress. These first choices make a good start.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Fastest Growing Economies Cut Tax Subsidies;
Debtors' Folly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Bad Breaks" (Op-Ed, Nov. 18) Ann Crittenden proposes levying a 5 percent "tax" on interest paid to foreigners on "investments" here. Interest is paid only to foreign lenders, not owners of real American assets. The latter are taxed here. "Taxing" foreign lenders would be like my trying to tax the bank that finances my house or car. The bank, of course, would simply not make the loan unless I agreed to increase the interest rate to cover any present or future such "tax."
Debt securities trade publicly in increments of .01 percent. A 5 percent "tax" would be 500 times this determining market measure. In real life it would function as a protective tariff, keeping most foreign loan funds out of the U.S., driving up domestic rates and collecting little revenue. 
 Owing as much as we do, we would be more than a little foolish to try to tax our creditors abroad for continuing to lend to us.
 
JOHN C. EVANS
New York, Nov. 24, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 38; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 288 words

HEADLINE: Fastest Growing Economies Cut Tax Subsidies;
Advertising Body Blow

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President-elect Clinton is getting lots of "free advice" about how to lower the deficit and get the economy moving again. And some of it is worth about as much as it costs: while the suggestion of Ann Crittenden in "Bad Breaks" (Op-Ed, Nov. 18) to change the tax deduction for advertising costs was "free," such a policy shift would be terribly expensive for the economy and the American public.
Businesses rely heavily on advertising to compete and grow in a diverse marketplace. The last thing that American companies need, particularly during a recession, are tax changes that make it more costly and less efficient to communicate with consumers. 
 The advertising tax proposal Ms. Crittenden now espouses had been previously examined and specifically rejected by two Nobel Laureates in economics, Dr. Kenneth Arrow of Stanford University and the late Dr. George Stigler of the University of Chicago. In August 1990, after a thorough review of the economic literature, they concluded that "proposals to change the tax treatment of advertising are not supported by the economic evidence."
President-elect Clinton has stated that he wants to develop an economic stimulus package to jump-start the economy. Nothing could short-circuit this effort faster than to burden the selling process by making advertising more expensive.
With businesses continuing to struggle to emerge from the recession, and the media reeling from cutbacks in advertising revenues, to change the tax treatment of advertising would be a body blow to the economy, the media, thousands of businesses and millions of consumers alike.
 
DE WITT F. HELM JR.
Pres., Assn. of National Advertisers
New York, Nov. 23, 1992

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 2180 words

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: A Cabinet Begins to Take Shape;
CLINTON TEAM TAKES SHAPE WITH BENTSEN AND 4 OTHERS NAMED TO ECONOMIC POSTS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 10

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton began to give shape to his Cabinet today with the appointment of an economic team of old hands from Washington and Wall Street to help him fulfill his campaign promise of fundamental economic change.
The distinctly mainstream array of advisers that Mr. Clinton introduced at the old Arkansas State House, led by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas as Treasury Secretary, seemed intended to mobilize lawmakers and executives behind his economic program, and to signal that the Clinton Administration will be as serious about reducing the deficit as about any new spending programs.
 
Diversity in Jobs
 Along with Senator Bentsen, Mr. Clinton named Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, as director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget, M. Alice Rivlin, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office, as Mr. Panetta's deputy, Roger C. Altman, an investment banker, as Deputy Treasury Secretary, and Robert E. Rubin, the co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, as senior economic adviser. 
 As he spoke, Mr. Clinton was preparing to name a more diverse group to other top Administration jobs. On Friday, Clinton aides say, he will name Carol M. Browner, a former assistant to Vice President-elect Al Gore and currently Secretary of Environmental Regulation in Florida, as head of the Environmental Protection Agency.
The choice of Ms. Browner was something of a surprise. Earlier in the week, aides said the top candidate was Madeline Kunin, a former Vermont governor. But now they say that Mr. Clinton chose to let Mr. Gore take the lead in appointing environmental officials.
In addition, the Clinton aides say he will name Donna Shalala, chancellor of the University of Wisconsin and former head of Hunter College in New York City, as Secretary of Health and Human Services.
 
Looking at Foreign Affairs
 And they say he will name Laura D'Andrea Tyson, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, to head the Council of Economic Advisers, and Robert B. Reich, a political scientist at Harvard University, as Secretary of Labor.
Mr. Clinton is also said to have all but formally decided to name former Mayor Henry Cisneros of San Antonio as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Senator Timothy E. Wirth of Colorado, who retired this year, as Secretary of Energy, and former Gov. Bruce Babbitt of Arizona, a 1988 Democratic Presidential contender, as Secretary of the Interior.
In light of the crisis in Somalia and other pressing foreign affairs problems that have recently come to the fore, the President-elect is vigorously trying to narrow his choices for Secretary of State, Secretary of Defense and national security adviser, aides said.
Mr. Clinton's transition director, Warren M. Christopher; Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, remain high on Mr. Clinton's short list for the State Department, the aides said, but he keeps pressing for more names as well.
Asked today about General Powell, Mr. Clinton said: "I certainly think he is qualified to be Secretary of State." But he added with a smile, "I'll tell you who I am considering for that position when I announce my appointment for Secretary of State."
Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic national chairman, has been asked to consider the post of Ambassador to the United Nations, but has not responded, members of the transition staff said.
At today's news conference, Mr. Clinton seemed intent on focusing exclusively on his core economic advisers and on economic issues.
"Our nation faces two deficits, a budget deficit and an investment deficit," Mr. Clinton said as he introduced his first Cabinet appointments. "I am going to work my heart out with these people to construct a strong, long-term plan for economic growth, for jobs, for incomes, and to reduce our national debt."
As he promised during the campaign, Mr. Clinton also created a new post in the White House -- a senior economic adviser to coordinate foreign and domestic policy through a new National Economic Council. Mr. Clinton named Mr. Rubin to that post, which carries the same rank as the national security adviser. The new council is intended to coordinate foreign and domestic economic strategies in much the same way as the National Security Council does in diplomatic and security affairs.
The choice of Mr. Altman, a friend of Mr. Clinton from their days at Georgetown University, as Deputy Treasury Secretary, may prove to be delicate issue for a President who campaigned on saving jobs and fending off foreign encroachments on American markets an industries. He is vice chairman of the Blackstone Group, an investment bank specializing in international mergers and acquisitions. Like many companies of its type, the Blackstone Group has aggressively solicited business abroad, and several years ago ran a a full-page advertisement in a Japanese newspaper offering its services to Japanese companies interested in taking over American companies.
Over all, Mr. Clinton has chosen a team of Wall Street and Congressional veterans, known more for parliamentary skills and business experience than for economic innovation. While the words change and innovation were the hallmarks of Mr. Clinton's campaign oratory, the appointees, aside from Mr. Bentsen, are probably stronger advocates of deficit-reduction than big new spending programs.
As a Clinton adviser said: "The message to Wall Street was steady as she goes, nothing different or innovative to worry about. This is the establishment here, all people very concerned about the deficit. I think Bill feels that with regard to economic policy, he can be his own top adviser. He knows what he wants to do and these people will be good at implementing it."
 
His Own Top Adviser
 Mr. Clinton said as much when he told reporters, "I will be the chief economic adviser in my Administration and I would take responsibility for addressing both the short and long-term economic challenges facing us."
As always, though, Mr. Clinton offered no specifics about painful measures he might offer to American taxpayers to pay for his programs.
Mr. Clinton said he wanted his economic team in place in time to help oversee the economic conference he has called for Monday and Tuesday in Little Rock, which will bring together about 300 business executives from around the country to discuss the state of the economy and how best to revive it.
The economic program Mr. Clinton's team will be asked to put into effect, as it currently shapes up, looks like some version of the outline he gave during the campaign: tax increases for Americans making more than $200,000 a year, tax reductions for the middle class, an investment tax credit for businesses creating jobs and $20 billion in new spending on roads, bridges, highways and high-technology transportation and communications systems.
Mr. Clinton promised all of that plus halving the budget deficit within four years.
The first challenge for the group will be deciding in the coming weeks whether the economy is rebounding enough now or whether it needs an extra dose of economic stimulus. Then, if more stimulus is needed, how should it be squared with a credible program to reduce the deficit.
As if reflecting some advance agreement, each of the new appointees included lines in their opening statements clearly intended to play down expectations for a quick fix.
"The American people realize that these challenges did not develop overnight and won't be fixed overnight," Mr. Bentsen said.
"The structural economic problems facing this country are deep-seated and can't be solved overnight," Mr. Altman said.
"There remain some deep and fundamental problems in the economy," Representative Panetta said.
Mr. Bentsen, Mr. Rubin and Mr. Altman, are all millionaires, and Mr. Rubin in particular has been a big donor to the Democratic Party for years. Mr. Clinton was asked, but did not answer, why he was turning to such Washington insiders, for his top economic advisers.
When Mr. Bentsen, who was known for granting more than a few large tax breaks for special interest business lobbies as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, was asked to respond to this question he sidestepped it. "I have heard all those stories about my being an insider," he said. "Let me tell you I felt like an outsider for 12 years, and I'm tired of the gridlock."
 
Defining Jobs
 One of the points that was not resolved in the news conference was exactly what Mr. Rubin will do, and how his role as economic coordinator will be meshed with the Secretary of the Treasury, who has historically served in that function.
Under President Bush, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady was the head of the Economic Policy Council, a body that was abolished about a year ago and drew wide criticism for producing little in the way of policy initiatives.
Trying to explain it, Mr. Clinton said: "First of all the Secretary of the Treasury will be the principal economic spokesperson for the Administration after the President. Mr. Rubin's job will be to coordinate, facilitate and provide some direction to the deliberations of our economic council. It will be a larger group than the National Security Council because it will include some others like Commerce, Labor, Energy, and it is a very important job. But in the end I will make the ultimate decisions and be the ultimate arbiter.
"Because we want to bring in more people in a systematic way and reconcile what these departments are doing so they can reinforce and energize one another. I decided I needed someone on the domestic side to be that sort of coordinator and facilitator, but these departments will each stand on their own bottoms and the Treasury will still be the place where the President's economic views are spoken for."
 
Old Hands for Clinton's New Economic Team
President-elect Bill Clinton turned to the center of the economic and political specturm with his choice of Senator Lloyd Bentsen, at right, as Treasury Secretary and Representative Leon E. Panetta as Director of the Office of Management and Budget, the top two economic jobs, and by naming Robert E. Rubin to the new post of senior senior economic adviser, Alice M. Rivlin as deputy budget director and Roger C. Altman as deputy Treasury Secretary. The choice of centrists could be important at a time when economists and politicians on the left and the right are arguing that the budget deficit is of secondary importance and when the number at the center willing to advocate the bitter medicine needed to lower the deficit seems to be shrinking.
 
Roger C. Altman -- Vice chairman of the Blackstone Group, a New York investment bank who was a student at Georgetown University with Mr. Clinton in the 1960's...46...Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance in the Carter Administration and played a role in the rescues of the Chrysler Corporation and New York City...is among those who say that any financial stimulus to the sluggish economy must be applied with caution so as not to aggravate the Federal budget dificit or disturb the financial markets.
 
Alice M. Rivlin -- Economist...61...first director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1975 to 1983, where she earned considerable respect for professional and nonpartisan economic forecasts, options and analysis...former president of the American Economics Association...now an economist at the Brookings Institution and visiting professor of public policy at George Mason University...has long sounded the alarm over the huge budget deficits...in a recent book she called for for a shift from Washington and to the state capitals of programs like job training and public works, a sharp contrast to Mr. Clinton's position that his foremost responsibility as President is to promote economic growth and job creation..
 
Rep. Leon E. Panetta -- Democrat of California...54...elected to the House in 1976...chairman of the House Budget Committee since 1989...started as a Republican and switched parties in 1971...was a leading architect of the 1990 budget agreement aimed at reducing the deficit and has defended it against spending proposals, including those of many Democrats, that would pierce the agreement's limits...this year he drafted a long-term deficit-reduction plan calling for deep spending cuts and tax increases to pay for any new spending programs.
 
Robert E. Rubin -- Co-chairman and 26-year veteran of the investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs and Company...54...has a reputation as a good manager who absorbs diverse opinions and then focuses on building consensus...not a particular ideologue, but many believe he would bring a willingness to balance concern about the financial markets with concern about economic and political needs...long-time Democratic fund-raiser who helped raise millions of dollars to finance the Democratic National Convention in July.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 12, 1992, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about President-elect Bill Clinton's selection of his top economic officials rendered the name of his choice for deputy budget director incorrectly in some copies. She is Alice M. Rivlin. An accompanying article about the Office of Management and Budget misstated her alma mater. It is Bryn Mawr College, not Radcliffe; she received her Ph.D. from Radcliffe.
