SECTION: Section A; Page 36; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1801 words

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION: A Cabinet Begins to Take Shape;
Excerpts From Clinton's Announcement of Appointments to Economic Posts

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference yesterday in which President-elect Bill Clinton announced the appointment of Senator Lloyd Bentsen as Secretary of the Treasury and named other economic advisers, as recorded by News Transcripts Inc., a private transcription service: 
 PRESIDENT-ELECT BILL CLINTON Today, I have asked you here to announce the first members of our economic team. These people are seasoned, skilled, incredibly able and ready to work for the American people. I stress the word "team" because the success of our economic action agenda will depend not only on the talents of these people as individuals and those whom I will announce in the next few days, but also in their capacity to work together for the common good of all Americans.
They are deeply aware that we must not be the first generation of Americans to leave a worse economy to our children. And as I have said repeatedly, our nation faces two deficits, a budget deficit and an investment deficit.
I'm going to work my heart out with these people to construct a strong, long-term plan for economic growth, for jobs, for incomes, and to reduce our national debt.

 	 	 		. . .	 	My first appointment, intentionally, is the Secretary of the Treasury. In filling this post, I wanted someone who had the unique capacity to command the respect of Wall Street, which showing an unrelenting concern for the Americans who make their living on Main Street.
When Lloyd Bentsen agreed to serve as Secretary of the Treasury, it is safe to say I succeeded. In American politics when you say the words "stature, dignity, and respects," Lloyd Bentsen's name comes right to mind. I've known Senator Bentsen for many years, and, as a few of my folks know, I've had him in mind for this position for a long time, long before I was actually elected President.
I followed his work for years as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee; I know about the tax bills he tried to have written into law, which would have promoted more investment and less consumption; I know about the trade positions he's tried to convince our country to take which would have promoted more free trade but a tougher set of demand to open markets to American products.
But he, too, needs a team, and the team that will take the helm at the Treasury Department is truly exceptional, in part because of the creativity and quality of the person who will be appointed as deputy secretary of the Treasury, Roger Altman. Roger is a longtime friend of mine, a former assistant secretary of the Treasury, a preeminent investment banker. And he's been one of my closest economic advisers throughout this entire campaign.
As director of the Office of Management and Budget, Congressman Leon Panetta will bring integrity to this critical office and restore the confidence of the American people and their elected representatives that O.M.B. is shooting straight with the Congress and shooting straight with the American people, and doing its best to help us not only to have a responsible budget but to manage the massive American Government in a different and better way than ever before.
As chairman of the House Budget Committee, Leon Panetta brought a unique combination of strong leadership and superb technical skills. With Leon Panetta as O.M.B. director, I believe that agency can play the pivotal role we have to have it play in the swift and effective implementation of our economic plan.
I'm also delighted to announce that Alice Rivlin, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office and one of our nation's most respected budget experts, has agreed to serve as deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget. Together, Alice and Leon promise to be the most dynamic team in the history of O.M.B. and to restore the confidence of the Congress that the executive branch is going to be a responsible partner in making the budgets of this country.
Finally, I have asked Robert Rubin to serve as assistant to the President for economic policy and to help to coordinate and to direct our new Economic Council. I've created this new role, similar to that of the national security adviser in the present White House, because the coordination of our nation's economic policy is every bit as essential as the coordination of foreign policy to our long-term national security.
Bob Rubin has enjoyed a brilliant career at his firm, and has throughout manifested concern for the welfare of all Americans, and a special concern for the welfare of the inner city poor for whom he has worked as a member of the Cuomo Commission and in other contexts. This new Economic Council which I will chair embodies our commitment to make economic prosperity the top priority of this administration and to sharply focus on economic policy in the White House.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Today's appointments are just the first of many. In the coming days and before too long, we will have appointed the entire economic team and the remainder of the Cabinet. When we are done, the American people know that I mean business when it comes to our campaign commitment to promote a high way, high growth, strong and vital economy, not only for today's Americans, but for the future generations as well.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 Q. Can you tell us, who will be taking orders from whom -- Mr. Rubin from Mr. Bentsen, or Mr. Bentsen from Mr. Rubin? It's not quite clear what each one will be doing here.
PRESIDENT-ELECT CLINTON Well, I think it is quite clear. First of all, the Secretary of the Treasury will continue to be the principal economic spokesperson after the President for this Administration, just as it has traditionally occurred. Mr. Rubin's job will be very much like General Scowcroft's job on the national security side in this Administration. His job will be to coordinate, to facilitate and to provide some direction to the deliberations of our economic council.
It will be a larger group than the National Security Council because it will include not only these departments, but also some others which I have discussed with you before, like Commerce, Labor, Energy. And it is a very important job.
But in the end, I will make the ultimate decisions and be the ultimate arbiter when there has to be an arbiter. I think that if you go back to the campaign structure that we tried to provide, which really did defy past organizations because it was less hierarchical and more team work oriented, that's what I expect to provide here.
And I think that because we want to bring in more people in a more systematic way and reconcile what these departments are doing so they can reinforce and energy one another, I decided that I needed someone on the domestic side to be that sort of coordinator and facilitator but these departments, each will stand on their own. . . . The Treasury will still be the place where the President's economic views are spoken for after the President does it.
SENATOR LLOYD BENTSEN I've heard all these stories about my being an insider. Let me tell you, I felt like an outsider for 12 years. And I'm tired of the gridlock.
To do the things we've tried to do on campaign reform, do the things we tried to do on a tough crime bill, to do the things that we did in the last tax bill, to put economic incentives in there to create jobs, and to get this country moving again, and to see those kinds of things vetoed, I'm just delighted to see us be able to bring about the kind of change, to create those jobs now, with a Democratic President, a Democratic President like Bill Clinton.
I think you're going to see those hopes turn into reality. And to be able to pass those and put them into law is what I'm so pleased about.
And as far as the Secretary of the Treasury's job, I know you're probably looking for more maturity in that job. But I'll do what I can.
REPRESENTATIVE LEON E. PANETTA I think everyone that knows me as chairman of the Budget Committee and my work on the budget, we've been basically fighting the budgets that have been presented over the last 12 years concerned about the priorities that we part of those budgets, the failure to invest in our society, and the fact that they would ultimately produce the record deficits that they have produced.
So I've been fighting against those kinds of budgets in the time I've been in Congress, and I think the President-elect and I share a common commitment, not only to long-term deficit reduction, but to making the investments in education and health care and infrastructure and growth that this Administration has failed to make over the last few years.
Q. Governor Clinton, and also Senator Bentsen, for both of you, were you at all concerned in picking Senator Bentsen that his choice might lead to the loss of yet another Democratic Senate seat in Texas that might make your job of getting your program passed harder? And Senator Bentsen, did that play any part in your decision whether to take this position?
SENATOR BENTSEN Obviously that's something that would be of some concern to me. But the Democratic Party in Texas is in great shape and we have a very effective and attractive Governor who will be making that decision and that choice and who will play a major role in that campaign and I think the odds are just excellent that a Democrat will succeed me in that spot.
PRESIDENT-ELECT CLINTON I did give it some thought. It crossed my mind. I think that frankly the kind of leadership that has been provided in Texas by people like Ann Richards, Henry Cisneros, John Sharp, that they and many others have embodied the kind of new Democratic Party that we're trying to bring to the United States. And I think there's a good chance that Governor Richards will name someone senator who will have the confidence of the people of Texas. I thought about it. But I also thought that Senator Bentsen was the best choice for America for Treasury Secretary and I think the people of Texas will respond to that. But I don't think there's any reason to believe that the Democrats can't be highly competitive in that job.
Q. The Justice Department has decided not to appoint a special prosecutor in the Iraqgate case. Do you believe that there is a need for additional inquiries in that? And will you appoint, have your Justice Department appoint, a special prosecutor after you take office?
PRESIDENT-ELECT CLINTON I certainly think we need to know more about it than we now know. And what I intend to do is to appoint an Attorney General and then get a recommendation on it. And generically, let me make a statement, the special prosecutor law, as you know, either just did or is about to expire and I had to tell you, I think it should be reenacted. And I will support that.

HEADLINE: At Issue in School Battle: the Chancellor Himself

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
What began as a provincial battle over what is taught about homosexuality in a small patch of Queens has mushroomed into a battle over the survival of the Chancellor and perhaps the way New York City governs its schools.
 On Wednesday night, in its harshest rebuff ever of Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, the seven-member Board of Education, by a surprising 6-to-0 vote, reinstated a Queens school board that had adamantly refused to adopt any multicultural curriculum that promotes respect and appreciation of gay people. 
Behind that vote lay a complex web of threads that included personal slights, political ambitions, moral and religious creeds and even an educational consideration or two. But at the nexus of that web stood one person, the Chancellor, and the question of whether he should or would stay on when his contract expires June 30.
 The answer to that question has implications that go far beyond the fate of the Chancellor himself. Mr. Fernandez was brought to New York three years ago with a mandate to radically overhaul a failing school system. And with often high marks, he has introduced a host of changes -- from letting teachers and parents help run schools, to breaking large high schools into smaller ones to offering greater choice of schools for all students.
 If the Chancellor were to leave, all his initiatives would be placed in limbo. And his departure, in the face of the city's withering politics, economic uncertainties and many other demands, would raise a perennially troubling issue: How can New York hope to attract innovative people to a place that so often frustrates their innovation?
 In recent weeks, Mr. Fernandez has clearly laid down the gauntlet, warning the central board that he will not remain unless it smoothes over its internal quarrels and ceases what he insists is its repeated meddling in his managerial prerogatives. The significance of the vote on Wednesday night was that the board not only rejected that warning, but that it also did so with virtual unanimity.
 And in doing so, the board appeared to send Mr. Fernandez its own convincing message: You can remain as Chancellor, but under our terms, by adopting a less combative leadership style.
 That leadership style was at issue once again yesterday as the battle over the curriculum refused to quiet down. Mr. Fernandez gave School Board 24 in Queens until the close of business today to meet with him to resolve the curriculum issue or face the appearance of trustees on Monday who will impose a curriculum on the district that teaches respect for gay people. And Mary A. Cummins, president of the board of District 24 in Queens, said she rejected his ultimatum and would appeal the Chancellor's actions once again to the central board.
 Even Mr. Fernandez's staunchest supporters seem to have grown weary with two years of struggle over condom distribution, AIDS prevention lessons and now lessons about gay people and wish Mr. Fernandez would find a more conciliatory way of approaching such emotional issues.
 A pithy remark yesterday by Michael J. Petrides, who has repeatedly tangled with Mr. Fernandez, was expected. "To a large extent, finding consensus is a measurement of leadership," he said. "Leadership is not just carrying a two-by-four."
 But even H. Carl McCall, who until his vote on Wednesday night had stood firmly behind the Chancellor, acknowledged "maybe some people did believe they were slapping him on the wrist."
 No doubt, a host of other factors also played a role, from personal irritation with the Chancellor's scornful comments about the board in a new autobiography, to the realities of politics in a mayoral election coming up next year, to the simple desire to put a multicultural curriculum in place. But the chief factor appeared to be disenchantment with what some saw as the Chancellor's overly autocratic manner.
 Mr. Fernandez's aides firmly deny charges about his leadership style, pointing out that they have struggled for more than a year and half to carry out a resolution of the central board itself to teach lessons that would stem episodes of bias in the city.
 The fact is that Mr. Fernandez's style has also served him well. After years of Board of Education lethargy in dealing with schoolwide corruption and incompetence, Mr. Fernandez came into office in January 1990 in a fevered burst of activity, dismissing three principals and a superintendent, superseding local boards seven times, and beginning a host of educational initiatives.
 
Needing Cross-Section Appeal
 But some school board members feel Mr. Fernandez has not sought to learn what would be tolerable to a broad cross-section of the city's parents like the more conservative blue-collar and Roman Catholic ones in Queens.
 The vote on Wednesday night represented a sea change in the board's attitude that holds ominous prospects for Mr. Fernandez's survival as Chancellor. In the last year, Mr. Fernandez had lost votes over the content of the curriculum on AIDS prevention, but always by 4-to-3 votes.
 What was particularly stunning on Wednesday night was that two of Mr. Fernandez's most stalwart supporters on AIDS instruction, Mr. McCall and Dr. Westina L. Matthews, voted against Dr. Fernandez. Even the third constant supporter of Mr. Fernandez, Dr. Luis O. Reyes, abstained.
 The central board gave the Chancellor the power to replace the local board with his own trustees on curricular matters should the local board not agree to mediation of the dispute, but it barred those trustees from imposing any curriculum unpalatable to the local board until it -- the central board -- decided the appeal.
 It thus seized for itself, and took away from the Chancellor, the power to resolve what kind of curriculum would be taught in District 24. The Chancellor could have lived with a switch from a suspension to a partial takeover, something Mr. Petrides and Carol A. Gresser, the board's Queens representative, had suggested earlier in the day.
 But he could not abide the evisceration of his powers that came out of a tangled three hours of closed-door debate on Wednesday night and Mr. McCall's desire to create a unanimous consensus behind any action.
 Mr. McCall is believed by his colleagues on the board to be interested in re-election as board president and could not attain that goal by remaining in the three-person minority on important votes like that on the Rainbow.
 His mentor, Mayor David N. Dinkins, is believed by some board members to have grown worried that an insistence on carrying out the Rainbow guide for children as young as first grade was alienating many Hispanic voters at a time he may be losing Jewish voters over his stands in Crown Heights.
 Mr. Dinkins was also said to be worried that the Rainbow fight was damaging his chances for obtaining long-craved legislation in Albany that would allow him a greater voice in the selection of Board of Education members.

PUB-DATE: December 12, 1992

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1889 words

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton Widens His Circle, Naming 4 Social Activists

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 11

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton today broadened the political and ideological profile of his emerging Administration, choosing three academics and an environmentalist known for strong advocacy of social causes.
A day after he turned to Washington and Wall Street for a notably mainstream economic team, Mr. Clinton today reappeared in the Old Statehouse here with a group of Washington outsiders that included three women. 
 Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the 51-year-old Chancellor of the University of Wisconsin, was chosen to be Secretary of Health and Human Services. Laura D'Andrea Tyson, 45, would become the first woman to head the Council of Economic Advisers. And Carol M. Browner, 36, who is a protegee of Vice President-elect Al Gore and who heads Florida's environmental agency, was chosen to lead the Environmental Protection Agency.
 
Choice for Labor Secretary
 Robert B. Reich, 46, a political scientist at Harvard University who has advised Mr. Clinton on economic matters, was selected to be Secretary of Labor.
Transition aides confirmed tonight that Mr. Clinton would announce Saturday that Ronald H. Brown, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, would be the Secretary of Commerce, making Mr. Brown the first black appointee for the new Administration.
Mr. Clinton, announcing his newest selections today, said that "while Washington stagnated over the past decade, states and universities have often been laboratories of innovation."
"My appointees today come from the top ranks of a new generation of American leaders," he said. "We can't look to government programs to solve all of our problems. These appointees know the limits of what government can do, as well as what government must do."
 
Reflection of America
 The new appointments reflected some of the influence wielded by two of Mr. Clinton's closest advisers: his wife, Hillary, and Mr. Gore. They also represented a concerted effort by transition planners to demonstrate that people other than white men would hold top Cabinet positions.
"I think when you see the whole Cabinet, it will be genuinely reflective of this country in racial and gender terms, and it will be very exciting to the American people," Mr. Clinton said. "I named these four people today because we're ready to go with these four appointments, and because together they represent the kinds of experiences and ideas, and the sort of generational movement that I sought to bring to this campaign. But I don't -- I wouldn't read too much into it."
The ideological contrast between the selection of activist social policy theorists today and more mainstream economic officials on Thursday seems to square with Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to seek innovation in solutions to social problems like poverty, homelessness, education and pollution after 12 years of Republican laissez faire. By contrast, his choice of tax and budget experts to top economic posts on Thursday suggests an emphasis on carrying out an economic program that is already well formed.
 
Sensitive to Criticism
 But Clinton transition aides have said they have been sensitive to criticism that no members of minority groups are represented in their early selections.
The appointment Mr. Brown, who had been offered but rejected the job of Ambassador to the United Nations, would complete Mr. Clinton's economic team in advance of a two-day conference that is scheduled to begin Monday. He is a native of New York City.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Brown agreed on the job he would take during a conversation at the Governor's Mansion here today.
Mr. Brown was widely credited for helping Mr. Clinton win the Presidential election by helping to build coalitions among widely divergent groups of Democrats, and his appointment was seen as a reward for those efforts.
Mr. Brown, a Washington lawyer and former head of the Washington office of the National Urban League, headed Jesse L. Jackson's 1988 campaign and was the first black person to lead the Democratic Party. He would also be the first black Secretary of Commerce.
 
New Stress on Environment
 Mr. Clinton let slip some of this awareness of the symbolic intent of today's announcements when he asserted incorrectly that Ms. Browner would be the first woman to head the environmental agency and was quietly corrected by Mr. Gore. Anne Gorsuch Burford headed the agency under President Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Clinton, as well as Mr. Gore, who wrote a best-selling book on the environment, has said he will support legislation elevating the environmental agency to the level of Cabinet department.
Mr. Clinton also used his news conference today to try to clarify an apparent difference of opinion with his newly appointed budget chief, Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, over whether short-term relief for the middle-income taxpayer should take precedence over long-term deficit reduction.
 
Reducing the Deficit
 "In order for our changes to have credibility, they have to be accompanied by a serious deficit reduction plan and I think you know, in that sense, I think we're in total lock step," he said.
Mr. Panetta and the complete team of economic advisers, led by Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, Mr. Clinton's choice for Treasury Secretary, will join the President-elect here next week for a two-day economic conference. Transition aides have said that they plan to use the meeting to solicit ideas on how to tackle the problems of the economy.
Mr. Clinton warned again today that there should not be too much optimism about an early economic recovery.
"A lot of those months where the unemployment rate was dropping, the employment rate was not going up," he said. "People were dropping out of the unemployment pool. I hardly call that a recovery."
Dr. Shalala, who succeeded Mrs. Clinton as chairwoman of the board of the Children's Defense Fund, an advocacy group, acknowledged her debt to Mrs. Clinton as she accepted the nomination.
"We have spent most of our adult lives, often together, working to get this nation to understand that our future is inextricably tied to the health, welfare and education of our children, and their families," Dr. Shalala said today. "As I join the Clinton administration, I want her to know how proud and excited I am to have the opportunity to continue our work."
Unlike her predecessor, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Dr. Shalala is not a medical doctor. But she said today that her work in children's advocacy and her service on the board of the National Institutes of Health had prepared her for the job she would hold.
 
Jobs and Environment
 Perhaps acknowledging the problems Mr. Clinton has had with his own environmental record as Governor of Arkansas, Ms. Browner said today that she was looking forward to a time "when we will finally move away from the trade-off and the debate that we have focused on for far too long between jobs and the environment, toward a sustainable economic future."
In Florida, Ms. Browner managed the nation's third-largest state environmental agency with 1,500 employees and a budget of $650 million. Under Gov. Lawton Chiles, she was the state's leading advocate for halting the construction of new hazardous waste and municipal waste incinerators because of unanswered questions about the potential environmental and health dangers from the pollutants they sent into the air.
It is likely that seeking answers to those questions will be among the first priorities Ms. Browner faces at the environmental agency. Mr. Gore, who is expected to exert a strong influence over environmental policy in the new Administration, is also concerned about the proliferation of incinerators.
Mr. Reich's appointment to be Secretary of Labor signaled the liberal Democrats who have advised and supported Mr. Clinton that they would not be left out of the decision-making process. A graduate of Yale Law School and a former Rhodes Scholar, Mr. Reich will fill a post that has generally not been considered a part of the White House inner circle in previous Administrations. But Mr. Clinton said today that Mr. Reich's job would be considered a part of his economic team.
"I'm excited about this job, because there is the possibility of working with a President who understands the importance of investing in people as a means of achieving economic growth," Mr. Reich said.
During the campaign, Mr. Clinton often said job-training programs would be a central part of his plan to revitalize the economy. But he has also appointed Robert E. Rubin, the co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company to be his senior economic adviser, a new position.
With the addition today of Ms. Tyson, who holds an opposite view from Mr. Reich on matters of international trade, Mr. Clinton has expanded the number of people who will have his ear on economic issues and set up potential overlap and conflict within his economic team.
Ms. Tyson, who has gained a reputation of favoring greater restrictions on trade to energize the economy, said she viewed her role as leader of the council as a chance to expand the role of the advisory body beyond forming monetary policy.
 
 
 
Outsiders Now On The Inside
Robert B. Reich
Nominated to be Labor Secretary
Lecturer at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government and author of several a number of books on economic subjects...46...friend of BillMr. Clinton for 24 years as well as a fellow Rhodes Scholar and Yale Law School classmate...director of the economic policy transition team...has argued for a bigger Government role in education, job training and builking roads and bridgesinfrastructure if the United States expects to strengthen industry and create more high-paying jobs...also supports a more active Ggovernment role in helping industry develop important technologies.
 
Laura D'Andrea Tyson
Nominated to be Chairwoman, Council of Economic Advisors
Professor of economics and business administration, director of the Institute of International Studies, and research director for the Berkeley Roundtable on the International Economy at the University of California at Berkeley...45...as member of the economic transition team she is overseeing work on policies regarding technology and manufacturing...a self-described "cautious activist" she is skeptical of free trade theories and contends that the Government should help its domestic high-technology industries so as to offset foreign government subsidies to their industries.
 
Carol M. Browner
Nominated to be head of the Environmental Protection Agency
Lawyer...Secretary of the Florida Department of Environmental Regulation, the third largest state environmental agency, since January 1991...36...former Senate aide to Vice President-elect Gore and now his transition chief...respected for her work in putting together a state and Federal pact for restoring the Everglades...has supported moratoriums on building new hazardous waste and municipal waste incinerators in Florida because of the role they play in releasing mercury into the air... concluded a groundbreaking agreement that requires the Disney Company to spend $40 million to improve for wildlife purposes a 13-square mile ranch near Orlando in return for receiving state and Federal permits to fill in roughly 400 acres of wetlands for Disney World projects.

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges Stronger U.S. Stand On Enforcing Bosnia Flight Ban

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton offered indirect criticism of President Bush's foreign policy today, nudging the Administration toward a new United Nations resolution enforcing the ban on Serbian flights over Bosnia and Herzegovina.
Mr. Clinton, who had been deliberately circumspect until today when asked his views on the international crises he will inherit from Mr. Bush, signaled that he would take a tougher approach toward the fighting in the Balkans. He said the United States and its allies should do whatever it takes, apparently including air strikes, to enforce the flight ban. 
 Mr. Clinton's comments, made during a news conference in Little Rock, Ark., to introduce new members of his Cabinet, came after an intensive review of the Balkan situation by his foreign policy advisers. They have argued privately for days that because of the inaction of the Bush Administration, which remains deeply divided over what to do in the former Yugoslavia, and because of the continued fighting, Mr. Clinton could not wait for Inauguration Day, Jan. 20, to make his position clear.
 
No Ground Troops Seen
 "I have been in favor of enforcing the no-fly zone for some time," Mr. Clinton said, adding that enforcement "can be done from the air without a commitment of ground troops." He added, "Anything we can do to turn up the heat a little there, to try to reduce the carnage, is worth trying."
Both Britain and France, whose forces are part of a United Nations peacekeeping force in the former Yugoslavia, have been reluctant to allow American planes to enforce the flight ban over Bosnia, fearing that the Serbs would retaliate against United Nations forces on the ground. But Mr. Clinton said there might be some softening of British and French opposition.
Mr. Clinton's statement today goes further than what he said at a news conference on Tuesday, when he expressed sympathy for Mr. Bush's unwillingness to commit American forces to a ground operation, but added, "There may be other things which can be done." Mr. Clinton declined to be more specific, saying only that he would review his options "at the appropriate time" and that he did not think he "should say more about specifics at this time."
 
Position in Campaign
 During the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton argued that the United States should take the lead in seeking United Nations authorization for air strikes to protect the effort to deliver food and medicine to victims of the fighting in Bosnia and should consider whether to push for lifting the United Nations arms embargo that some contend unfairly hurts the Bosnians.
But until today, both external and internal factors had constrained him from outlining his solutions for any of the international problems he will inherit.
Mr. Clinton has said since the election that he would not compete with Mr. Bush's foreign policy during the transition period. He has also been determined to remain focused on the economy, but has acknowledged -- with more than a hint of frustration -- that he will have to spend more time on foreign affairs than he wants to.
 
No Policy Team Yet
 Finally, he has yet to put his foreign policy team in place, which has meant that there is no one in authority to help formulate policy and explain what he means when he does not want to do that himself.
Mr. Clinton's remarks today could put pressure on the Bush Administration, which has concluded that Serbia is routinely violating the United Nations ban on flights over Bosnia, to decide whether or not to initiate a United Nations enforcement resolution. They also put President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia on notice that the new Administration may not permit his policies in Bosnia to go unpunished.
Mr. Clinton may also be seeking to regain control of the debate over Bosnia from former Republican policymakers -- notably former President Ronald Reagan and former Secretaries of State Henry A. Kissinger and George P. Shultz -- who have called for swift, selective military action against the Serbs.
This week, Mr. Shultz, in a rare criticism of the Bush Administration, urged the United States to use force to stop the Serbian "ethnic cleansing" of Bosnia and punish Serbian war crimes. The normally cautious former Secretary of State even advised his hosts on the "Macneil-Lehrer News Hour" to run footage of World War II Nazi concentration camps the next time they broadcast a program on Bosnia. "The message is the same," he said.
Mr. Clinton already knows he will inherit an American military commitment in Somalia, which his advisers fear could raise expectations that he may respond with similar, decisive action in Bosnia. "You can't move on Somalia without having pangs of conscience about Bosnia," a senior aide to Mr. Clinton said.
Mr. Clinton's remarks are also consistent with his stated desire for a "disciplined, aggressive," preventive approach to foreign policy to help head off global crises before they boil over and monopolize his time.
The Bush Administration is divided over whether to press for a United Nations resolution authorizing force to stop the Serbian flights, senior Administration officials said today.
The State Department, which favors quick action, had hoped to resolve the issue this week, so the Security Council could begin discussions before Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger meets with European and Arab foreign ministers in Geneva next week to discuss the Balkan situation.
 
Pentagon Is Opposed
 But the Pentagon has argued that until there is clear evidence that the Serbs are using their warplanes and helicopters in combat missions, there is no need for such strong action, officials said.
The Administration debate is reflected in a classified paper that discusses the consequences of enforcing the ban, officials said. The paper argues at one point that the lack of enforcement has made the ban meaningless and may embolden the Serbs to spread the war to the Kosovo region, which has been stripped of its autonomy by Serbia. But it also says the imposition of the Security Council ban has sharply decreased the number of flights over Bosnia and apparently stopped the bombing and strafing of villages in the former Yugoslav republics.
Aides to Mr. Clinton said in interviews that the United States had missed opportunities to curb fighting in the Balkans, and that American options were more limited than they would have been a year ago. But they added that his remarks today were not meant to be critical of the Administration or to push it to initiate an enforcement resolution in the Security Council.
Rather, one senior aide said, Mr. Clinton "is seriously concerned about the situation both with respect to continuing risk in Bosnia as winter approaches and the risk of a wider conflict if the Serbs act against Kosovo," the autonomous region with a largely Albanian population. "He understands it is something he will have to deal with when he becomes President."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
NATO Willing to Intervene
 PARIS, Dec. 11 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Secretary General of NATO, Manfred Worner, said today that the alliance was prepared to intervene in the former Yugoslavia if requested by the United Nations, adding that contingency plans for a military operation were under review.
But the United States Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, speaking at the end of a meeting in Brussels of NATO Defense Ministers, said Washington remained opposed to committing ground troops unless the objectives were clearly defined. He also urged NATO to admit some East European countries as members to confront security problems in the former Communist bloc more effectively.
Mr. Worner, while stressing that the United Nations should continue to have the leading role in responding to the Balkan crisis, said NATO was ready to act. "I have no doubt that, if asked by the United Nations, the alliance would do what is necessary," he declared.
Contingency plans have been drawn up, Mr. Worner said, declining to elaborate. Later, he told the BBC that he believed that the time had come for military intervention, although the consequences for United Nations relief forces already in the Balkans would have to be reviewed carefully.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.N. Sending 700 to Macedonia
 UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 11 (Special to The New York Times) -- The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously today to send some 700 peacekeepers to Macedonia in an attempt to prevent hostilities from spreading into that former Yugoslavian republic.
The decision represents the first time the Security Council has deployed peacekeepers for preventive purposes, with the aim of stopping an eruption of violence before it has begun.
Few countries recognize Macedonia, which has also not yet been admitted to the United Nations because of a quarrel with Greece, which wants it to change its name.
But there are fears that the fighting in Bosnia could spread to Macedonia, which has a large Muslim minority of Albanian descent.

HEADLINE: Big Jumps Are Posted For Sales

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Reinvigorated shoppers drove up retail sales in November for the fifth straight month and spent at a much faster pace in October than previously estimated, the Government said today.
Analysts said the sales figures indicated that the economic recovery -- now more properly called an expansion, since ground lost during the recession has been totally recovered by most measures -- continued to gather momentum. 
 Other figures released today showed a hefty rise in average weekly earnings last month and another jump in consumer confidence in early December. Consumer prices, meanwhile, remained subdued.
 "This is a long awaited and long overdue revival," said James E. Annable, chief economist for the First National Bank of Chicago. He was referring mainly to the sharp increases in retail sales, an area that accounts for a third of the economy.
The November sales rise was four-tenths of a percent, but this was after an already substantial gain for October, of nine-tenths of a percent, was revised upward to 1.9 percent. This made October the strongest month since January, which began with a fractional advance but finished with a jump of 2.3 percent.
 
 
Average Earnings Up 0.9%
 At $165.8 billion, last month's retail sales were 7.7 percent above those of November 1991, without any adjustment for inflation or for, in some cases, price declines.
 In another report, the Labor Department said today that average weekly earnings rose nine-tenths of a percent last month, reflecting a longer workweek coupled with a rise in hourly pay. But those gains were partly offset by a rise of two-tenths of a percent in consumer prices for November.
 Consumer confidence, as surveyed by the University of Michigan, jumped to 91.4 for the first two weeks of December, from 85.3 for November. Assessments of current conditions eased slightly, but expectations about the economic future, a component of the Government's principal forecasting index, soared more than 11 points, to 89.6, according to Wall Street subscribers to the survey.
The bond market, sensitive to any hint of inflation that might accompany a stronger economy, took the figures in stride. Analysts said this seemed to be still another instance in which the market saw an economic rebound as diminishing the chances that the Clinton Administration would offer an overly stimulative fiscal program.
But even as various analysts scrambled to raise estimates of fourth-quarter growth in the gross domestic product -- the consensus 2 percent pace appeared headed for 2.5 percent, or 3 -- one big question was left with no clear answer: What are consumers using to pay their bills in what has become a spending spree?
To be sure, job growth and income growth have resumed, but not by enough to support such a rapid pace of consumer spending, which rose in the third quarter at a 3.7 percent annual rate and was accompanied by a sharp decline in the rate of savings, to 4.5 percent of disposable personal income, from 5.3 percent.
 
 
Borrowing on the Rise
 And there is evidence from two straight months of rising installment debt that consumers -- many of whom have refinanced homes or are benefiting from automatic interest-rate reductions in adjustable mortgages -- are again willing to step up their borrowing. In addition, Mr. Annable said his bank's credit-card sales were "exceptionally strong," rising at double-digit rates.
But numerous economists, like Edward Yardeni of C. J. Lawrence, said they remained puzzled. "Something's wrong with this picture," Mr. Yardeni said. "Things just don't add up."
Among the possibilities analysts raised were that there may be more jobs being created than are being picked up by Government surveys, that severance pay and other nontraditional income is greater than realized, or that the hurricanes that struck Florida, Louisiana and Hawaii had a greater impact in creating rebuilding activity than had been assumed.
 
 
Buyers May Be Raiding Savings
 It is also possible, some say, that consumers are further drawing down their savings, reflecting a perhaps irrational amount of optimism arising from the November elections.
"But however it's being financed, it's apparently really happening," Mr. Annable said of the sales gain, although some early December figures have been less buoyant than those of a month earlier.
 Today's retail report showed that sales of durable goods rose five-tenths of a percent and that sales in the larger category of nondurables increased three-tenths of a percent. When the automotive sector is excluded, the overall gain was three-tenths of a percent.
Among durables, increases of 1.7 percent for stores selling furniture and other equipment and six-tenths of a percent for automotive dealers were partly offset by a 1.7 percent decline for stores selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes.
 
 
Department Stores Gain
 In nondurables, there were gains of nine-tenths of a percent for department stores, seven-tenths for food stores, three-tenths for apparel and accessory stores, and one-tenth at gasoline stations.
Spending at restaurants and bars, which was revised sharply higher in October, edged down a tenth of a percent last month while spending in drug and proprietary stores was unchanged.
Compared with November 1991, automotive sales were running 13 percent ahead while furniture and apparel sales were each up 11 percent.
"There's a lot of thrust in the consumer sector," said Gary Ciminero, chief economist for the Fleet Financial Group in Providence. But he said he was avoiding raising his estimate of gross domestic product for the current quarter because he considered it likely that growth in the July-September quarter would be revised above the 3.9 percent already posted.

HEADLINE: Challenger Steps Up Attack on Serbian Leader

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NIS, Yugoslavia, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Promising peace and prosperity, the Prime Minister of Yugoslavia brought his campaign to oust Serbia's hard-line nationalist President to this republic's industrial heartland today, trying to build support in a onetime stronghold of the President that has been laid waste by economic decline and international sanctions.
"There has been enough destruction, enough death, enough impoverishment," the Prime Minister, Milan Panic, told several thousand enthusiastic and mostly young supporters at a rally darkened by cold fog. "No longer, at the end of the 20th century, can cannon be used to solve problems." 
 "This is a rich land, and someone has made it poor," Mr. Panic said, attacking the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic. "This is not a struggle between two men, but between two systems. We're here to build."
The crowd roared as Mr. Panic jabbed at the Communists who run this dreary industrial town. He was born in Serbia but immigrated to the United States 35 years ago, returning to accept his current post this summer.
 
Election on Dec. 20
 The Dec. 20 election contest has sundered Serbian society, dividing people who see Mr. Panic as a traitor for opposing Serbian aggression in other former Yugoslav republics from those who see him as a potential savior from the international economic sanctions that were slapped on Serbia.
Mr. Panic, who made a fortune in the American pharmaceutical industry, returned in July to become Yugoslavia's Prime Minister at the invitation of Mr. Milosevic and the federal President, Dobrica Cosic.
Mr. Milosevic's strategy was to use Mr. Panic in an effort to persuade world leaders to lift the economic sanctions. The United Nations Security Council holds the new Yugoslavia responsible for militarily aiding Bosnia and Herzegovina's Serbs in their territorial conquests and forced expulsions of hundreds of thousands of Muslims.
But in the five months since Mr. Panic arrived, during which he narrowly survived two parliamentary votes of confidence, he has attacked Mr. Milosevic for stalling free elections and refusing to relinquish control of the country's major news outlets.
 
His First Such Tour
 The present campaign tour is Mr. Panic's first attempt at building up grass-roots support in Serbia. The latest polling results show the Prime Minister with a slight lead in the race, but more than 15 percent of people surveyed said they were undecided.
 
Support for Milosevic
 Milosevic supporters at the fringe of today's rally showed the antipathy that Mr. Panic faces.
"Mr. Panic has traveled the world but done nothing for his people," said a 71-year-old former salesman, Petar Radenkovic. "He is the worst kind of livestock."
Mr. Radenkovic angrily added: "He is Bush's agent and thinks only about his foreign masters and his business. He wants to sell Serbia out."
Ljubisa Petkovic, a 26-year-old water-works employee, said: "The West wants to take off Milosevic's head because he is wise and will not compromise. The Serbs have given many lives for this piece of land, and we will give many more if we have to."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Milan Panic, the Prime Minister of Yugoslavia, greeting supporters yesterday at a campaign rally in Nis. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Clinton's Choice of Reich Hints at a Stepped-Up Role for Labor Department

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton's choice for Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, brings a detailed and perhaps controversial agenda to an agency that has long been an administrative backwater.
Mr. Reich's torrent of writings over the last decade makes clear that he will bring a commitment to the notion that America's work force can be made more productive through Government job-training and education programs. 
 He wants to provide apprenticeships for high school graduates who do not go to college; he hopes to require companies to provide more training for workers on the shop floor, and he wants to improve productivity through better labor-management relations.
 
Shades of Frances Perkins
 Thanks to his formidable energy and close friendship with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Reich could well become the most visible Labor Secretary since Frances Perkins, President Franklin D. Roosevelt's trailblazing Labor Secretary, who played a leading role in creating the Social Security and unemployment insurance systems.
Those who keep track of who is up and who is down in Washington took note today when the President-elect, in announcing four appointments, called Mr. Reich "one of my most trusted advisers and closest friends." Indeed, parts of Mr. Clinton's "Putting People First" economic program read like excerpts from one of Mr. Reich's many books. Mr. Reich is the director of the Clinton economic transition team and is a lecturer on public policy at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
In his brief remarks today Mr. Clinton signaled his intellectual debt to Mr. Reich, saying he did not know of any American who had "done more to make the case for the need to invest in the skills and the training of our people than Bob has." The President-elect suggested a stepped-up role for the Labor Department, saying, "The position of Secretary of Labor is a vital part of my economic team because investing in the skills and training of our work force is central to our strategy for economic growth."
Mr. Reich's charge appears to be different from that of his predecessors; as the nation feels the heat of foreign competition, he is to help push new ideas for improving the work force. Several of his predecessors, especially John T. Dunlop under President Gerald R. Ford, were there for their mediating skills, while others, like Peter J. Brennan under President Richard M. Nixon, were there as bridges to the labor movement.
The last activist in the job was President Jimmy Carter's Labor Secretary, F. Ray Marshall, who focused on one of the biggest needs of the 1970's: providing jobs and training for the hard-core unemployed in the inner cities. Mr. Reich brings a 1990's focus: improving education and training for all workers.
Mr. Marshall said: "The reason the focus has changed was that if you asked experts in the 70's who had the best-educated, best-trained work force in the world, they'd say the United States. If you asked that today, I don't know anybody who'd say the U.S. has the best-educated work force."
In his book "The Work of Nations," published last year by Alfred A. Knopf Inc., Mr. Reich sketched a vision of a new world economy in which companies have no loyalty to their native countries and cavalierly move factories and jobs anywhere on the globe. The book asserts that the primary way the United States can keep and attract high-paying jobs is by improving the quality of the work force and the infrastructure, including improved telecommunications and safer, cleaner cities.
Mr. Reich had been on the short list to be the incoming President's senior economic adviser, some Clinton advisers said, but he balked at the job, seeing it as one for a neutral policy coordinator rather than a highly opinionated generator of ideas like himself.
Several aides said Mr. Reich also hoped to become chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, but was hindered because he has a law degree rather than a doctorate in economics.
While Mr. Reich may be regarded as an unorthodox choice for Labor Secretary, aides said he was nominated because Mr. Clinton wanted his valued friend and adviser at his side as he tries to get the economy back on track.

HEADLINE: Macy Reports a Narrower Loss in Quarter

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Losses at R. H. Macy & Company narrowed in the first quarter of its 1993 fiscal year, the bankrupt retailer reported yesterday. It added that holiday sales were running ahead of last year and slightly ahead of plan, but the company said it remained cautious.
For the quarter that ended on Oct. 31, Macy reported a loss of $135.8 million on sales of $1.5 billion, compared with a loss of $155.3 million on sales of $1.6 billion in the corresponding period a year ago. The first quarter of 1992 included sales at stores that have since been closed. 
 Excluding the effect of stores that have been closed, Macy said comparable-store sales fell by 5.7 percent in the quarter that ended on Oct. 31.
 
A 'Difficult' Quarter
 "We knew the October quarter would be difficult," Myron E. Ullman 3d, co-chairman and co-chief executive, said in a telephone interview.
Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a figure analysts of highly indebted companies watch closely, were $13.38 million, an amount Macy said was in line with expectations and that exceeded the minimum specified in bank loan covenants.
The company said borrowings from its $600 million debtor-in-possession financing were $124 million below expectations. Macy said it intended to repay all of its seasonal borrowings next week. The loans are used to pay for merchandise, utility bills, wages and salaries.
The credit line is being supplied by a bank group led by the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Bankers Trust New York Company.
Macy officials were guardedly optimistic about the important Christmas season.
In a statement announcing the results, Mr. Ullman and Mark S. Handler, co-chairman and co-chief executive, said: "Since Thanksgiving and the start of the holiday shopping season, we have seen an increase in store traffic. This has led to somewhat stronger-than-expected sales, particularly in Florida and Georgia."
But the executives said that economic conditions remained weak in California and the Northeast, areas where many Macy's stores are situated.
"For that reason, we continue to be cautious about the overall results for the holiday season," they said.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Ullman said that in addition to Florida and Georgia, "business looks very good in New York City and Washington, D.C." He said conditions in California were "very poor."
In New York, Christmas sales ofMacy's flagship store at Herald Square have been particularly strong, Mr. Ullman said, but added, "We planned very conservatively for this Christmas."
 "In terms of our ability to return to profitability, Christmas 1993 will be a much better barometer," he said.
Reflecting this year's conservative approach, Macy said inventories continued to be tightly managed, which analysts said should allow the company to avoid heavy price markdowns during the Christmas rush.
"Everybody has been playing it pretty close to the vest in terms of inventories," said Jan L. Dillow, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. "That means you have a chance to bolster your profit margins. But I am not sure that Macy's will participate to the same extent as other retailers in a stronger Christmas."
Macy, whose executives confidently took on billions in debt in the late 1980's, filed for bankruptcy protection last Jan. 27.

HEADLINE: Environmental Truce Clears Smoke in Rice Fields

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RICHVALE, Calif., Dec. 4

 BODY:
It is nearly winter in the wide, fertile valley of the Sacramento River in Northern California, a time when the poplars and willows turn golden and the rice farmers normally send up a ghastly pall of smoke over the valley as they burn the stubble of last season's crop.
But it will be different this winter. More and more farmers, with the blessing of state and Federal water officials and environmentalists alike, will get rid of their stubble not with fire but with water, flooding their fields to rot the remaining straw. 
 That this is happening is the result of an extraordinary truce in the environmental wars. Under the truce, the farmers get an environmentally benign way to clear their fields and relief from bad publicity and the environmentalists get new wetlands for migrating waterfowl. Everybody, it seems, wins.
 
Some Strange Bedfellows
 On this day a cast of strange bedfellows crowded into the board room of the Lundberg Family Farms, rice growers for more than half a century. There were Dennis B. Underwood, the Commissioner of Reclamation; leaders of the rice industry; representatives of leaders of duck and waterfowl groups; the Nature Conservancy, and environmentalists.
Most notable among the environmentalists gathered here was Marc Reisner, who in 1986 wrote "Cadillac Desert," a history of water use and misuse in the West, and has long accused rice farmers of wasting Government-subsidized water by growing a monsoon crop in the desert that is California.
But Mr. Reisner now calls the rice growers "the most progressive" of California's agricultural interests on environmental issues. "I am in the awkward position of being pals with my former enemies," he said.
The group had assembled to unveil a three-year pilot project by which about 12,000 acres of rice fields are being flooded to test its effect. If it works, it is expected that about 200,000 acres of new winter wetlands can be created.
The fields are already attracting great flocks of Canada geese, swans and mallards, whose numbers have dwindled because 95 percent of California's wetlands have been turned into farm land or residential tracts. The Sacramento Valley is the main wintering habitat along the Pacific Flyway, the migratory route that extends from the Arctic to Central America.
The participants in the project, called the Ricelands Habitat Venture, are the Nature Conservancy, the California Rice Industry Association, Ducks Unlimited, the National Audubon Society, the California Waterfowl Association and Mr. Reisner. Under the plan, the fields are to be flooded from December through February, a time when they are fallow anyway and when the birds come south for the winter.
Conservationists have long talked about cooperating with their opponents in industry and agriculture to reverse environmental degradation, but the rice truce is one of the few successes.
Mr. Underwood, who heads the Bureau of Reclamation, a Federal agency that is part of the Department of the Interior, called the truce a "fabulous marriage" in which economic and environmental values alike are promoted, at little financial cost.
The bureau, which operates the largest water supply system in California, is contributing $300,000 in matching funds for research and 5,000 acre-feet of water for the test. An acre-foot is about 326,000 gallons, or about enough to supply two typical households for one year.
What makes the rice project so unusual is that it allows the rice farmers, who have been criticized by Mr. Reisner and others for using too much water, to use even more.
 
A Crucial Question
 But a crucial question remains: Will there be enough water for the winter flooding, given that state hydrologists recently predicted a seventh consecutive year of drought? Ideally, with a normal rainfall, the flooding would be done in the fall and winter when the rivers are swollen, then the fields would be drained in mid-February after the stubble had decomposed and the birds had started north again.
While rice is not a major part of California's agricultural economy, it is the main crop here in Butte, Colusa and Sutter counties, where the adobe clay soil permits little water to percolate down. Nearly 500,000 acres a year are planted, with a cash value of about $250 million.
The crop is planted in April and May and harvested in September and October, after which the remaining straw is usually burned before replanting in the spring. But a new state law requires the farmers to end most burning by 1998, and that deadline has pressured them to come to terms with opponents of the rice industry.
Mr. Reisner said the "peace offensive" began two and a half years ago, when the rice industry invited him for a "good will" tour. He has since been retained by the Nature Conservancy to work out the pilot program.
In fact, environmentalists have taken a new view about the value of rice farming. Although it requires inordinate amounts of scarce water, the 300 pounds an acre of grain left after the harvest provides ideal food for migrating birds, according to Frederic A. Reid, a biologist with the Western regional office of Ducks Unlimited, a wetlands conservation group.
 
Added Storage Capacity
 The project also has another potential advantage: the flooded fields will add to the region's capacity to store water during the wet months without building costly dams and reservoirs.
According to Douglas P. Wheeler, Gov. Pete Wilson's Secretary for Resources, the program may serve as a national model for resolving environmental conflicts. "This has made allies out of former enemies," he said. "It is a model that we have not seen before in which each of the participants can be so well rewarded."
Some farmers are skeptical about flooding as an alternative to burning. But Doug McGeoghegan of Maxwell, Calif., a farmer in Colusa County who has been flooding his fields for years, says his yields are just as good as those on burned fields. And Gordon L. Brewster, manager of the 3,200-acre Lundberg farms, which have not burned straw since 1960, called flooding "most effective" as long as there is rain.
For their part, the chief concern of environmentalists is the flooding's potential effect on endangered species of fish. The Sacramento River is the spawning ground of endangered fish like the winter-run and spring-run chinook salmon. Mr. Reisner says the "most worrisome" aspect of the project is that water diverted from the river to the rice fields will further damage the spawning grounds.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
An Unorthodox Choice For Economic Adviser

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The new chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, is a decidedly unorthodox choice. And least of all because she is the first woman to head the council since it was created just after World War II.
The head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers has historically been the most mainstream of mainstream economists, hewing to an economic middleground. Yet Professor Tyson, a prolific author who is 45 and has a Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, says the United States is "teetering on the abyss of economic decline." She is almost certainly the first person to head the council who believes that managed trade is often preferable to free trade and that industrial policy works. 
 "It shows that the Clinton Administration is really trying to listen to someone with new ideas, someone with global views on the economy," said Lawrence B. Katz, an economist at Harvard University. "It's forward looking."
 
Focus on Economy
 Of course, Mr. Clinton has brought the economy to center stage for the first time in a long while, and the President-elect has set up a new structure, an economic coordinating council that will be over the Council of Economic Advisers in the White House hierarchy.
Professor Tyson, whose original specialty was the economics of planning, Eastern European style, outlined her views in a new book, "Who's Bashing Whom: Trade Conflict in High Technology Industries" (Institute for International Economics, 1992). In it, she contends that the nation with the initial edge in an important industry, whether camcorders or computer chips, often keeps that edge.
In her book, she strongly advocates using Government policy to make sure the United States gets this economic edge: subsidies to industries that are developing new technologies, especially if other governments are doing the same; tougher trade tactics, and channeling money into commercial research. The point is to hang onto high-wage manufacturing jobs.
But as chairwoman of the council, she is most likely to be asked immediately to make several judgments about the domestic economy. First, whether the economic expansion is weak enough to warrant short-term stimulus. And, second, how different strategies to reduce the deficit would affect the economy.
 
Not Worried About Deficit
 On such issues , Professor Tyson's views are not as widely known.
She does, in principle, support short-term stimulus to get the economy moving and has recently expressed the view that there is no necessary connection between the Federal deficit and economic health. "It's not the most important issue," she has written. And, she has does not fear that much higher taxes on the richest Americans will stifle economic growth.
"In direct contradiction to 12 years of Republican ideology, there is no relationship between the level of taxes a nation pays and its economic performance," she said in The Los Angeles Times, where she is a regular columnist.
Such positions are controversial. But what is beginning to draw attention is her longstanding relationships with Silicon Valley companies that stand to benefit from the policies she advocates.
The Berkeley Roundtable on the International Economy, which Professor Tyson has helped found in the early 1980's and now serves as a co-director, is a trade and technology research institute at the University of California that has received research money both from individual companies and trade organizations.
 
Attuned to Clinton
 Some wonder whether Professor Tyson's influence in the Administration may be too limited to fuss about. Such doubts may be premature, however, in large part because it ignores how compatible Professor Tyson's brand of Democratic supply-side economics and her approach are with those of the President-elect.
"The role of the chairman depends very much on what the President wants," said Herbert Stein, who served as President Nixon's chief economic adviser. "Alan Greenspan was an important C.E.A. chairman because he and Gerald Ford used to watch football together."
Consider the Professor Tyson's initial meeting with Governor Clinton last August when she and four other economists were invited to come and talk about the economy for two and a half hours. The least academically distinguished of the group, which also included a Nobel laureate, James Tobin, as well Lawrence Summers of the World Bank, Alan Blinder of Princeton and Paul Krugman of M.I.T., she nonetheless stole the show.
"She really shone," Professor Krugman said. "It would be a mistake to underestimate her."
"There are no curlicues and exfoliations of intricate details," said Erik Tarloff, her husband and a Hollywood screenwriter and novelist, "but she manages to abstract the most important issues and she has a really impressive intuitive grasp of the way that economic policies affect real people."
Besides, her husband points out, she's a mystery addict. Just like the President-elect.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Trading in Dollar Is Mixed As Pressure Builds in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed yesterday in foreign exchange trading, as the market was jarred by new uncertainty in the European currency system.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $335.20 an ounce, up $1.10 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $335.10, up $1.20. 
 Traders said the renewed pressure on Europe's Exchange Rate Mechanism, which sets limits for the fluctuation of member currencies, was intensified by Germany's announcement on Thursday that it would not lower interest rates. Germany's high rates have made the mark an attractive investment, prompting speculators to sell other currencies and stock up on marks despite worries about the German economy.
The European Community summit meeting in Edinburgh, Scotland, also caused uncertainty in the markets.
Dealers said trading was active, with Germany's central bank confirming its support of the French currency by purchasing the franc against the mark.
Norway's decision on Thursday to let its crown float freely against other currencies caused more turbulence.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 123.78 yen, down 0.32 yen from the Thursday close. Later, in London, the dollar rebounded to 123.80 yen. In New York, the dollar traded at 123.90 yen, up from 123.70 late Thursday.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5585, from $1.5575 late Thursday. In New York, 1 cost $1.5570, up from $1.5540 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5785 marks, down from 1.5795; 1.4085 Swiss francs, down from 1.4090; 5.3935 French francs, down from 5.3950; 1,396.50 Italian lire, down from 1,397.00, and 1.27425 Canadian dollars, up from 1.27275.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with the late Thursday rates, included: 1.5760 German marks, down from 1.5765; 1.4050 Swiss francs, down from 1.4105; 5.3875 French francs, up from 5.3870; 1.7735 Dutch guilders, unchanged; 1,394.25 Italian lire, down from 1,397.00, and 1.2765 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2717.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $335.10 an ounce, from $333.85 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold rose to a bid of $335.00 from $333.70. In Hong Kong, gold rose 87 cents, to a bid of $335.12.

HEADLINE: Climbing His Way Back, With Help From Neediest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
One day Larry K. was wearing expensive suits, hatching deals for a prominent brokerage firm and dating a woman he loved. The next day he woke up in a mental hospital and his life began a seven-year plunge that left him an angry and confused man cut off from family and friends.
After that first breakdown, he wandered the country for years, working at menial jobs as a series of doctors tried to treat him. "It was a tough time," he recalled the other day. "I fought with everybody and I was always wrapped up in my head. I was a total basket case." 
 Doctors finally diagnosed manic-depression in 1988 and he began taking lithium, which cured him of the worst symptoms. Now, at the age of 43, he is struggling to start over with help from Metro-House, a shelter financed in part by United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, a charity aided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
 
'I Don't Have to Worry'
 Metro-House, which opened earlier this year, assists mentally ill people who are trying to fit back into society after leaving hospitals. About 40 men and women live at the transitional shelter at 117 West 70th Street in Manhattan, which is run by the Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty.
Metro-House provides Larry K. with a room and meals while he searches for his first stable job in more than a decade. When he feels nervous about his return to the workaday world, he can seek out counselors there for advice and support.
"I'm constantly getting better now," he said. "This place has been very helpful. It gives me a place to stay, so I don't have to worry."
This year's Neediest appeal, the 81st, comes during a relentless recession in New York City that has heaped added burdens on charities like U.J.A.-Federation. Many are trying to aid growing numbers of the newly unemployed while also caring for people like Larry K.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was born in 1911, when Adolph S. Ochs, the publisher of The Times, decided that his readers would be eager to improve their city if they only knew about the poverty around them. The 1992-93 campaign ends on Feb. 28.
The Times pays for the fund's overhead, so all contributions are given directly to the seven charities, which must rely more and more on private donations because of strained budgets and reduced government help.
Now that his illness is under control, Larry K. wants to find a job at a brokerage, even though he would have to start slowly and could not put in the long hours he was accustomed to before his first breakdown.
"I loved that work and I was good at it," he said. "I feel like I have the chance to pick up with the rest of my life. This has been a very difficult and trying period. But now I feel good. I get along with people. My head is clear. I feel like I've gotten a new lease on life."
