HEADLINE: Tapping the Rich May Prove Tricky

SERIES: Tax Politics: Second of four articles

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
As Bill Clinton's new economic team considers how best to turn his campaign promises on taxes into legislative proposals, it may feel the ground shifting.
His campaign tossed around a host of proposals on Government financing, from spending cuts to getting more tax revenue from corporations and individuals, all aimed at getting the resources to accomplish goals ranging from middle-class tax relief to public works to halving the deficit. But the consensus among experts was that many of the proposals were unrealistic, and that the proposal most likely to yield significant new money was tax increases on the wealthiest taxpayers. 
 Getting the really rich -- the people who reaped an outsize share of the economic gains of the 1980's -- to pay more was a major plank of the Democratic campaign. For Clinton tax purposes, a couple with income of $200,000 and a single taxpayer with $150,000 count as rich.
 
Likely to Fall Short
 The problem is that while higher tax rates on high incomes are likely to provide a good deal of new money, they are not likely, barring an unexpectedly buoyant economy, to generate the $92 billion over four years that the Clinton camp has claimed.
Many experts had been skeptical of that claim from the start. Congressional Budget Office estimates put the added revenue at a maximum of $80 billion over four years and estimates from Treasury officials and the Republican side of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress are even lower.
But even as long-term deficit projections are looking gloomier, so also is the outlook for collecting as much from the rich as had been projected even in the lower estimates.
Perhaps the biggest consideration is one raised in a new study of how very rich taxpayers react to higher taxes. The study, published by the National Bureau of Economic Research, strongly suggests that extremely rich people -- the top slice of the top 1 percent of taxpayers -- have considerable flexibility to expose less of their income to taxation.
Just how much flexibility they have has recently become apparent. Those who can have raced to take bonuses now rather than next year, to cash in stock options -- as Michael Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company did -- and to move income forward in any way possible.
Economists have long known this type of behavior takes place, and there are some, like Lawrence Lindsey, a Federal Reserve governor, who suggest that it was a big factor in accounting for the sizable growth in income among the very rich in the 1980's as tax rates came down.
What the new study by James Poterba at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Daniel Feenberg at the National Bureau of Economic Research, suggests, however, is that it may have been an even bigger factor than many believed -- and may be a big obstacle now to raising revenues from the rich.
"If there's a significant change in rates, say from 31 percent to 41 percent, people will change their behavior to take advantage of ways to defer income," Professor Poterba said. "It would set into motion a return to pre-1986 tax shelters."
Another reason for thinking that the rich will yield less revenue than Clinton tax planners had hoped is that the rich may not possess as many riches as they used to. The latest Internal Revenue Service summary of tax returns, for 1989, released this year, shows that many high fliers -- real estate empire builders, retailers and newly redundant executives -- had their wings clipped during the last four years of economic drift.
The number of taxpayers reporting pretax income of $1 million or more dropped from 62,000 in 1988 to 58,000 in 1989, and their share of total income shrank from 5.5 percent to 4.7 percent. What is more, their income in excess of $1 million, which would be subject to a surcharge under the Clinton plan, dropped 13 percent in 1989.
 
$200,000 Threshold For the Rich
 Under the Clinton campaign tax proposals, the top tax rate would jump to 36 percent from 31 percent for people with gross pretax incomes of $200,000 or more. The plan would also impose a 3.6 percentage point surtax on incomes of $1 million or more, making their top rate 39.6 percent. It would also stiffen the alternative minimum tax, enacted a decade or so ago to wring dollars from taxpayers with big write-offs.
Some temporary provisions of the 1990 budget pact lifted the top marginal rate about a percentage point above the 31 percent already on the books, so the proposed increase would expose wealthy lawyers, rock stars and entrepreneurs to a rate just above 40 percent on their incomes of more than a million dollars. While still well below the 50 percent top rate during the first Reagan term and still on the low end of the spectrum for industrial countries, economists say such a rise is far from trivial.
"Higher rates always have incentive effects on work and saving," said Joel Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan. He added, however, that the negative impact on such decisions is not nearly as high as the Reagan-era tax-cutters argued.
Under the Clinton plan, the effective rate paid by the very rich -- the average share of income that is actually paid in taxes -- is also apt to climb a couple of percentage points, from about 22 percent now back to the 25 percent rate of the Carter years.
 
Capital Gains Factor Could Skew Results
 Yet another factor that could lead to a smaller-than-expected increase in tax revenues from the very rich is the prospect that the Clinton Administration may opt not to raise the capital gains tax rate in tandem with the top tax brackets. Capital gains account for nearly half of the income of taxpayers in the $1 million-plus category and one-third for those with incomes between $200,000 and $1 million. As long as capital gains are taxed at a substantially lower rate than ordinary income, the richest taxpayers will have a strong incentive to convert ordinary income into capital gains income.
"It doesn't take a genius to see what the result would be," Harry L. Gutman, chief of staff of the Joint Economic Committee, recently told an audience of accountants.
And the early assumptions of the Clinton team could also be shaken by the sharp turn for the worse in the prospects for reducing the Federal deficit. In the spring, when "Putting People First," the Clinton campaign's economic manifesto, was drafted, the Congressional Budget Office was optimistically predicting that the 1990 budget pact would tame the deficit monster. Using those projections, the Clinton team could contend that the deficit would fall by half without imposing much pain on the middle class.
Now, however, Mr. Clinton's strategists must find roughly $100 billion a year through permanent tax increases or spending cuts to fulfill his deficit-shrinking pledge. The latest Congressional Budget Office projections suggest that if the economy and policy follow current projections the annual deficit will still be more than $250 billion in 1996 and rising fast.
 
Middle-Class Relief Has Its Doubters
 Where does that leave the middle-class tax cut? Robert Reich and other spokesmen for the President-elect keep insisting that the middle class -- which accounts for three-fourths of total taxpayer income -- deserves tax relief. But the consensus view among economists is that the Clinton Administration will have to prune the proposal radically or even drop it altogether merely to avoid inflating the deficit further.
"Even without the middle-class tax cut, the plan is mildly deficit-increasing." said Paul R. Krugman, an M.I.T. economist. "It would be nice to get a sense from Little Rock that there are some hard choices being made."
Mr. Clinton said again yesterday that he would not back off from a middle-class tax cut, even though increasing numbers of experts say that the stimulus of a tax cut may not be needed since the economy has recently shown some healthy signs. But Mr. Clinton said a tax cut was a matter of "fairness," because in his view the middle class has borne too large a share of the tax burden.
Actually, Mr. Clinton made two proposals during the campaign. One was to grant $60 billion of relief to middle-class taxpayers, that is those with incomes under $80,000 for a couple. Such relief, spread over 60 million taxpayers, would amount to $300 a child, $200 for couples without children and $100 for singles.
The second proposal, really a part of Mr. Clinton's welfare reform program, is to raise the reward of working by expanding the popular earned-income tax credit for poor workers with children. Estimated costs are $2 billion to $3 billion a year.
Taken together, the two changes, if carried out on this scale, would swallow up the revenue raised from the rich and then some.
 
Uncertain Outlook For Merely Affluent
 Despite a blanket promise not to raise the tax rates of anyone but the really rich, some question whether Mr. Clinton will be able to spare entirely the 5.6 million merely affluent taxpayers, those with incomes between $80,000 and $200,000. That group commands some $600 billion in pretax income, even more in the aggregate than the over-$200,000 crowd.
There is also no explicit promise that his plans to get more revenue will be limited to raising top income-tax rates. Limiting the mortgage deduction or taxing fringe benefits could cast a wide net and bring in big money; such steps would, however, face formidable political obstacles.
Nobody knows what Mr. Clinton will actually propose, even less how Congress -- with new leaders in tax-writing committees and an influx of newcomers -- will dispose. His team is compiling a book of policy options to present to the President-elect after the so-called economic summit meeting next week.
One safe prediction, analysts say, is that higher rates will probably give a strong impetus to more special breaks for individual saving and investments.
"The driving force of the 1986 tax reform was to create a level playing field," said David Cutler, a Harvard economist. "This says the level playing field is wrong. There are some things that have much bigger social rates of return than other things, and this is a cheap way to get more of them."
Two possible candidates for adoption are a capital gains tax cut and expanded individual retirement accounts. The capital gains tax could be trimmed either by indexing capital gains for inflation or excluding from ordinary income a fraction of the capital gains from a start-up new business, prospects that excite some supply-side supporters of Reaganomics sufficiently to bring them into the Clinton camp.

HEADLINE: The Dow Declines by 8.11 As Storm Crimps Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks were trapped in a 10-point trading range yesterday as a severe storm in the Northeast brought Wall Street trading to a virtual standstill, squeezing volume to the lowest level in two weeks.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 8.11 points, to 3,304.08. For the week, the Dow rose 15.40 points.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was a meager 164.5 million shares, the lowest level since 106.1 million changed hands Nov. 27, the day after Thanksgiving. Trading compared with 240.6 million shares Thursday.
Losing issues outnumbered gainers by 919 to 840.
Drenching rain, heavy winds and flooding caused early-morning commuting delays, depleting Wall Street's staff and later causing several firms to evacuate their offices.
 
Storm the Big News
 Investors ignored news of more Clinton Administration appointees and positive economic reports, focusing instead on storm and commuting updates.
"The weather was considered bigger news than the Presidential appointments today," said Robert Stovall of Stovall/21st Advisers.
In individual stocks, Maybelline, a new issue, ended at 26 3/4. It was priced at 23 1/2.
Among Nasdaq stocks, Novell lost 3 1/4, to 27 1/2, after reporting slightly disappointing fourth-quarter results. Several analysts cut earnings estimates and ratings.
Shares of QVC Network jumped 4 1/8, to 37 1/8. Barry Diller, former Fox Inc. chairman, has agreed to take a nearly 3 percent stake in QVC as part of a group he heads. A rival, Home Shopping Network, added 1 1/4, to 8 3/4.
Biogen rose 3 3/4, to 47. It said it expected to earn more than $1 a share in 1992, compared with 15 cents in 1991. It also forecast a significant increase in revenues and earnings for the fourth quarter.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks fell 0.91, to 433.73. The American Stock Exchange index rose 0.99, to 393.38.
The New York Stock Exchange Composite index of all listed common stocks fell 0.34 point, to 238.63. The Nasdaq index fell 3.14, to 655.79.

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
A 'Messiah' Looks Back to Premiere in Dublin

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH

 BODY:
Handel's "Messiah," which had its premiere in Dublin 250 years ago, has throughout its history been a touchstone of the vicissitudes of Baroque music. One of few works from the era to circulate prominently through the ages, it held its own by evolving with progressive times, from Mozart's fluffy orchestration to the elephan tine inflations of the late 19th century. Some streamlining took place in the 20th century even before current notions of historical correctness began to take hold about four decades ago.
The result has been an incredible shrinking "Messiah," epitomized by the likes of the performance presented by Christopher Hogwood and the Handel and Haydn Society of Boston on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. Using the musical text of the Dublin premiere, Mr. Hogwood deployed a chorus and period-instrument orchestra of 34 each, and seven relatively small-voiced soloists. The performance illustrated the achievements of the early-music movement as well as its besetting problems. 
 As the movement has shown, it is possible to turn the clock back on performance style to some extent (a more limited extent, to be sure, than many of its exponents have argued). But it is not possible to function within economic or social circumstances like those of earlier periods. Steven Ledbetter, in notes for the Hogwood performance, writes that in Dublin, "a hall designed to seat 600 actually accommodated 700" for the premiere. Whatever that first performance may have sounded like, it must have had greater visceral impact than Mr. Hogwood's hardy little band could muster in this 2,700-seat hall.
Still, the wee sound was lovely. The chorus was ravishing, solid yet transparent, singing with excellent intonation and balance. The orchestra represented a particularly fine assemblage of players from the Boston-New York early-music axis. (The principal oboist was, of course, the estimable Stephen Hammer, not "Rammor," as listed in the program.) Only at the end of the evening did the string sonority grow a bit attenuated.
Developing suitably punctilious soloists of real temperament and stature has been another problem for the early-music movement, one not solved especially well here. David Thomas, who sings on Mr. Hogwood's Oiseau-Lyre recording of "Messiah," was perhaps the best-known soloist, but his bass once again proved a blunt instrument and not notably strong. From Sharon Baker, Judith Malafronte, Derek Lee Ragin, Johnson Flucker, Douglas Johnson and David Murray, mere competence prevailed.
Mr. Hogwood's use of the Dublin edition had a poetic aptness in this anniversary year. (His recording is based on the London version of 1754, and his performance with the society four years ago at Avery Fisher Hall played off later London accounts.)
But the edition entails severe losses for the "Messiah" fan. The chorus "Their Sound Is Gone Out" disappears altogether, and the magnificent aria "But Who May Abide" is restored to a piddling recitative. Of one of Handel's grandest inspirations in the work, the lift to soprano in the second part of the alto aria "He Shall Feed His Flock," there is no trace.
Mr. Hogwood's pacing was brisk and knowing. A few interpretive touches verged on the precious, like the showy diminuendo on the last chord of Part 1, for the word "light," as in burden. As added tone-painting, it seemed belated and gratuitous.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
JOSIE NATORI, the founder and president of the lingerie and fashion company that bears her name, gets lots of invitations, especially at this time of year, so nothing seemed exceptional to her about one that arrived in her office the other day.
"It went to the bottom of a pile of mail, and I didn't even notice it," she said yesterday, explaining why she had given short shrift to the hottest ticket in town: a summons to President-elect BILL CLINTON's high-level economic meeting in Little Rock tomorrow through Tuesday. "My secretary finally brought it to my attention saying, 'You didn't respond to this and your husband thinks you should go,' " she said. "I brushed past her, telling her: 'This is a last-minute invitation. It's a fax, but find out what it's all about.' " 
 When it sank in that she was one of only 300 people invited to help the President-elect formulate economic policy, Ms. Natori canceled a slew of business meetings and social engagements. Tomorrow she is off to Little Rock.
She may have been late with her R.S.V.P., but she's going well prepared. "I think I represent several angles," she said. "I am a woman, an Asian -- I was born in the Philippines -- and I run a small business. I want to tell him that he must consider the effects of his policies on small business as well as on I.B.M."
And in the future, she said, she will probably pay closer attention to invitations.

HEADLINE: Bill Clinton's Pragmatists

 BODY:
President-elect Clinton's announcement of four more high-level appointments yesterday made it clear that he intends to run a problem-solving Administration -- creative but not ideological, energetic but not confrontational. His managers, he said, must know "the limits of what government can do as well as what government must do."
Three of the four are women, reflecting Mr. Clinton's pledge for a diversified Administration. Laura Tyson, an economist at Berkeley, will head the Council of Economic Advisers. Carol Browner, Florida's top environmental official and a protegee of Vice President-elect Al Gore, will run the Environmental Protection Agency. 
 Donna Shalala, chancellor of the University of Wisconsin, will lead the Department of Health and Human Services. The Harvard lecturer Robert Reich will become Labor Secretary.
Ms. Tyson describes herself as a "cautious activist." She has been accused, wrongly, of protectionism. But she does call for retaliation against protectionism by other countries. And she would subsidize U.S. industries that promote advanced research, train skilled workers and otherwise spin off large benefits to the rest of the economy. All this gives heartburn to many economists who preach free, unsubsidized markets and multilateral solutions to trade problems.
Unlike Ms. Tyson, Mr. Reich opposes selective subsidies for industry. Yet he too champions major investments in education and workplace skills. That's the centerpiece of Mr. Clinton's strategy for spurring growth by "putting people first" -- a strategy Mr. Reich helped design.
Ms. Shalala is a more curious choice. A skilled backstage negotiator, she received high marks for her stewardship of New York City's Hunter College and the University of Wisconsin. Yet she is primarily an educator. The two most pressing tasks facing her department are reforming the welfare system and overhauling medical care.
Ms. Browner, the choice for the E.P.A., faithfully reflects Mr. Clinton's vision of artful activism. Few officials face more difficult choices -- choices between jobs and environmental protection, between committed environmentalists and businessmen who, as Mr. Clinton observed yesterday, are often disheartened by complex and sometimes contradictory regulations.
Ms. Browner won compromises on several thorny issues in Florida, satisfying environmentalists without enraging industry. Her strength was her ability to steer all parties toward agreement by balancing competing interests and avoiding ideological combat -- a defining and useful trait in all of Mr. Clinton's appointments thus far.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Political Democracy Hurts Russia's Economic Freedom

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire makes an important point about the need for Russia to push ahead with a comprehensive and not half-hearted economic reform program ("Visions in Collision," column, Dec. 3). His second point, however, that Russia should reject the Chinese model of reform -- authoritarian political rule coupled with increasing economic freedom -- is more problematic. 
 Certainly, political democracy and economic freedom are preferable to authoritarian rule and economic freedom. But in the real world, unfortunately, political democracy often works to undercut economic freedom and often leads to anarchy and lawlessness or authoritarian rule. The result: neither political democracy nor economic freedom.
Are the people of Somalia, for example, better off since they were granted political independence? Are their fellow Africans throughout the continent enjoying higher standards of living because they adopted the principle of one man one vote? Has either the political or economic situation in Brazil and Peru improved because these two countries embraced democracy?
It is not my purpose to belittle democracy. It is, as Churchill noted, the worst form of government except for all the rest. But stable and successful democracies such as exist in the United States and Western Europe can only emerge with the development of an entrepreneurial middle class. Indeed, the existence of such a class in these countries made real and sustainable democracy possible. There, the prosperous middle classes appealed to democratic principles to preserve their way of life. Economic freedom naturally led to political democracy; and the two concepts reinforce one another.
Similarly, the Communists may rule China today, but their days are numbered; and as history shows, it is only a matter of time before real, sustainable democracy gains sway in one of the world's oldest and potentially most dynamic civilizations.
Democracy has failed, by contrast, in those countries that have yet to agree on the rules under which they should be governed. Or they have agreed to rules that cannot work.
Russia is a case in point. By its actions thus far, it has committed itself to a post-Socialist economic order that is destined to fail. And political democracy, unfortunately, has proved itself not up to the task of dealing with this problem.
More than 90 percent of the reforms thus far in Russia, for example, have been enacted through executive decree -- that is, President Yeltsin's exercise of dictatorial powers. Mr. Yeltsin has never exercised his decree power to the extent necessary to put the Russian economy on a sound footing. His power to rule by decree expired, moreover, on Dec. 1, and is unlikely to be extended by the Congress of People's Deputies.
It is well and good for Mr. Safire to "root for the amalgam of political and economic freedom." But the unfortunate fact of life in Russia today is that political freedom now is the enemy of economic freedom and, ultimately, sustainable political freedom. As Russian inflation spirals out of control, and as Mr. Yeltsin's economic reform program is further watered down to buy peace from his opponents, it will become increasingly likely that Russia will have to choose between economic freedom and political democracy. For the sake of both, it must choose the former and not the latter.
 
JOHN R. GUARDIANO
Washington, Dec. 3, 1992
 
The writer is an analyst of Russian and East European economic affairs at The Heritage Foundation.

HEADLINE: S.I. Ferry Clock Would Overshadow the Battery

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your editorial "The Big Clock" (Nov. 23), which followed Sunday's thoughtful critique by Herbert Muschamp in the Arts and Leisure section about the winning scheme for the New Staten Island Ferry Terminal, over-romanticizes an unnecessarily oversized design. 
 Considering that this is a terminal for commuters (not a gateway for newcomers to the city, like the old Pennsylvania Station or the airport terminals), and is to be built at the tip of lower Manhattan (an area of the city not lacking in architectural heroics), a ferry slip with the equivalent of 18 stories of construction to celebrate crossing the Upper Bay seems to be overdoing it. While the view north from approaching vessels is famous the world over, at this point in our city's development the vista from the mainland may be even more critical. Imagine walking south through the dark canyons of Wall Street and emerging from Whitehall to be faced with the north side of a giant billboard (the Big Clock) where once there was a grand open sky.
It is especially ironic that as the hearings proceed on the New York City Department of City Planning's Comprehensive Waterfront Plan, a plan meant to conserve open space and discourage large-scale construction, the design appears to be sending the wrong message.
It would indeed be wonderful for New York to finally have a Robert Venturi/Denise Scott Brown building, but a much smaller one would not only save money but would also preserve the valued openness of the Battery.
 
PETER SAMTON
New York, Nov. 26, 1992
 
The writer, an architect, is a former City Club of New York president.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
WEYERHAEUSER SETS PULP MILL MODERNIZATION

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The Weyerhaeuser Company said yesterday that it had approved a $400 million modernization of its pulp mill in Longview, Wash., which is expected to provide a boost to the area's sagging economy. The project was approved by the timber company's board of directors. 
 "This project is the largest dollar expenditure and modernization in Weyerhaeuser-Longview's 63-year history," said Gary Healea, vice president and Longview mill manager. Weyerhaeuser had considered shutting down the mill if the modernization had not been approved by the board. At its peak last year, the mill employed 1,400. The work force has been gradually reduced to about 1,300.

PUB-DATE: December 13, 1992

SECTION: Section 6; Page 55; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5109 words

HEADLINE: Tackling Problems We Thought We Solved

BYLINE: By Perri Klass; Perri Klass is a pediatrician in Boston. Her most recent book is "Baby Doctor: A Pediatrician's Training."

 BODY:
'So this Salvadoran woman calls up and she has a 9-month-old baby with diarrhea, and the doctor on call gave her the right advice, said go to the pharmacy and buy Pedialyte. She had Medicaid, the doctor called the pharmacy, but when she got there, they said they couldn't give it to her for free without a written prescription. So she takes the kid home, and over the next 36 hours the baby gets worse. She doesn't call back -- she should have called back. The kid appears in the emergency room 36 hours later, moribund, and dies three days later." Alan Meyers, M.D., is an assistant professor of pediatrics at Boston University School of Medicine, and one of the primary care pediatricians at Boston City Hospital. The baby he is describing was a patient in the primary care system at this hospital, the child of an immigrant mother, growing up in inner-city Boston.
"My wife and I drove up there to that neighborhood, we went to every pharmacy. The rehydration solutions cost up to $6.30 a liter. It's obscene charging this much for a product that ought to be cheaper than Coca-Cola -- it has less in it." A baby dies of dehydration from diarrhea in an American city in the last decade of the 20th century. A mother cannot afford $6 worth of water and electrolytes, does not understand where to go for help. It is a particularly sad, pointed illustration of what anyone who cares about children already knows: growing up in extreme poverty is bad, stunting, dangerous. 
 Is there anything else to be done with this urban life-and-death story, any lesson to be drawn? Is there a way to translate these well-known truths of poverty into information that cannot be ignored? Those who offer medical care to the children of poverty find themselves using their research projects to demonstrate that poverty is not only damaging, but quantifiably damaging to infants and children, searching for specific indices of growth and development, individual health and family function, which will allow them to measure the parameters of growing up at the bottom of our society. And then, having gathered their data, these researchers find themselves using their medical degrees and their data to call attention, again and again, to the forces that threaten to destroy our cities from the inside out, to children who seem to be invisible to society.
Dr. Meyers and his colleagues reported the baby's case in an article in the Journal of the American Medical Association. He reflected on what he had learned on trips to the third world, where diarrheal dehydration is a leading cause of death in children under the age of 5. There the usual treatment is oral rehydration -- replenishing fluids orally rather than intravenously, as is done in this country. The treatment is a prepackaged mix of sugar and electrolytes, which parents then dissolve in water. Some doctors feel these parents should be trained to use a solution they can make themselves from rice gruel. Meyers says he thinks this home mix could be used here in the United States: "A homemade rice-based mixture," he says, "may be more effective at stopping diarrhea than the commercial solutions currently available." He is looking for financing for a study, to be conducted at Boston City Hospital, that will compare two different commercial formulas with the homemade mixture. His enthusiasm is obvious as he speaks of the "reverse flow of technology coming from the third world to the first world."
Those who practice pediatrics at Boston City Hospital become accustomed to these jumps: the clinical case, often a case that does not seem to belong to this country, even to this century, leads to a research project aimed at the same disadvantaged population that spawned the case, and then to social policy, political action and advocacy. Boston City Hospital serves the impoverished inner city, and the department of pediatrics takes care of its children. While some are the children of the working poor or even of the lower middle class, many are the children of the underclass, some exposed to drugs before they are born, some growing up amid violence and even murder, some the children of parents who are themselves only children. They are the children who may go hungry because there is not enough money in the house, and the babies for whose parents $6.30 may mean the difference between following the doctor's advice and taking the baby home without the medicine.
The people who work in this department are engaged as academic doctors, studying poverty and its effects on the growth and development of children. While almost any study in academic medicine is accepted as a contribution to knowledge, an end in itself, these studies are immediately turned around and used in advocacy work, in fierce and often passionate arguments that the situation could be changed, if our society cared to make those changes. At a moment of deep disillusionment and profound anxiety about the economics of health care in America, the researchers feel they must prove over and over what everyone should already know.
Children who grow up in dire poverty can be trapped in many dangerous cycles: the malnutrition-infection cycle, the children-having-children cycle, the abused-mother-abused-child cycle. To be useful to these children, research must do more than tease out the damage done at every turning of the wheel. The study of poverty and its traps must also become the study of ways out, ways around, ways through. And, because too much bad news can bring on a sense of fatalism, along with the message of the grim facts of the inner city there sometimes has to be, paradoxically, also the message of hope and resilience.
'WHAT BROUGHT ME BACK TO THIS place," Meyers says, "was that it was a department that could accommodate my noodling around in poverty issues, in policy." Meyers spent a year getting a degree in public health at Harvard before he came back to Boston City Hospital, where he had done his residency in the early 80's.
I had done my residency in pediatrics a mile or two away, at the Children's Hospital of Boston, and come to Boston City for a fellowship in pediatric infectious diseases. Children's also serves many poor inner-city children, but it is a very different hospital, private rather than public, and heavily oriented toward tertiary care: subspecialty care, all the miracles of modern pediatrics. In the emergency room and in the well-child clinic and on the wards, we cared for children with ordinary everyday pediatric problems but we also took care of children whose parents had flown up from South America specifically for heart surgery or a bone-marrow transplant, children who had come from a Persian Gulf emirate for a second opinion on a perplexing skin condition. This was a Harvard teaching hospital, which placed a very high value on research and perhaps the highest value of all on so-called basic science, investigations carried out in the laboratory, away from the ambiguities of patient care. Basic science is the reason childhood leukemia is gradually being conquered, the reason prenatal diagnosis is now available for cystic fibrosis. The mixture of clinical practice, clinical research and political activism at Boston City Hospital was new to me, as were some of the realities of working with a population of children who were almost all poor.
Joel J. Alpert, M.D., has been chairman of the department of pediatrics for the last 20 years. This past year he announced his resignation as chairman. When he thinks back on his early days at Boston City Hospital -- he also came from Children's -- he recalls being told by his chief, the distinguished pediatrician Charles A. Janeway, "If I stayed at Harvard, I would teach the people who taught, if I went to B.C.H., I would teach the people who did." In his first week at the hospital, back in 1972, Dr. Alpert saw two children on the wards with oral gonorrhea, "and then we had a power failure -- change was not going to be easy."
Over the past 20 years the department has grown from 12 faculty members to 40, a tribute to the resourcefulness of Alpert and the people he gathered around him. This year the department can claim 57 active grant programs, for a total dollar value of $38 million, and a high degree of academic productivity, with 135 research papers and 47 abstracts published by department members during the 1991-92 medical year. That productivity, while testimony to the energy and versatility of people who carry a heavy clinical load, is also the department's collateral for future grants.
The grant money is intended for research, and related research is designed to provide patient care: some programs study the developmental progress of babies exposed prenatally to cocaine, while others provide them with good medical care and regular developmental assessments; some study the best ways to support teen-age mothers, and others establish clinics they can attend with their babies. "We're a vulnerable department," Alpert says. "No endowment, no pots of gold. We had to practice the Willie Sutton rule: we went for where the money was. And fortunately, the money was in the right place -- early on, in primary care training, and later in child development and AIDS."
Public interest and possible financing often go together; the perception that the social fabric is threatened may translate into a push for more studies. Consider the recent news media leitmotif "crack babies" -- the shame of our cities, the death of our schools. Brain damaged, uncontrollable, unlovable and unable to love. Drs. Barry Zuckerman and Deborah A. Frank have argued that the loud public discussion of the effects of maternal crack use on the developing fetus is largely scaremongering, based on incomplete scientific evidence, and has disturbing political consequences. By portraying these children as permanently damaged, we make them into "throwaway children," as Dr. Zuckerman puts it, children for whom society is not responsible. In the medical journal Pediatrics this year, they staked out their position: Prenatal drug exposure is only one of multiple treatable or preventable biologic and social "stressors" experienced by children living in poverty. By focusing on cocaine and not on lack of adequate nutrition, health care and education, we conveniently can blame mothers and not the conditions of poverty.
Drs. Zuckerman and Frank go on to criticize the study that sounded the alarm: sample size too small (only 18 babies), confounding variables (babies exposed to many drugs), nonblind examiners (medicalese referring to the fact that the people doing developmental assessments of the babies in the study knew who had been exposed to drugs). In another study they point to, by a team including Ira J. Chasnoff, the president of the National Association for Perinatal Addiction Research and Education, children who were prenatally exposed to cocaine and then received good follow-up care, including family support services and developmental programs, did as well on developmental testing at the age of 2 as other children of similar socioeconomic class who were never exposed to cocaine. But both groups of children scored below the national average. In other words, children growing up in poverty, with or without the disadvantage of prenatal cocaine exposure, do not develop as well as they should.
A large prospective study of infants exposed to cocaine is underway at Boston City Hospital. It involves setting up elaborate programs, which regularly assess the effect not only of prenatal drug exposure but also of many of those other biologic and social stressors. At the same time other hospital programs follow up on these careful assessments, trying to mitigate the effects of the risk factors. This is the dialectic of the pediatrics of poverty: the study that may be financed partly because it is the stuff of dire headlines, the results that must offer more than information, must point the way to social policy. These are the medical problems that cannot be solved by science alone.
AND THEY ARE MEDICAL problems. Children who are severely malnourished may suffer neurological problems. They are vulnerable to infections (which may in turn interfere with growth and development). They are more vulnerable to lead poisoning than properly nourished children.
The staff at the Failure to Thrive Clinic meets at the start of the day. Sitting around the table are Deborah Frank, who is the clinic director, social workers and nutritionists and a home teacher. This is a clinic for children who don't grow, don't gain weight properly. Here the secrets of the poor are discussed, the contents of kitchen cabinets, family budgets, household dynamics, parent-child interactions. The staff runs through the list of patients who are expected that day:
"We've seen him since he was a toddler -- not one of our great successes. The mother has boundary issues -- when we gave him a nutritional supplement, she drank it. We have to give them enough for them both."
"I did a home visit, and the little girl isn't taking the Pediasure" -- a high-calorie nutritional drink -- "but she will take vanilla Instant Breakfast. Her mom says she's eating. We worked on substitutions -- if not peanut-butter crackers, give cheese crackers. And it's getting warm out, so give ice cream."
Frank interrupts a story of a child in a shelter to editorialize, "Homelessness is probably just a major growth knocker-offer. We have a number of families where a kid who was born or was a toddler at the time the family was homeless is still doing poorly. And this shelter is just an old-fashioned poorhouse. They won't let children have snacks without a written letter from a doctor!"
"The kid had strep and got put on penicillin. Mom came in and got her high chair. We're working on adding fats."
"This is the mom who I told, her mantra was going to be no diet soda for her or for her kid for a whole week -- we'll see if they survived."
"This girl is actually ready for discharge from a growth point of view. I'm just concerned about her affect: she's very anxious, won't take her clothes off, keeps her coat on. It's a dysfunctional, chaotic family, and I worry about sexual abuse."
"This is a mom who gets up at 6 A.M. to feed her baby. She works part time, leaves the baby with the other kids, leaves a meal. I think they don't give her the meal, they give her a cookie. They have no medical insurance, they have food shortages -- I brought her groceries on my last visit. All the kids were there, all dressed and clean and extremely social and nice."
A first visit, a baby newly referred to the clinic: "Mom is a scared little teen-ager who was removed from her own mom, and was nomadic and homeless during the pregnancy. She has untreated pelvic inflammatory disease, she doesn't keep her appointments. She's not a hostile kid, just lonesome and young."
Frank's formal title is director of the Growth and Development Program. "I would go bonkers if I wasn't very active in advocacy, I would feel so futile," she says. She sits in a big and somewhat gloomy office, behind a messy desk, next to a shelf of baby food. "I use my clinical knowledge and experience to inform public debate around children. I have quite good medical and academic credentials, I have a knowledge of what malnutrition does to children's health and development. Your grandmother knew this, my grandmother knew this -- but when I articulate this, people say, oh doctor, how courageous of you to tell us this! I feel a little silly wrapping myself in my M.D. degree to tell something mothers and grandmothers know. But the people who need to hear it make public policy, control funding."
Frank started out as a fellow in developmental pediatrics at Children's Hospital, a protegee of T. Berry Brazelton, the distinguished Harvard developmentalist. In the Failure to Thrive Clinic there, she became aware of the developmental and behavioral effects of inadequate caloric intake in children, the ways that malnourished children reduce their activity and their interactions with the environment. She came to Boston City Hospital in 1981. In the Reagan years, she began seeing a deterioration in children in the program who had been doing all right. "We started to see kids who had been better, but had been cut from WIC or food stamps, kids I had worked with for a year -- malnourished because they were cut off federal feeding programs. I got so angry. I decided writing my Congressman was not enough. I'm mad. You don't mess with my patients."
Since then, Frank has traveled around the country as part of the Physician Task Force on Hunger in America. She operates a food pantry for which she solicits donations from churches, schools and synagogues. And she runs Boston City Hospital's Failure to Thrive Clinic, which she founded in 1984. It has served more than 600 families, and takes care of about 150 at any given time. The waiting time for an appointment is two months.
Failure to thrive is a complicated syndrome, occurring not only in the poor but also in families with enough money, where children may develop what are called interactive feeding disorders, or behavioral feeding problems. Frank estimates that perhaps 10 to 20 percent of the children in her clinic have such problems. Many of the rest, she says, are malnourished because of poverty. The problem is getting worse as hard economic times continue and social services are cut; in the first nine months of 1992, the clinic treated more children than in all of 1991.
"I trained at Children's in Seattle, then at Boston Children's," she says. "There were lots of kids with horrible rare diseases. But at least you knew everything had been done, the limits of medical knowledge had been applied and you were up against God. We sit and watch kids being destroyed by things we know how to fix. That was awful, this is worse. It's not that nothing more could be done. There's a great deal more that could be done, but we can't do it."
ROBERT NEEDLMAN, M.D., and Kathleen Fitzgerald Rice, an educator, are co-directors of a program called Reach Out and Read, which has volunteers reading to children in the waiting rooms, and pediatricians in the primary care clinic giving away picture books at check-up visits and encouraging parents to read to their children. When Dr. Needlman and his co-workers tried to measure the efficacy of their "interventions," they found, as they published in the American Journal of Diseases of Children in 1991, that parents who had been given a book were four times as likely as parents who had not to say they had looked at books with their children over the past 24 hours, or to list looking at books as among their children's three favorite activities.
The success of the R.O.A.R. program is testimony not only to the power of books, but also to the impoverishment of some children's lives, and to the possibility of making a difference with a small, nonglobal, nonmedical change. But Needlman doesn't want anyone to get the idea that just because society gives a child a book, all obligations are fulfilled. "Simple answers don't work and simple programs don't work," he says. "Kids need comprehensive services, adequate social services and jobs and housing and medical services. This is a small part. It's one other thing that pediatricians can do that moves things in the right direction and is nice. But it's no substitute for substantive changes."
AGAIN AND AGAIN AT Boston City Hospital, the question comes up: what kind of parent do you become after a blighted childhood? This is perhaps the most numbing cycle of them all, and those parents who attempt to break it need long-term assistance and practical, hard-nosed encouragement.
"I hear mothers' stories of how they were abused, the violence they saw. These parents have the same stories as the children I take care of," Zuckerman comments. "When we started our clinical work, we were impressed by how hard addicted mothers will work to take care of their children, even at times when they can't take care of themselves. We have to acknowledge how important their children are to them." When they give the mothers and children clay to play with, he says, "the mothers have to make their own models before they can make them with the kids; they haven't had a childhood."
Six mothers and their ten children, all of whom are in the Women and Infants Program, are gathered in a small circle at the Family Development Center. Everyone is rubbing on hand lotion, an activity that provides a chance to touch yourself and your child, gently. Carol Seval-Brooks, a registered nurse who is co-director of the program, explains that it was established three years ago, as a place where addicted women and their drug-exposed children could receive treatment in a single visit: medical care and drug treatment for the mothers, pediatric care and developmental attention for the children. Treatment programs that take children into account are difficult to find. Most of all, though, it's meant to use the mothers' concern for their children as a way of treating the whole family. This concept -- modeled on "one-stop shopping" -- is also applied in other clinics, where people who would themselves avoid the medical system will bring their children for help and accept help themselves while they are there. This one-stop approach is highly desirable for patients for whom every trip to the hospital means overcoming the obstacles that loom large in the lives of parents without money and without social supports: transportation and child care, money, fear of the streets, fear of venturing into any large institution.
Of the 13 women that this program recruited three years ago, 8 are still involved, these 6 and 2 others who aren't here today. All had a history of abusing cocaine as well as other substances. "Our philosophy is: the best way to help the child is to help the mother," Seval-Brooks says. Although two of the eight women have lost custody of their children, Seval-Brooks ticks off some of the program's successes: Most of the women are using birth control, pregnancy rates are down to zero (following what she says was a 100 percent rate of repeat pregnancy in the first year), all the children are immunized, none has had any serious health problems thought to be the result of neglect. The mothers are in various stages of drug recovery -- a couple have gone for years without relapsing, the others have had periods of relapse more recently. When they relapse, they may go into more formal all-day treatment programs, but they stay part of this group.
The women range in age from 23 to 36. "All come from extraordinarily dysfunctional families -- two witnessed murders as children, several were sexually or physically abused," Seval-Brooks says. Echoing Zuckerman, she adds, "What I believe is, what comes around goes around -- my clients were their children 20 years ago. Each time it goes around, the children get less."
She passes out vials for urine samples, which will be checked for drugs. Matter-of-factly, each woman goes off to the bathroom, leaving coat and purse behind; people have been known to switch vials. A woman hands over her sample with a grin: "It's clean -- just don't make no mistake and give me somebody else's that's dirty!" There are shouts of laughter, and then the group settles down. There is some catching up, some discussion of the women who aren't there -- someone was in detox and then maybe got arrested, someone else is doing really well, some discussion of halfway houses and shelters.
The conversation turns to children: one mother announces that she was ready to push her son's head through the wall the other day, and others chime in with stories of similar frustration. Before Seval-Brooks can say anything, one of the women pleads, "Please don't say not to touch them; that's the worst thing not to do!" There is general agreement; laughing, the women tell stories on themselves: "They had to tell me, stop shaking that boy -- or else, girl, we will be visiting you in the joint!"
"I beat 'em all down. One of them I had on the walls. . . ."
"That's my child, I can do whatever I want to, and if the state of Massachusetts doesn't want me to hit my kid they can take him and raise him themself!"
"No," says another mother, "you know you be crying." She turns to another, quieter woman. "You just got yours back."
Seval-Brooks tries to make the case against hitting children, beating children, the case that when you beat children you only teach violence. The women listen to her patiently, but it is clear that she is a long way from convincing them.
"None of you got appropriate parenting," she reminds the group. "None of you had a mother and father who treated you with respect and dignity."
AT THE TEEN-TOT clinic it all comes full circle, and much too soon; the pediatric patients, some growing up without the physical and spiritual nourishment that should have been provided by their parents and their society are having their own children. Patients who have not yet outgrown their pediatricians are producing children of their own. This program provides pediatric care to teen-age mothers and their offspring. One-stop shopping once again. Here they study ways to keep the repeat pregnancy rate down, but they also study the strengths of young parents, their resources and their coping mechanisms. Again, the members of a multidisciplinary team sit around a table -- doctor, nurse-midwife, social worker, family planner, public health home-visiting nurse and pediatric nurse practitioner. Another barrage of patient stories:
"She started talking about the attack -- all I asked for was her address. This pregnancy was the result of a rape."
"She's coming to parenting class Monday. She's the one who disappeared down south six months ago, comes back pregnant again. Her mother's a poly-drug abuser."
"I've written a letter recommending that the baby be removed from the home. The grandmother was arrested, and the mother is clearly incapable of taking care of the baby."
"I like teen-agers," says Marie Hayes, the nurse-midwife. "We have to give our teen-agers different messages, help them believe that having babies is not all they can do. Actually, my sympathies are more and more leaning toward the grandmothers -- they're in the trenches. But they say, well, I had you at 16 and I did O.K. But what's O.K.? We never starved is O.K., the bare essentials is O.K."
"I don't think anyone knows how to break the cycle," says Leslie Ramsay, the pediatric nurse practitioner. "One doctor talked about lap time -- a lot of kids don't get enough lap time. Our kids love it, they love for you to hug them."
Tesi Kohlenberg, M.D., is the director of the Teen-Tot Clinic, which cares for about 400 teen-age mothers and their 500 children. She sees more in her patients' stories than just the relentless tragedies of abuse and the stunting of promise. She sees evidence of what she considers almost miraculous human resiliency. Of one young patient she says, her "heart and her health is in her role as a mother, a very good mother given that she has a very active, healthily impulsive 2-year-old. There's no question in the mind of any observer that she's doing a good job." Dr. Kohlenberg says she believes that these parents could be helped to give their offspring a very different childhood.
"It is possible to break the cycle, and it is cheaper in dollars than not breaking the cycle, but it's a choice our society has not been ready to make," she says. "Say you intervene with a young mother -- give her five years in a structured residence with four or five other troubled young women, two or three full-time staff. You then have all of her children likely not to have to go into foster care. Even if you just save her kids at the cost of five years of intervention, you more than make it back if the kids are functional and don't need social services for the rest of their lives."
"WE HAVE TO REMIND ourselves," Alpert says ruefully, "that despite our successes, our kids are worse off, and young doctors aren't standing in line to train here." In the recent past, the Boston City Hospital pediatrics program had done very well in the national residency "match" -- that is, the internship candidates that the hospital most wanted were also the ones who wanted to come. This year the match was much more disappointing for the hospital. This may have something to do with the declining number of doctors going into primary care medicine, a problem for the whole profession. Alpert boasts that 75 percent of the residents who graduate from his program go on to practice primary care pediatrics, and that half of those are taking care of the underprivileged.
There are, of course, pitfalls to doing research with a political agenda -- or with any agenda save that of allegiance to truth. Many of the subjects that are studied in the inner city lend themselves easily to sensational treatment: there are not only crack babies and their mothers to be vilified but also innocent victims of starvation to be pitied. Sentimentalism, like sensationalism, has nothing to do with good science.
But there are also studies that can tell a harsh truth more vividly than any political speech. There was Frank's "Heat or Eat" study, which found that more underweight babies were seen in the emergency room during the three months after the coldest month of the winter. Meyers talks about a study of children from low-income families that showed that their standardized test scores improved if they were given breakfast. "The press went nuts," he says. "We're gathering data so that advocates can load their guns, but we have to maintain good science." He shrugs, shakes his head. "Proving that poverty is bad for you -- we need to do that?"
"How do you work with families like these?" Kohlenberg asks. "You experience not only powerlessness and sadness and horror but tremendous excitement, a spiritual experience of human resilience. The fact that anything can repair this kind of injury is very moving. That you can turn and see an abused young mother smiling with delight as her baby tries for the 17th time to open a closet he was told not to. What's called the self-righting tendency of the organism, the tendency to grow toward the light.
"People are very scared of inner-city teens, seeing them as violent, uncaring, irretrievably damaged, and my experience is that isn't true. We know that people can change. We don't need to be afraid of these children."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 27; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1466 words

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Rap After the Riot: Smoldering Rage And No Apologies

BYLINE: By Jon Pareles

 BODY:
Ice Cube does some gloating on his new album, "The Predator." "Anything you wanted to know about the riot was in the records before the riot," he says in an interview-style interlude. "All you had to do was go to the Ice Cube library and pick a record."
He's right: "Death Certificate," released on Halloween in 1991, not only articulated the rage surrounding the beating of Rodney King, but showed exactly where the flashpoint would be in the April riots in Los Angeles. The album included "Black Korea," which revealed the deep resentment between Korean shopkeepers (whom Ice Cube, in one ignorant flourish, described as "chop-suey-eatin' ") and blacks, who felt they were being treated more like potential criminals than customers; when the riots came, Korean businesses became targets. 
 The album was vengeful and divisive, airing deep-seated prejudices and treating ethnic groups as if they were warring gangs that could never share turf. But it was also prophetic, which may be one reason "The Predator" shot to No. 1 on Billboard's album chart upon release at the end of November. In the wake of the riot, people had been waiting for rap's next bulletin from the front.
Before South-Central Los Angeles went up in a billion dollars' worth of flames, the only voices from the area that most Americans had heard were the swaggering storytellers of gangster rap. Taking violence for granted, flaunting ugly attitudes toward women and homosexuals, savoring gory details, gangster rappers weren't documentarians or responsible spokesmen; they were pulp auteurs, exploiting America's appetite for violent entertainment while dropping enough local details or "reality" to sound credible.
When Los Angeles burned, the reality dwarfed gangster rap's tales of drive-by shootings and petty but deadly feuds. Yet amid the violence, the rappers suddenly seemed like experts. And as the immediacy of the riots faded, rappers are again the voices most likely to be heard outside the ghetto. They are not diplomatic or conciliatory with the outside world; they have little to say about the riot victims or about rebuilding burned-out areas. That's for politicians and community leaders to take care of. Rappers talk about how they feel.
Hip-hop is by far the most topical zone of popular music, so it was inevitable that the riots would make their way into rap's fall releases. For the most part, Los Angeles rappers have preferred to stay with their usual postures and material, with increasingly redundant tales of crime, sex and battling machismo. Although explicit post-riot raps are greatly outnumbered by more typical gangster material, they have been emerging on new recordings over the last month. They suggest that the acquittal of the police officers who beat Rodney King has left enduring anger and that racial and ethnic polarization has only increased.
There are no apologies, just a few second thoughts. On recent releases, gangster rappers like Ice Cube vent rage and vow retribution, while noting with approval the post-riot truce between the two most entrenched Los Angeles gangs, the Crips and the Bloods. More politically inclined rappers, like Paris (from Oakland, Calif.), ricochet between fantasizing about terrorism and trying to draw broader lessons from the carnage.
The usually outspoken Public Enemy (from New York) plays defense. In "Tie Goes to the Runner" on the new album "Greatest Misses," Chuck D says he's "not suprised at all about the riots," but his only word about the situation is to insist that raps like "Black Korea" didn't create the problems: "This was predicted, not self-inflicted/ By the rap out of the 'hood that kicked it good." Sound bites from news coverage of the riots also appear as signs of authenticity on efforts like "Whut? Thee Album" by Redman, a performer from Newark who starts the album by placing himself in a "psycho" ward, talking out his sociopathic fantasies. The album includes "News Break," in which a fictitious interviewer asks Redman about reaction to the riots. "Yeah, they still mad," he says, and threatens the interviewer.
As with the rest of hip-hop, pluralism reigns. But the sentiment they share is that it took an all-out insurrection to get the attention of a white power structure.
Ice Cube, the best-known voice of South-Central, is involved not just on "The Predator" but on a forthcoming album by a rapper called Kam, due in February, and on an all-star post-riot single called "Get the Fist," which Mercury Records released but made little effort to promote. Sales of the single, a sequence of snippets by Ice Cube, Yo-Yo, Cypress Hill, Kam and others, benefit the Brotherhood Movement, which was formed in the aftermath of the 1965 Watts riots and is currently working to rebuild South-Central. But it's obvious why Mercury didn't try to turn it into another "We Are the World"; "Get the Fist" is probably the most belligerent charity single ever made.
It starts with on-the-spot defiance -- "I'm black and I'm proud to be lootin' in your face" -- and moves on to calls for black unity against the police and whites: "Not black on black/ The other color gets beat." "Get the Fist" also includes part of Ice Cube's riot commentary from "The Predator," "We Had to Tear This -- Up." In the complete song, between news bulletins about the verdict and the riots, Ice Cube raps about looting ("Now I got a laptop computer") and fantasizes about killing the policemen who beat Mr. King and the jury members who acquitted them. His conclusion is that the riots were necessary for blacks "to get some respect."
Kam's single "Peace Treaty," due in January, praises the gang truce but starts out discussing the riots: "It wasn't just the blacks, everybody was looting and had each other's backs. . . . We all had a hand in the cookie jar and took it far enough to make a statement."
Paris echoes that sentiment on his second album, "Sleeping With the Enemy": "Don't be tellin' me to get the nonviolent spirit/ When I'm violent is the only time you devils hear it." Those lines are part of "Bush Killa," Paris's vision of assassinating the President, a calculated provocation to draw attention to what he sees as genocide against American blacks ("I hope he thinks of how he done us when he's laid to waste/ From guns given to my people for my own kind").
Talking about the riots themselves, in a simulated telephone conversation that opens "Long Hot Summer," Paris and a friend dismiss those who are looting sneaker stores as "tired" and worries that in the aftermath of the riots, blacks will benefit as little as they did after the Watts riots. "If we don't think about things that we need to do for ourselves," he says, "this is just going to happen again and again and again and again." But in the rap that follows, he plays a gun-toting guerrilla stalking cops, with a chorus of "rat-a-tat-tat from my gat."
In cities where pistols are used to settle schoolyard arguments, it's pointless to wish for gun control in rap lyrics. And while no one should take such songs literally, they do reflect a pathology born of all-American myths and of smoldering frustrations. Weaned on the image of the frontier gunslinger who can single-handedly clean up a town, or the Rambo who can refight and win the Vietnam War without a shirt, rappers aren't the only ones who long for decisive action backed by armed force.
Rappers have all sorts of motives, ethical and unethical, to remind the outside world about their frustration, and in the commercial realm of popular culture, no motives are entirely unmixed. A rapper can identify with his or her community, hoping to shock listeners into paying attention to real troubles, and simultaneously realize that contention and notoriety and sensationalism will publicize and sell recordings. For rappers who portray their characters as gunslingers and guerrillas, there's also a large component of machismo, the determination to convince the archetypal street-level listener that the performer is as "hard" as the competition.
Post-riot raps don't offer practical solutions to urban unemployment, declining education, drugs and crime, any more than governmental bodies have. Instead, they shout and snarl about an escalating desperation that makes all sides seek scapegoats, raising friction and shutting off the possibility of dialogue.
Amid the gunplay and vengeance fantasies, the raps make one thing clear. While April's flames may have been quenched, the hostility that ignited them has not gone away. "I do want the white community to understand our community more," Ice Cube says on "The Predator." "I've given so many warnings on what's gonna happen if we don't get these things straight in our lives." His conclusion: "Armageddon is near."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 34; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1450 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Gehry's Disney Hall: A Matterhorn for Music

BYLINE: By Herbert Muschamp

 BODY:
Walt Disney is a trademark. Walt Disney is an empire. But Walt Disney is also the name of a popular American artist whose subject was enchantment. A pumpkin grows into a coach. A kiss breaks the spell. Trick photography makes the bud blossom. Disney's enchantment was America's. His images of wonder were metaphors for a nation that, in his time, was as blessed as any magic kingdom. Then, like American moral authority, the Disney magic waned. The padded Mickeys, the bloated theme parks, the denatured wholesomeness came to seem like desperate overcompensations for curdled American innocence.
Last week, ground was broken in downtown Los Angeles for a building that will recast that lost enchantment in a bold, contemporary form. Walt Disney Concert Hall, designed by the Los Angeles architect Frank Gehry, is by no means innocent of worldly ambitions. The $80 million, 2,400-seat hall, the future home of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, doesn't shrink from civic booster scale. Like the Museum of Contemporary Art, its neighbor on Bunker Hill, Disney Hall is expected to help revitalize the city's downtown district and lift its cultural profile. Fortunately, Gehry has resolved not to be crushed by the burden of such exemplary goals. For once, an architectural imagination soars to the level of the highest civic hopes. 
 Frank Gehry has often looked to artists for inspiration, so it is not surprising that his design takes more from Disney than a name. (Disney Hall, which is not affiliated with the Disney Corporation, is a beneficiary of a
$50 million donation from Lillian Disney, the artist's widow.) Yet the design offers no nostalgic escape into the realms of Tinkerbell or the Seven Dwarfs, or a Main Street that never was. Nor does it rely on smoke, lasers, hidden machines or the theme park's cordon sanitaire. Gehry's fiercely idealistic design creates a place of wonder in the city's hard, contentious core. It turns the pumpkin of family entertainment into the coach of art.
Like Fantasia, Disney Hall is an epic of music visualization, though what Gehry has set out to visualize is both more and less concrete than a musical score. Acoustics and empathy are the two forces driving the design. The building's acoustical structure is straightforward. The ideal concert hall, say experts, is a shoe box lined with wood and plaster. But, as those who've felt the panic of premature burial at Avery Fisher Hall can attest, it takes more than measurably good vibrations to make concertgoing a joy. Gehry and his project designer, Michael Maltzen, have worked closely with the noted acoustician Minoru Nagata on the design, and they've adopted the basic shoe box shape. But this is a box fit for Cinderella's slippers.
The walls of the box slope outward, shaping the auditorium into a trapezoid. It resembles the hull of a primitive ship, an effect heightened by the convex slope of the seating that surrounds the orchestra on three sides. Gehry has described the hall as a "ceremonial barge for music," and ship shapes play subtly throughout the house. The ceiling, sculptured in gentle scallops, resembles billowing sails but also a theater curtain's festive swags. A bank of organ pipes rises at the "prow," though in their jumbled profusion the pipes could also be a Baroque altarpiece remodeled by Duchamp.
The ship image, though intuitively arrived at, is not an arbitrary symbol. It holds meanings in tune with the Romantic spirit of the symphonic repertory: adventure, discovery and, ultimately, survival -- the idea that art is not a pastime but a necessity of life. For Gehry, creativity is not a Romantic abstraction but an imperative of his time and place. In his most important public work to date, he has fashioned a symbol of social harmony for a city that has come to stand for the dissonance of contemporary life.
It has been said, and not unfairly, that Frank Gehry is the poet of this troubled condition, that the fragmented forms of his buildings speak of the breakup and dispersal of the traditional urban center. It is a paradox, then, that he has been called upon to design a project intended to symbolize the rejuvenation of downtown Los Angeles. But, in fact, fragmentation is just as much the rule downtown as further out along the freeways. The fragments are more concentrated and they sprawl not only horizontally but in the jagged verticals of the skyline.
Gehry has responded to this context by enlarging to civic scale the layering techniques he employed when remodeling his own Santa Monica home in 1978. There, he wrapped an existing suburban house with screens of glass, chain-link fence and corrugated metal. At Disney Hall, the auditorium is clad with stainless steel panels, then partly wrapped with walls of French limestone. Or, rather, unwrapped, for the effect is like a gift from which the paper has been torn by an impatient birthday boy.
The "wrappers" peel away from the auditorium in curves subtle and pronounced. Some rise vertically to a height just above the hall's roofline. Others form curving horizontal strips at the building's base. Glass walls bulge forth from breaks between the wrappers, or rise above them in towering crystalline cages of Coney Island contour.
The main hall is not the only gift within this elaborate presentation. Like Mother Ginger, Gehry has tucked an array of surprises into the areas between the wrappers and the auditorium: lobbies, terraces, foyers, a cafe and gift shop, a "pre-concert" room for smaller musical events, a founders' room, and two areas Gehry calls "the baggages." Free-form containers, slung off the sides of the auditorium like saddlebags, they provide space for stairways, elevators and restrooms.
You can, if you like, read the fragmentation of these forms as an expression of social breakdown. Actually, what the design breaks down is the hierarchical order that large civic buildings traditionally express. The asymmetrical wrappings, the fissures that open up between them, the hall's off-center axis and its thrusting diagonal lines break up the building's imposing mass without recourse to classical scaling. Instead of proceeding toward a monumental entrance framed by a symmetrical facade, people will enter through movable glass panels that further erode the barrier between inside and out. More than simply providing access, the design promotes accessibility.
In the past, Gehry has relied on ostentatiously humble materials to convey a populist ideal. Humility, perhaps, is not the first thing French limestone will bring to mind. But the stainless steel segments that push through the wrappers will reveal a blue collar beneath the formal dress. And Gehry hopes to line the interior of the hall with Douglas fir. With the right lighting, this staple of weekend carpentry takes on a candle glow.
The cumulative impression of these complex forms is less building than landscape: a Matterhorn for music where thousands can gather to take the ride. Mrs. Disney requested that a garden adjoin the hall, and Gehry has laid out a sumptuous one. But he has also turned the entire city block that the site occupies into an urban park. Its cascading stairways, planted terraces and plazas are as ample as the foyers and staircases of the old Paris Opera, with the added advantage that they are set outside. You won't need a ticket to enjoy them. Nor will you have to quit the outdoors entirely to attend a concert. Skylights will admit natural light into the hall during the day.
What is most democratic about the design is the mutability of the images its forms give rise to. Gehry has not included fish, the creature that has occupied a place in his work analogous to the mouse in Disney's. Yet his grappling with those slippery shapes is discernible in the mercurial images that slither through Disney Hall's wavy contours. A ship. A cello. An unfolding flower. Hands thrust upward in delighted surprise. These images never crystallize. They surface and submerge like "the thing that dashes through the water," as Virginia Woolf once termed elusive insight.
The building is generous both in inviting such images and in refraining from making them explicit. It does not restrict the capacity of individual viewers to quarry their own figures and abstract images as they move through the building's serpentine spaces. That empathic approach is the essence of this building. It achieves unity by provoking multiple perspectives, and inviting them to co-exist in one place. The place will be the sum of the perceptions it invokes. That is why, when people climb the steps to Disney Hall, it is not a magic kingdom they'll be entering. It is a magic democracy.
