SECTION: Section 10; Page 3; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1460 words

HEADLINE: Perspectives: Public Housing;
Seeking to Improve Quality in Shelter

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
REMEMBER the principle of economic mix in the tenancy, say the managers of large publicly assisted housing developments. It is one of the keys to success in providing decent housing to lower-income people over time.
The theme has been sounded again of late by Sally Hernandez-Pinero, chairwoman of the New York City Housing Authority for the last 10 months. "New York is working hard at keeping to the one-third, one-third, one-third mix on admissions," she said. She defined that in general terms as one-third elderly, one-third working families and one-third publicly assisted families. 
 Many pressures work against this effort. Some come from the state level. The situation takes on special significance at a time when the incoming Clinton Administration is likely to give a new look to housing policy and the way it is implemented at the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Washington.
The ability to sustain a desirable economic and social mix of tenants is one of the keys to the long-term quality of publicly assisted housing, housing managers say. There are others that also involve Washington's policies: adequate operating subsidies to compensate for declining rents; a reasonable amount of new production to ease the pressure on admissions; rules that give flexibility to competent local managements.
The principles apply to assisted rental housing in general. The Housing Authority is only one among many managers of low-income housing.
Quality, oddly enough, has gotten short shrift in recent years. In Washington the political pressures from opposite sides of the ideological spectrum threaten to push public housing heavily into the position of houser of very-low-income tenants only. Last year the Housing and Community Development Act attempted to reverse this trend by giving local authorities more discretion to achieve a diverse population.
In New York City, court rulings that effectively require local government to provide permanent housing to homeless people on demand have also had the effect of increasing the proportion of the dependent families in assisted housing generally.
The question is, will H.U.D. in the Democratic Administration start working collaboratively with local managements? Or will ideological issues continue to draw attention from the need to improve the quality of shelter?
The economic and social mix issue will be one test. Many public housing officials feel that in the 1980's the Department of Housing and Urban Development viewed public housing too exclusively as a preserve for the most disadvantaged tenants. At the same time, many advocates for the homeless were driving a Federal response that made the policy a reality.
Seven years ago, 35 percent of the new admissions to public housing in New York City were from the neediest segment of the population, with income from public assistance programs only. By last year this component, called Tier 1 by the Housing Authority, had reached 53 percent, roughly half the 4,000 new admissions each year.
Partly this was the result of Federal admissions standards under a five-year-old admissions preference program. Starting in 1987, housing agencies had to give preference on their waiting lists to people who are involuntarily displaced, people who live in substandard housing and people who pay more than 50 percent of their income for rent. By accelerating these families on waiting lists, new admissions have been weighted toward the lowest-income applicants.
DURING most of the 80's, 90 percent of new admissions had to meet these preference standards. Under the 1992 housing act, Congress authorized the Department of Housing and Urban Development to allow local housing agencies to adopt local standards for as much as 50 percent of new admissions. Once implemented this could lead to better economic and social balance in new admissions.
Meanwhile, public housing in New York has grown less attractive to many eligible working people, and certificates and vouchers have helped make alternatives feasible. These working families are defined as low income because they earn between 50 to 80 percent of areawide median income, or roughly $20,000 a year for a family of four. Currently they constitute only 16 to 18 percent of the total waiting list, the Housing Authority says. About 11 percent of new admissions are working families from this income tier. A typical household profile is a working mother with one or two children, earning about $15,500 a year.
The failure of Congress to make economic mix a consistent goal of housing policy has contributed to the problem nationally, many specialists agree. But the solution hardly lies in Washington exclusively. By agreeing to provide emergency shelter some years ago to any family on public assistance who requested it, New York City has found itself overwhelmed with demand for permanent housing from a heavy flow of families moving into limited but improved transitional housing facilities. Much of the rehousing burden has fallen on public housing, which also seeks to place young families doubled up within its own buildings.
In the last four years 25 percent of all new admissions to public housing were from the homeless population in transitional housing. In August the authority and the office of Mayor David N. Dinkins agreed that the authority would accept an annual allocation of only 1,670 homeless families, which would be 20 percent of total annual admissions.
On the production side, Ms. Hernandez-Pinero said she has no desire to move back to the days of large new housing projects. Instead she wants to use production allocation for renovating buildings supplied from the tax-foreclosed city-owned housing stock, or buying existing new but untenanted privately developed buildings, or acquiring housing units within developments produced under the New York Housing Partnership program of for-sale homes or the low-income buildings developed with tax-credit financing by the Local Initiative Support Corporation and the Enterprise Foundation.
Quality comes into play here as well. The most desirable new developments have turned out to be gut rehabilitations, built internally to Federal standards, of handsome older apartment buildings acquired from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development's tax-foreclosed housing stock.
The Housing Authority also hopes to be able to get HUD's permission to acquire newly developed privately owned buildings for public-housing tenants, said Deborah Wright, a board member who oversees development. "We've been made aware of buildings in Queens and Staten Island that were built for the market and then the market collapsed," she said. Buying them would be cheaper than building them.
That is the type of activity that has been difficult to carry out under Washington's thumb. Accordingly, the Housing Authority seeks more independence of action.
The Housing Authority runs about 180,000 apartments in public-housing developments. It also gets 61,000 certificates or vouchers that are issued to low-income housing seekers looking for apartments in privately owned buildings. In New York City in particular, with its huge housing stock and a large population unable to afford the rent necessary to sustain that housing, these Federal subsidies under the Section 8 program have proved particularly valuable.
Vouchers are more flexible than certificates, in that they allow tenants to pay more than 30 percent of their income as rent and are usually more "portable" than certificates because they are always issued to a tenant rather than a building. In both cases the Government makes up the difference between what the tenant can afford and what it calls the "fair market rent," the rent required for operation.
"WE have no problem issuing certificates and vouchers," said John Nelson, general manager of the Housing Authority. "We get about 1,000 new ones each year." The fact that tenants want them and find them usable suggests that this mechanism of serving the housing needs of lower-income people has been a success in New York. If the tenant cannot find a suitable apartment within 60 days, the certificate or voucher must be returned.
Another area in which public-housing advocates hope for a change in policy by the Clinton Administration is Federal spending on modernization of existing buildings. Programs to stimulate the economy, they say, could lead to an increase in spending over the $3.1. billion that Congress aleady appropriated for fiscal 1993, according to Maryann Russ, executive director of the Council of Large Public Housing Authorities. In fiscal 1992 H.U.D. spent $2.5 billion.
"Money put into public housing modernization will create a lot of jobs," Ms. Russ said.

HEADLINE: Talking: Tax Planning;
Taking Advantage Of the Law

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
AT the close of the calendar year, along with partying and Santa Claus, comes the need for tax planning. For anyone who owns a home this means finding out about the tax deductions that might be available for use on the 1992 income tax return and doing something about those items that may need attention before year-end.
These can differ from year to year, as much as a result of changing personal circumstances as of alterations in the tax code. For one, "We've had a lot more people who became landlords for the first time because they couldn't sell," said Timothy Morse, a tax manager for KPMG Peat Marwick, the national accounting firm. And that change alone makes a dramatic difference in the tax status of property. 
 Martin M. Shenkman, a tax attorney in Manhattan, recommends starting by separating any bills, receipts or canceled checks for any improvements made during the year, putting them in an envelope with the year noted on the front and adding this to any existing folder containing documents connected with the property.
When a home is sold, the seller's accountant seeks the full "cost basis" to help minimize taxes due on the profits (if the gains cannot be deferred). The cost basis may include all subsequent improvements in addition to the original purchase price.
Because improvements may have been made over time -- new wiring here, a built-in bookcase there -- they are not easily documented, or even recalled, unless those papers are separately filed, said Mr. Shenkman.
William J. Greenberg, a certified public accountant in Manhattan whose practice is limited to co-ops and condominiums, reminds owners of these units that they can include as an improvement any special assessment levied to improve common areas such as a roof or lobby. However, an assessment used to make up a shortfall in cash flow -- perhaps because a growing number of owners have been delinquent in paying their common charges -- cannot be added to the cost basis.
Any home improvements that are being financed generate a more immediate tax benefit. Even though it's now common knowledge that the origination fees -- points charges -- connected with refinancing a mortgage are not fully tax deductible in the year in which they are incurred, this is not true of any additional mortgage financing being taken out for home improvements.
Mr. Shenkman provided the following example. Say, for example, a couple had an outstanding mortgage balance of $90,000. They decided to increase the loan balance to $120,000 to cover the $30,000 cost of a new kitchen -- a typical move in 1992 since the low interest rates made it possible to do so without sharply higher monthly payments. Points charges on the transaction came to $2,400.
The points charges directly applicable to the $30,000 being used for the improvements ($600) would be tax deductible. The tax deduction for the remaining fees would have to be amortized over the life of the loan.
Anyone who rented out a home during the year because he couldn't sell it should be aware that all expenses connected with its ownership and operation are now tax deductible as a business expense, said Mr. Morse. Under such circumstances even condominium common charges, formerly nondeductible, can be factored in. So can the full cost of co-op maintenance charges.
Anyone who might have lost a job during the year and who has since used part of the home as a home-based office should brush up on the tax benefits of doing so.
These benefits are now more easily calculated and identified as a result of a form (Form 8829) the Internal Revenue Service introduced last year. Its stated aim is to help the homeowner make the correct calculations, although critics say its goal was also to prevent abuses through more detailed reporting requirements.
Getting a copy of this form early in the season, either through an accountant, an office supply store or the I.R.S. itself (listed in the Blue Pages), should help the new home-office user better understand the regulations and gather the documents and data.
IF, on the other hand, a personal residence is about to be sold in 1993 and was being used as a home office, it might be better to disqualify the office by introducing domestic activities in the year of sale, such as a child's toy box, said Julian Block, a tax attorney in Larchmont, N.Y., and author of "The Homeowner's Tax Guide," available for $14.95 from Runzheimer International by calling (800) 942-9949.
If it remains a qualified office at the time of sale, noted Mr. Block, the taxes due on any profits attributable to that portion of the home -- say, 20 percent -- could no longer be rolled over into another residence. Instead, they would have to be paid immediately.
Thus, for example, if the sale generated a profit of $100,000, the disqualification could add a tax bill of $5,600 (20 percent of $100,000 x 28 percent) to any income taxes due, plus state of local levies.
Another common mistake, said Mr. Block, is to misunderstand the regulations that govern the once-in-a-lifetime capital gains tax exemption of $125,000 available to anyone over 55 years of age who may have sold a primary residence in 1992 or intends to do so in 1993.
To qualify, the owner must have passed his or her 55th birthday before the actual sale takes place -- not anytime during the year in which the sale is completed. Also, if the owners are a married couple they cannot each qualify for a $125,000 exemption. Only if they are divorced before the sale takes place, or the owners are not married, can each qualify for a separate $125,000 exemption.
Mr. Block also noted that this year may have been one of the first occasions when a substantial number of sellers failed to buy another residence of the same or higher value within the two-year period provided by the I.R.S. to qualify for tax deferment on the profits of the previous sale -- a consequence of the uncertain property market.
If so, he said, they will need to amend the return for the year in which that sale took place (probably 1990). When doing so, he said, they should be sure to include any offsetting capital losses available to them at the time of sale. Subsequent losses cannot be used to offset the profit.
Those capital losses may have come from the sale of stock, limited partnerships, investment real estate or a business failure.
Finally, despite recent Congressional attempts to change current law, losses incurred from the sale of a personal residence remain ineligible for tax benefits.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Concierges;
The Concierge Comes to Office Buildings

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
ONE recent morning, Bernadette Hakin, the office manager for Trebol International Corporation, walked into her office in the Seagram Building to a rather daunting sight: a pair of six-foot skis, with a note asking her to send them to her boss's son in Colorado. Sounds easy -- except how do you wrap skis, is the post office the cheapest way to get them there, do they need insurance, do they . . . ?
Ms. Hakin had no idea. So she made one call, to Penny Wallberg, the building's full-time concierge. Ms. Wallberg, in turn, made many calls. Result: The skis went out Federal Express two-day economy service, which Ms. Wallberg decided was the cheapest and safest way to get them there. 
 Now Ms. Hakin says she plans to "inundate" Ms. Wallberg with requests for flowers, for help with last-minute Christmas shopping, for mail services, for aircraft leasing, even for selling some excess furniture.
"Having a concierge is like having another employee," Ms. Hakin said.
Geoffrey C. Rockhill, the 38-story building's asset manager, loves hearing kudos like that. "For the cost of a salary plus benefits, we can cement our image as a high-service building," he said.
The Seagram Building is just one of a small but growing number to take a tip from the top hotels and put full-service concierges in their lobbies. There's one at 650 Fifth Avenue and another at 14 Wall Street. Management at One Exchange Plaza is talking about putting in an abbreviated concierge service that would offer such amenities as dispensing umbrellas on rainy days.
In all cases, the concierges are part of management's desperate search for ways to attract and retain tenants in a market where the competition grows ever fiercer.
"We wanted this building to be a distinct environment and that meant more than taking care of the elevator mechanicals," said John Wheeler, a managing director of Galbreath Riverbank, which manages 14 Wall for GE Investments.
Herbert Yellin, a managing director at Koppel, Tener, Riguardo, which manages 650 Fifth Avenue, is more blunt. The 36-story building is about 94 percent rented, but Mr. Yellin is by no means cavalier about lease renewals.
"We can't let anyone look at this building as just another office-space commodity," he said. "Sooner or later, if you're in a commodity business you fail." 
Indeed, with the glut of office space showing few signs of abating, even buildings that once rented on reputation alone are no longer trusting their laurels as resting places; many are replacing their carpeting and windows, overhauling their roofs and elevators, sprucing up their lobbies.
And now a handful also are looking for ways to humanize themselves to tenants by providing the type of one-on-one service that is more generally associated with the most expensive condominium apartments and residential hotels.
The Seagram Building, for example, has always been a prestigious address. The 34-year old landmarked building was designed by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, and was one of the first to have a plaza out front.
But when new luxury office buildings like 712 Fifth Avenue and the Swiss Bank Tower at 10 East 50th Street came on stream a couple of years ago, the Seagram Building's management recognized that cachet was no longer enough. It is carpeting the common corridors and upgrading the air-conditioning. And, it reasoned, a concierge service would be particularly welcome to the 140 tenants, most of them individuals or small companies with meager support staffs.
"OUR best way to differentiate ourselves is to do everything we can to make life better for small tenants," Mr. Rockhill said.
Similarly, 14 Wall, whose location across from the New York Stock Exchange used to be selling point enough, has seen tenants and potential tenants siphoned away by the World Financial Center and other lower Manhattan buildings. The 33-story building has about 115,000 square feet of vacant space out of a total of 950,000, and 10 percent of its leases are rolling over in the next 12 months. Since GE Investments took the financially ailing building over in March, it has replaced the roof, the windows, the sidewalks. And even though its 25 tenants are primarily large companies, with large secretarial staffs, it has installed a full-service concierge.
One reason: The secretaries and events planners who held their jobs during the last decade's rash of corporate downsizing have had to assume many of the duties of those who lost theirs. That, in turn, has left them with far less time to meet the broad spectrum of requests that bosses can make.
"Concierges help the private secretaries meet their bosses' needs," said Mr. Wheeler.
Considering the low cost, full-service concierges are surprisingly rare in New York office buildings. There are a few in buildings in Philadelphia and Washington and probably at some scattered buildings elsewhere (there is no national organization of concierges, so it is impossible to track where they exist).
But New York has remained a hard sell. Some years ago a short-lived business called Concierge Services of America set up shop in New York, offering to supply trained concierges to office buildings for a fee, but it could not drum up enough interest to stay afloat, which Mr. Wheeler, for one, did not find surprising.
"There is no tangible bottom-line justification for a concierge, and most owners balk at even a low cost when they can't do a cost-benefits analysis on results," he said.
Many Class A buildings in New York have lobby people who carry the title of concierge. But rarely do they actually fulfill that function. Far more often they are adjuncts to the security desk and serve as uniformed repositories of information about the tenants and the area. Although they are happy to answer tenant's questions, they spend far more time dealing with visitors to the building.
At 712 Fifth Avenue, for example, Edward A. Van Sickle serves as concierge cum tour guide. He is supremely knowledgeable about the statuary in the lobby, the architecture, nearby restaurants, what's good to buy at Henri Bendel -- which has an entrance in the building -- and, of course, which tenant is on which floor. But as such he is more the building's face to the outside world, a greeter of visitors, than a service to tenants.
In contrast, concierges like Ms. Wallberg at Seagram, Ellen Starsia at 650 Fifth Avenue and Lisa Motzfeldt at 14 Wall Street serve the same function for tenants as their hotel counterparts do -- plus more. They will get theater and concert tickets, make restaurant reservations, order flowers. They will hold buildingwide functions like concerts and seminars and coordinate food and blood drives. And they neither expect nor accept tips for anything they do.
"Basically, tenants need just phone me with a project and I'll take care of the details and the work," Ms. Motzfeldt said.
Requests are not always run-of-the-mill. Ms. Motzfeldt has had to find pink lawn flamingos and an Uncle Sam poster ("Sounds simple? It took me three days before I found one, in a secondhand book store" she recalled.) and once shipped a hero sandwich overnight as a birthday present.
Ellen Starsia recently helped Diana Komito, an office administrator for Ithaca Industries, a tenant, find a $15 throwaway bridal bouquet and a place with a view for a reasonably priced office lunch (they went to the executive dining rooms on top of the Time-Life Building, a place Ms. Komito never thought of). She's been asked for gourmet baskets for people on restricted diets and welcome packages for relocating executives.
She even helped a maid working for a tenant at 650 Fifth Avenue find inexpensive uniforms. And she found a dry cleaner who could take care of the designer Joseph Abboud's ultra-expensive tuxedo in a few hours.
"Even if I'd known where to go, which I didn't, I couldn't have gotten such quick service," said Mabel Lovett, Mr. Abboud's executive assistant. "They know I'm a one-shot customer, but they probably figure she could provide repeat, volume business from an entire building."
In fact, since so many of the tenants at 650 Fifth are in the fashion business, cleaning services have become a staple request. "Ever try to find a laundramat in midtown?" asked Ms. Komito, who recently needed to get some fashion samples washed quickly. Ms. Starsia found a place near Second Avenue. "If Ellen can't find it, no one can," Ms. Komito said.
Even for services that are relatively easy to find, the concierges often can wield clout that small companies don't have. Carrie Webster, personnel administrator for GFT USA Corporation, recalls checking out a few catering places and restaurants when she needed to cater some in-house lunches. The prices seemed exorbitant, so she asked Ms. Starsia to see what she could turn up.
"Not only did she take the responsibility off my hands, but she got us great deals on everything from the sodas to desserts," Ms. Webster said. "She was calling with the clout of an entire building behind her, and that really made a difference."
Similarly, Interactive Data, a subsidiary of Dun & Bradstreet with offices at 14 Wall Street, wanted to hold a meeting, with meals, for about 65 people last month. Ms. Motzfeldt gathered brochures about facilities nearby, even visited a few. They wound up going to the Shearson Lehman Conference Center on Beach Street, a facility no one at Interactive Data knew existed.
"Lisa said, 'Tell us your needs and budget,' and she took it from there," said Debra Marty, Interactive Data's office manager.
It all sounds too good to be true -- and in fact, many tenants think it is. Although the concierge service is free (except for lengthy errands, for which most concierges charge about $15 a half hour), and available to anyone working in the building, from mailroom personnel to chief executive, many tenants remain skeptical.
"People always assume there's a cost associated, that you can't get this kind of service for free," said Ms. Webster of GFT, who says she's still having trouble persuading colleagues to ask Ms. Starsia for help.
INDEED, all the concierges say they have had to really drum up business for themselves. Ellen Starsia probably has the easiest time of it: She is the third concierge in two years (the two others weren't "proactive" enough, Mr. Yellin recalled), so although tenants say they hardly ever used her predecessors, the concept isn't entirely alien to them. She worked in the management office before becoming concierge, so most of the tenants knew her already. And while her building is hard to find -- the 650 Fifth Avenue address notwithstanding, the only entrance is on West 52d Street -- her glass-enclosed office, directly to the left of the entrance, is impossible to miss.
Still, she leaves nothing to chance. She held a cocktail party for tenants to remind them she was on call. And each week she invites a vendor to display wares for sale in her office. One week it's vintage jewelry, another it's handcrafted pens, others it's ceramic works, artistic birdhouses, sterling silver jewelry, teddy bears or even brownies from Greenwich Village. Ms. Starsia collects the money for the vendor, without commission.
"It's another way to get tenants to drop by the office," she said.
Ms. Motzfeldt, who just signed on in August, is starting from scratch. What's more, her Art Deco wood desk is obscured from the entrance by the security desk, although the huge bouquet she always keeps on it can be seen from the front door. So she has sent a newsletter to tenants introducing herself and describing the services she can provide. She will send out newsletters every few months.
SLOWLY, tenants are starting to test the waters, calling on her for some distinctly unconcierge-like duties.
"People walk past the desk, see Lisa and say, 'Oh, by the way, I meant to call the building office. The paper towels are out in the 21st floor men's room or a faucet is dripping,' " said Mr. Wheeler. "She's facilitating communications between the tenants and building management, and that's a fringe benefit we did not anticipate."
Tenants echo that theme. Ward Mauck, president of the American Institutue of Marine Underwriters, still books his own airline reservations and gets his own theater tickets. But one thing he simply had not been able to do for himself: get mangement to list his name on the directory at 14 Wall. So he asked Ms. Motzfeldt to take care of it. She called management, and the name is now up.
"It's a lot easier to just tell Lisa something than to deal with the building manager by phone," Mr. Mauck said. "And she gives the building a sense of class."
Ms. Wallberg has probably the most formidable getting-to-know-you task. She just joined the building fresh from the Regency Hotel in October. She sits at a large rectangular desk at the back of the lobby, behind the elevator banks, easily spotted from the side entrances but practically invisible from the front. (The management plans to move the desk up front soon.)
So Ms. Wallberg has sent a note around to tenants introducing herself and listing all the services she's ready to provide. "I'm still only getting a couple of calls a day, but it's starting to pick up," she said.
Indeed it is. There was the gourmet basket and African violet she found for one office that wanted to send it to the boss's hospitalized wife. There were Ms. Hakin's skis.
And there were the Four Seasons reservations she got for Janel Moll, credit manager at Korff USA, who says she never really saw a need for a concierge service.
"She got me the best table in the house," said Ms. Moll, now a convert to the service.

HEADLINE: Tale of Two Cities: Yonkers and 'Yonkers'

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
THIS is a story about Hollywood make-believe. It is the story of one city that wants to be a star and another that lost a chance for stardom. It is also a glimpse at how one movie was made and the trail of disappointment it left behind here.
The story begins in the imagination of Neil Simon, the playwright who wrote "Lost in Yonkers." His story, which won a Pulitzer Prize and a Tony Award -- about two young brothers sent to live above a candy store with their grandmother -- takes place in the Yonkers of 1942. Most of the play is set inside an apartment, where the boys are swept into a tangle of bewildering family relationships. 
 Cut to the environs of Cincinnati, where "Lost in Yonkers," the movie, was filmed last summer. Cincinnati is hilly, like Yonkers. Like Yonkers, it has a river running alongside it. Unlike Yonkers, however, Cincinnati is not in high-priced metropolitan New York City. So, for financial reasons, said Martha Coolidge, the director of "Lost in Yonkers," Cincinnati won out as the location.
Speaking from Culver City, Calif., where the film is being edited, the director said she had wanted to make the movie in Yonkers and was disappointed when she couldn't. "I didn't want to lose the atmosphere," Ms. Coolidge said, adding that she had extensively photographed the city and communities to the north along the river.
 
Cincinnati Area 'in a Time Warp'
 Joe Caracciolo, the movie's executive producer, said he had also hoped to film here but trying to lower labor costs and other expenses became "an exercise in futility." Trying to create a 1940's look in Yonkers or Nyack would have been especially expensive, he said, while areas around Cincinnati are "more or less in a time warp."
"Lost in Yonkers," which was produced by the Raystar Production Company of Culver City, is scheduled for release by Columbia Pictures in August. Mr. Caracciolo would not divulge the movie's budget, but it was reported to be $13 million, not high by today's standards.
The Directors Guild of America, which has offices in Los Angeles, New York and Chicago, also wanted the film to be made here. Alan S. Gordon, Eastern executive secretary of the guild, which represents nearly 10,000 motion picture and television directors and their assistants, said Yonkers's loss was part of the "terrible, devastating loss" in film production that the New York City area had experienced since the spring of 1990, when a disagreement with unions led to a seven-month boycott of the region by major film studios.
The Directors Guild intervened on behalf of Yonkers last spring, trying to help the producers make deals with the unions, said Mr. Gordon, a Scarsdale resident. He added, "We had a big battle to change their minds, but we got into it too far down the road, when the psychological decision to shoot somewhere else was already made."
 
No Calls Received
 Mr. Gordon added that the guild tried to fill a leadership vacuum in Mayor David N. Dinkins's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, which had been without a director since last April. (The position has since been filled by Richard Brick, a member of the Directors Guild, who began work on Nov. 30.) It is Mr. Gordon's view that if the Manhattan office had lobbied aggressively to keep "Lost in Yonkers" here, it might have succeeded, although Patrick Pleven, an assistant director for broadcasting in Mayor Dinkins's office, said the guild "never called us about anything" regarding the film.
Yonkers's loss may be measured by Cincinnati's recent boom as a film- production capital. Lori Holladay, executive director of the Greater Cincinnati Film Commission -- which encompasses parts of Kentucky and Indiana -- said the filming there of 12 motion pictures in the last five years had pumped $30 million into the local economy and created 10,000 jobs. The films, which include "Eight Men Out" and "Little Man Tate" as well as "A Rage in Harlem" and "The Public Eye," both of which are set in Manhattan, generated "lots of tax dollars, from payroll taxes to sales taxes to hotel taxes," she added.
The commission, which didn't exist five years ago and is now staffed full time only by Ms. Holladay, is "looking into building a studio here to better accommodate production companies," she said. She is an enthusiastic saleswoman who has persuaded producers in Manhattan and Los Angeles that Cincinnati can look like any city anywhere at just about any time they would like.
Indeed, said Ms. Coolidge, director of such films as "Rambling Rose" and "Real Genius," Cincinnati has "entire neighborhoods that have been arrested in periods from the 1750's, 1850's and 1950's." She added, "It's an amazing place to shoot period films."
 
Other Sites Also Used
 But as Cincinnati's star rises, and other cities like Toronto, Pittsburgh and Wilmington, N.C., aggressively market themselves as New York and California look-alikes, what is the cost to film authenticity? Yael Woll, an award-winning film and television director who serves as national vice president of the Directors Guild, thinks the artistic cost is high. "The bottom-line budget in the larger scheme of things is virtually irrelevant to the eventual success of a project," said Mr. Woll, a Bedford resident. "To put up four walls and call it a room -- that's converting everything into mass entertainment."
Films about Manhattan and its suburbs should be shot there to capture the area's true ambiance, he added, although New York will "never compete with Cincinnati or Dallas" on an economic level. "The real problem," Mr. Woll said, "is how to convince the studio people that there is a life here -- a creative energy that ought to be exploited."
Ms. Coolidge said she is happy with how "Lost in Yonkers" looks, but turning suburban Cincinnati into Yonkers was no small task. (Much of the movie was shot in Ripley and Wilmington, Ohio, and Ludlow and Augusta, Ky.) For one thing, she said, the Ohio River runs in a "curvy east-west" direction instead of "straight north-south" like the Hudson. "We could never find a location where the sun crossed the river properly" and set over what was supposed to be New Jersey, the director said. Furthermore, there were no Palisades.
The Southern accents of the bit players also posed a problem for the movie, which stars Richard Dreyfuss, Mercedes Ruehl and Irene Worth. Ms. Coolidge said the local actors received coaching lessons in how to talk like New Yorkers.
 
Photographs Made Available
 If the movie captures the feel of mid-century Yonkers, in large part it will be thanks to a group of city employees and longtime residents who provided the film makers with historical facts and reminiscences. Michael Rebic, the principal historic preservation planner with the Yonkers Department of Planning and Economic Development Bureau, said that last winter, before the decision was made to film in Cincinnati, he and others met with Lillian Michelson, an independent California research librarian contracted by Ray-
star. They gave her a tour of the city, provided her with photographs of Yonkers in the 1940's and a videotape of municipal films from the period and put her in touch with people like Philip R. Pistone and Jerry Wiffler.
Mr. Pistone, a 68-year-old retired Yonkers Planning Commissioner, said he had lived over a grocery store on Palisade Avenue here as a child and could identify with the movie's characters. He said he had "had a grand time" with the Hollywood group, inviting them into his home and having dinner with them. All Yonkers needed was "a little dressing up and cleaning up and it would have been just fine," Mr. Pistone said wistfully. "I thought it was a fait accompli."
Mr. Wiffler, a 28-year-old member of the Yonkers Landmarks Preservation Board and a fifth-generation resident of the city, said he made his personal collection of photographs available to Ms. Coolidge when she visited here and was one of her tour guides. Mr. Wiffler, who is also a trustee of the Yonkers Historical Society, said he showed the director buildings that looked "virtually unchanged since the 1940's," which he felt captured the flavor of the story.
Communication between the film makers and city officials cooled once the crew moved to Cincinnati, but requests for help continued to arrive at City Hall and at the Hudson River Museum and the Yonkers Public Library. Mr. Rebic said a new researcher in Cincinnati replaced Ms. Michaelson and in an imperious way asked him to send "a laundry list of details" to the film makers.
 
'The Play Was Wonderful'
 The list included questions about "the color of the street signs, the color of the median lines painted in the streets in the 1940's and what the parking meters looked like, if there were any," Mr. Rebic said. He added:
"I was taken aback by the tone. I faxed back that what she had asked for would take several weeks of research and that the city didn't have the staffing or ability to do this. I suggested that if they wanted to send someone here, we would be happy to cooperate. That was the last I heard."
Dee Barbato, the city's public information officer, said the episode had let Yonkers down a second time. The first time was when Mr. Simon, the playwright, turned down an invitation to visit the city after "Lost in Yonkers" opened on Broadway.
About her brush with Hollywood, Ms. Barbato said, "We were really quite excited about the whole venture and equally disappointed that it fell through."
Neither she nor anyone else here bear the film makers hard feelings, however. "I will absolutely see the film," Ms. Barbato said. "It's Yonkers. The play was wonderful. If the movie is half as good, I'm sure it will be a success."
Having lost in Yonkers, the city can perhaps content itself with something else: the good opinion of people who live 3,000 miles away. Ms. Michaelson, for one, called her experience in Yonkers "one of the high points of my life."
The people she met here, she said, "had the epitome of Southern hospitality in their bones."

HEADLINE: A Church in Scarsdale Losing All 3 Ministers

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: SCARSDALE

 BODY:
TWO years after rebuilding its sanctuary in the wake of a suspicious fire, the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church here must withstand another trauma. All three of its ministers have resigned, including its ecumenical-minded senior minister, the Rev. Robert S. MacLennan.
Sitting amid packing clutter in the church office he has occupied for nine years, Dr. MacLennan, who has forged strong bonds with the county's Jewish community, said irreconcilable differences among the ministerial staff had led to his resignation in mid-October. The Rev. Norman Stanton and the Rev. Shannon White, associate pastors, announced last month that they would also resign. 
 The resignations, which were said to stem from personality clashes and no particular single event, have made public deep rifts in the Hitchcock congregation, which pulled together after the 1986 fire to raise $6 million for a new sanctuary. "There are open wounds," said Jim Oberhelman, a Hitchcock elder who serves as an assistant church administrator.
The three ministers took part in counseling sessions with a mediator to try to avert the present crisis. Ms. White, who has served as a youth minister since joining the staff three years ago, likened the church to a family in which there are often conflicting relationships.
 
A Leader in Interfaith Relations
 "The church has been struggling for centuries" with such conflicts, including those among its clergy, she said, adding that Hitchcock's present situation was "not out of the ordinary."
Dr. MacLennan, a biblical scholar, earned his doctorate in early Christian texts on Jews and Judaism. He is a recognized county leader in interfaith relations and known for organizing such events as ecumenical Thanksgiving Day services at the church and a service in both Japanese and English to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the bombing of Pearl Harbor. Dr. MacLennan is also a co-chairman of the Westchester Holocaust Commission and Foundation, which sponsored the Garden of Remembrance in White Plains.
The minister said he plans to move with his wife, Jane, a lawyer, to Princeton, N.J., where he will consult on church affairs, write and teach and continue his present volunteer work at the Princeton Theological Seminary. He said he would remain on the advisory board of Moral Rearmament, an international peace group, and would continue his connection with the Holocaust Commission.
Phyllis Goldman, who directed the Holocaust Commission and is president of the county chapter of the American Jewish Committee, said Dr. MacLennan's work to build bridges between Christians and Jews had made "a tremendous impact" on the community and that his leaving would create "a true void."
 
'Growing and Constriction Pains'
 "Who is going to stand up and fill that void?" she asked. "We're in such troubled times now. I hope there are others who will stand up and take this on."
Mr. Oberhelman said that if he could "describe in one word what Bob has meant to us, he is a teacher, capitalized and italicized -- probably one of the finest biblical teachers I have ever come across. He speaks and understands Hebrew, Aramaic, Greek and Latin and reads for us from all of the texts in the original language."
Mr. Oberhelman, a self-employed businessman here, said that like many other traditional Protestant churches, Hitchcock was experiencing "growing and constriction pains" in a changing society. "We have looked at ourselves over time and have figured out we're not the church we were 25 years ago when there were 2,500 members and no financial problems," he said of the 850-member congregation. Besides new economic stresses, he said, "We need to start confronting questions about the changing multiracial and ethnic makeup of our congregation."
The formerly all-white congregation now includes several black families and many Japanese and Korean families, Mr. Oberhelman said. "How do you reach out to these other communities as white Anglo-Saxon Protestants?" he asked. "How do we grow the church when the traditional ways no longer apply?"
A committee is looking for two interim ministers to take over when Dr. MacLennan and Mr. Stanton leave this month. Ms. White will remain on the job at the church until February. Meanwhile, Dr. MacLennan, who described the present turmoil as "embarrassing, diminishing and sad," continues to preach Sunday sermons and keep on with a semblance of normal church life.
He will deliver his final sermon at Hitchcock next Sunday at 11 A.M., on the topic, "Why Is the Birth of Jesus So Important?" Before that, on Saturday from 4 to 6 P.M., religious leaders from churches and temples in the area will gather for a farewell service and reception for Dr. MacLennan. The event is open to the community.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Christmas 1993: Store Sales Up, Stocks Down

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
FOR the first time in three years, it looks as though Christmas will be a merry one for the nation's retailers. But on Wall Street, that already is being treated as old news. Share prices in the big store chains peaked within a day or two of Thanksgiving, the traditional kickoff of the shopping season.
That performance appears to provide another piece of evidence of how the stock market can be a leading indicator, showing knowledge of what is going to happen long before the economists or the politicians figure it out. Retail stocks began to leap just as summer, along with rhetoric about how bad the economy was, began to heat up. 
 From the end of June through Thanksgiving Day, an index of 12 retail shares rose 18.1 percent, while the Standard & Poor's 500 was up just 6.3 percent. But since then, the S.& P. has continued to move up, while the retail index has fallen 2.2 percent.
It is that underperformance that perhaps should be attracting attention now. Maybe it is nothing more than a momentary setback, a blip in a continuing recovery. Or maybe it is a warning that the surge in consumer spending is not destined to be long-lasting.
For those looking for signs that the recent rally in share prices is going to falter, the turnaround in retail stocks is not the only available indicator. While the Dow Jones industrial average registered a small gain last week, indexes of small stocks turned lower. The Nasdaq composite declined after rising for eight consecutive weeks. The drop was not large, but it came, as Robert Farrell, Merrill Lynch's chief market analyst, noted, amid virtual unanimity that small stocks were the place to be. The market has a way of frustrating such widely held opinions.
In any case, the strong Christmas season does appear to be here, whatever happens on Wall Street. "Things are going very well, unless you happen to be in California," said Daniel Barry, Merrill's retail analyst, who is forecasting that this season's sales for the industry will be up 8 percent from last year, after falling 1.5 percent in 1990 and rising just 1.3 percent last year. Some retailers are scrambling for merchandise, a problem Mr. Barry said was especially acute for J. C. Penney's catalogue operation.
Mr. Barry was a big booster of retail stocks for most of 1992, but he has turned cautious, noting that sales in the first few months of this year were pretty good, so comparisons will be tough in early 1993.
An important question for retail stocks, and for the economy as a whole, is whether consumer confidence, which spurted after the election, will keep rising. One possible negative will be the result of George Bush's failed effort to stimulate the economy earlier this year. Then he changed the rules on tax withholding, increasing the take-home pay of millions of workers by a few bucks a week. In early 1993, those workers will find out they will be getting smaller tax refunds than they are used to receiving. That fact is not likely to make them want to spend more.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/December 6-11

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
Clinton's Team Looks a Lot Like Cuomo's 

Aside from Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, whom President-elect Clinton tapped for Treasury Secretary, and Representative Leon E. Panetta of California, his choice for budget director, Mr. Clinton's dream team of economic advisers all have the same pedigree: they were part of the economic brain trust of Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York. Mr. Clinton's team of pinstripes and mortarboards -- Robert B. Reich, Labor Secretary; Robert E. Rubin, senior economic adviser; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Roger C. Altman, Deputy Treasury Secretary all advised the Cuomo Commission on economic competitiveness, said Vincent Tese, Director of Economic Development for New York. What kind of policies will the dream team promote? "They'll be working on a growth strategy with investment tax credits as the cornerstone," Mr. Tese said. "The idea is for G.D.P. to grow at 3 percent a year or better."

Taking the Deficit Pledge
 
"The economy, stupid" may have been what brought President-elect Clinton to Washington, but now that the economy's breath is once again fogging the mirror, what will Mr. Clinton do? Last week at a meeting in Washington, Mr. Clinton said he would make good on his pledge to leave the country with a "substantially smaller" budget deficit at the end of his term, but he refrained from promising how small the deficit would be. The deficit is expected to reach $340 billion in 1993. And while recent statistics may be showing that the economy has left its comatose state, Mr. Clinton cautioned the country not to confuse signs of life with economic health. The "evidence is more mixed," he said, adding that long-term problems, like the nation's slow productivity growth, must still be addressed.

Cable's Next Rival
 
For decades, cable TV systems have had no competition. That is beginning to change. First the Federal Communications Commission said it would let local phone companies carry "video dial tones" and now it has approved a new microwave technology that uses super-high-frequency radio waves to transmit 49 channels of television. The new system sends signals over the airwaves and is far less expensive to install than cable. The F.C.C. proposed offering licenses to two companies in each market and gave Cellular Visions of Freehold, N.J., which developed the technology, the choice of a license in either New York or Los Angeles. "It's another form of competition that we're prepared to face," said Carole Shandler, a spokeswoman for Cablevision Systems, based in Woodbury, L.I.

Finally, a Rosier Forecast
 
The nation's purchasing managers are to the economy what the groundhog is to spring. The National Association of Purchasing Managers surveys its 300 members' corporate buying activities and forecasts future economic activity. Last week the association's members overwhelmingly said they expected business activity to pick up next year -- but with a caveat. Though business will be better, it will not boom. The group forecast a 5.2 percent increase in revenues for the companies, after inflation. But while the upturn won't be robust, at least it will be widespread. "There wasn't a single industry that predicted a decrease in revenues in 1993 over 1992," said Robert Bretz, chairman of the group's business survey committee.

Keeping Inflation in Check
 
Outside of Detroit, few businesses are bold enough to raise prices when the economy turns sluggish. As a result, according to the Labor Department, prices at the producer level fell 0.2 percent in November, after inching up by a barely perceptible 0.1 percent in October. "Inflation is well contained," said Donald Kohn, director of monetary affairs at the Federal Reserve.
 
Those incredibly shrinking prices at the producer level have had a salubrious effect on consumer prices. According to the Labor Department, the Consumer Price Index increased by 0.2 percent in November, after increasing by 0.4 percent in October. Inflation for the year is running at 3.1 percent.

Out of the Woodwork
 
It may be a green Christmas after all. Retail sales grew by 0.4 percent in November, the fifth monthly gain in a row. "This raises the possibility that real G.D.P. in the fourth quarter could be as high as 3 percent," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
Why Yeltsin Is Stymied
 
When President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia failed to get his Congress to approve his economic plan along with his choice for Prime Minister, Yegor Gaidar, he accused the legislative body of seeking to return the country to the dark days of Communism. Then Mr. Yeltsin proposed holding a national referendum next month to determine who is the country's boss -- the President or the Congress. But not everyone agrees that Congress is against reform; some say it's just Mr. Yeltsin's current plans. "Who gave Yeltsin special powers to conduct his economic reform? Congress," said Vladimir Kvint, a professor of international business at Fordham University. What annoys Congress now is that Mr. Yeltsin's reforms have been badly executed, Mr. Kvint said. "When Gaidar started the reform process, inflation was 150 percent. Now it's 1,850 percent a year."
 
Stopping Soviet Brain Drain
 
While Mr. Yeltsin and the Congress wrangle, Russia's scientific establishment continues to crumble. To keep former Soviet scientists working, George Soros, the American investor and philanthropist, said he would give $100 million over the next two years to support the researchers. "To lose them because of economic difficulties would be really a loss for mankind," Mr. Soros said.

A Japanese Chip Coup
 
Cramming ever more memory capacity onto a wafer of silicon is a high-stakes business. Taking the lead in that race were four Japanese companies -- Fujitsu, Hitachi, NEC and Toshiba -- which disclosed they had independently developed chips that store 256-megabits of information, 64 times more capacity than current chips. But that does not mean they will have the market to themselves. "You can assume that other makers have comparable levels of technology," said Hiroyuki Mizuno, an executive at rival Matsushita Electric Industrial Corporation.

 
 
COMPANIES

 
Lockheed's Longer Reach
 
With the Pentagon's budget shrinking, the nation's arms makers have been scurrying around to consolidate their operations and pare down their work forces. Last week, in the largest consolidation so far, the Lockheed Corporation said it would acquire the General Dynamics Corporation's military aircraft division for $1.53 billion in cash. Lockheed, which already has the lion's share of the contract to build the Air Force's next-generation F-22 fighter, will now also be responsible for putting together the F-16. The sale is part of the General Dynamics strategy of shedding military businesses where it does not retain dominance. "There is massive overcapacity in the industry and this merger is the first real step toward rationalizing that capacity," said William A. Anders, chairman of General Dynamics.
 
The Big Three Join Forces
 
Electric cars are the vehicles of the future. At least they are in California, where tough new emissions standards go into effect in 1998 requiring at least 2 percent of each manufacturer's cars to have zero emissions. Trouble is, developing those cars takes a lot of scratch, the one commodity Detroit is short of right now. To remedy that, Detroit's highly competitive Big Three have already wired together an alliance to develop lightweight, long-lasting batteries. Last week they said they were also exploring ways to work together to develop a common infrastructure for recharging tomorrow's battery-powered cars.
 
Iacocca to the Rescue?
 
Ross Perot may not be the only one with a rescue complex. What about Lee A. Iacocca? Mr. Iacocca, who will retire as chairman of the Chrysler Corporation later this month, left a cushy job at the Ford Motor Company to nurse Chrysler back to health in the early 1980's. And last week he was in New York talking to investment bankers and members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers about forgoing a cozy, perk-filled retirement to battle Trans World Airlines back to health. T.W.A. is struggling to emerge from Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. Why ask Mr. Iacocca to be the rescuer? "There are only a few people with his ability to instill confidence," said Brian Freeman, an investment banker working with T.W.A. Will he do it? Mr. Iacocca said he is not looking for a full-time job.

What's Next? McBroccoli?
 
The newest "burger" being tested by the McDonald's Corporation contains all the trimmings and none of the meat. But McDonald's is doing its best to play down the significance of its new meatless fare so it won't scare off any hard-core carnivores loyal to Big Macs and MacDLT's. "It's only a five-restaurant test in the Netherlands," said Richard Starmann, senior vice president at the company's headquarters near Chicago. Health-food advocates, vegetarians and animal rights activists have applauded the test burger, which is made of potatoes, peas, carrots, onions and spices. Peas and carrots? Aren't those vegetables? The test will expand to 84 stores next month. "But that's only 84 stores out of nearly 13,000 worldwide, 1 country out of 63," Mr. Starmann explained.

Serious Cutting at Northwest
 
Like most domestic carriers, Northwest Airlines has had its share of recent disappointments. Not only did this year's fare war sap its earnings, but it ran out of credit last month. Northwest managed to get a new $250 million line of credit, but to regain its altitude it must also trim expenses. It's doing just that. It got an agreement with lenders to defer $340 million in payments in 1993 and began talks with its unions. But the deepest cuts came when it canceled $3.5 billion worth of aircraft orders from Airbus Industrie.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Risk-Reward in Latin Debt Funds

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
SEEKING to capitalize on investors' frustration with rock-bottom yields in the United States, a trio of closed-end bond funds that invest in Latin American debt and yield roughly 11 percent have come to market in the last five months.
The yields are high, of course, because the risk is high. Combine Latin America's long history of political turmoil with illiquid fund holdings and some leverage, and "you've got a pretty dicey investment," said Thomas J. Herzfeld, who specializes in closed-end investment and analysis in Miami. Invest only small amounts in these funds, analysts warn, and only when their share prices fall from premium levels. 
 Analysts call the 1980's in Latin America the "lost decade," but the outlook has changed as many controlled economies converted to free markets. More recently, Latin American equity funds multiplied to the point of satiety, so closed-end sponsors have turned to debt.
The Latin America Dollar Income fund, managed by Scudder, Stevens & Clark, came to market in July. The Emerging Markets Income Fund, managed by Salomon Brothers, began selling in October, and the Alliance World Dollar Government Fund started up in November.
The Latin funds reduce currency risk by buying dollar-denominated bonds -- mainly Brady bonds, issued under a program designed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady in 1990 to help developing countries refinance their debt. In most issues, the principal is guaranteed by zero-coupon United States Treasury bonds; in many, 12 to 18 months of interest is also guaranteed.
The Scudder fund invests mostly in Mexico (32 percent), Argentina (21 percent), Venezuela (19 percent) and Brazil (17 percent).
The Alliance fund invests mainly in Mexico (20 percent), the Philippines (15 percent), the United States (15 percent), Venezuela (10 percent), Argentina (10 percent) and Brazil (5 percent).
Emerging Markets focuses on Mexico, Argentina, the Philippines and Morocco, Salomon Brothers said, refusing to be more specific.
Because the funds own mostly government securities, investors may think they are as safe as United States Government bond funds. Not so. They are basically junk bond funds, especially vulnerable to sudden policy shifts -- Brazil's recent refusal to negotiate with the International Monetary Fund is one example. And there are coup attempts, as in Venezuela recently.
The danger of default in Latin America dates back to 1890, when the House of Baring, a prosperous London financial firm, guaranteed interest on its loans to Argentina. When the issues defaulted, a panic ensued. British investment trusts, predecessors of today's closed-end funds, suffered large losses. Latin American defaults came in the 1980's, too.
Then there is the danger of leverage. The Latin America Dollar Income fund, which is authorized by its prospectus to leverage up to one-third of its portfolio through bank borrowing, has already taken $10 million in loans against its $92 million in assets. As 80's survivors learned, leverage is bad news indeed when interest rates rise.
Share-price volatility is also a problem. Because Brady bonds are long-term issues, share prices will move sharply when interest rates shift, falling markedly if rates climb.
Add to that the usual concerns about buying new closed-end fund issues: that underwriters' costs are built into the offering price and that initial investors also bear the transaction costs to assemble the portfolio.
The Latin America Dollar Income fund, for example, traded at a 6.9 percent premium at inception. The premium rose briefly to 12 percent, then disappeared this month. Since July, the share price has fallen 12 percent.
But the biggest risk comes from taking advantage of an accounting method used by the funds to bolster income. To yield 10 percent, for example, a fund might earn 8 percent from its underlying bonds and then count in 2 percent more from the year-by-year increase in value of its zero-coupon bonds. That's fine, unless the zeros hit a stretch before maturity where their values drop, and you want to sell.
Finally, a restructuring of the debt or a setback in the United States Treasury markets, to which the Brady bonds are tied, would create capital losses that would come out of shareholders' pockets.
Mr. Herzfeld is considering buying the Latin American Dollar fund as a short-term play. He assumes it will fall to a discount of 5 percent to 10 percent before year-end as people dump shares to lock in tax losses. He then expects prices to rebound, enabling him to sell at a profit in January.
Michael Porter, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham, says that if President-elect Clinton stimulates the United States economy and investment yields move back up, why not wait to buy United States issues rather than risking Brady bonds? For investors who insist on Latin America, he recommends Latin America Dollar, even at a slight premium, but for no more than 5 percent of a portfolio.
Ron Olin, president of Deep Discount Advisers, in Houston, says the Latin American debt funds are just too pricey and advises not buying until they trade at discounts of 10 percent or so.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Britain-First Cure Is Working

BYLINE: By BARBARA PRESLEY NOBLE

 BODY:
It is only technically accurate to call what occurred in rural Vermont last weekend a retreat. True, some 50 A-list women, influential in policy, economics, the women's movement and plain old politics, gathered away from the ambitions and distractions of everyday life to develop an economic plan attendant to the needs of women.
But by all accounts the proximity of what most of the participants would call the Clinton millennium, at least for now, gave the gathering the kinetic force of an advance rather than a retreat. In the week since the meeting ended, members of the group have revised an outline into a working paper they will circulate at President-elect Bill Clinton's "economic summit" in Little Rock, which begins tomorrow. 
 "It was the best meeting I've been to in 20 years," said Betty Friedan, one of the weekend's organizers, who has been to her share of meetings in 30 years of feminist advocacy.
Hyperbole? A return to influence after a long exclusion from power can be intoxicating. But it seems quite possible that the meeting in Vermont may turn out to be a watershed feminist event.
It represents a departure from the defensive position women's groups have been forced into generally since the last Democratic Administration. And though the women's movement has roared back in the last couple of years from a political coma, much of its specific agenda -- the struggle to protect reproductive rights, for example -- is still reactive.
"Working on reproductive rights wasn't our agenda," said Linda Tarr-Whelan, executive director of the Center for Policy Alternatives and a major force behind the meeting. "It was put on the table by the right wing."
The weekend, Ms. Tarr-Whelan said, was dedicated to developing a "pro-active" agenda for the first 100 days of the Clinton Administration. When the call went out a few weeks ago, invitees scrambled their schedules to make room for the trip to Vermont.
Organizers invited a long list of eclectic, high-powered but apparently mellowed feminists. "Egos were checked at the door," said Sarah Kovner, a member of the Clinton transition's economic cluster, who was there. Others present included movement veterans like Bella Abzug, Ms. Friedan and Carol Bellamy, at least two corporate executives, several foundation representatives and academics, and one or two other Clinton people. Diana Meehan and Gary David Goldberg, Hollywood F.O.B.& H., donated their estate.
The luster of the stars apparently did nothing to disguise the tarnish on the American economy and the worry it causes. "Clinton tapped into concern and anxiety in the general population," said Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research, a Washington research organization. "This is a logical extension of that."
Impetus for the weekend came in part from the results of a bipartisan, multi-ethnic poll sponsored earlier this year by the Center for Policy Alternatives and the Ms. Foundation for Women. What issues, pollsters asked, do women really care about?
The poll revealed that women, like most Americans, worry most about the economy and jobs. Health care ranked second, with crime and education close behind. More than half the women surveyed reported that they had "fallen behind economically" during the previous year. Four-fifths said that discrimination in pay is a problem and about three-quarters favored tougher anti-discrimination laws. The family values movement aside, few were interested in full-time homemaking. "Women are totally committed to work and family," said Ms. Tarr-Whelan. "They are looking for the ability to control their own time."
The group emphasizes that its suggestions are designed to complement rather than contradict proposals already on the policy table of the new Administration. Proposals in the seven-page document are organized into five categories:
* Flexible work structures, including flex- and part-time arrangements, job-sharing and compressed workweeks.
* Equal pay for work of equal value.
* Expanded entrepreneurial opportunities for women.
* A redefinition of "infrastructure" to include people and communities, so that women and families benefit from increased government investment.
* A rethinking of welfare from subsistence-level support into a program that could provide economic security.
The group asks, for example, that Mr. Clinton issue an Executive Order mandating flexible work arrangements in Federal workplaces and one requiring Federal contractors to implement equal-pay-for-equal-work schemes. The working paper calls for stronger enforcement of anti-discrimination laws, a move, Ms. Hartmann argues, that would increase productivity and income. "It goes to women's purchasing power," she said.
 MS. FRIEDAN and others argue that many of the group's initial proposals are low-ticket items that could be done cheaply and easily, a contention possibly designed to forestall any eye-rolling, "there you go again" responses from the deficit-reduction types appointed to the Clinton economic team last week.
Innumerable feminist working papers have emerged from countless meetings over the last two decades, all on an express train to the archives. The women's economic policy working paper is already getting a hearing. Members of the group have met with a representative of the transition team and some of the women present in Vermont -- Ms. Tarr-Whelan and Ms. Meehan, for two -- have been invited to the summit meeting. The sense of liberation so many experienced last weekend wasn't just the effects of that clean Vermont air.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Britain-First Cure Is Working

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
WHEN it abandoned the heart of its economic strategy in September and allowed the pound to float in value outside the European system of semi-fixed exchange rates, the British Government said it was adopting a new policy tailored for the needs of Britain, not of a unified Europe.
The new approach, which has consisted primarily of slashing interest rates and paying little attention to the tumble in the pound's value, has not yet lifted the nation out of its three-year recession. But, by reducing the costs of borrowing, it seems to have given a kick to the economy, and it has been an undeniable winner on the London stock exchange, where share prices rose to their all-time highs at the beginning of this month. 
 Having bottomed in September at 2,281, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading shares surged 22 percent over the following two and a half months, peaking on Dec. 1 at 2,792.
It has since slipped somewhat on profit taking, on concern about the effect of an economic downturn in Germany and on a growing consensus that rates will not fall any further in the next several months. Share prices fell last week, and the index closed on Friday at 2,716.2, down 43.2 for the week.
The rapid run-up in share prices during the fall was fueled by interest-rate cuts that pushed the benchmark base lending rate from 10 percent in September down to the current 7 percent. Now investors are wondering whether they have bet correctly that lower rates will bring a rebound in the economy and in corporate profits next year, and whether the market will surge further.
Economists and analysts said the evidence is mixed. Inflation has continued to fall. There have been some tentative signs of an upturn in consumer spending and confidence. Retail sales and car registrations, for example, have both started rising in the last several months. Retailers reported more early Christmas traffic in many locations, with consumers showing a somewhat greater willingness to spend despite continued concerns about rising unemployment -- now at 10 percent -- and falling home prices.
Because most homeowners in Britain have adjustable-rate mortgages, falling rates have left more cash in their pockets each month. The Government has tried other tactics as well to get the economy going; one was to eliminate a tax surcharge on new-car purchases.
Companies are benefiting directly as well, because lower rates mean reduced debt-repayment costs. The weaker pound has given a big boost to exporters, whose products can now be priced more competitively in markets like the United States and Germany. The signs of an incipient upturn in the economy of the United States are also good news for large British companies, many of which have large presences in the United States and earn significant portions of their profits in dollars, which can now be translated into pounds at very favorable rates.
But the British economy has shown signs before of shucking the recession, only to lapse once again. As a result, analysts said, investors remain somewhat wary that share prices have gone too high, and are still seeking concrete signs that the recovery will take hold in the new year as strongly as they are assuming. At about 17 times projected 1992 earnings, the market is near the top of its historical standards, but not, in the view of most analysts, overpriced.
"The big risk to the market, which I don't attach a great deal of importance to, will be if we get to March or April and we don't have better news on the economy," said Sushil Wadhwani, an equity strategist at Goldman, Sachs in London. "Even on simple valuation indicators the market is still, even after the rise of the last several months, somewhat undervalued."
Some economists think the risk to British investors lies not in the domestic economy but in Europe's other economies, particularly Germany's. The Bundesbank said on Thursday that it would not cut official interest rates, despite growing signs of a recession, because of its deep-rooted fear of inflation.
Economists think the Bundesbank will eventually change course and ease its monetary policy, but probably not for several months at least, increasing the risk that exporters to Germany -- Britain's largest export market -- may see demand slacken.
"To some extent you're trading off the consumer recovery at home versus recession in Europe," said Andrew Bell, an equity strategist with Barclays de Zoete Wedd in London. "The risk on earnings estimates for 1993 still seems to be on the down side."
Mr. Bell said he thinks that the British economy will expand by about 1 percent next year, and that the market should hit 3,000. He said, though, that because the market tends to surge in January, all of the gain could come at the beginning of the year.
Mr. Wadhwani at Goldman, Sachs said he thinks that the market will hit 3,100 in the next year, and that it could be "meaningfully higher by the end of January."
He said some of the best investment opportunities were in retailing, where companies such as Sears (not related to Sears, Roebuck in the United States) and Next remained undervalued compared with the market. Among companies with heavy exposure in the United States, he said, Hanson P.L.C. remains a good bet. With the overall British economy ready to turn around, he said, companies in the chemicals and metals industries also offer good opportunities for profit and share-price growth.
