HEADLINE: Profile/William Amherst Vanderbilt Cecil;
Opening His Door to 700,000 Visitors

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

DATELINE: ASHEVILLE, N.C.

 BODY:
WILLIAM AMHERST VANDERBILT CECIL owns the largest house in the nation, more than three times the size of the White House, with a yard more than nine times the size of Central Park.
Problem is, the place is too small. 
 Mr. Cecil has turned the 255-room house, called Biltmore Estate, built by the Vanderbilt family a century ago, into a thriving tourist attraction. More than 700,000 people, most of them paying $21.95 each, will visit this year -- never mind the out-of-the-way location here in western North Carolina. When 10,000 of those guests all wanted to come the day after Thanksgiving, the wait stretched beyond two hours, with visitors cramming the parking lots, ticket office, gift shops, restaurants and house.
Mr. Cecil, through his Biltmore Company, has achieved his improbable business success by making the contradictory seem logical. An aristocratic heir to an aristocratic home, he commissions marketing studies to make sure he can appeal to commoners' tastes. To keep the house private he has welcomed ever-larger throngs of the public, adding dining halls and shops, a winery, Christmas music, candlelight tours and more bathrooms than he can count.
"George Vanderbilt never envisioned 700,000 people a year flushing his toilets," he said, gesturing with a sweep of his arm to the entryway crowd as he called to mind the grandfather who finished the house in 1895. The White House may get twice the tourists, but then Biltmore is far removed from any urban downtown.
Now, at age 64, Mr. Cecil is facing his greatest challenge since he first turned a money-losing, deteriorating estate into a showplace more than two decades ago. When he dies, the tax collector will want his family to pay 55 percent of Biltmore's value in estate taxes. This would probably force his family to sell or develop the property, or turn it over to a foundation or government agency unlikely to afford the upkeep, he says.
"In today's climate, where you have homeless, you have poor, you have far more important, quote unquote, things to look after, where does the legislature cut?" he said. "Maintenance would fall apart."
And so, a man who prides himself on getting along without Federal grants, subsidies, tax breaks, anything -- "We're a contributor to the economy," he said -- has begun lobbying for kinder treatment: a tax deferral until his family sells the estate, or at least a 10-year period in which to pay the taxes.
People like Mr. Cecil, you see, really aren't supposed to flourish in these United States. Alexis de Tocqueville, a French visitor, observed more than a century and a half ago that American conditions, laws and ideals barred the development of a European-style gentry passing vast estates from generation to generation. "The soil of America absolutely rejected a territorial aristocracy," he wrote.
Mr. Cecil laments that Americans show so little attachment to their land. "Europeans have a different outlook on property than we do here," he said. "We're a mobile nation. Most of us Americans move five or six times in a lifetime. Europeans are sticks in the mud."
To meet Mr. Cecil is to begin learning about how he resolves the conflicts that have shaped him and his business. His words are somehow clipped and drawled at the same time, reflecting a parentage and upbringing half American, half British. He was born at Biltmore in 1928, the son of George Vanderbilt's daughter and a father descended directly from Lord Burghley, Queen Elizabeth I's Lord High Commissioner.
The estate's grounds, originally 125,000 acres but now 8,000, were landscaped by Frederick Law Olmsted, whose preparation for the Biltmore job included Central Park. The architect was Richard Morris Hunt, who piled on so many towers and turrets and gargoyles and spires that he needed to raid the designs of at least three of the greatest Loire Valley chateaux.
In recent years, Mr. Cecil has spent less time on the estate than in his office building five miles away, a stark corporate fortress of concrete and tinted glass, designed by I.M. Pei, that he bought second-hand.
The sense that he is sometimes talking down to visitors and employees there comes from both height (6 feet 4 inches) and hauteur: "Let me correct one mistake," he began. "It's not the Biltmore. It's Biltmore. Biltmore House. The Biltmore is a hotel."
His staff whispers that he is reluctant to go to the estate too often because his health and size have hobbled him. He says that he is afraid he will be asked to sign guidebooks and brochures: "I don't do windows and I don't do autographs."
BUT he does do balance sheets and marketing plans. "I never had any qualms about making this a serious business," he said.
To emphasize that it's a family business, not a family playground, he lives in a house off the estate, with his wife, Mary. "There's no way you can say Biltmore is a private home," he said. "It's a private corporation. My daughter wanted to get married there. I said, 'Hell no. It's not your home.' She'll never forgive me."
His son and daughter, William Jr. and Diana Pickering, both in their 30's, have been in the business for several years. His own path back to Biltmore was more circuitous.
His parents divorced, and he went off to Britain in 1936. After a stint in the Royal Navy and a degree at Harvard, he joined Chase Manhattan, advancing in a few years to run the Spanish, Swiss and French desk, then the Washington office.
A family friend and judge who was managing Biltmore was meanwhile getting on in years. Against the advice of New York friends and Chase executives, Mr. Cecil left for Asheville in 1960.
 BILTMORE had been grudgingly open to the public for 30 years. But after three decades, revenues from 50,000 visitors a year were falling $250,000 short of maintenance costs. There are 16th-century tapestries to repair with silver and gold thread, Renoirs to clean, hundreds of rooms to heat. Only a profitable dairy on the estate made it possible.
Mr. Cecil began providing a hearty welcome. Advertising and marketing until then had meant a page in the annual agriculture and travel issues of The Asheville Citizen-Times. Mr. Cecil made Biltmore familiar in advertisements and billboards for hundreds of miles around, buying space himself to save the 17.5 percent agency commissions. He churned out news releases, taking photographs himself. He opened more rooms.
In 1968, he had 200,000 visitors and his first profit, $16.34. "It was a lot more fun than losing a quarter of a million dollars a year," he said.
Mr. Cecil courted tour operators and local hotel owners. He added restaurants, gift shops and other attractions, which together generate about 40 percent of the estate's $29 million in annual revenues (with a pre-tax profit margin, one Biltmore executive said, of about 12 percent).
His is on a continual quest for new revenue sources, always with an earnest reference to the sanctity of the nation's history and his grandfather's intentions. "I could put condos, I could put factories on the property," he said. "But are you then preserving the patrimony of the United States?"
By 1985, he had hit upon a more fitting source of new sales after he noticed visitors munching some of the grapes in his gardens. The winery he opened that year is now the most visited in the United States, he says, with about 500,000 guests. (A professional's sampling of three of his best bottles indicated that his genius may lie more in marketing than wine-making. "Robert Mondavi has nothing to fear," said Frank J. Prial, wine critic for The New York Times.)
Other plans include a new visitor center, restaurants, more parking and larger shops. Drexel Heritage will introduce a Biltmore Estate Collection of furniture.
Besides talking to Washington about the inheritance laws, Mr. Cecil wants the Smithsonian to use part of the estate to display oddities it can't show under its own roof. Not an unprecedented move, Mr. Cecil said. During World War II, the National Gallery, fearing an attack on Washington, sent choice objects to Biltmore for safekeeping.
If Mr. Cecil's marketing of his family's past remains exceptional, his grandfather's monumental ambitions are not. Modern-day Vanderbilts are even now busily building. The $35 million home William H. Gates III of Microsoft is erecting near Seattle may not be as large, but the house's high-resolution computer display screens are every bit as advanced as Biltmore's plumbing and circuitry were in their day.
Who knows but that in another century, William H. Gates V will be looking for ways to attract more visitors while he arm-wrestles the Government to keep a historical estate in the family? And just maybe, he will call William Amherst Vanderbilt Cecil IV for advice.

 
 
THE SHEKELS OF CHRISTMAS
 ATTRACTING motorists and tour buses to Biltmore Estate when the nearby Great Smokies are in spring bloom or fall color is one thing. Doing so in Christmas season, when the region's other attractions boil down to the outlet stores in Pigeon Forge, Tenn., is another. Yet William Cecil has made Christmas his busiest time of year.
It took some doing: Mr. Cecil began tentatively, putting up a Christmas tree or two 15 years ago. Then he added a couple more.
This season there are 30, including one more than three stories tall that still fits comfortably in the medieval banquet hall. These decorations help Mr. Cecil collect an extra $3 a head, or $24.95, and still attract more than 100,000 December guests.
As the crowds grew, and the house didn't, he added candlelight evening Christmas tours a few years ago, with tootling musicians and an admission charge of $27.95. Some dates sell out weeks in advance.
To further spread the Christmas cheer, Stephen P. Miller, a Biltmore senior vice president, did some marketing research about raising the decorations, and the admission charge, by Nov. 16. "Not only didn't people think it was too commercial, but they actually liked it," he said. "It gives them more flexibility."
Mr. Cecil reluctantly went along, but not before asking, "Are you going to put it to Aug. 1 next year?"
By early this month, Mr. Cecil was fully convinced, having seen November attendance jump 31.7 percent. "Now," he asked himself, "how are we going to beat that?"

HEADLINE: ENGAGEMENTS;
Jill E. Purdy, Paul D. Sarkozi

 BODY:
Jill Elizabeth Purdy, an associate at the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, and Paul David Sarkozi, an associate at the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, plan to marry in February.
Ms. Purdy, 26 years old, graduated from Tulane University, from which she also received a law degree. She is a daughter of Judith E. Pridgen of Charlotte, N.C., and Dr. J. Gerry Purdy of Cupertino, Calif. Ms. Purdy's father is the vice president of the mobile computing group at Dataquest Inc., a market research company in San Jose, Calif. The prospective bride is a stepdaughter of Samuel Pridgen of Charlotte and Melanie Purdy of Cupertino. 
 Mr. Sarkozi, 26, graduated summa cum laude from Yale University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a law degree from Harvard University. He is the son of Dr. Laszlo Sarkozi and Marilyn Sarkozi of Rye Brook, N.Y. Mr. Sarkozi's mother teaches Spanish at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx. His father directs the chemistry laboratories at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York and is a pathology professor at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Saab Updates Its 9000-Series Sedan

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
LET'S say you don't know where to go for your next vacation. Tokyo is too expensive, and the Bahamas are . . . well, too close. But how about Trollhattan?
That might be just the place, in fact, if you are in the market for a new car or, more specifically, for a new Saab. 
 Trollhattan is home to the Swedish company's headquarters, and it is one of 13 delivery sites in Saab's current "International and Diplomat" sales program. It is also one of two sites -- the other being Gothenburg, Sweden -- where buyers receive a complimentary arrival package.
The package includes free airport-to-hotel transportation, a night's accommodations, breakfast and dinner for two and tours of the company's museum and assembly plant. More to the point, though, the program will save a customer as much as $5,000 on the car's purchase price, while eliminating the need for a rental car.
Saab also has designated 28 drop-off points throughout Europe, with free shipment back to the United States from two of them, Gothenburg and Bremerhaven, Germany. Fees from the other 26 locations can be as low as $50, and buyers are spared the cost of customs clearance, duty and marine insurance.
The program is available through any of Saab's 305 American dealers and encompasses the company's entire line, including the newly redone 9000 series.
All of this largess doesn't mean that Saab is rolling in kronor, of course. Quite the opposite, and Saab is merely doing what it can to stimulate sagging sales, while rethinking its marketing strategies in the United States.
Saab, which is a 50-50 venture between General Motors and Sweden's Saab-Scania, lost $4 million more in the third quarter of this year than the $88 million loss that was posted for the same period of 1991. As a result, the company has announced that it needs an infusion of cash from its owners, and that it has embarked on a massive cost-cutting program, including layoff of 22 percent of its workforce.
At the same time, the prices of some 1993 models have been held to '92 levels, and the 9000 CD sedans actually have been reduced. Of particular note is the fully equipped CD Turbo, whose price has dropped to $35,745 from $37,615.
The big news for '93, though, is the addition of the 9000 CS and CSE sports sedans. The cars, which replace the 9000, 9000S and 9000 Turbo, have a changed profile, with new treatments at front and rear, bodies that are almost 4 inches longer and a 25 percent increase in structural rigidity.
The new body incorporates door beams, strengthened crossmembers in the floor and reinforced roof pillars. A roll-bar has also been added behind the rear doors. According to the company, all that creates a resistance to side impacts that exceeds the Federal standards that will go into effect in 1997. All '93 Saabs also have standard antilock brakes and driver-side air bags.
The tester was a bright red CSE Turbo, a four-door hatchback that is the top of Saab's line. The car had blackout trim and molded wheels, and it carried a black spoiler across the hatch. For '93, there also is a new high-mounted brakelight, and the taillights extend all the way across the car's rump.
The hatch itself rises from the cargo floor, which has a sturdy cover to keep prying eyes off any valuables within. The split rear seats fold down, allowing 23.5 cubic feet of carrying capacity.
While interior space means that the Government rates the car as "large," its exterior dimensions really aren't all that big, with a wheelbase of 105.2 inches and an overall length of about 188 inches. All the same, the test vehicle offered good room in the rear and comfort aplenty up front.
Bucket seats for the driver and front passenger are power adjustable, and the driving position is excellent. The tester had black leather upholstery, although wool now is an interior option.
Options, in fact, are part of Saab's '93 marketing approach, and a company spokesman said the "new" program takes a leaf from the Detroit manufacturers, allowing various equipment packages to satisfy different tastes and budgets. A sunroof and leather seats are now available in the least expensive models, for example, while a turbocharged 9000 can be had without the full range of luxury features.
The red CSE was thoroughly well-dressed, however, with complete power equipment, automatic climate control, central locking and a superb sound system, including a compact-disk player.
One problem, at least as far as I'm concerned, is the location of the buttons for the power windows. As usual with Saabs, the buttons are down between the seats, along with the button for the flip-or-slide sunroof, and they are inconvenient.
Amazingly, though, the rear buttons send the back windows all the way down, a rarity in modern automobiles and a feature that merits applause.
The tester's main gauge was a 140-m.p.h. speedometer, flanked by a 7,000-r.p.m. tach and gauges for temperature, fuel and turbo boost. When the turbo cuts in, the car with its standard five-speed stick is quick off the mark and fast on the road. But the four-cylinder engine does require some stirring of the gears in city traffic.
Actually, two engines are available in any of the new CS and CSE models. Both are 2.3-liter fours and both breathe through four valves per cylinder. The base powerplant, naturally aspirated, produces 150 horsepower, while the intercooled and turbocharged version puts out an even 200.
The turbo also features something that Saab calls "Trionic," a new 32-bit microprocessor that integrates ignition, fuel injection and knock-control systems for improved efficiency and reduced exhaust emissions. Economy ranges from 18 miles per gallon in the city to 27 highway.
Either of the engines can be teamed with a four-speed automatic transmission, a $920 option. Other options, like leather and power seats, can also raise the car's price considerably.
The bottom line for a base 9000 CS is $25,725. The CSE starts at $31,060, and the CSE Turbo is $35,055. One way to save, of course, is to go on vacation.

HEADLINE: Lincoln Square

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Trading Low-Income Housing for Bonuses" on Nov. 1 cites the city's inclusionary housing bonus program, which enables developers to build up to 20 percent additional floor area in exchange for constructing permanent low-income housing, as a major contributor to the size of the Lincoln Square project. While the program did provide the project with a zoning bonus, the problems with the height, massing and commercial usage of the building reflect the developer's marketing and financial objectives. 
 The Westside commmunity has raised legitimate concerns over the Lincoln Square development. Therefore, City Planning has initiated a review of the zoning regulations of the Special Lincoln Square District to insure that future developments are more appropriate additions to one of New York's most vibrant and vital mixed-use neighborhoods. This review will examine a number of urban design and planning issues, including the impact of retail and commercial uses, which cause far more congestion than residential development. In addition, we believe revised envelope controls could package the bulk of new buildings in ways that are more compatible with the neighborhood.
The inclusionary housing program and the City Planning Commission's precedent-setting approvals of Riverside South and Brighton-by-the-Sea, which mandate economically integrated new communities, reflect our belief that, as a principle of sound urban planning, communities need to include a variety of housing available to occupants with different income levels.
It would be a mistake to eliminate the inclusionary housing program in a misguided attempt to regulate the physical form of building. There are far more effective ways to mandate more sympathetic urban design and planning guidelines than to restrict a necessary, unique and important way of constructing the low-income housing New Yorkers so desperateely need.
 
RICHARD L. SCHAFFER
 
The writer is chairman of the New York City Planning Commission.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Calls to Restrict Immigration Come From Many Quarters

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

 BODY:
IN the last year, many politicians have sensed that the national mood -- frustration -- permitted the kind of complaints about immigrants that are traditionally considered un-American. Senator Robert C. Byrd, for example, took to the Senate floor last June to offer some highly public trepidations about the changing face of America.
"I pick up the telephone and call the local garage," said Mr. Byrd, a Democrat from West Virginia. "I can't understand the person on the other side of the line. I'm not sure he can understand me. They're all over the place, and they don't speak English. Do we want more of this?" 
 With the economy on the decline and the number of new immigrants on the rise, the U.S. welcome mat has become somewhat worse for wear. Across the country, and particularly in California, Americans have felt freer to voice a rude inhospitality that at other times they might have considered racist or at least xenophobic. Advocates for immigrants cringe and call it scapegoating but expect a mellower tone in the coming year. Those who call for a freeze on immigration, however, saw the sour mood of the past year as a harbinger of a new conservatism ahead.
The question is where such talk can lead. In recent history, political conservatives have been repeatedly unsuccessful in pushing through any measures restricting the legal flow of immigrants. Indeed, Congress's most recent move increased immigrant quotas by 40 percent. And advocates are skilled at playing to the nation's sense of itself as a land of immigrants, at promoting the benefits of diversity and discounting what they say are unproven theories that immigrants take more than they give.
Nonetheless, in the last year and a half, in political campaign rhetoric, magazine articles and legislative proposals, the tenor of public conversation about immigration has changed, with emphasis shifting from romantic rhapsodies about the melting pot to anxiety attacks about the dwindling resources of an economically strapped nation. In such, some Americans have found a way not only to vent their frustration but to express racist discomfort with the nation's darkening complexion, as most immigrants are Latino and Asian.
Tenuous alliances, too, have been forged between anti-immigration groups, some environmentalists and some civil rights advocates. In California, the Sierra Club, concerned that immigrants are causing a population explosion harmful to the environment, joined forces with three groups that favor immigration restrictions to create the Coalition to Stabilize Population. And in Congress, a proposed Constitutional amendment that would deny citizenship to the American-born children of illegal immigrants was sponsored by 12 Republicans and two Democrats who are civil rights advocates, Representatives Charles Rangel of New York and Anthony C. Beilenson of Los Angeles. Many civil rights leaders are torn between their conscience and their constituents, as American-born blacks worry that immigrants are displacing them from jobs and political power.
It became particularly trendy in California for politicians to blame the state's economic woes on immigrants, and especially on illegal ones. With Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, claiming that immigrants were bankrupting the state by using more in services than they pay in taxes, Los Angeles, San Diego and Orange counties all commissioned studies to determine just how much new and illegal immigrants cost taxpayers.
And during the campaigns there was much tough talk from Republicans and Democrats alike about "defending the border" with Mexico. When Senator John Seymour, a Republican, proposed hiring 1,500 additional border patrol officers, Dianne Feinstein, the Democrat who defeated him, said she wanted to see the Army help reinforce the border.
The New Jersey Legislature eliminated public assistance benefits to illegal immigrants and appears to be moving swiftly to deny them the right to a driver's license. In New York's suburban Suffolk County, the welcome of more generous times has given way to such negativity that when a principal in Elmont, N.Y., reported two of his students, the children of illegal immigrants, to immigration authorities, he was applauded by his local school board.
Advocates have been alarmed by the ugly repercussions of this attitude change, which was exacerbated by the participation of Hispanic immigrants in the riots in Los Angeles and Washington Heights. Bias incidents and biased comments against immigrants multiplied, they said. And few Americans came forward to protest President Bush's May executive order that forced the repatriation of Haitians fleeing their country by boat.
But for Patrick Buchanan and a contingent of conservative academics and writers, the mood was ripe for exploitation. "Look, we have to speak up when we can, when we're least likely to face the charges of racism that are our occupational hazard," says Dan Stein of the Federation for American Immigration Reform, which lobbies for a freeze on immigration.
Mr. Stein is usually careful to base his fear about increasing immigration on arguments about scarce resources. He often voices concern about immigrants displacing black and Hispanic Americans from jobs. But others, Mr. Buchanan, for example, also resent the "dilution" of their European heritage. "If present trends hold," Mr. Buchanan noted during the campaign, "white Americans will be a minority by 2050."
And in "Time to Rethink Immigration?" a cover story in a June issue of The National Review, Peter Brimelow, a senior editor at Forbes magazine, compares the immigration service waiting room to the subway, "an underworld that is almost entirely colored." In articles in conservative policy journals, immigrants were portrayed, variously, as displacing Americans from jobs, draining government resources, crowding cities with their large families, importing drugs and disease and threatening the dominance of English.
Even Eugene McCarthy, the former Presidential candidate and Senator from Minnesota, criticized U.S. immigration policy as a "virtual entitlement" of "ethnic interest groups" to be "defended at all costs" in his new book, "A Colony of the World: The United States Today," (Hippocrene Books). Mr. Stein's group has offered to finance the book's advertising campaign.
After George Bush and Bill Clinton scarcely mentioned immigration during the campaign, advocates hoped the national bad mood would blow over with an economic improvement and a new President. But anti-immigrant groups foresee two opportunities to capitalize on Americans' souring toward foreigners and refugees: debate on the North American Free Trade Agreement and a potential exodus from Haiti.
Still, now more than ever the United States is a multicultural society, and the inter-ethnic clashes of the last year could be seen as growing pains. Certainly the antagonism of the moment pales in comparison to the vehement nativism that followed World War I, or the overt hatred of the 1850's and 1890's. And few expect the situation to boil over into the bloody tensions and closing borders of some European countries. Ill will is ill will, observers say, but it is not a shut door.

HEADLINE: What Counts Is Productivity and Productivity

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
TOPIC A at Bill Clinton's economic extravaganza next week in Little Rock will no doubt be the recession. But as the President-elect told everyone from newspaper executives to Congressional leaders last week, it is productivity that will mark the success or failure of his economic policies. And most economists, it is safe to say, would agree with him.
Recessions come and, mercifully, always go. However, the only way to raise living standards and pay for dreams like universal health care and welfare reform is to increase productivity -- how manycars, hamburgers and everything else Americans make per hour. 
 And for reasons poorly understood, this vital fire of progress has dimmed to an ember since the early 1970's. The business-sponsored Committee for Economic Development's new report, "Restoring Prosperity," estimates that if labor productivity had grown as anemically in the century before 1972 as it has in the two decades since, Americans would live no better than Brazilians.
The route back to a more productive future is uncharted. But Mr. Clinton is apparently prepared to fulfill his campaign promises by investing serious political capital in fostering growth. And he may benefit from a business climate sobered by hard times and fierce foreign competition.
Political battles over economic policy usually focus on who gains and who loses from taxes, subsidies and regulation. But over decades, trends in wages have far more impact on the typical family's living standard than the way government reshuffles the economic deck does. Wages, in turn, are more or less tied to output per hour worked. "Productivity isn't everything," concludes Paul Krugman of M.I.T., "but in the long run it is almost everything."
From 1948 to 1973 productivity in private business rose 2.9 percent annually, nearly doubling average wages along the way. But since the mid-1970's the pace has slipped to just 1 percent, and wages have been in virtual gridlock. Most of the continuing gain in living standards during the Reagan years came from the fact that more women were putting in more hours in paying jobs. Much of the rest has come from lower savings, as both families and the Government responded to leaner times by spending beyond their means.
Economists, alas, are better at figuring what didn't take the wind out of the productivity sails than what did. Higher energy costs, the alleged source of the slowdown in the 1970's, could not have had much to do with it since productivity did not perk up when oil prices plummeted in the 1980's. And Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, finds little substance in the argument that increased government regulation was at fault. Environmental controls have indeed begun to bite. But the resulting drag was partially offset by productivity gains in industries that benefited from deregulation -- notably the transportation and energy industries.
More plausible explanations focus on investment -- or, rather, the lack thereof. Alicia Munnell, director of research for the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, pins some of the blame on government's pennywise policy toward public investment. Between 1970 and 1990 the total value of everything owned by government -- from highways to computers to office buildings -- fell from about half of the gross national product to just 41 percent. That left the nation with traffic-choked roads, crowded air routes, and perhaps as a consequence, lower productivity growth in private industry.
 
Diplomas Guarantee Less
 The link between education and worker performance is hard to measure. But the 3 R's must matter. And research by James Heckman of the University of Chicago suggests that a high school diploma or its equivalent is less of a guarantee of basic workplace competence than it used to be. What's more, notes Van Doorn Ooms, the research director of the Committee on Economic Development, the rapid entry of women and young workers into the labor force has reduced average experience levels, and presumably diluted the pool of skills gained on the job.
Some also blame the what-me-worry ethos of the 1980's. With personal and corporate thrift on the wane and Washington running deficits unprecedented in peacetime, the overall savings rate went from about 8 percent of income in the 1950's and 1960's to just 2 to 3 percent in the last decade.
A great tide of foreign investment -- about $900 billion in the 1980's -- did pay for the computers, airplanes and machinery needed to keep an industrial economy humming. Foreign investment did not, however, make up the entire shortfall. The result, estimate Ethan Harris and Charles Steindel of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was a half-percentage point drop in productivity growth -- a giant difference in the post-60's world of just 1 percent growth.
And the impact may be even stronger than the Fed economists suggest. Bradford DeLong of Harvard and Lawrence Summers, the chief economist for the World Bank who is now working for the Clinton transition team, are convinced that equipment investment is the great catalyst for technological change.
Most economists concede they are not really sure what slowed productivity growth. Robert Solow, the Nobel Prize-winning growth theorist, once remarked that discussions of the puzzle usually end "in a blaze of amateur sociology." But the economists' one consistent theme, that sluggish investment in machines and people made a big difference, has not been lost on the Clinton team. And it is no secret where Mr. Clinton is heading.
During the campaign he pledged to spend an additional $20 billion annually on public infrastructure and plow billions more into education and job training. He will almost certainly also add rich incentives for investment in business machinery -- most likely a tax credit for purchases beyond a firm's average over the past few years.
Mr. Clinton also pledged to halve the deficit, and again last week insisted that he would hold Congress' feet to the fire on deficit reduction. But this less direct route to private investment will probably rate a lower priority. After all, he could only make good on the pledge by raising taxes for the middle classes or by making a frontal assault on well-armored spending.
The Clinton capital blitz is unlikely to yield a quick payoff. Robert Gordon of Northwestern University notes that the returns on some of the most promising investments are bound to trickle in over decades. "Money going into Head Start," he jibed, "will raise productivity during some Republican Administration 30 years from now."
And in any case, 3 percent productivity nirvana may simply be beyond the reach of the mature American economy. William Baumol of New York University believes roughly half the decline in productivity growth since the early 1970's represents a return to the very long term trend -- that the quarter-century of growth above 2 percent was a one-shot phenomenon, a delayed exploitation of great science and engineering advances from plastics to pesticides to radar that accumulated during the Depression and World War II.
But President Clinton may be in a better position to deliver the bacon than is commonly understood. Productivity growth always looks good coming out of a recession, since when orders go up, businesses are generally able to reduce the slack in their operations. And some economists, among them Stephen Roach of Morgan Stanley, think the exceptionally large bounce in output per worker during the third quarter of this year signals more enduring changes -- in Mr. Roach's words "a trend breaker."
If Mr. Roach is right, the ongoing restructuring of competition-battered businesses, services like banking and industrial dinosaurs like General Motors, will add a shade less than a percentage point to the rate of productivity growth for several more years. Clintonomics could thus look like a winner, whether or not Mr. Clinton's initiatives to spur investment, innovation and savings prove to have much kick.
By this not-unhappy scenario, the Clinton productivity boom may resemble the serendipitous taming of inflation during the Reagan Administration. President Reagan, after all, got the credit for the success of unpopular anti-inflationary monetary policies dictated by the Federal Reserve during the Carter Administration.
Felicity, however, has its price. Like President Reagan, President Clinton may confuse good luck with policy acumen. And like Mr. Reagan, Mr. Clinton may be tempted to delay the tough measures needed to lock in higher productivity growth -- notably deficit reduction -- when he is still popular enough to push them though Congress.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
DEMOCRATIC LEADER AND CLINTON FRIEND GAIN MAJOR POSTS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 12

 BODY:
President-elect Bill Clinton reached back to Hope, Ark., and into the corporate lobbying culture of Washington today to fill two more top jobs, naming his oldest childhood friend, Thomas F.McLarty 3d, as chief of staff, and the Democratic Party chairman, Ronald H. Brown, as Secretary of Commerce.
In picking a self-effacing boyhood chum for chief of staff, a job that in recent years has been filled by ambitious empire builders, Mr. Clinton signaled that he wanted an apolitical referee to reconcile competing factions, not an advocate for any particular point of view. He was also determined to pick someone who could keep a secret, a specialty of the press-shy Mr. McLarty, whose friends call him Mack.
 
Concerns of Real People
 "The people of America will learn, as I have over the years, that they can trust Mack McLarty to bring the real concerns of real people to the table," said Mr. Clinton, his eyes watery with tears as he introduced his friend to the nation. "I trust him to build a team in the White House. He is a chief executive officer who knows how to get things done. The American people can feel confident that he will make sure everyone's voice is heard before I make an important decision and that everyone pulls together once that decision is made." 
 In naming Mr. Brown, Mr. Clinton was simultaneously paying off a big political debt and working to fulfill a campaign vow to have a racially diverse cabinet. Mr. Brown, who is black, works for one of the most powerful lobbying law firms in Washington, and was instrumental in engineering Mr. Clinton's election by uniting the fractious wings of the Democratic Party behind him.
Speaking of the need for a national strategy to bolster the economy and make it more competitive, Mr. Brown, who could face a tough confirmation battle because of his lobbying for foreign Governments in recent years, said his mission at Commerce would be "to bring business and labor and government together for the benefit of all of our people."
At his news conference today, Mr. Clinton said he intended to make the Commerce Department, which is responsible for promoting trade, economic growth and technological advancement, more important than it had been in recent years. "I am nominating someone who will make the Commerce Department a powerhouse," he said.
The naming of Mr. McLarty, chairman of Arkla Inc., a natural gas conglomerate, to the job of chief of staff, appeared to make the appointment of Mr. Clinton's current transition director, Warren M. Christopher, as Secretary of State more likely, aides said. Mr. Christopher has been expected to be named to either one of the jobs.
 
Half the Jobs Filled
 In the last three days Mr. Clinton has named roughly half of the members of his cabinet and senior staff. Thus far it is shaping up as a political Noah's ark, with veteran Washington and Wall Street insiders, newcomers from the left wing of the Democratic Party and the academic world, appointees placed both by his wife, Hillary, and the Vice President-elect, Al Gore, and now one old friend from Arkansas.
Mr. McLarty, 46 years old, was an important fund-raiser for the Clinton campaign. He has been serving on Mr. Clinton's transition board, but his friendship with Mr. Clinton dates back to kindergarten in Hope, where Mr. McLarty was born two months before Mr. Clinton. Mr. Clinton's mother, Virginia Kelley, has been quoted as saying that the two of them always introduce each other as "my oldest friend."
For the last few weeks Mr. Clinton has been asking members of his staff to research how the chief of staff's job has been handled in the past and how it might be reorganized to fit his own consultative form of decision-making. He made clear that he did not want an ideological warrior like John H. Sununu or an ambitious political animal like James A. Baker 3d, two of Mr. Bush's chiefs of staff. As Senator David Pryor of Arkansas put it after today's news conference: "I cannot imagine turning on 'Crossfire' and seeing Mack McLarty there. I just cannot imagine that." Mr. Sununu is the co-host of the highly combative television interview show.
 
Style of Management
 Mr. McLarty, who is a former state legislator and Democratic chairman of Arkansas, described his management style as collegial.
"As his chief of staff I will do whatever I can to help him organize, manage, facilitate and carry out the duties of the President of the United States," Mr. McLarty. "And as his friend I will always be straight with him and he knows that. Bill Clinton has my complete loyalty and trust -- always has and always will.
"I am by formal definition not a Washington insider. I have lived my life in the heartland but through my experience as a citizen and as a business person, I do know Washington fairly well and I've learned something about how to make organizations work."
Mr. McLarty said he would divest himself not only of all his Arkla stocks but also of all common stocks to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest in his future role.
 
Former Chiefs of Staff
 The chief of staff's job is a relatively new one, dating to 1946, when John R. Stedman, serving with the title of Presidential assistant, ran the White House for Harry S. Truman. Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson did without a chief of staff; Ronald Reagan had four, and for part of his Presidency divided the job into thirds.
While the chief of staff is usually described as a gatekeeper, deciding who and what comes before the President, chiefs of staff have also become important policy advisers. Many have boasted of doing Presidential dirty work: dismissing aides, confronting issues and people the President prefers to dodge, and taking the blame for Presidential mistakes.
In recent years they have usually, but not always, enjoyed great influence on the President, a tradition Mr. Clinton's appointee today is expected to observe.
"There is no case where a President has reached back to such an old childhood friend for his chief of staff," said Michael Beschloss, a historian of the Presidency. "What that would suggest is that this person will have a great deal of power, because of his unique relationship with Clinton, because of the weight of the position itself and because Clinton has made clear that his is going to be a White House-led Administration."
 
Surrounded by Strangers
 It also seems to suggest that Mr. Clinton is sensitive that in Washington he will be surrounded by people he does not know well. Much like Jimmy Carter, who named his old friend Bert Lance to be his budget director, Mr. Clinton is pulling in a man upon whose loyalty he apparently feels he can always count.
He is also choosing someone who is neither part of any of the factions of Mr. Clinton's entourage nor allied with any Democratic Party constituency.
Mr. Brown is a partner in the quintessential Washington corporate lobbying firm Patton, Boggs & Blow and has represented a number of foreign clients. One of the firm's partners, Tommy Boggs, the son of the late Louisiana Congressman Hale Boggs, was recently pictured on the cover of the National Journal magazine, a weekly on politics and government, under the caption: "Ready to Cash In on Clinton," with the firm's name alongside him.
Among Mr. Brown's clients have been Japanese companies seeking to buy American firms and Jean-Claude Duvalier, the former Haitian dictator who was run out of office for corruption.
Asked about his years as a lobbyist and how he will deal with that at his confirmation hearings, Mr. Brown said: "I will deal with it very forthrightly as you would expect me to. I have been a practicing lawyer for over 20 years and am proud of my skills as a lawyer and as an advocate."

HEADLINE: Puerto Rico's Coastline: New York's Back Door

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AGUADILLA, P.R., Dec. 8

 BODY:
For tens of thousands of Dominicans who dream of a better life in New York, the long road to Washington Heights or Queens begins here on the rugged, reef-lined shores of Puerto Rico's west coast.
With the help of smugglers, they cross the perilous Mona Passage in rickety wooden boats called yolas, arriving under cover of darkness in groups as large as 175, and are put ashore on isolated beaches. If they manage to evade the United States Border Patrol agents assigned to this corner of America's Caribbean frontier, they will make their way to San Juan. After earning enough money for plane fare, they will try to continue on to New York. 
 Separated from the Dominican Republic by only the Mona Passage, a 90-mile stretch of water, Puerto Rico is regarded by Dominicans as an increasingly attractive route to the American mainland.
 
Smugglers' Back Door
 Immigration officials say Dominicans have constituted the largest group of immigrants to New York in the last decade, numbering at least 500,000 in the metropolitan area. Many of those who have arrived in the United States illegally since the mid-1980's entered this convenient back door.
"I don't think there is a single town in my country that doesn't have someone who made it to New York by going through Puerto Rico," said a Dominican construction worker in San Juan who gave his name as Wilfredo Villegas and who said he arrived here nine months ago. "Everybody knows that this is the best way to get there."
But the route is dangerous and costly. Dominicans typically pay $500 each to smugglers to cross to Puerto Rico from the east coast of the Dominican Republic, and passengers often drown or are eaten by sharks when their small and overcrowded boats sink or when unscrupulous captains force them to jump into the seas just offshore.
 
Passing for Puerto Ricans
 "This time of year especially, the waters are really, really nasty," said Michael H. Wimberley, a Border Patrol senior agent here. "This is where the Atlantic Ocean and the Caribbean Sea collide, and 10-foot swells are common in winter."
Dominicans are willing to take that risk because Puerto Rico offers them unique entree to the United States. Puerto Rico's residents speak Spanish with a similar accent and have a similar culture and racial composition but enjoy the benefits of American citizenship. Many Dominicans feel they can pass themselves off as native Puerto Ricans, with the right to travel to the American mainland without a passport or the usual immigration formalities.
Estimates of how many Dominicans are living illegally at any one time on this Caribbean island of 3.6 million people vary widely, ranging from 100,000 upwards to 300,000. "We only know what we catch," said John A. Abriel, deputy district director of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service in San Juan. "Anything else is a guess."
 
A Growing Presence
 During the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, the immigration service and the Border Patrol expelled 4,093 Dominicans from Puerto Rico, compared with 1,958 in 1988. But immigration officials acknowledge that those figures represent only a fraction of the actual influx of Dominicans, and they do not include another 2,953 people whom Coast Guard vessels have intercepted in the Mona Passage this year.
It is becoming increasingly obvious that the Dominican presence in Puerto Rico is widespread. Some areas of San Juan, like Barrio Obrero and sections of Santurce, are now predominantly Dominican, as demonstrated by the proliferation of exchange houses that wire money back to relatives in Santo Domingo, merengue clubs and even offices of the Dominican Republic's major political parties.
Dominicans account for more than 90 percent of the illegal immigrants captured here. Immigration officials said their agents also caught "a sprinkling" of other Latin Americans, mostly Colombians or Ecuadorans, as well as Haitians and some Chinese, Pakistanis, Koreans and Indians.
 
Coordinating Efforts
 Since the Border Patrol began operating here in October 1987, it has more than tripled the number of agents assigned to Puerto Rico, from 10 to 33, and has worked out a system of cooperation with the Customs Service and Coast Guard, which supplies most of the information on boat movements that lead to interceptions. In addition, the immigration service has 17 field officers assigned to Puerto Rico, whose activities range from inspecting departing passengers at airports to raiding neighborhoods where illegal immigrants are believed to live.
But Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon argues that Washington needs to do even more. The Border Patrol presence here, he said, "is totally insufficient to limit the entry of Dominicans." In addition to a shortage of manpower, he said that not enough money has been devoted to halting an influx that Puerto Ricans regard with growing irritation. The Border Patrol is expecting delivery of a new 41-foot vessel next spring that will give it more mobility on the high seas, but while Congress approved expanding the number of the patrol's agents, it has refused to appropriate the necessary money.
 
Economic and Social Ills
 The Dominican presence on the island "has increased" in recent years and "is creating problems," especially in terms of employment, Governor Hernandez Colon said.
News commentators and community groups throughout Puerto Rico say Dominicans are also responsible for a disproportionate amount of crime and drug trafficking on the island, and many have called for harsher sanctions against "the usurpers." Last year legislation was introduced in the Puerto Rican legislature to fine the government of the Dominican Republic $1,000 for each illegal Dominican apprehended here, and organizations like the Committee Against Foreign Migration to Puerto Rico and Citizens United for Rapid Action have sprung up here and in New York.
 
'These Are Desperate People'
 But the immigrants and their defenders respond that the vast majority of Dominicans here are hard working, honest and willing to take jobs that local people do not want. "When you see a guy dangling from the 10th floor of a building, you don't even need to ask his origins," said Andres Moreta Damiron, the Dominican Consul General in San Juan. "You can be sure he is a Dominican."
Immigration officials said they, too, find the Dominicans to be unusually tenacious. Border Patrol agents report incidents in which Dominican immigrants have attacked them with knives, tried to seize their weapons, scaled barbed-wire fences or kicked out bus windows trying to avoid capture.
"These are desperate people," said Joseph B. Bennett, the Border Patrol chief in Puerto Rico. "After investing all their money in a dangerous boat ride, they don't want to give up."
Border Patrol officials estimate that at best they capture one of every five Dominican vessels that land here. "Our priority is to intercept them out there on the water," said Mr. Wimberley, the Border Patrol agent, "because once the yolas make landfall, the people disappear into the jungle or get picked up by vans or buses before we can get there."
 
Timing of Capture Crucial
 Once on Puerto Rican soil, the Dominicans do their best to blend in, mimicking a Puerto Rican accent and vocabulary and adopting local names for fruits and animals. In some cases, they are aided by criminal groups that steal blank Puerto Rican birth certificates from government offices here, or that print false documents of their own. The certificates are sold throughout the island and in the New York metropolitan area.
"It's easier to catch them up when they're fresh off the yola," said Manuel Flores, a Border Patrol agent from San Antonio who has been here for two years. "After six months, they learn to talk just like Puerto Ricans, and it gets much harder."
The smuggling organizations that bring Dominicans here are run by Dominicans and Puerto Ricans, both cooperatively and independently, and some promise to get their customers all the way to New York for prices as high as $3,000. Courts here have convicted 165 smugglers since 1988, but immigration and Border Patrol officers say the laws limit their ability to stop and interrogate suspected illegal immigrants on the street.
 
Avoiding Rights Violations
 "Since the people we are talking to are on U.S. soil, we have to be very careful about who we question and how we question them," Mr. Abriel said.
Mr. Bennett added: "You can't just stop someone on the basis of a sixth sense. You have to be able to articulate the reasons you think someone is here illegally, and that gives them quite a bit of an advantage over us."
For its part, the Dominican government argues there is little it can do to halt the flow. "We cannot prohibit the departure of our citizens," Mr. Moreta said. "We can only discourage those departures because they cause problems with our neighbors and contribute to the disintegration of the Dominican family.
"We do not have a naval force capable of patrolling all of the hundreds of miles of our coast. That would require the 6th Fleet, and I do not think the United States is going to help us that way."

HEADLINE: Chelsea Strikes Back at Influx of Pornographic Video Stores

BYLINE: By MARVINE HOWE

 BODY:
When a new adult video store put up its Welcome sign a few weeks ago on the corner of 22d Street and Seventh Avenue, amid sedate brownstone residences and near a public school, community reaction was swift and angry.
In the last few months, seven new pornographic video stores have appeared in Chelsea -- three opened by one owner -- making a total of 10 and angering residents and tradespeople, who fear their neighborhood will become "42d Street South." 
 Led by the newly formed Chelsea Action Coalition, residents have picketed the video stores, signed petitions, sent appeals to their community board and called for a meeting with landlords to persuade them to remove their unpopular tenants.
 
'An Invasion'
 "We believe in First Amendment protection, but what we object to is the overwhelming presence of these porn stores," said Susan Herman, a leader of the coalition, recently. "One is an eyesore. Ten are an invasion."
William H. Daly, director of the Mayor's Office of Midtown Enforcement, said that a similar expansion in the porn video trade is occurring in other parts of the city. In 1990, he said, there were only five adult video stores in midtown, but as of May, there were 20. Last year, in Chelsea -- from 14th to 29th Streets -- there were three.
To explain the proliferation of such stores, Mr. Daly noted that sex-related business are highly profitable. He suggested that the AIDS epidemic had stimulated a rise in "electronic voyeurism -- people who prefer not to participate in sex, but just watch." And, he said, landlords who have been stuck with vacant storefronts during the recession might be more willing to rent to anyone.
Many Chelsea residents say that the video stores will ruin their neighborhood, drive away business and make families with children uncomfortable.
The Chelsea Action Coalition, which has about 70 members, plans to lead a protest march on Dec. 20. to one of three video stores opened in Chelsea in the last two months by Ike Bova. Mr. Bova, a 26-year-old Israeli businessman who owns three other sex video stores in Manhattan, said this week that he wanted "to apologize to the community and make a new start."
In an interview, Mr. Bova said he would reopen his shop at 210 Seventh Avenue next week as a regular video store "with a very small porno section in the back." In addition, he said he would make 50 percent of the stock in his store at 725 Sixth Avenue standard videos, but would retain the adult videos at his other stores.
Michael Kramer, vice-chairman of Community Board 4, which covers the West Side from 14th Street to 59th Street, met with Mr. Bova but was not satisfied. He said it was clear that Mr. Bova did not understand that Chelsea was "a close-knit community, with strong family values."
The board has asked the City Council and the City Planning Department to regulate the stores. The requests include zoning sex-related businesses, limiting the concentration of such businesses, regulating exterior signs and windows, and requiring the notices barring anyone under 21 years old.
Lonnie Soury, a spokesman for the City Planning Department, said, "It's legally possible to regulate adult uses but very difficult because of constitutional limits." He said such regulations had been rejected by the Board of Estimate in 1977.
 
'New 42d Street'
 Chelsea merchants resent what they see as Sixth Avenue becoming "a new 42d Street." Marianna Vitale, who owns a pizzeria at 761 Sixth Avenue, said business was down and that it might be because of the influx of porn video stores.
"These video places don't realize people live here and have children, who are curious," Mrs. Vitale said.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Behind Appointments, Quiet Warring

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. Dec. 12

 BODY:
As President-elect Bill Clinton begins to fill out his Cabinet appointments, a spate of political knife fights have broken out behind the scenes between interest groups trying to cut their people into the new Administration, and their opponents out.
Already, this ideological combat appears to have dimmed the prospects of Lawrence H. Summers for a top economics job, and of John Young, a business executive who was once the leading candidate for Commerce Secretary. And it is endangering the chances of others. 
A flavor of this combat was given by one potential candidate, who said he received an anonymous phone call on Election Day on his home answering machine.
"You don't know me," the voice said, "but I know your work and I was flying on the shuttle between New York and Washington today, and someone sitting just behind me was doing business very loudly on the airplane phone and you were the subject."
 
Intense Competition
 The Clinton prospect, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the caller then revealed that the man behind him on the plane was organizing a meeting of interest groups to plot a blocking action against the appointment and signed off: "I thought you'd like to know."
This sort of competition for jobs takes place with every Administration but seems particularly intense this season. Not only are Democrats all pushing to the fore at once, having been out of power for 12 years; different ideological wings of the party that banded together to elect Mr. Clinton are now redrawing old battle lines. Moreover, interest groups have proliferated since the last time the Democrats took the Presidency, 16 years ago.
In the spirit of the times, The New Republic has taken to running a series of articles not on people who are getting jobs but on those the authors hope will not. The column, "Hit List," has featured Paula Stern, the trade lawyer and lobbyist; Mickey Kantor, who was Mr. Clinton's campaign manager; Representative Lee Hamilton of Indiana, and Robert Reich, who was named Friday to head the Department of Labor. The magazine's editor, Martin Peretz, says he is now receiving phone calls from Clinton hopefuls lobbying not to be mentioned.
One of the first people to find himself in the gun sights of ideological opponents was Joshua Muravchik, an American Enterprise Institute scholar who contributed to Mr. Clinton's human rights platform during the campaign. Mr. Muravchik is said to be a candidate for Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights.
But as a prominent member of the circle of "neo-conservative" thinkers during the cold war, Mr. Muravchik was at odds with some human rights groups, notably Americas Watch, over his emphasis on defeating communism as the primary goal of human-rights efforts. He had argued that the most important human rights issue was defeating communism, because nothing would liberate more people; his opponents argued that while the cold war was crucial, so were human rights abuses by America's allies.
 
Letter of Disapproval
 Several such groups sent a joint letter three weeks ago to Mr. Clinton's transition office titled "Criteria for Assistant Secretary for Human Rights," which those familiar with the issue say was aimed against conservatives like Mr. Muravchik.
The letter, drafted by a board member of Amnesty International and first published by the weekly journal Jewish Forward, said, among other things, that "The candidate must not have been previously associated with the defense of abusive governments" and must demonstrate "commitment to a single standard for fundamental human rights reporting."
Asked for his reaction, Mr. Muravchik said: "Between me and some of these people there was a lot of antagonistic history that had to do with the cold war. But the cold war is over. And I think that the whole significance of the Clinton campaign was that it got us beyond these old fights. If these people were looking forward instead of backward they would understand that we now have a lot in common: insuring that human rights remains on the front burner of American foreign policy."
Another increasingly active foreign policy interest group is the Jewish Peace Lobby, which is eager to make sure that no Clinton Middle East advisers are drawn from the ranks of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, a more conservative lobby known as Aipac. Aipac in recent years tilted in favor of the right-wing Likud Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and has been pushing its own favorite appointees.
The Jewish Peace Lobby sent Mr. Clinton's transition team a letter describing its criteria for the ideal Middle East advisers. "What he must avoid," the letter said, "are appointees closely associated with groups that blindly supported the Shamir government, and analysts who crossed over into advocacy for the positions of the Likud."
On a different front, The Washington Blade, a newspaper aimed at gay readers, broke the story two weeks ago that Senator Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, had asked two aides a decade ago to give up their high security jobs because of their homosexuality.
Senator Nunn confirmed the account, saying he had no choice because the two men were dealing with sensitive data and were deemed security risks by the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon. He said he now employs openly homosexual aides in nonsecurity related jobs.
But Tanya Domi, a former army captain now heading the civil rights project for the National Gay Lesbian Task Force, said the action should disqualify Senator Nunn for any Cabinet post. "Having Nunn in the cabinet would be a very difficult thing to swallow for the gay and lesbian community," she said.
Another potential Clinton choice that has fallen victim to the political mores of the 1990's is Mr. Summers, who is on leave from his post as chief economist of the World Bank. He was the early favorite to be Mr. Clinton's Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers.
Several environmental groups, led by the Worldwatch Institute, sent letters to Vice President-elect Al Gore, noting that Mr. Summers once wrote that it might be more economically efficient for heavily polluting industries to move their factories from the industrialized world to developing countries, where there is less concern about such matters.
Mr. Summers says this thought was taken out of context from a draft document in which he was simply musing aloud about different alternatives. Nevertheless, a few days later he was out of the running for that job.
 
Attack on Educator
 The conservatives are in this game, too. They made a pre-emptive strike last week against Johnnetta Cole, the president of Spelman College, the black women's college, who heads the Clinton transition group dealing with education, arts, labor and humanities. The national conservative weekly Human Events carried an article headlined "Clinton Chooses Extremist" that said Ms. Cole "has been actively involved in support of Communist dictatorships in Cuba and Grenada."
Ms. Cole referred all inquiries to Dee Dee Myers, Mr. Clinton's spokeswoman, who said: "She is a lifelong academic, a member of the board of Coca-Cola and a respected member of her community. These charges are silly."
Republicans and liberal Democrats also seem to have helped kill the candidacy of Mr. Young, the president of Hewlett Packard, who was an early Clinton favorite to lead the Commerce Department. Hewlett Packard technology was found at Iraqi military installations after the Persian Gulf war. While the sales were legal and approved by the Commerce Department, anti-arms export groups were incensed at the prospect of Mr. Young's running the Commerce Department.
On Dec. 4, Mr. Young took himself out of the running for a job, saying it "might create the appearance of a conflict of interest because of my financial holdings."

HEADLINE: Eagleburger Says U.S. Now Wants Ban on Serbian Flights Enforced

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM, Dec. 12

 BODY:
In a stiffening of the Bush Administration's position on the war in the Balkans, Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said today that the United States would support a United Nations resolution to enforce the ban on Serbian flights over Bosnia and Herzegovina.
He also said the Administration was rethinking its opposition to lifting a United Nations arms embargo that has the effect of benefitting the well-armed Serbian forces. 
 Mr. Eagleburger's statements came a day after President-elect Bill Clinton, speaking of President Bush's policy, may have nudged the Administration toward a new resolution enforcing the flight ban. Mr. Eagleburger's remarks reflected an apparent desire within the Bush Administration to leave office having done what it could to ease the crisis in the war-torn remnants of Yugoslavia.
Speaking to reporters en route to Stockholm, where he will meet with European foreign ministers to discuss the Balkan crisis and other issues, Mr. Eagleburger explained why the United States had changed its position. He cited the deterioration of the situation on the ground in Bosnia and added that, as in Somalia, the United States could not "simply ignore it and leave it to the next Administration."
The Administration, he added, had to deal with the crisis in the Balkans so it would be "containable and manageable."
 
'History Doesn't Stop'
 "We cannot obviously make commitments that tie down a new Administration," Mr. Eagleburger said. "On the other hand, history doesn't stop between now and the 20th of January."
At a news conference in Little Rock, Ark., on Friday, Mr. Clinton said the United States and its allies should do what it takes, apparently including air strikes but not the deployment of ground troops, to enforce the flight ban. During the election campaign, Mr. Clinton also said he would consider recommending an international call to end the arms embargo.
[Asked about his Friday remarks at another news conference on Saturday, Mr. Clinton said he had not criticized the Bush Administration policy. "I did not question the Administration's policy," he said. "I pointed out that the reason this no-fly zone had not been enforced in the past is not because the Bush Administration had not been willing to, but because of the concerns the French and the British had about putting their soldiers at greater risk because they are on the ground in Bosnia and we are not."]
Mr. Eagleburger acknowledged that there was still opposition within the Administration to enforcing the ban on Serbian flights as well as resistance by both the French and British Governments, which are concerned that the safety of the troops they have committed to the United Nations peacekeeping force in Bosnia could be jeopardized.
"We would like to see an enforcement resolution passed," he said, adding that he would discuss the issue at meetings in Stockholm, Geneva and Brussels next week. But he added, "I am not going to go in there with a baseball bat and say we are now going to go for an enforcement resolution."
 
Serbs Violate Ban
 The Serbs routinely violate the ban on flights and have flown both warplanes and helicopters more than 200 times since it was imposed in the fall. There are reports from United Nations military observers that Serbs have used helicopters in combat missions against targets on the ground in recent weeks, but no independent confirmation from United States intelligence officials.
Until now, the Bush Administration has remained firmly opposed to lifting the United Nations arms embargo in the Balkans, arguing that any move to allow arms to flow to either side would only increase the level of violence and prolong the fighting. But in recent days the State Department has drafted a memorandum that argues both sides of the issues, senior Administration officials said.
The United States, Mr. Eagleburger said, is prepared "to examine with others whether it would be wise to move away from the solid position we have all taken of a flat arms embargo with regard to the Bosnian Muslims."
