HEADLINE: Juggling Jobs and the Deficit: Executives Doubtful

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Many of America's senior executives say job creation is the Government's most important immediate task and the budget deficit the nation's most important economic problem. But foreshadowing what is almost certain to be a major economic conflict of Bill Clinton's Presidency, the executives say that the President-elect will not be able to address those two concerns simultaneously.
Those views, on the eve of Mr. Clinton's economic summit in Little Rock, Ark., this week, surfaced in a New York Times/CBS News poll of 499 senior executives in early December and in follow-up interviews with a dozen of them. Both the poll results and the interviews revealed some enthusiasm for the new President. While 53 percent of the executives voted for George Bush, a whopping 71 percent said the President had not displayed as much concern for the economy as Clinton had during the campaign. And 81 percent said the Clinton election has increased consumer confidence and spending. 
 "Clinton will speed up the economy initially because he has a lot of people feeling good," said John R. Albers, chairman of the Dr Pepper-Seven Up Companies, the Dallas-based concern that makes the concentrate for the two soft drinks. "A lot of people, including myself, would have preferred Bush as a proactive President, but he was not. Clinton is satisfactory, he is proactive, and we will see what happens."
 
'Mutually Exclusive Goals'
 But faulting Mr. Bush is one thing and voting for Mr. Clinton -- only 21 percent of the executives did -- or endorsing his proposals is another. The executives stressed the importance of job creation, with 63 percent calling it the more important immediate task. Thirty-nine percent labeled the budget deficit as the nation's most important economic problem. Fifty-three percent, in fact, opposed increasing the deficit next year to create jobs and stimulate the economy through public-works spending.
John Watson, chairman of the Horizon Potash Corporation, which has a potash mine in New Mexico, said: "The key issue is, Can you create the jobs and control the deficit? And the answer is that these are mutually exclusive goals. The only way the Government can do it is to create jobs through public-works projects, and that is wasteful spending. A Democratic President and Congress will spend; that is a certainty. But they cannot tax people enough to cover their spending."
No theme is likely to be more hotly debated during the early months of the Clinton presidency than the tradeoff between public spending and the deficit. The executives, as well as the Federal Reserve, argue that deficit spending on highways, fiber-optic networks, high-speed trains and the like damages the economy over the long run by driving up the inflation rate and with it, interest rates. Seventy-four percent of the executives polled said they expect the inflation rate to rise during the Clinton years.
Top Federal Reserve officials have recently asserted that the economy has in fact surged since October, but the rapid growth, they say, will soon slow. And a slowly growing economy is preferable, they say, even if slow growth limits job creation.
Mr. Clinton has not come down clearly on either side of the tradeoff between public spending and the deficit. He has mainly argued that his proposal for $20 billion a year in additional public-works spending -- needed not only to help re-employ idle Americans but also to rebuild the nation's infrastructure -- will be self-financing, partly through new tax revenues. But 62 percent of the 499 executives said Mr. Clinton would not be able to create jobs and reduce the deficit in the next four years, and 58 percent added that he is unlikely to reduce the deficit.
 
'A Leap of Faith'
 What's more, most of those in the follow-up interviews rejected a key assumption of the Clinton camp -- that public spending, if properly directed, helps Americans and thus adds to the national wealth.
"Intuitively, a better railroad system should have some benefit by moving people and goods more efficiently," said Robert Harris, senior vice president of the Fidelity Mutual Life Insurance Company of Radnor, Pa. "But I am fearful that Mr. Clinton will revert to the spending programs that have been in place with Democrats before, without figuring out which are productivity-improving and which are wasteful."
Not everyone agreed. Roger W. Johnson, chairman of the Western Digital Corporation of Irvine, Calif., insisted that Mr. Clinton can break a pattern of wasteful Government spending. "There are prudent reductions in defense and health care costs that can be made," said Mr. Johnson, who campaigned for Mr. Clinton and voted for him. "This will not reduce the money spent, but it means that money badly spent can now be spent by the Government on more productive things. This has not been the history of our Government. It requires a leap of faith, and the American people took that leap in electing Bill Clinton."
The 499 executives represent a cross-section of American industry, from multibillion-dollar corporations to small family concerns. Optimistically, 60 percent of them said the economy was getting better, while 34 percent said it was neither improving nor deteriorating. That response compares with a more pessimistic view held in late February, when 47 percent of 490 executives polled found the economy getting better and 44 percent said it was staying the same.
 
'Our Best Year Ever'
 Seventy-nine percent of the executives said their own companies had been doing well lately, often better than their surrounding communities. For example, Charles Updegraff, president of the Citizens Trust Company in Coudersport, Pa., said, "We are having our best year ever."
He noted that profits were up because the interest rates that Citizens Trust charges for the mortgages and consumer loans in which it specializes are so much higher than the rates paid for deposits. But loan demand remains weak. "Consumers have so much debt that they don't qualify for more," Mr. Updegraff said.
The executives polled in early December were more sanguine than the general public. Only 29 percent of all American adults say the economy is getting better, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll last week.
"I travel to our branches a lot, and our customers tell me that the country is in a big recession, but they are doing better," said Benjamin F. Edwards, chairman of A. G. Edwards Inc., a stock brokerage firm based in St. Louis. "I thought the economy was getting better in March, and I still think so."
Thirty-seven percent of the executives participating in the latest poll, which was conducted by telephone from Dec. 1 to Dec. 9 -- before President Clinton announced his new economic team -- said they planned to increase employment over the next year, while 54 percent said they planned no changes. Those percentages were virtually the same as those in the late February poll, and since then the number of Americans holding jobs has hardly changed. Both polls had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 6 percentage points.
A few executives interviewed, including Mr. Edwards, have hired workers in recent weeks, but most said they had either frozen hiring or shrunk their staffs in recent years. They achieved this mainly through automation or other efficiencies so they could maintain production with fewer workers and thus cut costs and compete more effectively.
 
The Main Message
 But the executives' main message for Mr. Clinton's economic conference tomorrow, expressed most clearly in the follow-up interviews, appeared to be this: Although civilian jobs have increased only 1 million during the Bush Presidency, or one-tenth of 1 percent, job creation should nevertheless be mostly the domain of the private sector, and Mr. Clinton's economic policies should be channeled to encourage the private sector, mainly through tax incentives.
Ninety-two percent of the executives polled, for example, favored a tax credit that would reduce the cost of new investments in factories and machinery. This, however, is not necessarily the proposal put forth by Mr. Clinton, who wants to reward mainly the investment that results in expansion and more jobs. Only 62 percent of executives said that an investment tax credit, whatever the form, would actually prompt them to invest.
"Clinton does not create jobs; private business does," said Mr. Albers of Dr Pepper-Seven Up. "He can only do this through public spending, which runs up the deficit and is wasteful." But Mr. Albers also said that the private sector was still cutting costs, largely through labor cutbacks, and that until that process is completed job creation in the private sector would be minimal. His own companies, for example, are now hiring, but only after having reduced the work force from 1,200 in the late 1980's to 980 people today.
Regarding taxes, the executives had some strong views. Apart from favoring an investment tax credit, 67 percent of them endorsed higher taxes on foreign companies operating in the United States, a Clinton proposal. By a narrow margin they opposed another Clinton plan: higher taxes on family incomes exceeding $200,000. The verdict was 51 percent to 48 percent.
Fifty-nine percent of the executives favored a Clinton proposal to cut the taxes paid by middle-class families, with most of the support coming from senior executives at small companies.
Seventy-seven percent of the executives expect expect retail sales during the Christmas season to be better than last year, a prediction that appears to be holding up in the early returns from retailers.
And many executives were more optimistic than they had been in February about stock prices. In February, the executives expected the Dow Jones industrial average to rise to 3,388 by the end of this month -- an expectation that right now is just short of being reached, at 3,304. Now they expect the Dow to rise to 3,426 by December 1993.
That is not much of an increase. But then Arnold M. Nemirow, chief executive of the Wausau Paper Mills Company in Wausau, Wis., says the economy is not yet all that strong, either. "We have not recovered yet," he said. "There are just beginning signs. We need to run with this recovery for a year to see what happens."
 
 
 
HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
 The New York Times/CBS News Poll of American business executives is based on interviews with 499 senior executives at companies throughout the United States, interviewed by telephone from Dec. 1 to Dec. 9.
The sample of companies and executives called was provided by Dun and Bradstreet Information Services and was randomly drawn from those listed in its nationwide data base of private and publicly owned companies.
Companies with $5 million or more in annual revenues were eligible for the survey. Within each company one executive at a senior level was interviewed. Titles eligible for the poll included owner, partner, chief executive, chairman, president, executive vice president and senior vice president, with first opportunity for an interview given to the most senior official.
The completed sample included 245 interviews in companies with $5 million to $99 million in annual revenue, 120 interviews in companies with $100 million to $499 million, and 134 interviews in companies with $500 million or more. The completed sample was then weighted by revenue size to reflect the actual distribution of all listed companies in the country because small companies predominate.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, results based on such samples will differ by no more than six percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out senior executives at all listed companies in the country with annual revenues of $5 million or more.
The potential sampling error for smaller sub-groups is larger. For example, for the biggest companies, those with $500 million or more in annual revenue, it is plus or minus nine percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey can introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
In Mayor's Race, Gay Vote Is Appealing

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The raucous debate over whether New York City's schools should teach first graders to respect homosexuals, and how they might do so, has probably obscured other and clearer signs of the growing political power of the city's gay voters.
Both Mayor David N. Dinkins and his all-but-certain Republican challenger, Rudolph W. Giuliani, have gone out of their way to appeal for the votes of gay New Yorkers. 
 The Mayor tried to demonstrate his commitment last week by joining the national debate over a constitutional amendment approved by Colorado voters last month that overturns laws prohibiting discrimination against homosexuals. Mr. Dinkins had already said that in response to the amendment he would not attend a meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors planned for next June in Colorado Springs. Last week, he turned up his efforts, writing a letter to the mayors' group asking it to relocate the meeting outside Colorado. (He mentioned that New York might make a nice alternative.)
While the Mayor declined to agree to an economic boycott, in which the city would refrain from buying goods and services, he did impose a ban on travel by city employees to Colorado. The ban, of course, is largely symbolic, since city officials don't exactly flock to the Rocky Mountain State on municipal business.
Mr. Giuliani is also acutely aware of the importance of symbolism when it comes to attracting New York's rainbow of voters. The former Federal prosecutor got together two weeks ago with four Republican City Council members to endorse a proposed city bill that would enable victims of bias attacks, including homosexuals, to seek civil damages of as much as $100,000 from their attackers through the city's Human Rights Commission.
 
Little Rock Talk
 Several people from the New York metropolitan area have figured in the discussions over the emerging shape of the Clinton Administration. Dennis Rivera, the head of Local 1199 of the hospital workers' union, will be among those invited to Little Rock tomorrow for the President-elect's economic summit. Mr. Rivera, a progressive Democrat, is one of only four national labor leaders invited to participate, according to an aide.
Some local officials have also been rumored to be under consideration for cabinet posts and other jobs in the new Administration. The city's Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez has ruminated publicly about the honor of national service.
In Hartford, there was talk that some old Washington friends of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. were lobbying on his behalf for a Federal post. Like Mr. Fernandez, the Governor did nothing to discourage the speculation.

HEADLINE: THE STORM'S HAVOC: The Costs;
Calculating a Storm's Costs: Rebuilding Is Just One Factor

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
As a brutal wintery storm continued its assault on the metropolitan region yesterday, retailers and public officials began assessing the financial costs, ranging from wind and water damage to thousands of homes and businesses to a setback on what had been brisk holiday sales. While the total impact on the region was impossible to measure, large losses seem certain on several levels of its economy. For large retailers in all three states, the storm all but obliterated sales for at least 24 hours, with empty department stores in New York City and malls closing in surrounding areas. By yesterday, customers were returning and stores were reopening in much of the region, but malls in Connecticut reported a drop-off in the number of patrons because of the snow that had started falling.
Glen Wielgus, marketing manager for the South Street Seaport, said that the storm came at "a very unfortunate time."
 
Immense Costs of Cleanup
 "It's particularly unfortunate at the time between Thanksgiving and Christmas," he said. "For most major retailers, this time can be upwards of 20 percent of annual sales. So to lose one busy, one good Christmas Day is very unfortunate.
"It was definitely a blow, but it was not a major blow," he said. 
 Stephen Byron, a manager of the Monmouth Mall, with 160 stores in Monmouth, N.J., agreed. "If this was a hurricane and we sustained damage that closed us for a week, it would have been a different story."
In beachfront communities throughout New York and New Jersey, residents and businesses feared a far greater problem than a short-term loss of business: an expensive and prolonged effort to repair severely eroded beaches and thousands of watefront homes.
Even before the storm had subsided, officials in all three states had said the cost for cleanup and repair of tunnels, bridges, roads, breakwaters, sea walls, and eroded beaches would be immense.
"One lost day is not going to wipe us out, but this will be expensive," said Stanley Brezenoff, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, an agency that was, perhaps more than any other, at the economic eye of the storm.
It was forced to close La Guardia Airport from Friday until midday yesterday, canceling 400 flights. It closed the New Jersey PATH system, affecting 50,000 riders, and the system's flooded train tunnels were still being pumped out yesterday. Two of its major bridges, the Outerbridge Crossing and the Goethals bridge, reopened yesterday after being closed on Friday.
'Every available body we have is either on call or out there working," Mr. Brezenoff said yesterday afternoon. "I'll tabulate the cost later."
"It is safe to say that the damage is worse on the New Jersey shore than anything we've had in years," said Jon Shure, a spokesman for Gov. Jim Florio.
He said it will take at least until tomorrow to tabulate even preliminary estimates of damage.
In a host of ocean-front communities along the Jersey Shore, the South Shore of Long Island, Brooklyn, the Bronx, Westchester and Connecticut, homeowners were just beginning to assess the damage.
"I've been here 30-odd years, and this is the worst," said Ted Hommel, whose home in Long Beach, on the south shore of Long Island, was flooded yesterday. His heat and telephones were out, and his yard was strewn with the tangled flotsam of splintered docks and Styrofoam.
Damage to many homes was even more severe.
"There were some that the ocean just blew through, in the back and out the front," said Mary Lou Murphy, a spokeswoman for the Ocean County Office of Emergency Management in New Jersey.
In ways that were scattered and sometimes perverse, there were glimmers of a silver lining in the storm. With thousands of commuters stranded in New York City on Friday night, hotels reported crushing demand for rooms, business was brisk at restaurants, and bars were packed wall-to-wall with unfamiliar patrons.
Restaurant and theater managers in the Theater District of Manhattan said the surge in business seemed to carry over to yesterday.
Video stores were also meccas for customers. On Friday, "there were twice as many people in here, maybe three times as many as normal," said Karim Baez, manager of the Blockbuster Video store at Eighth Avenue and 17th Street in Manhattan. The reason: legions of people in his neighborhood, as throughout the region, simply stayed home when the storm began gaining force.
Other merchants said they benefitted by providing shelter from the storm to commuters with nowhere else to go.
"One woman said at least the mall was warm, and she could get her kids something to eat," said Daryl Hasko, marketing manager of the Seaview Square Mall, just west of Asbury Park, New Jersey. "While she was here, she decided to do some Christmas shopping."
But those finding reason for solace in the storm were far outnumbered by those who said the storm's legacy would be a huge costs to businesses, homeowners, insurance companies and taxpayers.
"It's worse than any hurricane we've had," said Mary Cavanaugh of Long Beach as she surveyed the severe damage to her waterfront deck yesterday. Not far away, a stray canoe was surging in the waves and trapped between the pilings of what had been her deck.
With a laugh , she added, "At least I got a new boat out of it."
At Westfarms Mall in West Hartford, the number of shoppers on Friday was about normal, but it dropped yesterday as snows that missed central Connecticut in the first leg of the storm began falling in earnest, according to Dianne Noth, the mall's general manager. At the Danbury Fair Mall, shoppers scared away by Friday's severe weather apparently stayed scared yesterday.
"Yesterday was a disaster," said Leo Rogoza, the assistant general manager at the mall. "Today is even worse." Mr. Rogoza said the mall would typically attract 25,000 or more shoppers on a pre-Christmas Saturday. He estimated that only several hundred shoppers had made it into the 238-store center by late morning.
Many companies and stores that closed Friday reopened yesterday, only to find their own basements or showrooms damaged by floodwaters and wind.
"There is no one down here," said Joseph Caraballo, manager of the Fulton Market Retail Fish store at the South Street Seaport.
His store, like others on the building's lower floor, were flooded on Friday, and clean-up efforts were in high gear yesterday.
"It's killing us," Mr. Caraballo said. "Things were already bad because of the economy, and we didn't need this storm.

HEADLINE: MISSION TO SOMALIA;
Seared by Faces of Need, Americans Say, 'How Could We Not Do This?'

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BROOKVILLE, Ind., Dec. 9
<

 BODY:
Huddled against the cold outside the Franklin County Agricultural Co-Op, his 18-wheeler loaded with pig innards, Todd Schuppert doesn't consider himself an expert on foreign affairs, but he knows exactly what he thinks about the decision to send American troops to Somalia.
"I think it's a pretty doggone good idea," said Mr. Schuppert, a 31-year-old truck driver from Pekin, Ind. "You just have to turn on a television to see that those people need help, and no one else is going to help them but us." 
 Americans may have spent an endless political year stressing the primacy of domestic concerns over international ones. But interviews this week from a military base in Alabama to the "American Gothic" towns of Indiana, from an embattled housing project in Atlanta to a festive downtown mall in Cincinnati, indicate that the desperate images of starvation halfway across the world have produced a moral clarity for people like few issues in recent years.
There are dissenters, and many people seem aware that time could make the issues more complicated than they seem now. But like a shadow Christmas, never quite absent from the joyous one unfolding at home, the hellish images from the Horn of Africa have left most Americans with a feeling that action is appropriate if only because inaction is unthinkable. A New York Times/CBS News poll taken Dec. 7-9 found that 81 percent of those polled favored sending American troops to Somalia.
 
Disquiet Beneath Compassion
 Thus, as he and his 3-year-old grandson, Matthew, admired a towering Christmas tree and model railroad exhibit at a shopping plaza in downtown Cincinnati, Lee Hoskins came back three times in a 10-minute talk to the same thought.
"You see those starving kids on TV," said Mr. Hoskins, a 59-year-old route salesman for a dairy company, who lives just across the Ohio River in Villa Hills, Ky. "And you think, 'How could we not do this?' "
Of course, some people see the issues as more complicated, compounded by questions of race, politics and economics. Some see a quintessentially American naivete in the idea that United States military action can be safe, brief and successful. Others see something more troubling than comforting in the way television has made the world's suffering as inescapable as a four-alarm fire next door.
But in a season suffused with indelible imagery, Americans clearly see timeless images of themselves -- more Jimmy Stewart than John Wayne -- in the military action under way in Somalia.
 
New Wave of Idealism
 Paul L. Simon, a history professor at Xavier University in Cincinnati, said he thought the Somalia mission could be more protracted and "stickier and nastier" than many people think. He said changes in the post-cold war world should make Americans rethink their role as an international Lone Ranger, whether in humanitarian operations or bellicose ones. And the nation's inaction in the equally horrific but far less manageable nightmare in the former Yugoslavia underscores the fact that practical considerations as well as humanitarian ones are involved.
But Professor Simon said the Somali operation and the initial reaction to it resonated with the nation's historic sense of itself. "Here again we have another one of those waves of American idealism, of Woodrow Wilson and others," he said. "Make the world safe for democracy, make the world safe, spread democratic principles, spread kindness in this holiday season. That's us, that's what we do."
Of course, in a time of economic distress at home, some people are looking askance at another enormous American effort to send help elsewhere. The Times/CBS News poll found that 48 percent of the 1,333 respondents said the troops should stay only so long as it takes to set up supply lines, while 44 percent said they should stay as long as it takes to make sure Somalia remains peaceful. Forty-two percent of those polled said they were "very concerned" the United States could become involved in a civil war there. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
"I'm not pleased with it," said Pam Suver, 40-years old, who owns a straw brokering and baling business in Circleville, Ohio. "I don't think we know what we're getting into. There are ways we can help, but I don't think we should be sending our troops there."
 
Problems Right Here
 Aliton Murphy, the 38-year-old manager of the agricultural co-op's store here in this county seat and farming town of 2,500 people where the parking meters downtown still take pennies, worries that the operation is another case of the United States taking on a role other nations should play. He said the Government should set a deadline of early January for other nations to take over the operation and should leave then, regardless.
"Americans are a caring and a giving people, but we shouldn't be taking all the risk," he said. "We need to get others, particularly African nations, involved and then pack our bags and get out of Dodge. You can only ride a free horse for so long."
The most often-cited reason for opposing the operation is that the United States has enormous problems of its own it should be addressing.
"People here need help," said a 30-year-old deliveryman from Cincinnati who would give his name only as Coy. "It's like me helping you get your car fixed when mine doesn't work. I don't feed your kids when mine are hungry. We have too many problems of our own."
 
More Holidays Far Away
 Seldom, if ever, have the miseries of a people half the world away been as omnipresent as they were in the United States this week. In the otherworldly face of a starving Somali child staring out from the cover of Time magazine and the skeletal bodies waiting for food on TV screens, Somalia's agony seemed to be everywhere.
In the PX of the United States Army Aviation Center at Fort Rucker near Enterprise, Ala., a half dozen televisions turned to CNN's Headline News beamed out the pictures from Somalia.
Many of those looking on had a particular interest, like Specialist 4 Glen Williams, 24 years old, and Pfc. Sara Smith, 20 years old, both water sanitation specialists with the United States Army Aviation Medical Center here. Fort Rucker, so far, has not been a part of the military buildup.
With memories of the December buildup before the Persian Gulf war so fresh, many military people shudder at the thought of another holiday-season military action.
"I just hate to have another Christmas war," said Private Smith. "It's pretty rough."
 
Rebuke to Budget Cutters
 But she and Specialist Williams see the operation in Somalia as both an important use of the American military and a telling warning against too rapid a reduction in the nation's forces.
Kris Reese, a 29-year-old warrant officer candidate training to be a helicopter pilot, was one of the few people interviewed at Fort Rucker who voiced strong reservations about the Somalia mission. He worried that it could set a burdensome precedent and that the situation there was less manageable than people expect.
"We have a mission, and we have to carry it out, but I have very mixed feelings about it," he said. "For me, the question is who's the enemy? Are people going to be smiling at you one minute and then shooting at you the next? You don't know."
More common was a combination of post-gulf war pride and a sense the Somalia mission, unlike intervention in Bosnia, was both worthwhile and manageable. Several saw it as a harbinger of the changing role the military can play in a post-cold war world.
 
Not Slaughtering, but Saving
 "There are a lot of things the military can do beyond combat," said Specialist 4 Patrick Gross, a 22-year-old soldier from Chicago. "I think this shows a better side of the military than just a force that's good at slaughtering people. The military is more than trained commando killers. It can also be a force for good."
To some people, particularly some blacks, the question is not whether the United States should go in, but why it didn't do it sooner.
"I think we should have moved faster," said Joseph Arrington, a 45-year-old mail carrier and retired Army sergeant-major from Enterprise. "I'm retired military and a whole-hearted flag waver, so I hate to read racist overtones into things, but it's like with the Haitians, we move slower when people of color are involved."
Most Americans were less critical. In the latest Times/CBS News poll 73 percent of the respondents approved of the way President Bush has been handling the situation in Somalia. Mr. Bush's overall job rating stood at 50 percent approval; that was up from 37 percent approval just before Election Day, and was the highest level measured for Mr. Bush in any Times/CBS News poll taken during 1992.
For many of the black poor, like the residents of the East Lake Meadows housing project in Atlanta, a forlorn vista of boarded-up buildings where the frigid wind whips the wash hanging out, intervention was an easy decision.
"As an ex-soldier, I think they're doing the right thing," said Luther J. Wells, who was one of the first black soldiers called to duty in World War II. "I would volunteer today if I could."
 
TV's Bully Pulpit
 While doubts sometimes surface, more common is an almost awestruck sense of the ways in which the crisis in Somalia highlights an ever smaller, more intimate world. To some, there is something troubling in television's ability to set a national agenda simply by the force of the images beamed into America's living rooms.
"I really believe this is our fourth branch of government," said Wasif F. Abboushi, a political science professor at the University of Cincinnati. "We can control Congress, the President, we can yell and scream, but we haven't devised a way to hold the media accountable to the people."
But for many, this is a case where television has been a force for good, appealing to the world's conscience.
"I really don't think this has anything to do with race or religion," said Kathy Johanneman, 51 years old, who was shopping in Cincinnati. "There's a lot of hatred in the world, a lot of prejudice, but this is the kind of thing that reminds you how the world keeps getting smaller and closer every day. We can't afford not to help each other anymore."
 
Parable for the Season
 There are already signs the operation may become more complicated than people expect, and the moral certainty of December could easily become the political quagmire of February. But for many people Somalia has become a Christmas-season parable, making it difficult to look at the commercial icongraphy of plenty -- golden arches, all-you-can-eat steak joints and manic Big Boys bearing overstuffed burgers -- without thinking twice.
If there's a bottom to American life, Kenneth Moss lives there. For two months he's been homeless and living on a vacant lot in southeast Atlanta. He keeps warm by a roaring fire in an industrial barrel, blocked from the wind by two pieces of plywood, and begs for spare change for food. But even here, the case for intervention in Somalia seems obvious.
"Even though we've got people starving here, I feel it's necessary for us to go," he said. "I'll survive. But you've got kids starving to death over there."

HEADLINE: Jaruzelski Faces Accusers, or Is It Vice Versa?

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the last Communist leader of Poland, sits impassively at the head of a long wooden table in Parliament. Arrayed behind him are the balding and gray-haired Communists who, on Dec. 13, 1981, crushed the Solidarity movement with a show of force they called martial law.
It is a cathartic scene, one that 11 yeas ago could have been no more than a fantasy to Solidarity leaders: General Jaruzelski and his aides summoned to account for themselves by a democratically elected Parliament. 
 But the reality, unfolding in a series of hearings this fall, has proved far less emotionally satisfying for a country that has been more reluctant than its neighbors to pursue the old Government.
Thus far, the committee's grand hopes for ferreting out the truth about martial law from Polish and Soviet archives have proved unavailing.
Meanwhile, General Jaruzelski has been using the inquiry as his own bully pulpit, restating that he was a patriot who saved Poland from civil conflict or Soviet intervention.
Edward Rzepka, the lawyer who is chairman of the Commission on Constitutional Responsibility, said: "We're in an extremely difficult situation. We must operate within the limits of the law. We can do nothing that would be seen as restricting the rights of the defendants."
One focus has been on such arcane questions as whether the Constitution permitted the imposition of martial law while Parliament was in session.
The legalistic tone has infuriated the political leaders who feel that Poland has dragged its feet in settling accounts with the Communists.
But the public seems decidedly unmoved. In one recent survey, a majority agreed that General Jaruzelski was a patriot and that Ryszard Kuklinski, the Polish Army officer who disclosed the martial law plans to American intelligence in 1980, was a traitor.
Initially, the case was based on a section of the Polish code relating to abuse of office that carries a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison.
When the defendants contested this statute, the commission said it would consider charges of treason under a law that makes it a crime to take away Poland's independence or overthrow the "social-economic system." Penalties range from a minimum of five years in prison to execution.
Solidarity, Eastern Europe's first free trade union, born in 1980, challenged the Communists' monopoly on power.
By December 1980, the Soviets were poised to invade Poland, and American intelligence detected troop movements on the border. A stern warning from President Carter, already a lame duck, dissuaded Moscow.
The following year, General Jaruzelski became Communist Party chief in Poland. In his book "Martial Law: Why," he recounts hints from Moscow that an invasion was imminent in December 1981.
Recently released Soviet documents suggest that, in fact, Moscow never had any intention of invading Poland in 1981. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet leader, has confirmed this fact in recent interviews, but he added that General Jaruzelski had no way of knowing it.
Arguments about martial law quickly become cerebral. Did the Soviets bluff General Jaruzelski and his Government into the crackdown? Or are the Communists creating after-the-fact justifications for what amounted to a coup d'etat?
Many Poles see a basic question of fairness in charges against the Communists who played a role in their own demise.
Under the leadership of General Jaruzelski, Poland's Communists were the first in Eastern Europe to relinquish power, and they did so through "round table" negotiations in 1989. The general remained as President, resigning in 1991.
In his testimony, General Jaruzelski betrayed no anger. At one point, though, he reminded the committee of his role in smoothing Poland's transition to democracy. "The round table did not drop out of heaven," he said, looking Mr. Rzepka squarely in the eye.

HEADLINE: Trenton Reports Tax Revenues Are Up Slightly From Last Year

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
New Jersey tax revenues are up slightly, even though the state reduced its sales tax this year, the state treasurer, Samuel F. Crane, reports.
The state revenues were bolstered by higher-than-expected income tax collections, reflecting money received by Nov. 30. 
 While Mr. Crane said this "suggests an increase in economic activity," he added a caution.
"It would be premature to attach too much significance to these collections," Mr. Crane said. "I am encouraged by the income tax collections, but we need to see sustained growth over a number of months before we can get optimistic about economic recovery."
In total, state revenues were up by 0.4 percent. The income-tax revenues collected from July 1 to Nov. 30 are up by 10.9 percent.
"To me, that indicates more employment," said State Senator Robert E. Littell, chairman of the Senate budget committee. "Our unemployment is still high, but there's also been an increase in employment."
The sales tax, which was reduced from 7 percent to 6 percent on July 1 by the Republican-controlled Legislature, produced about $140 million less than last year over the first four months of the fiscal year. The figures for sales tax released Friday are through Oct. 31 because these collections lag by one month.
Projected over the year, the sales tax would be down by about $420 million -- less than the $608 million shortfall predicted by the Florio administration earlier this year.
Mr. Crane said the sales-tax revenues were "on target" with his predictions, noting that the Christmas retail season -- not included in this report -- represents a large share of that tax. The January and February revenue reports will include Christmas season sales, he said.
Corporation taxes are also up by 3.5 percent for the first five months of the fiscal year.
Mr. Littell said he thought the state revenue picture would improve by "8 percent or 9 percent" in the coming fiscal year.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Teams Open Wallets And Insert New Faces

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
A year ago, the Mets, the Cincinnati Reds and the Kansas City Royals were the most active off-season teams, the ones that made the most dramatic moves. The results, however, did not match the expectations. The Mets stumbled their way through the season and finished fifth, the Reds' injuries undermined their effort, and the Royals never recovered from 16 losses in their first 17 games.
The Mets, whose 1992 payroll was more impressive than their performance, decided to play a more reserved game this off season. But the Reds and the Royals would not be deterred and once more are among the teams that have taken the most significant steps to try to improve their chances for the 1993 season. 
 Bob Quinn was the general manager last year when the Reds acquired Greg Swindell, Tim Belcher, Scott Bankhead and Bip Roberts. Jim Bowden is the general manager who has orchestrated the team's recent moves.
The Reds have replaced the departed Swindell with John Smiley, also a left-handed free-agent pitcher, and they have tried to bolster their offense with the acquisition of Kevin Mitchell and Roberto Kelly. To achieve their offensive aim, though, the Reds will need Mitchell and Kelly to produce considerably more runs than they did this year.
Herk Robinson, the Royals' general manager, continued the renovation project he began last year when he obtained three-fourths of an infield -- Wally Joyner, Keith Miller and Gregg Jefferies -- plus an outfielder, Kevin McReynolds.
This time Robinson has traded for second baseman Jose Lind and signed shortstop Greg Gagne as a free agent. In his biggest coup, though, he signed David Cone for the starting rotation, which missed the stabilizing influence of Bret Saberhagen, the staff ace Robinson traded a year ago.
The Boston Red Sox and the Chicago Cubs have been active, too. The Red Sox have signed a big hitter, Andre Dawson; traded for another hitter, Ivan Calderon, and signed an effective reliever, Bankhead. They also have added second baseman Scott Fletcher.
The Cubs, who let Dawson go, have plowed through the free-agent market nonetheless. They have signed one starting pitcher, Jose Guzman; two left-handed relief pitchers, Randy Myers and Dan Plesac, and an outfielder, Candy Maldonado. They also have obtained a starting pitcher, Greg Hibbard, in a trade.
Then there are the three clubs whose new owners joined the spending spree their previous owners had resisted. The Houston Astros signed Doug Drabek and Swindell, the Detroit Tigers signed Mike Moore and Bill Krueger, as well as retaining Lou Whitaker and Bill Gullickson, and the Seattle Mariners (with money they didn't use while wrapping up Ken Griffey Jr. for four years and hiring Lou Piniella as manager) signed Chris Bosio and Mike Felder. They also acquired a bullpen leader, Norm Charlton, while shedding Mitchell's large salary.
 
The Blue Jays' Strange Moves
 The most debatable ventures belong to the Toronto Blue Jays. By keeping Joe Carter from defecting to the Royals, then coming back later the same evening last week and snatching Paul Molitor from the Milwaukee Brewers and luring Dave Stewart away from Oakland the following evening -- all for $41 million -- the Blue Jays caught everyone's attention.
But there might have been more style than substance in their dramatic maneuvers. Are the Blue Jays, on paper, now a better team than the one that won the World Series in October?
No.
First, they have substituted Molitor for Dave Winfield as their basic designated hitter. Molitor, five years younger than Winfield, may be more productive than Winfield next season or three seasons from now, but it's not very likely that he will provide more punch than Winfield did last season, when he batted .290, hit 26 home runs and drove in 108 runs.
Second, although Stewart's supporters believe he has solid seasons left despite his 23-21 record the past two seasons, he cannot replace both Cone and Jimmy Key, who have departed as free agents.
Third, Tom Henke hasn't officially departed, but he is expected to. They have Duane Ward to replace him as their closer, but Ward cannot be as good as Henke and Ward together have been for Toronto.
Which is not to say the Blue Jays won't be the favorite to win the American League East championship a third consecutive time. The Brewers, by losing Molitor and Bosio and possibly Robin Yount, and the Baltimore Orioles, by remaining relatively inactive, could insure the Blue Jays' preseason position at least.
 
The Yankees' Values
 Do not overlook the Yankees' activity. No team has made as many offers -- rich offers -- to free agents and emerged with so little. The Yankees have improved their starting rotation with Jimmy Key and Jim Abbott; they have added a veteran shortstop, Spike Owen, albeit one with limited range and a below-average arm, and they have acquired a left-handed hitter, Paul O'Neill, who, if he remembers how, could hit some home runs.
But the Yankees continue to astound other clubs and agents alike with some of their offers to free agents. The Yankees have come to believe that they must pay a premium to lure players to their clubhouse, but what they did in signing Owen was reminiscent, on a smaller scale, of their pursuit of Danny Tartabull last year.
At the time the Yankees put a fullcourt press on Tartabull, he had one offer -- from the Texas Rangers for three guaranteed years at $11 million. They gave him a guaranteed $25.5 million for five years.
The Yankees gave Owen $7 million for three years, but no one else was prepared to give him half that much. Furthermore, the Yankees' offer was so overwhelming, they could have asked him to wait until last Tuesday to sign. That would have given the Montreal Expos a chance not to offer salary arbitration, and the Yankees could have avoided giving up a draft choice as compensation.
The premature and unnecessarily expensive signing of Owen shows what happens when a general manager is superseded by a managing partner who has no baseball training and whose father-in-law many people suspect is calling the shots three months before he is permitted to become involved again.
 
A No-Load Right-Hander
 David Cone will pay more income tax on the $9 million signing bonus he will receive from the Royals this month than most people earn in a lifetime. Do not feel bad for him, however. Baseball's biggest-ever signing bonus will nevertheless be kind to Cone.
After paying 31 percent Federal tax and 6 percent state tax, Cone will still have $5.8 million. If he were to do nothing more adventurous than invest the entire amount in 6-percent triple-tax-exempt municipal bonds, Cone would receive $350,000 a year for as long as he maintained the investment.
The median salary in the major league this year was $400,000.
 
New Member for P.R.C.
 When Richard Jacobs, owner of the Cleveland Indians, was added to the Player Relations Committee board of directors last week, Bud Selig was asked why only hard-line, anti-union owners are put on the board. Douglas Danforth of the Pittsburgh Pirates was the last owner added before Jacobs, and he has an anti-union reputation from his tenure as chairman and chief executive officer of Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
"That's not a fair characterization in both cases," said Selig, who disputed the assessment of the owners as hard-line and anti-union. Selig is owner of the Milwaukee Brewers and chairman of the P.R.C. board and the executive council.
However, a year ago, when the Mets signed Bobby Bonilla to a then-record $5.8 million-a-year contract, Jacobs told then-Commissioner Fay Vincent that he should have fined them.
 
A Baseball Dictionary Addition
 With the owners' reopening of the collective bargaining agreement, the terms revenue sharing and revenue participation will become as familiar in coming months as split-fingered fastball and grand slam.
Revenue sharing is what clubs do with each other; revenue participation is what clubs want to do with players. However, revenue participation is, in the view of many, simply a nicer way to say salary cap, though it is no less unappealing to the players by any euphemism.
A proposal that Richard Ravitch, the clubs' chief labor executive, has presented to the owners includes an increased amount of revenue sharing and the adoption of revenue participation. The report of the economic study committee recommends that the clubs share a greater proportion of their revenue, but it remains neutral on a salary cap.
The committee report lists advantages and disadvantages of a salary-cap plan. Among the disadvantages, it says if player salaries were tied to revenues, the players "would insist on the right to have an equal voice in the negotiations and decisions which the clubs now make unilaterally," like television contracts, ticket prices and franchise sales.
The committee also notes that such a partnership would "require a relationship of trust" in the accuracy of clubs' financial statements that the union does not have at present.

HEADLINE: Save Us From the Wild Recruiter

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a professional from the executive ranks in the biomedical industry, I have been out of work since April -- the first time in a 20-year career that this has happened to me and a source of extreme financial and family burdens. 
 As a client of Mr. Starr's WSA Corporation, I sent over 3,000 resumes to prospective companies recommended by him, 80 percent of which were not remotely connected with my industry. I did not receive one phone call in response. When I mentioned this to Mr. Starr, he did offer to send a small number of resumes at a reduced cost. These also brought negative results.
My job search has cost more than $9,000 to date, including $7,500 to WSA. WSA's services are not successful for all. I for one can attest to this!
 
HAROLD S. HESS
Westlake Village, Calif., Nov. 30

HEADLINE: Battle Lines Drawn For Major Struggle Over Rent Control

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
"RENT control is like a drug," said Jim Whelan, Atlantic City's Mayor. "Once you're on it, it's very difficult to get off it."
In the two decades since New Jersey's municipalities began enacting rent-control ordinances in large numbers, local officials have become increasingly disenchanted with the laws that limit rent increases. They say that rent control, which exists in 119 communities, has shifted an increasing share of the tax burden onto residential and commercial property owners and led to the deterioration of rental housing in many areas. 
 But few municipal officials are willing to express their opposition to rent control on the record. "There are a lot more tenants than there are landlords," Mr. Whelan said. And those tenants represent votes.
Landlord and tenant groups, however, have been anything but bashful about presenting their positions and battling for advantage. For example, landlords have helped persuade many communities to adopt some form of vacancy decontrol, softening their rent ordinances by allowing an owner to charge higher rates for a controlled apartment after it has been vacated.
And in recent months, both sides of the rent-control issue have begun gearing up for a major confrontation next year.
A 600-member taxpayer association has sprung up in Hudson County with the express intent of persuading officials to modify or eliminate rent controls. "We're going to make our presence felt at every board meeting of every city in this county," said Robert G. Sacks, the group's president.
Last month, a bill that would exempt all new multifamily housing from local rent controls passed unanimously in both houses of the Legislature. The bill extends for five years an expired five-year exemption for such properties.
Meanwhile, advocates of tenant rights are planning their own countermoves. "We know the attack is coming," said Phyllis Salowe-Kaye, president of the New Jersey Tenants Organization, based in Hackensack. To meet what she called "a major mobilization to get rid of rent control," her group is organizing a statewide voter registration drive and a series of forums on tenants' rights.
Ms. Salowe-Kaye and other supporters of rent control say controls to protect tenants from rent-gouging landlords are needed as much as ever, if not more, particularly in light of New Jersey's dismal economy and chronic high unemployment.
"The fact is that landlords have made a bunch of gains in the past few years with vacancy decontrol," Ms. Salowe-Kaye said. Currently 85 municipalities with rent-control ordinances have some form of vacancy decontrol. She is also concerned, she said, that the Republican-dominated Legislature will attempt to "get rid of" rent control. Traditionally, she said, Republicans have been less sensitive to tenant issues than Democrats.
Opponents of rent control say it has caused an unfair tax shift in many municipalities. Because landlords' rental income is limited, they can often persuade officials to reduce the assessed value of their property, which lowers their real-estate taxes. As a result, the remaining owners of single-family homes and commercial properties end up paying a higher proportion of the municipal taxes.
Opponents also charge that rent control has led to the deterioration of rental housing in many areas because landlords who receive below-market rents for their apartments are more likely to cut corners on maintenance and capital improvements.
Rent control has also inspired some landlords and tenants in controlled apartments to strike illegal, clandestine agreements under which tenants pay higher rents than the law permits.
While several municipal officials interviewed for this article expressed opposition to rent control, they spoke only on condition of anonymity. One local official in northern New Jersey said that in his municipality, "Rent control is killing the tax base."
A municipal rent-board administrator in the southern part of the state referred to rent control as "a tax on the immobility of real estate." He said any attempt to set pricing controls on a local supermarket, for example, would be met by "the supermarket picking up and moving to the next town." Such an option, he said, is not available to property owners.
Only Mr. Whelan was willing to go on record. "I'm one Mayor who's not afraid to say that I have reservations with rent control," he said. "I'm not sure that it works, I think it has helped deplete our rental stock, and I think it is a strong disincentive to investment."
Yet officials are of two minds. "If you repeal rent control, you create havoc," Mr. Whelan said. "You end up having a lot of people who can't afford to live where they're living."
 
Neighborhood Stability Seen
 Ms. Salowe-Kaye of the tenants' organization would be the first to agree. "Rent control lets people who can't afford to buy homes know that they can stay in their apartments for a reasonable rent," she said. "Strong rent control means you get stability in a neighborhood."
Mr. Sacks, the head of the newly formed Hudson County Taxpayers Association and a Jersey City real-estate agent, said his group intended to bring pressure on communities to repeal their rent ordinances.
"People who own rent-controlled buildings are not making any money," he said, "so they have a choice: they either walk away from their buildings or they fight. One of the ways to fight is to appeal their taxes. And in case after case they're successful."
But cities still need the same amount of money in their budgets to provide necessary services, Mr. Sacks said, adding: "So who picks up the burden? The guy who owns a one-family house. The people who are living almost scot-free in rent-controlled apartments are living off the fat of the land. They're freeloading off the community, and it's unfair."
Ms. Salowe-Kaye said her tenants' organization would combat efforts to derail rent control. "We are starting a major education process, a huge voter registration drive statewide," she said, "and we're going to do a series in January of regional educational forums for tenants on tenants' rights."
 
Formula for Increases
 Most rent-control ordinances establish a base rent for each apartment in a building and then allow set increases each year. Those increases range from as little as 2 percent a year to as much as 7 percent.
Some ordinances allow for direct "pass-throughs" to tenants for expenses like real-estate taxes and for surcharges covering such expenses as heat and water. Many communities permit landlords to apply for rent increases if they can prove that the controlled rents they receive are causing them financial hardship.
Joseph Pojanowski, a Ramsey Councilman and a lawyer who often represents landlords before local rent and tax boards, said such hardship provisions typically do not work.
"In order to get a hardship increase, some towns have formulas that are impossible to achieve," he said. "It is a hardship in itself to file the appeal."
Moreover, he said, landlords forced to charge artificially low rents often attempt to cut their losses by trimming expenses rather than engaging municipalities in protracted legal battles.
"They take the easier road," Mr. Pojanowski said. "They eliminate preventive maintenance, they let their buildings get run down, and they file tax appeals." And that, he said, depreciates the quality of existing housing stock in a municipality.
 
'Three Elements' of Control
 Proponents of rent control, however, say that rent-control ordinances allow honest landlords to make a fair return on their investment while providing them with the ability to maintain their buildings properly.
"Rent control has three elements," Ms. Salowe-Kaye said. "Yearly increases, hardship increases and capital improvements." If landlords really wants to fix up buildings, she said, they can get more rent. "But where landlords have milked the property for years and years," she said, "surely the repairs that are necessary are not going to be covered."
Supporters of rent control also challenge the proposition that controls have led to a shifting of tax burdens to owners of private homes and commercial real estate.
"What we found is that tax shifts tend to be universal," said Mitchell Kahn, executive director of the Bergen County Housing Coalition and professor of social work and social policy at Ramapo College.
Mr. Kahn said he had recently conducted a survey of all 70 Bergen County municipalities to determine whether towns with rent control had greater tax shifts than those without. He discovered, he said, that rent control had no discernible effect on shifting taxes, and that "even towns that had no apartments had tax shifts."
On the other hand, Joseph W. Hottendorf, executive vice president of the Hudson County Board of Realtors, said his dissection of the tax history of an area of Bayonne had yielded a different result.
"We took one of Bayonne's three wards and looked at every apartment building in that ward," Mr. Hottendorf said. Using assessments made during a citywide revaluation in 1991, he said, he found that the assessed values of the 66 apartment buildings in the ward had decreased by 12.1 percent.
At the same time, Mr. Hottendorf said, the assessments on single-family homes increased by 32.25 percent.
"I know what that says to me," Mr. Hottendorf said. "It says the politicians want fewer people to be affected by tax increases, so the small homeowner gets affected but not the tenants in the apartment buildings."
 
Decontrol as 'Safety Valve'
 The only real "safety valve" for rent control, said Dr. George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of city planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, is vacancy decontrol. In addition to allowing landlords to increase their rental income without raising the rents of existing tenants, he said, vacancy decontrol also acts as a catalyst for better building maintenance.
"It's in the owner's best interest to improve the building because he wants the new rent to be as good as possible," he said.
Mayor Whelan described how some landlords and tenants behave in towns with no vacancy decontrol when the disparity between the controlled rent and the market rent becomes great.
"They cheat; that's what they do," he said, referring to the practice of landlords' and tenants' entering into clandestine rental agreements for rents that exceed the rent-control limits.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A:CAROLE BOBRUFF;
Radio Host Tries to Close a Generational Gap

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
PEOPLE older than 50 now make up about 25 percent of the population of the United States, and those over 65 now outnumber teen-agers for the first time in American history. Carole Bobruff cites these statistics as she urges people to look harder at both the power and the needs of older Americans. She says it is time to forget myths, recognize markets, tap skills and stop ignoring problems.
 Since 1990, Ms. Bobruff has been the producer and host of "Senior Focus," a twice-weekly hourlong talk show, aimed at those 50 and older, on radio station WSUB in Groton. For the show, which she said was the only one of its kind in Connecticut, she writes scripts, schedules guests, takes calls from listeners, solicits advertising and operates the equipment. Recent guests have included a lawyer discussing tax laws and asset protection, pharmacists talking about drugs, and a lawmaker who urged area agencies for the elderly to work together. 
From 1984 to 1990, Ms. Bobruff was the executive director of the Retired Senior Volunteer Program of New London County, which placed hundreds of volunteers each year in nonprofit agencies.
 Now 57 years old, she earned her bachelor's degree in human services 10 years ago. She said her own experience demonstrated that it was never too late.
 Here are excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Bobruff at her home in Niantic.
Q. How do you rate older Americans as a political force?
 A. Seniors are living longer, more active lives. They are the demographic group that votes most. By their numbers and by the fact that they vote, they have the potential to influence every institution in this country.
 Q. What are some common myths about older people?
 A. The biggest myth is people think that seniors are different, that their interests are different. That's not true; seniors are interested in everything, perhaps with a slightly different twist, that's all.
 Q. If businesses do not recognize the importance of the elderly market, what are they missing?
 A. A lot. In our country today seniors control 50 percent of discretionary income. There are 63 million Americans over the age of 50, and they control 77 percent of our nation's assets.
 Q. What are older people looking for when they purchase goods and services?
 A. It's a myth that seniors are not interested in new products. They are interested in new products. They're interested not in something that's going to save them time, but in something that's going to enrich their life. What we call younger seniors are interested in convenience and price equally. As we get up to the old-old, in their 80's, they're definitely interested in convenience first.
 Q. You've mentioned instances where those targeting older people seem to miss the mark.
 A. Seniors want to be involved. I've heard from a lot of seniors that they really don't like the term retirement community because it seems to mean that one is retired from life.
 Of course, terms like that have been thought of not by seniors, but by other segments of our society.
 What companies really should do is ask groups of seniors how their products could be better. They'll find out if they ask.
 Q. What are some products or services that you think older people would buy if they were offered?
 A. When you get to an airport, you have to reclaim your luggage. It can be a difficult task, carrying bags. If you're going to rent a car, you could pay a little premium to get off the airplane, have the bags claimed by the rental company. The next time you'd see the bags, they would be in the car.
 I think that if the auto makers asked seniors what they might like in cars, they'd come up with a seat that completely swiveled around so you could get out of the car.
 I think that seniors would pay for some modifications, but I also think that a lot of things are being overlooked.
 Q. What led you to start your radio show?
 A. I worked as director of a program that involved senior citizens as volunteers. I saw how important it was for them to feel needed, involved. I also saw that they were a segment of our society that was compartmentalized -- at senior clubs, in senior housing. My aim was to bring people -- different parts of our society -- together.
 I also found there were so many different programs for seniors and so much legislation that it was very difficult to keep up. I felt that I could do a service if I could communicate with seniors over the radio and get out some of this information. We have a lot of legal shows, a lot of medical shows, because the issues are so complex.
 Q. What are the major concerns that you hear from your listeners?
 A. Health is the No. 1 issue for them as it is for other age groups in our country. Health costs are catastrophic.
 Connecticut, facing its financial crisis, has put into effect new laws that make it more difficult for people to go on Medicaid. People are wondering how they're going to pay their bills; they're afraid of losing their assets.
 Q. In these times, with budget cuts everywhere, it can seem as though generations are pitted against one another. Are there ways of alleviating this?
 A. I've heard of a plan that's being proposed for Connecticut -- it comes from Colorado -- called the Senior Tax Exchange Proposal. It provides relief of up to $500 of property tax for seniors who, in turn, devote 125 hours to the local schools. That is what I would like to see more of, the generations coming together.
 Q. What about people beyond traditional retirement age who need or want to be employed?
 A. Seniors are a wonderful pool for part-time employment, and as our country ages we're going to need to use this pool. Perhaps employers will have to develop some more flexible programs and hours.
 Q. Does Connecticut have any unusual programs for its older citizens?
 A. Connecticut is the only state that has a mandate for municipal agents. Each town has a municipal agent who provides service information for seniors on all kinds of programs, from Medicare to housing to legal services. It's a well-kept secret; people don't know how to find this municipal agent. All they have to do is call their town hall.
 Q. What issues relating to older people are being ignored?
 A. The things I see being ignored are things that people don't want to realize might be problems. Certainly depression is a problem. It's not acknowledged by seniors and it's not acknowledged by our society; seniors are supposed to be old enough and mature enough to handle all of life's problems. I believe that some depression results in suicide. That's not talked about as a cause of death.
 Another problem among seniors is alcohol and drug abuse. It's a hidden problem, but it certainly is there, and most of the groups that one sees for rehabilitation with this sort of problem are for young people. We haven't made it easy for older people; we haven't targeted them at all.
 Q. Are there special concerns about those past 80?
 A. The escalating costs of hospital care and nursing home care. The thrust now is to keep people at home, but to do that you need to give them lots of services. You also need to make them feel useful and needed, and that is going to be the challenge of the 90's. Perhaps nonprofit agencies need to bring mailing, knitting, telephoning projects to people at home.
 Q. Many groups now represent older Americans. Is that good?
 A. I see a problem with that. In these difficult economic times a lot of senior entitlement programs are going to be attacked. Seniors need to get organized; they tend to be fragmented among too many different organizations that are not used to being united. Only by being united will they have power.
 Q. You say you keep an ancient, but timely, quote over your desk?
 A. It's from Plato: "It gives me great pleasure to converse with the aged. They have been over the road that all of us must travel, and they know where itis rough and difficult, and where it is level and easy."

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut;
For a Watershed, a Cemetery Proposal

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
A PROPOSAL to construct a regional, nondenominational cemetery on 62 acres of a potential watershed on the Woodbridge-Orange border has been so vociferously opposed by both towns that the South Central Regional Water Authority in New Haven, owner of the land and author of the plan, has temporarily withdrawn it.
 The controversy has exposed some broad issues arising from problems of growing populations and shrinking open space: burial vs. cremation, vaults leaching embalming fluids into water supplies, pressure on legislatures to weaken clean-water statutes and threats to the value of homes that suddenly abut a new graveyard. 
Right now we are taking another look and consulting with the State Health Department," said Richard McHugh, chief executive officer of the utility, "before determining whether to resubmit a proposal. There is a strong possibility that we will."
 The utility's reason for getting involved in cemeteries is economic.
 "If we do nothing to generate additional income over the next decade," said Thomas C. Jackson, head of land management for the utility, "we will have to raise rates 5 to 7 percent a year." The average customer now pays $77 a quarter, and rates since 1983 have been increased by 37 percent.
 A cemetery was deemed by the utility to be the best solution for creating substantial revenue while maintaining parklike open space, based on a study by Grever & Ward, cemetery planners in Orchard Park, N.Y. The study also indicated that a regional burial facility was needed to supplement waning capacity in the area that would be depleted in about 38 years.
 While there is no record of the number of cemeteries in Connecticut, Paul Basch, a land-use analyst with the Hartford Parks Department, which oversees that region's public cemeteries, said:
 "Cemeteries that have space are 99 percent filled, and we believe that there are barely 50 of those statewide. We have two to three years left in Hartford, so we are encouraging cremation. We started to do double-depth burials a decade ago. In southern Connecticut there is no public space left to speak of."
 But Robert Hannigan, past president of the Connecticut Cemetery Association, said that "existing cemeteries can expand and are doing so" and that "a new cemetery would be uneccessary competition."
 A per-household saving of $6 a year, estimated by the water company if the cemetery is built, was derided as minuscule and unpredictable by townspeople. Dorothy L. Berger, First Selectman of Orange, said:
 "The water company should go back to its purpose of stewardship, to insure that we have an adequate supply of pure drinking water at reasonable cost. The world in general is finding itself short of water. Once that land is committed to this use, it's gone forever. We've heard no complaints about running out of burial ground."
 Alerted to the situation by local residents, Dr. Gerald Iwan, head of the water-supply section of the state's Department of Health Services in Hartford, said: "We are concerned that the land in question is located less than the half-mile required between a cemetery and any source of drinking water -- in this case the Race Brook Reservoir. And we must decide on the future need for it as a watershed."
 To proceed with its plans, the utility must have the approval of the Health Department. In addition, it would need a zoning change from the towns and a change in state law to permit any entity other than a religious institution, cemetery association or municipality to own and operate a public cemetery.
 But before any of those procedures could be followed, the plan would need the approval of the 17-member Representative Policy Board, made up of a citizen from each of the 12 towns the utility serves, plus four towns in which it owns property, and a 17th member appointed by the Governor.
 THE board had planned to vote after a public hearing scheduled by the utility for Nov. 19, but the water company canceled, saying that correspondence from the Health Department and from Alice S. Miskimin, Town Counsel of Woodbridge, had been received too late for the utility to prepare a suitable response.
 Had the meeting taken place and the board voted against the plan as anticipated, the utility would have been summarily defeated. Richard Krodel, head of a neighborhood group called Save Open Space, or S.O.S., and many other residents believe that by cancelling, the utility grasped the opportunity to regroup and try again.
 Mr. Krodel's home on one-plus acre backs up to the cemetery site, and almost two dozen other homes on Race Brook Road and Wedgewood Drive abut or face the site.
 "We think that the utility has a hidden agenda to get the legislation changed," said Mr. Krodel, "allowing it to do pretty much what it wants and giving other watershed property owners the opportunity to do irreversible things with their land."
 According to Mr. Jackson, the public is unduly concerned.
 "The terrain does not drain to the reservoir, therefore the half-mile limit is moot since there is no danger of contamination," he said. Drainage is to Long Island Sound via the Weppawaug River into Milford Harbor.
 Terry Becker, an environmental watchdog known throughout the region as the "Long Island Soundkeeper," said: "A lot of watershed land is held by water companies that want to develop it to make money. These lands should be set aside in perpetuity, left in their natural state."
 Moreover, he added, "cemeteries are no longer a viable way to dispose of bodies. We have too much need for land for the living."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Top, Richard McHugh, left, and Thomas C. Jackson of South Central Water Authority with cemetery plan. Richard Krodel of Save Open Space at the proposed cemetery site with some of his group. (Photogrpahs by Steve Castagneto for The New York Times)
