PUB-DATE: December 13, 1992

SECTION: Section 6; Page 36; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 6257 words

HEADLINE: Silence of the Frogs

BYLINE: By Emily Yoffe; Emily Yoffe, a former senior editor at Texas Monthly, is a writer who lives in Los Angeles.

 BODY:
In the early 70's, a bizarre, inexplicable illness was sabotaging the academic career of Cynthia Carey. Then a young biologist, she was writing a dissertation on the physiology of coldblooded animals. Her creature of choice was Bufo boreas, named for the ancient Greek god of the north wind, an extravagant tag for a warty, blotchy, four-inch toad. It is more commonly and appropriately known as the western toad, its range encompassing the mountains of western North America. Twice a week, Carey went into the vast, pristine wilderness of Colorado to do her research. At times the toads were so plentiful she had to be careful when driving away not to crush them under her wheels.
In 1973, two years into her work, the illness struck. When she went into the field, Carey started coming upon an alarming sight: dozens of dying toads, toads barely able to move because their legs were puffy and red. She took one back to a veterinarian, who told her the toads were dying from an opportunistic infection because their immune systems had collapsed. But why?
Carey was in no position to unravel the mystery -- she had a dissertation to do. But by 1979, there were no western toads, healthy or sick, to be found at any of the previous sites, or anywhere else in Colorado she looked. "These are wilderness areas," she says today from her laboratory at the University of Colorado at Boulder, where she is an associate professor of biology. "There was no development, no housing, no habitat destruction. I was sad and mystified." 
 She was also in trouble. "I had to change my research. You can't tell your tenure committee, 'I haven't done my research because all my animals went extinct.' " Instead she switched to bird eggs, became an expert on them and for the next nine years thought little about where all the toads had gone.
Then in 1988, she read a scientific paper on how environmental disturbances suppress the immune systems of fish. "That's when all the lights went on," Carey says. She has since set out to discover what happened to Bufo boreas, now missing from at least 80 percent of its historic range.
Around that time the same light bulb was clicking on for herpetologists (scientists who study amphibians and reptiles) all over the world. And by 1989, the light was blinding. That year in Canterbury, England, the first World Congress of Herpetology was taking place. On the agenda were esoteric and, to the non-herpetologist, faintly ridiculous-sounding presentations like "Belly Pattern of Triturus Carnifex and Triturus Vulgaris in Two Ponds of Ligurian Apennines, Northern Italy." But to many of the 1,300 participants from around the world, it was as if there were another conference taking place in the hallways and over meals, during breaks and at talks late into the night. The subject of this impromptu conference could be summed up in one ominous question: Where have all the frogs gone?
"A bunch of us got together and started comparing notes," recalls Jay M. Savage, a professor of biology at the University of Miami. "People were struck by the fact it seemed to be occurring on a worldwide basis."
Savage has spent much of the last 40 years studying the evolution and ecology of amphibians, mostly in Central America. In 1964, he and a colleague discovered a species of toad native to Costa Rica, in what is now called the Monteverde Cloud Forest Reserve. The toad's Latin name is Bufo periglenes, but it is better known as the golden toad -- the male a Day-Glo orange. The golden toad lives underground, and emerges for an annual, explosive, breeding season. Since 1964, scientists have watched as thousands of these tiny, vivid animals gathered for their yearly ritual. That was until 1988. That year, at the primary breeding site, only one adult male was found. Two years later, there were none -- and none have been seen since.
The apparent disaster is being repeated among other Cloud Forest species. The exquisite glass frogs, small lime-green animals with see-through undersides and large quizzical eyes, were abundant until the late 80's; now they can hardly be found. "Jewels in the night we called them," Savage recalls. "You used to see hundreds."
The black, yellow and red patterned harlequin frog, an amorous creature that can spend days clamped in a breeding embrace, also virtually disappeared in the late 80's. "Human beings are great at rationalization," Savage says. "We said, it must be local damage; if we just went over the hill, we'd find them. Most herpetologists were trying to explain things that way. What was striking was we found it was happening on such a broad basis."
At the meeting, Michael J. Tyler, an associate professor of zoology at University of Adelaide in Australia who has an enviable record for identifying remarkable species, told of the disappearance of the gastric brooding frog named Rheobatrachus silus. In 1974, Tyler identified the reproductive strategy of this inhabitant of the rain forest in the Connondale Ranges in Australia. The strategy was so implausible that when Tyler wrote a paper describing it, the editors of Nature rejected it. (Science magazine, however, did publish the findings.) The Rheobatrachus female swallows her fertilized eggs, which then gestate in her stomach and are regurgitated as tiny froglets six weeks later. It was hoped the frog, who somehow turns off her gastric activity, could provide a breakthrough in treating human stomach ailments.
"We were looking at the frontiers of biological science," says Tyler. "We were rewriting concepts of how bloody magnificent some animals are." In 1980, the gastric-brooding frog disappeared, as usual, in the rocks for the winter. But then not one emerged that spring, nor has one been seen since. The species is now presumed extinct. To add to the puzzle, a number of the area's other frog species vanished as well, and remain missing.
In the United States, Bufo boreas is not the only amphibian disappearing from the West. Also in decline are the Yosemite toad, the mountain yellow-legged frog and the red-legged frog, which was likely the protagonist in Mark Twain's famous story "The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County." These frogs are missing from sites where they have been abundant in naturalists' accounts going back 75 years.
In all, almost one-third of North America's 86 species of frogs and toads appear to be in trouble. (In general, frogs have a smoother, more moist skin and live more closely to water than toads, which are squatter and often covered with warty bumps.) Gary Fellers, a research biologist with the National Park Service, visited Lassen Volcanic National Park in Northern California last year looking for the once-common Cascades frog. He used as his guide historic research papers describing the frog as being present every few feet. "We visited 50 sites with decent habitats," he says. "We found two frogs at one site." This year there were none.
Until recently, one of the most common sounds in western Canada's national parks was the low, throaty grunt of the northern leopard frog, Rana pipiens, the green-spotted creature almost everyone dissected in high school. Then, in the 1980's, the frogs started dying and populations plunged. The government of Alberta has even put out a "wanted" poster. Above a photo of Rana pipiens are the words, "Have You Seen This Frog?"
PERHAPS THE NEED TO FIND overarching explanations is encoded in our genes. From the search for a unified field theory of physics, to deconstructing the big bang, to proving that it was a straying asteroid that wiped out the dinosaurs, we like definitive theories to explain the phenomena that create and govern life.
What is killing the frogs? In many instances, the answer, as with much of the world's disappearing flora and fauna, is no mystery. Humans are destroying habitats with unprecedented frenzy. Researchers estimate that one-quarter to one-half of the earth's species could be extinct in the next 30 years. Cut down a forest, drain a wetland, build a shopping center, and the local frog species die. No one puzzles as to why Southern California is virtually barren of most of its native frogs.
There are other obvious human causes. For one thing, pesticides and herbicides that have been found safe for humans may be devastating to other animals at vulnerable points in their life cycles. For another, in national parks, the Government's fire-suppression policies have greatly accelerated the slow process of marshes becoming woods, thus robbing amphibians of habitat. Then there is the human impulse to rectify nature's oversights. The effect of this is seen in the Sierras. After the last Ice Age, fish did not colonize the high-elevation lakes; frogs did. These lakes have been stocked with nonnative game fish, which feed on tadpoles. This has left many frog populations isolated at higher headwaters, where they have become vulnerable to disease or harsh weather. And when the frogs are wiped out at a site, they can't recolonize it. Frogs themselves can also be the problem: when foreign species are introduced, they can overrun native populations.
But nothing explains it all. "I wish there were a death star to explain it," says David B. Wake, from his office at Berkeley, where he is the director of the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology at the University of California. "I don't see a single toxin, a single virus. My theory is that it's general environmental degradation. That's the worst thing. Frogs are telling us about the environment's overall health. They are the medium and the message."
Most herpetologists recognize that the world will never rally around their cosmetically challenged creatures. Their only hope is to portray frogs as four-legged, bug-eating Cassandras, and pray the prophecy is heard. "Frogs are in essence a messenger," Wake says. "This is about biodiversity and disintegration, the destruction of our total environment."
They aren't the only messenger. Visit any well-stocked zoo that identifies endangered animals, and you begin to feel you are walking the corridors of a hospice. Most of these endangered species, from migratory songbirds to rhinoceroses, are dying because of human actions -- from habitat destruction to outright slaughter. Some signals are more mysterious; coral is bleaching out in some of the world's oceans for yet-unknown reasons. But one of the most disturbing things about what's happening to amphibians is that species are disappearing from some of the most remote, pristine places left on the earth -- as if following some synchronized command.
Herpetologists, with perhaps not the greatest objectivity, say frogs are the ideal creature to reflect the health of the environment. In their view, frogs are living environmental assayers, moving over their life cycles from water to land, from plant-eater to insect-eater, covered only by a permeable skin that offers little shield from the outside world. Over and over, these scientists say amphibians represent the global equivalent of the proverbial canary in the coal mine. "They're very fragile organisms," says William Duellman, director of the Center for Neotropical Biological Diversity at the University of Kansas.
There is a paradox in portraying frogs as delicate creatures experiencing a collective case of the evolutionary vapors. After all, in the 200 million years since frogs first surfaced on the earth, they have survived whatever killed the dinosaurs, whatever did in the woolly mammoths and other huge animals that wandered this continent. They have withstood glaciers coming and glaciers going. They have been found everywhere from the Himalayas to the Sonoran desert. It is precisely because frog species have been so historically hardy that scientists now find themselves so baffled -- and alarmed. "Something is out of balance," says James Vial, professor of Wildlife Ecology at Oregon State University. "The changes in the environment may be more drastic than they appear."
Since Canterbury, David Wake has been a leader of a save-the-frogs movement among his colleagues. That conference three years ago was the first time, he says, "that a number of us herpetologists expressed our concerns openly to each other." And when the herpetologists started talking, they began to realize how much they had in common: for years many of them had been losing the subjects of their lifework. Before Canterbury, the scientists were reluctant to share their bad news with the rest of the world. "No one wanted to publish on it," Wake says. "It was sort of like a macho thing. 'I can't find frogs. I can't do the job anymore.' "
In 1990, Wake helped organize a symposium on the topic in Irvine, Calif., out of which came the Declining Amphibian Populations Task Force. The group, with headquarters in Corvallis, Ore., was conceived as a three-year project to determine the extent and possible causes of amphibian decline. Operating as a unit of the World Conservation Union in Switzerland, which provides part of the $250,000 budget, the task force now has more than a thousand researchers in 40 countries. The task force is set to expire at the end of next year, but already members are discussing making it a permanent organization. The Frog's Leap Winery in Napa Valley has donated the money for its bulletin: Froglog.
Like the species they study, herpetologists are solitary, even quirky creatures. Getting the task force organized, deciding how to accomplish its goals -- long-term monitoring or short-term assessment, field research or lab experiments -- took about a year. In the end, the members decided on all of the above.
One member of the task force's board, John Wright, the curator of herpetology at the Los Angeles Museum of Natural History, has been a vocal critic of the delays. But even if herpetologists were suddenly to adopt the cooperative social model of, say, ants, Wright would be pessimistic about the future. "In the real world and the scientific world, someone throws a dollar in the corner and everyone runs to it," he says. "Dollars are being thrown at other corners than biodiversity. If we can't do it with the warm fuzzies -- mammals and beautiful birds, we aren't going to do it with frogs." The answer to finding out what's going on with frogs, many herpetologists believe, would be a project documenting the world's species that is akin to the Human Genome Project.
An equally challenging problem is the need for herpetologists to move beyond alarming anecdote to absolute proof. Since almost no carefully controlled, long-term studies have been done on frog-population dynamics, can scientists even be sure they are seeing the disaster they think they're seeing?
"There is a lot of data on a number of populations taking nose dives over the last 20 years," says David Bradford, a wildlife ecologist with the Environmental Protection Agency. "It's a good record, but it's anecdotal."
Using frogs as their study species, scientists have focused on exotic subjects like the physiology of living at high altitudes or the genetics of skin coloration. Then their research yielded something unexpected: there were no more frogs to study. Like Cynthia Carey, Bradford watched in the 70's as his study population -- mountain yellow-legged frogs in Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks in California -- sickened and died. Ten years later, in 1989, he returned to census 26 of his study sites. He found frogs at one.
But a few herpetologists -- a decided minority -- are deeply troubled about the lack of long-term data. After the Canterbury conference, a Rutgers University biologist, Peter J. Morin, recalls: "I and a number of other people were a little alarmed that the data weren't there to support the conclusions. We need more real data on populations to find out if they are increasing, decreasing or just fluctuating." To be conclusive, such studies take 10 to 20 years.
Some skeptics say the problem isn't too few frogs, but too many frog researchers. It could be called the baby-boom theory of frog decline. The idea is that about 20 years ago graduate schools were filling up with young scientists studying the new biological discipline of population dynamics. "When people go out to do research projects, they usually pick common organisms," says Stephen G. Tilley, professor of biological sciences at Smith College. "If populations fluctuate, there's a good chance when you go back to look they might not be as common as they were when you first studied them." He points out that many animals, like some rodents or insects, have large population swings.
Tilley does believe that some species of frogs, like those in the Sierra Nevada, are in trouble. But he has seen nothing to convince him disappearances around the globe are linked. "I'm concerned about the species that are documented to have undergone a radical decline," he says. "But I am not convinced they tie together."
Many of the most alarming population crashes, he points out, like those in Costa Rica or Australia, are among species that have been discovered only recently. "The problem is a lot of the species people are concerned with right now haven't been studied long-term. For all we know, they fluctuate. There's a paper in Science, and the bottom line is when people do long-term studies of amphibian populations, they find they fluctuate a lot."
At first glance, the Science article does look like a T.K.O. to those crying extinction. From 1978 to 1990, census information was collected for species of three salamanders and one frog at a well-protected two-and-a-half acre pond near the center of the 300-square-mile Savannah River Ecology Laboratory in South Carolina. At the end of those years, breeding populations increased in one species and showed no declines in the others. Nevertheless, during the 12 years themselves, population size fluctuated widely -- one salamander was virtually absent for the first two years of the study, but by 1990, almost 600 females of the species bred.
But to the worried herpetologists, the article is equivalent to proving there is no homelessness in Los Angeles by going on a tour of Beverly Hills. They claim to be seeing not fluctuations, but dead drops. David Wake, who wrote a commentary in Science to accompany the article, praises its research and agrees that more long-term data are needed. But he takes no comfort from it, because the Savannah River site is located in an area that is vast and wet and green. "It's an excellent breeding site," Wake says. "They could have total extinction of a local pond, and it would be recolonized the next year. There's no risk to those animals moving back and forth."
Joseph H. K. Pechmann, an author of the Science article on the Savannah River project, agrees with Wake that, in many ways, his site is unique. "We would be the first to say the results from one study should not be generalized to the next pond down the road, let alone to a pond halfway around the world," says Pechmann.
But he adds his own warning: conclusions about a global frog crisis should not be generalized from existing evidence. "It remains an open question whether declines and disappearances of some frog species in isolated, pristine environments represent a natural fluctuation or some subtle effect of human activities that we don't understand," Pechmann says. "My money is on the natural fluctuations, but I can't prove that. Only further research will say for sure."
NO herpetologist disputes the value of long-term studies. But many insist that to wait for the data to come in would be foolhardy. "These declines, in many cases, are so catastrophic and are occurring simultaneously in so many parts of the world that we cannot wait for monitoring studies before we express our concern," says James Vial of Oregon State University, who is the task force's international coordinator. "Because if we wait for a prolonged period, there may not be anything left to study."
Many researchers refuse to wait, and are now exploring the possible causes of the mysterious declines -- those not clearly linked to habitat destruction. At the top of the list is an increase in ultraviolet radiation. Among the hardest-hit amphibians are those that live at high altitudes, or near-the-ozone-hole southerly latitudes, from the Rockies and Sierras to the Andes to Australia. High-altitude frogs have already developed strategies to protect themselves from harmful radiation, while absorbing the heat so necessary to their survival. Many highland species lay black eggs and have a black peritoneum and, in the male, black testes. "This suggests they already live at the edge," says Wake. "How much more does it take to push them over?"
While there may be indications that those who wear sunblock will inherit the earth, right now it's difficult to prove that increased ultraviolet radiation is a major cause of the decline. The simple reason is that studies have yet to be done to show if UV radiation really is increasing, and there is little historical information. More than a century's worth of temperature and rainfall statistics leaves the very false impression that similar data exist on all other atmospheric phenomena. "I can't believe how little we know," says Wake. "One reason global climate change is a touchy field is we don't have the right records."
There is, of course, another species not protected by fur or shell or feathers that seems to be suffering from exposure to the sun's rays. Human skin-cancer rates are rising dramatically around the world. And Wake says we need to heed such warnings. "I say use biological indicators," he says. "The instruments won't do it. We need to measure effects."
Andrew R. Blaustein, professor of zoology at Oregon State, is using instruments and measuring effects. The National Science Foundation and the National Geographic Society are helping to pay for his three-year, $272,000 study of ultraviolet radiation on amphibians. Blaustein has discovered that in the past four years, there has been a large dying off of western-toad eggs. What is unusual about this is that while very few toads and frogs make it to adulthood, mortality does not normally occur until after the eggs have hatched. "This year there were about two-and-a-half million eggs," Blaustein says. "Ninety-five percent of them died." There have been experiments that show exposure to UV radiation will destroy the development of eggs, but these have been in the laboratory. Blaustein wants to find out what effect current UV radiation levels are having in the field.
As for other possible causes, acidification also has its partisans. But for every study that shows acid rain is damaging frogs, another one refutes it. "I have dismissed it as a factor in the Rocky Mountains," says Stephen Corn, a zoologist with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in Fort Collins, Colo., who has just completed an extensive survey of acid rain's effect on western amphibians. And Blaustein, too, can find no evidence of acid in the Cascade Mountain lakes he is studying. "The acid stuff doesn't fit at all," he says. "We've taken pH measurements for two years. It's totally normal. And in the three lakes we've studied these animals, there are no pollutants."
The mystery of the frog decline challenges the distinction between what is local and what is global. Because we as a species are so successful, so pervasive, the consequences of our local actions now ripple across the globe. No pristine place can protect a species from hazardous levels of, say, UV radiation. What is happening to frogs calls into question our belief that we can preserve the natural world in small, unsullied pockets. "You cannot lock up nature," Wake says. "There's no Noah's ark big enough."
"THEY HAVE BEAUTIFUL eyes. You can really fall in love with them."
Cynthia Carey is talking about the large, amber, if rather unexpressive, eyes of the specimen of marine toad now bloating up in the hands of her research assistant, Judy Bissonnette. The bloating, which makes this six-inch toad start to resemble a tiny dirigible, is a natural response to danger. In this case, the danger is being one of a dozen research animals in this small lab room at the University of Colorado at Boulder.
Almost 20 years after she first wondered why all the western toads she saw were dying, Carey, who wears a small, silver frog pendant around her neck, is trying to decipher the immune system of frogs. The sick toad she had autopsied many years ago died of a massive infection from the bacteria Aeromonas hydrophila, which is ubiquitous in fresh water. In the final stages of infection, the circulation of a toad or frog will break down, causing hemorrhaging that brings blood to the skin -- thus the common name, red-leg disease. Red-leg, like AIDS, is a condition caused by the collapse of the immune system. A healthy frog should not succumb to massive Aeromonas hydrophila infection, just as a healthy human should be able to fight off the staph and strep infections that can be so devastating to AIDS patients. But unlike AIDS, no one knows what is triggering the toads' immune system breakdown; if it is a pathogen, it remains unidentified.
Departing from several of her colleagues who are looking to prove that a specific environmental factor kills frogs outright, Carey says she believes the problem is more complex. Her hypothesis is that a combination of several factors -- be it ultraviolet radiation, acid snow or something yet unknown -- creates a degree of sublethal stress sufficient to cause the cascading breakdown of the immune system.
With a $20,000 grant from the National Science Foundation, Carey is figuring out what a healthy toad's immune system looks like. Once she has this basic information, the next step will be to expose toads to acidified water, pesticides, ultraviolet light and rapid temperature change. The object is to try to find out which of these conditions, if any, will induce the collapse of toad immune systems. It's a large undertaking. "We don't really understand why when you and I get under a lot of stress, and then the stress is over, we immediately get sick. We don't understand that for us, let alone amphibians." She can't risk using the remaining western toads for her preliminary experiments -- their population is too fragile. Instead, she buys marine toads, natives of the Gulf Coast, from an animal supply house.
In a way, Carey's research is as metaphorical as molecular. What if she does find that what's killing frogs is some mix of global environmental changes? Aren't they really, then, a disturbing sign about the health of the planet's immune system? "Frogs aren't the only thing disappearing," she says. "The more biological diversity we destroy, the less flexibility we have to create new food sources that can tolerate the environment we are creating."
THERE WAS THAT unprecedented moment in amphibian history when a frog was America's sweetheart. But Kermit aside, frogs have never been much loved by people. Carolus Linnaeus, the 18th-century Swedish naturalist who developed the classification system of living things, once wrote, "These foul and loathsome animals are . . . abhorrent because of their cold bodies, pale color, cartilaginous skeletons, filthy skin, fierce aspect, calculating eye, offensive smell, harsh voice, squalid habitation and terrible venom."
Frogs lack the qualities that seem to arouse human passion toward other species -- the wild variety and soaring ability of birds; the cuddliness or majesty of mammals. They are not the subject of riveting nature specials or glossy coffee-table volumes. They are of little economic value. For most urbanites and suburbanites, they are creatures long ago encountered at summer camp, dismembered in high-school lab -- and little thought of again. This distant relationship with humans has made quantifying their disappearance more difficult. Amateur bird watchers, for example, keep records, so there is abundant long-term data showing the decline of migratory songbirds.
The first amphibians emerged around 350 million years ago. Depending on what you consider a frog, the first frogs appeared about 200 million years ago during the Triassic period or 180 million years ago during the Jurassic. Amphibians -- the word comes from the Greek "amphi" and "bios" (living a double life) -- are a bridge between the aquatic and the terrestrial, the link between fish and reptile. They include salamanders as well as frogs and toads.
Herpetologists have not done a very good public relations job for their creatures; Linnaeus's attitude toward frogs has been passed down through the centuries. "This popular concept that they are imperfectly adapted, lowly vertebrates is garbage rooted in an archaic vision of evolution," says Stephen Tilley of Smith College. "They are a highly adapted group in their own right. They have extremely complicated behaviors, anatomies, physiologies and reproductive patterns."
There are about 3,800 known species of frogs and toads that occur on every continent except Antarctica. As with much of life, frogs are more colorful, more diverse and more plentiful in the tropics. For example, the forests of Borneo are host to probably 200 species. Texas, which is of equivalent size, has only about 35. Paradoxically, during the 80's, when the great disappearances were first noticed, there was an explosion in species identification. Twenty percent of South America's frog species were named in that decade. "I'm just sitting here, looking at material I just brought back from Peru," says William Duellman, from his office at the University of Kansas. "They have apparently two new species of tree frogs that no one has ever collected before."
For the past 30 years, Duellman has concentrated his research on South and Central America. He has a particular fondness for documenting frogs' astounding breeding strategies -- from marsupial frogs, which carry fertilized eggs in a pouch on their back that develop into tadpoles or froglets, to Darwin's frog, whose males incubate newly hatched tadpoles in their vocal sacs until they emerge as frogs, to a type of dart-poison frog, which deposits her tadpoles in water pooled in bromeliad leaves and then feeds them during their development with her unfertilized eggs.
While Duellman says the frog situation in the environs of the Midwest seems "copacetic," he, too, has been perplexed as South American species he has studied for years appear to be dropping off the face of the earth. "About 1984 was when I started getting an inkling of declines in frog population in the Andes of Ecuador," he recalls. "You'd have frogs crawling all over one year, then the next year, none. That's pretty dramatic. What we're facing now are indications of a crisis. This is the first time in my tenure as a herpetologist we've seen anything of this type."
TREADING carefully in the muck, Stephen Corn of the Fish and Wildlife Service reaches down and picks up a small, mottled, olive-green and brown creature found nowhere else on earth. This unprepossessing animal is one of the last surviving members of its species, the Wyoming toad. Corn looks at its front foot. "It's a male," he says. In the males of many species the "thumb" is dark and calloused-looking, an "all the better to squeeze you with my dear" adaptation. During mating, called "amplexus," the male grabs the female and mounts her; from similar-looking orifices, they simultaneously spew either sperm or eggs, which are fertilized outside the female.
Unfortunately for the future of the Wyoming toad, there have been no breeding females to grab for the past year. Adding to the problem has been an outbreak the past two years of red-leg disease.
The toad's Latin name is Bufo hemiophyrs baxteri, after George Baxter, a retired professor of zoology at the University of Wyoming who first discovered the species -- actually a subspecies of the Dakota toad -- in 1946. Over the years, Baxter would take his classes to the dozens of sites of the animal's small range, 100 square miles around Laramie. Then, as the familiar story goes, in the mid-70's Baxter realized he was having a hard time finding his toads. By 1983, no one could find any; they were placed on the endangered species list, and presumed to be extinct.
But in 1987, a sharp-eyed fisherman spotted some at a small, stocked fishing lake about 10 miles west of Laramie -- a last, holdout population of about 100 toads. Introduced fish do not seem to be the cause of this toad's demise. These amphibians produce fairly toxic tadpoles, unlike many species whose yet-to-metamorphosize young are prime fish morsels. This year, the Fish and Wildlife Service bought the fishing lake, as well as three nearby lakes and 1,800 acres around them, for about $300,000 -- one of the few Government refuges established for amphibians.
The burly, bearded Corn is running an annual census of the toads. Three times last summer, he and a group of biologists came to the lake to capture every toad they could, photograph them and try to match their unique markings with previous toad mug shots. The population is considered too unstable for the more common identifying procedure of toe-clipping, or the new high-tech version being used on a population of western toads in which a transponder the size of a grain of rice is inserted below the skin.
Corn is pessimistic about the future of Bufo hemiophyrs baxteri. This fall's population was 162, but then his research team found that an estimated one-quarter of the total had been hit by red-leg disease. And in 1989, an unusually cold winter probably killed off many of that year's young. Researchers believe that the female of the species breeds only in the third year of its life, so the 1989 die-off has left a female population that is too young to breed. As Corn holds the toad, a male he estimates was born in 1990, it emits a small, alarmed cheep. "They cheep when a predator or another male grabs them," he explains. "The breeding call is a low-grade whine." The male has had plenty to whine about the last few years. "This is one that tried to breed this year," Corn says, "but he couldn't find any girls."
Such population fluctuations, as the Savannah River study shows, may have less serious consequences when there is a larger population of the species available to recolonize a site, but the Wyoming toad has no such backup. "I think realistically it's a matter of time," Corn says.
Adding to the mystery of the Wyoming toad is the thriving population of chorus frogs that are hopping along in the same muck. This frog, bright green and skinny with dark green stripes, has an intense chirp of a breeding call; in fact, some herpetologists joke that these creatures have caused them some loss of hearing. What is the secret of their success? One irony-rich theory is that chorus frogs have shorter individual life spans than Wyoming toads. That is, they reach maturity and reproduce so quickly that they don't live long enough to succumb to whatever is doing in the toads. But dying young isn't a foolproof method of survival: The chorus frogs of eastern Canada now appear imperiled.
WHAT WOULD HAPPEN if frogs died out? Understandably, that's a world few herpetologists care to imagine. One consequence, they say, may be a field day for insects; amphibians provide a far safer method for keeping insect populations in check than any chemical insecticide. Bangladesh, where native frogs have been nearly wiped out to appease the French appetite for their legs, appears to be reaping the consequences. "They now have increased numbers of mosquitoes and malaria," William Duellman says. And the indisputable importance of frogs to the food chain is not just a matter of what they eat, but who eats them; they are a major food source for many birds, fish, reptiles and mammals.
But herpetologists say that simply saving frogs is not the point. "We don't know how many species can be lost before the system ceases to function," says Richard L. Wyman, adjunct associate professor of biology at the State University of New York at Albany. "But eliminate enough species and sooner or later it will cease to function. In the past, life responded to change through evolution, and that process depends on genetic diversity. If everything's the same, evolution stops. It's as if we are killing evolution itself."
In his book on the history of earth's extinctions, "The Miner's Canary," the paleontologist Niles Eldredge writes, "Extinction resets the evolutionary clock." So far, six mass extinctions have reset the earth's evolutionary clock -- like the one that happened at the end of the Cretaceous period that took the dinosaurs with it. And some scientists, including Eldredge and celebrated biologist Edward O. Wilson of Harvard, insist we are in the midst of another cataclysm -- the first to be caused by man.
Life has never stopped completely, however. A few species have always managed to cross the valley of death, and those that made it to the other side were able to begin the evolutionary process again. In light of that, David Wake is more sanguine about the frogs' future than ours.
"They have been here hundreds of millions of years, humans less than five," Wake says. "I have no doubt there are survivors among them. I think they will do better than we will. I am totally convinced that frogs will be here when we are long gone."

HEADLINE: Focus: Charleston, S.C.;
A Village Proposed for a Pastoral Island

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C.

 BODY:
THE completion of the Mark Clark Expressway last June linking the pastoral Daniel Island with downtown Charleston just minutes away across the Cooper River has paved the way for a proposal to build a village over the next three decades to support as many as 17,000 residents.
Daniel Island is now home to two caretakers, deer, pigs, cattle and birds. 
 The proposal, put forth by the Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation of New York City, which owns the island, must first win the approval of the Charleston City Council. As an initial step, the Planning and Zoning Commission is expected to begin reviewing the proposal in January.
Spreading across some 4,500 acres in the center of Charleston's busy waterways, the development would be one of the largest ever undertaken in South Carolina. The plan calls for 4,000 to 7,000 homes in several neighborhoods, a million square feet for light industry and three million square feet of office space. A town center reminiscent of Nantucket, Mass., would be built on 23 acres beside the Wando River.
Central to the plan is the foundation's desire to foster a livable yet lively urban environment while respecting the beauty of the island, said John H. Alschuler Jr., president of the Daniel Island Development Company.
The company was formed to develop the island, since under Internal Revenue Service regulations the nonprofit Guggenheim Foundation may not have a controlling interest in a profit-making enterprise.
The foundation hired the architects and planners and will sell the island -- except for 800 acres to be sold to a state agency -- to Daniel Island Development, in which it will retain a minority interest.
The plan is the work of New York architects Cooper, Robertson & Partners and planners Andres Duany and Elizabeth Plater-Zyberk.
Mr. Duany and his wife, Ms. Plater-Zyberk, are best known for the plan for Seaside in Florida, a resort modeled after the traditions of America's small towns with homes of many styles clustered around a central business district that lies within easy walking distance.
The Daniel Island plan echoes that theme, but on a larger scale. There would be several large public parks, including a 337-acre one at the southern tip of the island, and some smaller waterfront parks at the ends of streets, with no residence more than a quarter mile from a park.
The roads, built on a grid pattern rather than the more common cul de sacs of modern subdivisions, would be narrower than now allowed by Charleston zoning law, so a zoning change or variance would be needed. The houses would range from low-income to very expensive. The island is 5.75 miles long and 2.25 miles broad at its widest point.
"The foundation brings to this task a sense of civic purpose," said Mr. Alschuler, largely because of the Harry Frank Guggenheim Foundation's mission to address the problems of violence and aggression in society.
While the development is not intended as an experiment in urban development as it relates to the foundation's mission, the planners hope it will provide a model for how to make cities more desirable.
"DANIEL ISLAND is really a unique entity," Mr. Alschuler said. "I have never before seen 4,000 to 5,000 acres under single owners without a structure on it at the heart and center of a city."
The island is sandwiched between two densely populated land masses: downtown Charleston, with 68,000 people, to the west and Mount Pleasant, a suburb of about 18,000 people, to the east. It has remained undeveloped largely because it was difficult to get to.
A small, two-lane bridge provided the only access to the island until the Mark Clark Expressway was completed. The road, joining North Charleston and Mount Pleasant, bisects the island.
Harry Frank Guggenheim, the founder of Newsday and grandson of the mining magnate Meyer Guggenheim, bought the island in the 1940's for $70,000. He used it as a hunting preserve and cattle farm and maintained a plantation on a mainland peninsula just north of the island, said Henry Smythe, his Charleston attorney.
At the 10,000-acre Cain Hoy Plantation, Mr. Guggenheim raised race horses (one of his horses, Dark Star, won the 1953 Kentucky Derby). Cain Hoy remains in the hands of Mr. Guggenheim's heirs; Daniel Island was bequeathed to his foundation when he died in 1971.
The foundation agreed to Charleston's annexation of the island last year.
Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. of Charleston has said that he considers the island crucial to the future economic well-being of his city. Without it, he has said, Charleston has little hope for further growth.
"If Charleston became hemmed in, and home to the most affluent and the poor, there would be no way to expand its tax base or incorporate the growth of the middle class," Mr. Alschuler said.
In return for agreeing to the annexation of the island, the foundation won an agreement from the Commission of Public Works to provide water and sewer service to it, a $15 million project, and the city's pledge to build the island's parks, including the big southern one, which is to be built on material dredged from the Cooper River.
The foundation has also agreed to sell 800 acres on the Cooper River to the State Ports Authority for $7 million. The authority plans to build a $1 billion containerized shipping terminal, the largest public works project ever undertaken in South Carolina.
The terminal, which will take at least 20 years to build, will handle some 5,000 container-hauling rigs a day. A 15-foot-high landscaped soundwall costing as much as $4 million will separate the terminal from the rest of the island.
Unlike most other island developments off the coast, Daniel Island would be an open community, Mr. Alschuler said.
"There will be no locked gate and no hidden gates constructed by price barriers," he said. "We want to create new neighborhoods and truly have public open space."
Diversity in building will be encouraged and 10 percent of the proceeds from the development will go into a fund to build affordable housing. An area would be set aside for schools and other institutional buildings.
ALREADY, some criticism has been leveled by a local nonprofit environmental organization, the South Carolina Coastal Conservation League. Dana Beach, the organization's president, said that except for the grid street pattern and the preservation of trees, the plans looked like every other island development built on the coast in recent years. Under the plan, an 18-hole golf course would lie in the center of the island, surrounded by residential lots all the way to the waterfront.
Mr. Beach said he had hoped the plan would call for a denser concentration of housing to preserve natural walking paths along the Wando River and its tributaries and to make a mass-transit system feasible.
But Mr. Alschuler said the housing units were as dense as the market would bear and Daniel Island would have two and a half times the amount of public open space as required by law. He also said the foundation had no desire to be "cute" in the development.
"Daniel Island should look like it evolved from the historic tradition of the Carolina Lowcountry," Mr. Alschuler said. "We don't need some Disneyland recreation of downtown Charleston."
The first land transaction from the foundation should be made next year. At that time, the first neighborhood and a few of the buildings in the town center will be built.
"I think it's a great plan," said Mr. Guggenheim's lawyer, Mr. Smythe, who regularly hunts dove on Daniel Island. "In many ways, its going against the trend of the last generation to go back to the concept of a town rather than a subdivision."
Looking out across the dredge material that one day would be a city park, Mr. Smythe said: "Something like this, which produces virtually no income, has to be converted to produce income. The time has come."

Map of Daniel Island showing route of the Mark Clark Expressway.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Rutland, Vt.;
A Downtown For the Future

BYLINE: By Kent Shaw

 BODY:
THE owners of a downtown shopping center here have agreed to undertake a $12 million renovation in the spring by replacing a 20,000-square-foot Price Chopper supermarket with a new 58,000-square-foot version.
The new store would be the largest in the state and anchor the Rutland Shopping Plaza, which in turn would be the centerpiece of almost $50 million in construction and renovation work expected over the next two years. 
 Each of the projects was targeted in a 1989 planning study commissioned by the city. Along with bringing new jobs to a weary downtown economy, planners want to capture a growing tourist market.
For a city of 18,200 built on railroads and industries like marble mining, the change is striking.
"We're redefining in very unequivocal terms what downtown is going to be," said Mayor Jeffrey Wennberg. "We're letting go of the past."
The agreement between Rutland officials and the owners, NET Properties, of Boston, comes after several years of planning and negotiations prompted in part by the possibility of a 450,000-square-foot shopping mall about two miles south of the city. That project, mired in the approval process, would be at least three years in the making.
Other downtown projects include a proposal by the Central Vermont Public Service Corporation, the state's biggest electric utility, for a $20 million, five-story headquarters within the plaza, at the end opposite the Price Chopper. The project should begin in 1994, according to Bruce Simons, a utility spokesman.
On Merchants Row, a central commercial artery that borders the plaza, a new complex of state offices will occupy a renovated four-story building owned by the Hulett Associates limited partnership. State Commissioner of Buildings John Zampieri said initial work on the phased $7.2 million project could begin in late December. The 1906 building would eventually house all state satellite offices now dispersed through Rutland County.
A final downtown component is to be an $8 million transit center and parking complex next to the state offices.
Taken together, the downtown projects would mean a strong infusion of real estate investment in a city core area sorely tested by outlying malls and commercial strip development extending 50 miles north to Burlington on Route 7.
Much of the negotiating has been handled by the Rutland Redevelopment Authority, formed in 1989, which has the power to levy special taxes on businesses in a downtown district.
The agency has raised about $180,000, most of which was spent on streetscape improvements and planning for downtown festivals and sales events.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 2783 words

HEADLINE: The Threepenny Verdi

BYLINE: By John Simon; John Simon is the theater critic of New York magazine and the film critic of National Review.

 BODY:

KURT WEILL
Composer in a Divided World.
By Ronald Taylor.
Illustrated. 358 pp. Boston:
Northeastern University Press. $29.95. 
 THE ever courteous Kurt Weill tried to make things easy for his biographers. Born in 1900 and dead in 1950, he made his life span coincide with the first half of the century he epitomized -- a true mnemonic bonus. Furthermore, his composing career segments as neatly as an orange: the European Weill, from 1920 to 1935; the American Weill, from 1935 to 1950. Weill I composed classical music and wry operettas for European sophisticates; Weill II composed tuneful musicals for Broadway and American innocents everywhere. And, for ultimate symmetry, Weill married his wife, Lotte Lenya, once in Germany and, after she divorced him, once in America. Simple, isn't it?
Not really. Ronald Taylor's new biography, "Kurt Weill: Composer in a Divided World" (first published in England in 1991), implies that Weill's world was unusually antinomian. Actually, the world is never short on divisiveness and dissension. So, as Mr. Taylor, who has written books about other German composers, states right off, "People perceive a split in [Weill's] musical personality which fatally divides the European from the American, the former brilliant and sparklingly original, the latter a sad regression and capitulation to inferior values." Perhaps, then, the author is out to demolish the notion that one half of Weill is better than the other: "There is not one 'pure' and one 'applied' music," he writes, as if agreeing with Weill's contention.
For, eventually, Weill made the claim of "never [having] acknowledged the difference between 'serious' music and 'light' music. There is only good music and bad music." But Mr. Taylor disagrees: between "The Magic Flute" and "The Mikado," between "Fidelio" and "Die Fledermaus," there is a difference. Then what is his book's aim? It is to keep technical matters at a minimum, provide few musical examples and concentrate on telling the man's life story and assessing his achievements in historical perspective. A book, the author says, for the people who have been whistling Weill songs for years and want to know more about their composer. As a whistler's Weill, the biography comes off most satisfactorily; nonwhistlers, though, may have a few demurrers.
The book's chief merit is in its steering a middle course between extremes, between temptations to one excess or another. Because Curt Julian Weill (he soon streamlined his name) was indeed a complex person under his quiet, pipe-smokingly withdrawn exterior, it is easy to latch on to some deceptively simple surface aspects and ignore the rest. What Mr. Taylor has elected to do is judicious, considering how little material on Weill there is in English. Ronald Sanders's biography, "The Days Grow Short" (1980), is estimable, but hardly definitive; the works by Kim H. Kowalke and David Drew are chiefly for specialists. Mr. Taylor's attempt is at a brief but helpful overview. Nothing essential is overlooked, but initiates seeking detailed analyses, esoteric data or piquant revelations won't still their hunger here.
All the same, Mr. Taylor does retell this extraordinary life story with smiling fluency, a spry attention to thought-provoking details and an audacity refreshing in a popular biographer. He is very good at succinctly sketching in the lives of those who importantly impinged on Weill. We get a compelling account of that monster of genius Bertolt Brecht, with whom Weill wrote some of the epochal works of 20th-century music. We get a clear sense of Brecht's strengths and vices, the help and hindrance he was to his uneasy collaborator; neither man, we are told, ever addressed the other by the familiar German du. We relish, for instance, the account of the particularly frantic and acrimonious rehearsal period of "The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny," with the pair nearly coming to blows. The always magisterially calm Weill, able to work on additions and revisions while the rehearsal turbulence would have burst the Richter scale, finally left in a huff only to hear Brecht shout at his back, "I'll put on my war paint and throw that phony Richard Strauss down the stairs!"
Again, the portrait of Lotte Lenya that emerges here is full and clear. Mr. Taylor captures the "not beautiful, barely even pretty but attractively roguish-looking" Lenya, who left high school "at 13 and took to the world's oldest profession more or less full time" in all her capriciousness, vivacity and irrepressible candor. As a very young man, Weill inquired by mail whether his schoolteacher sister had among her students a girl who would make him "a decent wife." She would have to be "extremely pretty, extremely stupid, unmusical, with a dowry of a million marks." Instead, he got the opposite, Lenya, who, as he later told a Munich newspaper, was a foul housewife but fine actress; who couldn't read music ("any composer whose wife can read music has my sympathy") but, when she sang, was listened to like Caruso; who took no interest in his work ("which is one of her greatest assets") but demanded it for hers. Weill went on with some apt ironies about Lenya and her many other men.
Yet the secret of their getting on so well together was, as he wrote his parents (upset at his marrying a shiksa), that here were "two people with different, unconnected artistic interests, each helping the other along his own path." Another thing was the shared love of animals, particularly "large, shaggy dogs," a special favorite being named Harras. By one of history's ironies, Mr. Taylor might have told us, the sire of Hitler's favorite dog bore the same name. In the earlier years of the marriage, it was Lenya who cheated on Weill; later, especially in Hollywood, he managed to -- almost -- equal the score. But they put up with each other's infidelities mostly with grace, and in all other ways complemented and supported each other.
There are vivid sketches of Weill's other collaborators here: Georg Kaiser, the dramatist with whom Weill wrote three important German stage works; Caspar Neher, the great set designer and poor part-time librettist, whose wife embarrassingly yearned for Weill; Moss Hart; Ira Gershwin; Maxwell Anderson, whom Mr. Taylor overestimates ("a sense of poetic language unique in its place and its time" indeed!); and several others. There is even a sly bit about the artsy millionaire Edward James, whose passion for the alluring dancer Tilly Losch inspired him to propose the last, and in some ways greatest, Brecht-Weill collaboration, "The Seven Deadly Sins." Personally, I could have used more about Weill's rift with Franz Werfel, and something about Maurice Magre, that obscure but fascinating poete damne, to whose texts Weill wrote two of his most ravishing French chansons.
Mr. Taylor deals with the music at about the right length and level for the general reader; if he errs in his judgments, it is usually on the side of severity, a novel trait in a biographer. He seems greatly to favor the European Weill. Thus he maintains that in "Johnny Johnson," Weill's first American musical, in the passages dealing with war and history, "whether somber . . . or satirical, the Weill of old is at his striking and powerful best," but "the lyrical numbers . . . show how far the fuzzy hit-parade flaccidity of his new environment has encroached." I myself think that much of Weill's American music, though less sophisticated or sardonic, is just as good as the European, and I would certainly not say that "Weill's show tunes do not make the Big Five [Gershwin, Porter, Berlin, Kern and Rodgers] into the Big Six."
QUITE aside from his classical music, Weill as a theater composer and chansonnier has produced marvels that surpass the Big Five. To cite only a few: "Nanna's Song" (the 1939 setting of an earlier Brecht lyric, as a birthday gift for Lenya), the "Epitaph" for Rosa Luxemburg from "The Berlin Requiem," "Surabaya Johnny" from "Happy End," "Fennimore's Song" from "Silverlake," "Captain Valentine's Tango" from "Johnny Johnson," "Trouble Man" from "Lost in the Stars" -- these and many others strike me as out of the reach of the best popular composers. It is Weill's know-how as a classical composer, simplified (but without condescension) for the popular ear, that elevates such pieces, above Gershwin even, to the realms of Hugo Wolf and Henri Duparc. This is consistent with Weill's aim "to reach the real people, a more representative public than any opera house attracts."
Yet even though he conscientiously addresses Weill's classical music, Mr. Taylor, I believe, underestimates that, too. He does, to be sure, like the programmatic First Symphony, which I find showy and sprawling, but he is unenthusiastic about the Neo-Classical Violin Concerto and the visceral Second Symphony -- even the charming early Cello Sonata -- which I would squarely add to the standard repertory. He is, however, aware of the importance of Weill's many writings about music, and makes good, if not extensive, use of them.
Where Mr. Taylor is particularly helpful is in limning Weill against the background of the musicians of his time. Many composers regarded him with the kind of snideness that brings to mind Debussy's remark on "The Rite of Spring": "It's primitive music with all the modern conveniences." Especially condescending (and, I suspect, envious) were such men as Aaron Copland and Virgil Thomson -- and even Marc Blitzstein, whose only real success was a cuckoo's egg in Weill's nest; indeed, among Americans, only Elliott Carter showed fair-mindedness. In England, Constant Lambert recognized "The Seven Deadly Sins" as "the most important work in ballet form since 'Les Noces' and 'Parade,' " although Brecht's text takes it even beyond that. And the view from the top? Stravinsky greatly liked both Weill and his music, but Arnold Schoenberg declared: "Franz Lehar, yes; Weill, no. His is the only music in the world in which I find no quality at all." As Mr. Taylor aptly comments, "One feels sorrier for Schoenberg and the twelve-tone-row boys than for Weill."
Finally, though, the problem with "Kurt Weill: Composer in a Divided World" is the lack of a governing idea, a point of view. There are two important threads that run through the book, both of which Mr. Taylor could have done more with. He almost does justice by the first, Weill's amazing adaptability. Wherever he lived -- Berlin, Paris, New York -- Weill promptly gauged the tastes, needs and idiosyncrasies of his audience, and produced good work as if to order. The man fell on his feet, humanly and musically, wherever history swept him.
Thus, as Mr. Taylor tells us, even "the style of his letters to Ira Gershwin, written in idiomatic English, mimics that of Ira's letters to him with uncanny accuracy -- the same conversational, almost playful tone, the same lingering over matters of slight import. . . . To Brecht, on the other hand, he writes briskly and to the point -- sober, practical letters with a minimum of sentiment. It is as though he were assuming his partner's persona." The magnificent chameleon aspect -- but with a firm, solid backbone -- is there in the book.
Of the other red thread, Mr. Taylor seems only dimly aware: Weill's relationship to his Jewishness. The son of a cantor, with siblings who were Orthodox Jews, Kurt himself was a lifelong nonbeliever. He refused (as Durrenmatt once remarked about the writer Walter Mehring) "to seek his salvation in a world view, let alone in a political party"; still less in a religion. Yet he retained a distinctly dual attitude toward Judaism. "He was," Mr. Taylor writes, "a European composer who was a Jew, not a Jewish composer." Who or what is a "Jewish composer"? Darius Milhaud? Ernest Bloch? Leonard Bernstein? But Mr. Taylor may be right in contending that Weill's "experience of the Gesamtkunstwerk [total work of art] of the synagogue service, during the years he spent in his parents' home, played its own part in heightening his susceptibility to the power of drama."
As an impoverished music student during Berlin's horrendous inflation in the early 1920's, Weill supplemented his subsidy from a wealthy uncle by playing the organ in a synagogue by day, and the piano in a Bierkeller till late in the night. What could better emblematize the German Jewish experience? The only significant "Jewish" work Weill composed in Europe was the 1923 oratorio "Recordare: Lamentations of the Prophet Jeremiah," well characterized by Mr. Taylor as "a confusing, problematical" piece. In America, however, he wrote a number of works on Jewish subjects, ranging from the biblical drama "The Eternal Road," which brought him to the United States from France in 1935, through various propaganda pageants for a Jewish state in Palestine, all the way to an orchestral setting of "Hatikvah," the Israeli national anthem.
On the other hand, the young Weill told his brother Hanns, "Never will a Jew write a work like the 'Moonlight' Sonata." In 1924, he wrote his mother about his "profound contempt for these Jewish circles," whereas "the other Jews -- the assimilators and the Zionists -- are . . . totally impossible." When his opera "Die Burgschaft," written with Caspar Neher, failed in 1932, Weill said that it was not "only nationalist and anti-Semitic circles that stood in the way of . . . modern theater. . . . The blame lies at least as much with the wishy-washy, spineless attitude of the liberals," who, then as now, included a great many Jews. And even while collaborating with Ben Hecht on rabble-rousingly Zionist superspectacles in the 40's, Weill deplored to Maxwell Anderson "Hecht's silly one-man campaign against the English [sic] empire."
Mr. Taylor might have given this dichotomy more than cursory attention; it may be that the "divided world" of his subtitle was not so much around as inside Kurt Weill. But, then, Mr. Taylor has a tendency not to think things through. Thus he observes, to its supposed advantage, that John Gay's "Beggar's Opera" helped topple a government, whereas its derivative, "The Threepenny Opera," for all its splashy popularity, changed nothing. Yet later on, as he well knows, the songs from "The Threepenny Opera" and "Mahagonny," outlawed by the Nazis, became clandestine hymns of hope and resistance, just as one of Weill's French songs, "J'Attends un Navire," became an anthem of the underground. Surely those are political achievements, though nothing to measure artistic worth by.
Mr. Taylor's insufficiency, however, is at its most glaring in grammar, spelling, usage and style. I can give only a few examples of his numerous offenses: "disinterest" for lack of interest, "parameters" for perimeters, "anxious" for eager, "Germanies" for Germanys, "Louis B. Meyer" for Mayer, "Adele Astaire" for Adele, the subjunctive "were" in a statement not contrary to fact, "psychotic" for neurotic (about the heroine of "Lady in the Dark"), the nonexistent "self-reproachment," the gross redundancy "general consensus," and so on. Stylistically, things get even worse, what with frequent overwriting, or a sentence containing a fourfold "which," topped off with a jingling "pitched." I checked the galleys I read against the finished book, but found only one error corrected: a reference to the Neil Simon Theater as the "John Simon Theater." That one I would have kept.
Ferruccio Busoni, Weill's illustrious teacher, once scornfully asked his pupil, "What do you want to become, the poor man's Verdi?" Weill retorted, "Is that so bad?" A biography, even flawed, that helps him to his rightful place should be welcomed with at least guarded approval.
 
 
 
KURT'S BAD DREAMS
 That sensitivity to the feelings of others which so endeared Weill to those around him was affectionately recalled by Maxwell Anderson in a little story from the time of the tryouts of "One Touch of Venus":
"Once when Kurt was in Boston with the tryout of a musical he came downstairs to have breakfast with the producers, the lyric writer and the man who wrote the book for the show. He found them all sitting about the table over black coffee discussing the problems of the play and the sleepless night they had spent. Each one described the sleeping pills or prescription which he had tried and which had failed, and then turned to Kurt and asked wearily how he slept.
" 'Oh, fine,' Kurt said, because he had slept well and always did. Then he realized that they all hated him for that answer, and he added gloomily: 'But I had bad dreams.' " -- From "Kurt Weill."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 10, 1993, Sunday

A picture caption on Dec. 13 with a review of "Kurt Weill: Composer in a Divided World" included an erroneous identification, from the book, for an actor in the 1943 production of "One Touch of Venus." He was John Boles.

PUB-DATE: December 13, 1992

SECTION: Section 13CN; Page 2; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1549 words

HEADLINE: THE VIEW FROM: STAFFORD;
Old Mill Town Revived By Foreign Investment

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
AT one time Connecticut's textile industry was world renowned, employing tens of thousands of people and accounting for much of the state's manufacturing base.
Today, textile employment in Connecticut has shrunk to 2,600 jobs -- representing less than 0.2 percent of all employment in the state -- with a loss of more than 100 jobs in the last year alone. It would seem like a dying industry for Connecticut. 
 But not in the northeast part of the state. The Warren of Stafford textile mill has undergone a $30 million renovation, and over the next few years $21 million more will be spent on further expansion and improvements. In three years, employment is expected to exceed its original level of 300 employees, up from the current 200 employees now working there.
No one seems bothered that it took an Italian company to save the mills. Loro Piana, headquartered in Quarona, about a half-hour drive northeast of Milan, bought the struggling Warren Woolen Company and Cyril Johnson Woolen Company in 1988. It abandoned the upholstery business the Johnson company had pursued, and focused on the fine camel hair and cashmere fabric Warren has produced since 1883. Loro Piana brought in the latest in textile manufacturing equipment and technicians to train people here how to use it.
The plant manager, Robert V. Modica, a vice president with Loro Piana, said American textile manufacturers had tried to continue the strategies that made them successful in the first half of the century, but fell behind the rest of the world.
"They did not invest, they did not modernize," Mr. Modica observed. "Some of the equipment here when we came in dated to the 1940's and 1950's. How are you going to compete with the Germans and the Italians who have equipment of the 1990's?"
 
Specializing in Quality Fabric
 Mr. Modica's message is perhaps less unsettling since he is not a foreigner bashing the United States. He was born in Dayton, Ohio, 30 years ago, and although he spent some of his younger years in Italy, he graduated from Vanderbilt University in Nashville, and worked at the New York-based Benetton before he was hired to manage Warren of Stafford in 1988.
Mr. Modica said Warren could never compete with cheaper fabrics produced with low-wage labor in Southeast Asia, but it had already carved out a niche in the high-end fabric market, and there is tremendous room for growth.
"I see it as an example of what American industry should be trying to accomplish -- investing heavily in capital equipment, and looking at the business really long term," Mr. Modica said. "I see it as the most modern textile producing facility in the United States."
Stafford is the stereotypical New England mill town. The railroad station in the heart of downtown still has the sign out front, "Stafford, population 12,000, elevation 479 feet," and benches that are not even bolted down. An ailing President John Adams came to Stafford in the late 1700's for the mineral springs that made the town famous. The water power of several rivers made it one of the leaders of the Industrial Revolution, with iron mills in the 18th century and textile mills replacing them in the 19th century.
 
Mainstays Have Disappeared
 But things have changed. Riverside Woolen Company went out the business in the 1950's. Swift River, Glenville Worsted, and Stafford Worsted, once the town's business mainstays, have since gone under. Today, under the American flag in front of the Warren company store flies the flag of Italy. Inside, there are $200 suit jackets and even more expensive women's wear, not exactly standard fare for thrifty Yankees.
Still, employees approve of Loro Piana's tactics. Under Mr. Modica, there has been extensive repainting and new ventilation. Bare hanging incandescent bulbs, common in old mills, have given way to energy efficient, brighter fluorescent fixtures.
From the mill's reception area, there is a view of a room where banks of powerful computers hum, keeping track of production and warning of possible problems. Instead of low-paid laborers, the company employs people who have to know how to run the terminals scattered throughout the building.
Wendy Batz was recently trimming fabric in the finishing area of the plant, stopping occasionally to check orders on her screen. She has worked at the plant since 1979, and said that the technology was probably the most remarkable change. "There was one computer, maybe, before," Ms. Batz said. "It was in accounting. I never had one, and now I don't know what we'd do without them. When the system shuts down you're in trouble, you've come to depend on them so much."
 
Improvements Allay Shutdown Fears
 Town officials, too, approve of the changes at Warren, where the brick and stone facades have been cleaned and sandblasted, where hedges and trees have been planted and flower boxes installed.
"I worked in woolen mills when I was young, and I tell you, you can't believe how immaculate this is," said Stafford First Selectman Benjamin Muzio. "They've brought some pride to our community. They're going to prove textiles can survive in New England."
In many towns the purchase of a big mill by a foreign competitor was the prelude to a shutdown. Mr. Muzio said, however, that Loro Piana's investments quickly allayed any fears. "They're putting big money into the town," Mr. Muzio said. "They wouldn't be doing that if they weren't going to stay."
Mr. Modica said the biggest problem renovating the mills had been modernizing the equipment. There were 12 carding machines when he arrived, for instance, but only four of the units that convert raw wool into yarn could be upgraded sufficiently to meet his needs. In Italy the warehouse operation is computerized, and the inventory is retrieved by robots, but Mr. Modica's staff still hauls hand-labeled boxes out from beneath tables by hand. Mr. Modica is in the process of refurbishing the finishing department, from machines where someone watches the entire process and gauges how much soap is needed in the washing machinery, to automated equipment that does all that itself.
"The operator's role has changed, Mr. Modica said. "He's basically monitoring the machine today, as opposed to dumping in a bucket of soapy water."
Mr. Modica said if Loro Piana wanted to continue to compete in world markets its modernization would never be finished. "Believing as we do in the product, we've got to continually to invest in modern equipment, reorganization of the plant, training of the personnel, and so on," he said.
So far, the strategy seems to be working. Warren gets much of its raw material from overseas -- cashmere and camel hair from China and Mongolia, wool from merino sheep in Australia and New Zealand -- but Warren now exports about 15 percent of its product, and the amount is growing every year. Mr. Modica said his long-term plan was to have the mill begin producing the finer worsted yarns, which are even more in demand abroad.
The state Department of Economic Development is enthusiastic about what Warren is accomplishing, said a spokesman, Joseph Cohen, and it has given the company an $800,000 grant toward its expansion program, and the promise of at least $200,000 in tax relief.
"Connecticut is not going to return to the days when textiles were a significant part of its industrial base, but it shows international manufacturers can thrive here," Mr. Cohen said.
Mr. Cohen said Warren's exports to Europe and other places where there was intense competition in quality fabrics showed that Connecticut, in particular, was a place where manufacturers should come when they want quality.
"It's a reflection of the quality of Connecticut workers and, to some extent, the tradition of quality manufacturing, including textiles, that made Connecticut a very wealthy state," Mr. Cohen said. "People really work hard here, and they do a good job."
The transition has been bumpy in a few spots. Because of the more sophisticated manufacturing equipment, more than 120 workers were laid off when Loro Piana took over. In addition, the work rules changed, to the chagrin of at least one local entrepreneur.
Kirsten A. Morascini, who with her husband, David, owns the Springs House bar and grill across the street from the textile mill, said the company no longer permitted employees to go there for lunch, a century-old tradition, because they are not allowed to leave the grounds.
 
Liability Problems
 "This was a very popular place with the workers until 1988," Mrs. Morascini said. "They used to meet here, have a beer and a sandwich, play some pool, and go back to work."
She was also a bit disgruntled by the state assistance Loro Piana received.
"So the mill gets a million dollars to expand their business, and meanwhile all the small businesses that have grown up around it are losing their trade," Mrs. Morascini said.
Mr. Morascini, however, said he could understand the liability problems of allowing employees to have even a single beer at lunch, then returning to operate sophisticated yet dangerous machinery. He said that in Mr. Modica's place he would do the same.
"He's got to do what he's got to do," Mr. Morascini said. "It's a great place, and he's doing good things for the town."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Warren of Stafford textile company has evolved with a $30 million renovation. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

STATE: CONNECTICUT, USA (95%); OHIO, USA (79%); TENNESSEE, USA (79%); NEW YORK, USA (79%); NORTHEAST USA (79%); 

CITY: DAYTON, OH, USA (52%);
