HEADLINE: A la Carte;
Seasoned Hands Take On New Restaurant Ventures

BYLINE: By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM

 BODY:
DESPITE the recession and softness in restaurant business, the big are growing bigger on Long Island. The expansions, evident in recent months, are far from over. These are some changes in the last few weeks:
*The owners of Navona in Great Neck and Il Tulipano in Huntington opened Stresa in Manhasset. 
 *Pomodoro of Port Washington and Huntington expanded to Great Neck.
*Jerry Della Femina, whose restaurant in East Hampton opened at the end of the East End summer season, joined with some partners and purchased Wings Point on Three Mile Harbor.
*La Viola of Cedarhurst and Fort Myers, Fla., branched out to Syosset.
*Jholla, an Indian restaurant in Smithtown, opened a carryout in Huntington.
 
Fourth Site Sought
 The owners of La Viola are looking for a fourth site, in the Great Neck-Manhasset region, and Jholla plans to open restaurants in Syosset-Woodbury, Stony Brook-Port Jefferson and Westbury.
Pomodoro is considering an outlet in Syosset, and Rothmann's of East Norwich, which has been empty since the American Bistro failed to renew its lease on its property a year ago, will reopen in the spring. The 200-seat restaurant has been leased by the owners of the Empress Diner in East Meadow.
Although the owners of Navona and Il Tulipano recently opened Stresa, they have already given some thought to a fourth restaurant after their newest venture is solidly established.
Gino Gianuzzi, the sole or part owner of La Caravella in Hicksville, Caffe Donatello in Plainview, Villa Parma in Syosset and La Pizzetta in East Norwich, is looking into establishing a fifth restaurant.
Jholla and the new restaurant at Rothmann's, which will probably be called the East Norwich Restaurant and Lounge, have begun expanding.
Construction has started at the Rothmann's site, where the sagging front porch has been removed. An American restaurant featuring steaks, chops, seafood and pasta is planned. Mike Panagatos, who formerly owned and managed Paddy's Clam House in Manhattan, plans to open the restaurant in the spring in collaboration with other members of his family.
Sewa Arora, who in early October opened Jholla, an Indian takeout in Huntington Village that he hopes to expand into a sit-down restaurant, has detailed plans for three additional sites.
Mr. Arora believes that the lack of volume at Indian restaurants on the Island has made Indian food more expensive than it should be. He intends to introduce modestly priced family-style Indian dining to the Island. "I think I can offer complete Indian dinners for under $10," he said. "Children will be able to eat for less than $5."
All three of Mr. Arora's new restaurants will also feature carryout food. He hopes to open the first such restaurant in the Syosset-Woodbury area in February or March.
Until recently, Danford's Inn of Port Jefferson was known more for its lovely harborside setting and view than for its food. Three months ago, things began to change.
Stephen J. Meade was hired as the chef. Mr. Meade, a graduate of the Culinary Institute of America, earned kudos for his innovative dishes as executive chef at the Garden City Hotel. Before that, he cooked at La Cote Basque, Le Perigord Park and the Helmsley Palace in Manhattan.
The menu, kitchen and philosophy at Danford's are undergoing major changes. The conservative pedestrian menu of old-fashioned seafood, steaks and chops has been modernized.
The new contemporary bill of fare includes sauteed almond-crusted chicken breast with a honey glaze and wild rice ($17.50), Atlantic salmon grilled over mesquite wood and thyme and served with a green lentil salad ($19.50) and bouillabaise a la Marsaillaise ($21.95). These dishes are being created in a completely new kitchen.
Danford's Inn is also featuring a series of food-and-wine dinners. The six-course meals, accompanied by five wines, cost $65, including tax and tip.
Menus for the January and February dinners are not available. Two dishes served at the wine dinner last month were smoked chicken rissoto cake with arugula and julienne vegetables and roast loin of New Zealand venison en croute, with dried-cherry cumberland sauce and spaghetti squash.
OPENINGS: The Afghan Samovar, 4994 Sunrise Highway, Massapequa Park (798-9000), is the most recent of a number of Afghan restaurants to open on Long Island.
The 50-seat storefront, which was once a Kentucky Fried Chicken outlet, is owned by three partners -- Hakim Ghiasi, Assad Reuspa and Abdul Khalil -- who operate 18 Mama's Fried Chicken fast-food restaurants in New York City.
Afghan Samovar is housed in a building filled with Afghan carpets, antiques and pictures. A modestly priced restaurant, it features kebab dishes. Entrees are $7.95 to $14, soups and salads cost $2 and $2.50 and most appetizers are priced at $2.50 and $3.
The venison dishes being offered over the holidays at Cafe Max, 85 Montauk Highway, East Hampton (324-2004), are a last-minute entry on the restaurant's menu.
The chef, Morris Weintraub, has never been satisfied with the quality of the venison available from regular commercial sources. But when a hunter friend of his offered a freshly killed, 150-pound deer to the restaurant, Mr. Weintraub accepted.
Cafe Max is serving a $35, four-course, roast leg of venison dinner that includes chateau potatoes, mixed vegetables, apple cake and beverage, plus a half-carafe per person of Gristina or Santa Marina merlot or Undurraga Chilean cabernet sauvignon. The roast leg of venison served a la carte with poivrad and a mixed salad is also available for $20.
A dish of saddle of venison for $22 is going to be on the menu on Christmas Eve. The restaurant also plans to serve a five-course roast-quail New Year's Eve dinner for $55.
The Pindar Winery on Main Street in Peconic is serving free hot mulled wine and cornbread to all who visit its tasting room for the holiday season.

HEADLINE: Action Urged on L.I. Sound Cleanup

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
AFTER seven years and $15 million, a long-awaited and controversial plan to clean up Long Island Sound is about to be released, even though a specially commissioned computer model -- due two years ago and essential for developing certain proposals for the ailing estuary -- is still not finished.
While members of the Long Island Sound Study policy committee say they are frustrated by the delays in the computer model, they have taken a long-range approach to solving the estuary's problems. They are confident that in the years to come their plan, which has been financed by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, will reverse at least some of the environmental damage suffered by the 1,300-square-mile waterway. 
 And although they also cite steps that have already been taken to mitigate pollution in the Sound, their plan has generated much criticism, especially since Nov. 27, when a draft of the final proposal was released.
 
Results Being Sought, Not Promises
 Environmentalists, elected officials and representatives of the construction industry who have grown impatient with promises of long-range cures and intermediary steps, are clamoring for stronger action. They say any further delays are unacceptable, and they want a firmer plan to clean up the Sound.
Environmentalists say that proposals contained in the draft are too weak to be effective. They also say that the public, tired of repeated beach closings and fish kills during the summer months, wants results that can be seen right away and not promises of solutions.
The environmentalists, moreover, are quick to point out the political ramifications of further delays. With the advent next month of the Clinton Administration, which appears sympathetic to their causes, the Long Island Sound Study must act now to develop project proposals or be overlooked when funds for other projects are allocated, they claim.
"We've got to get our ducks in line," said Jeffrey M. Kane, program coordinator for the Citizens Campaign for the Environment, an advocacy group representing 85,000 members in New York and Connecticut.
"I'm aghast at the lack of forward movement on this plan," Mr. Kane said from his office in White Plains. "It's a disservice to the public."
In Connecticut, Lawrence A. Bock, outreach coordinator for the Long Island Sound Task Force, a Stamford-based education and advocacy organization representing 1,200 members, criticized the plan as "vague and nonspecific" and lacking firm deadlines for getting projects off the ground.
"We're pushing for programs now, because the Sound can't wait any longer, and the fish can't wait," Mr. Bock said. "The Clinton Administration presents an unprecedented opportunity to get things done."
But Gordon C. Colvin, Director of Marine Resources for the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, challenged the environmentalists' claims that remediation must begin at once.
Mr. Colvin said: "Are we in immediate danger of seeing marine life wiped out? No."
The Long Island Sound Study -- which has involved Federal, state, interstate and local agencies, universities, environmental groups, industry and the general public -- recently recommended a no-net-gain policy for the amount of nitrogen entering the Sound from sewage-treatment plants. Scientists say the nitrogen contributes to reduced levels of dissolved oxygen in the Sound, and when there are severely depleted levels, a condition known as hypoxia, free-swimming organisms flee in search of more aerated waters, and slower-moving marine life, like lobsters and other crustaceans, sometimes die off.
 
A Middle Ground Proposed
 "Clearly, if hypoxia gets worse, there is the potential for a long-lasting impact," Mr. Colvin said. "It is difficult to estimate exactly the dangers of waiting, but in the short run, I don't believe there will be a problem."
He added that it will take "many, many years, at least a decade and maybe more," to solve the Sound's problems.
And while many environmentalists were critical of the long-range approach and said they had hoped for more than just a no-net-gain policy now, the Long Island Soundkeeper, Terry E. Backer, who patrols the Sound and investigates pollution problems, suggested a middle ground.
"We should be careful not to throw out the baby with the bath water," Mr. Backer said from the offices of the Long Island Soundkeeper Fund in Norwalk. "I agree that the plan is vague and not stringent enough, but it is a lot better than what we had before."
"Clearly, we all agree that we can't just sprinkle fairy dust over the Sound and make the problems go away," he said.
A serious point of contention for Mr. Backer and other environmentalists is the minimum goals set in the plan for dissolved oxygen levels in the Sound. The draft plan says that oxygen concentrations should never fall below 1.5 parts per million to avoid lethal effects to marine life. Environmentalists, on the other hand, say the minimum oxygen level must be set higher.
Both sides, though, have come together in their anger over the delay in the three-dimensional computer model, which scientists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration of the Department of Commerce were supposed to complete in 1989.
The $3 million computer model will be able to simulate different remediation plans for the Sound to see which will be most effective, said Mark Tedesco, director of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency's Long Island Sound office in Stamford.
For example, a computer model that shows how water mixes in the estuary could pinpoint how individual waste-water-treatment plants that discharge nitrogen into the Sound are affecting overall water quality, Mr. Tedesco said. It would also reinforce the Long Island Sound Study's recommendations for future plant upgrading and provide detailed information for grant applications.
"We share the environmentalists' concerns on the delay," said Robert L. Bendick, deputy commissioner for Natural Resources in the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation and the state's representative to the Long Island Sound Study policy committee. "It's more than concern. We're very, very frustrated."
Mr. Bendick also expressed the fear that proposed Environmental Protection Agency budgetary cuts for next year may hamper some of the work of the Long Island Sound Study.
But he disagreed with much of the criticism and said the study did include specific goals and that changes were being made to treatment plants to hold the line on nitrogen entering the Sound.
To speed release of the computer model, Congressional representatives from New York and Connecticut recently backed legislation that would put the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Agency's "feet to the fire," as Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat from the 18th Congressional District in New York, described it. The legislation withholds financing for the agency's other projects until it completes the Sound model.
"First things first," Ms. Lowey said. "We want a firm commitment from them that this work will be done."
Ms. Lowey and Rosa L. DeLauro, a Democrat from Connecticut's Third Congressional District, introduced the DeLauro-Lowey Water Pollution Control and Estuary Restoration Financing Act during the last Congressional session. The proposed bill, scheduled to be reintroduced early next year, links job projects with cleanup of the Sound and other estuaries.
A new coalition of environmentalists and representatives of the construction industry is also pushing for strong action on the Sound. Last winter, labor union workers, building trades leaders and environmentalists in Westchester formed the Clean Water Jobs Coalition to lobby for capital improvement projects -- like upgrading waste-water-treatment plants -- that would not only improve water quality in the Sound but would also create jobs in the construction industry.
"The politics is now," said David J. Miller, Northeast regional vice president for the National Audubon Society and a founder of the Clean Water Jobs Coalition. "If this conservation and management plan lacks courage, the Long Island Sound will miss the train to Washington, and that would be a tragedy."
The coalition that began in White Plains has since expanded to include environmentalists and union representatives nationwide, and it is lobbying for financing to improve estuary sites, the Great Lakes and other American waterways.
Ross J. Pepe, president of the Construction Industry Council of Westchester and Hudson Valley and a member of the coalition, said money for plant and sewer system upgrades would "provide a much-needed shot in the arm" for construction workers.
Modifications and upgrading of sewage-treatment systems on Long Island and in New York City, Westchester and Connecticut will cost about $6 billion, officials have estimated.
"The environmentalists, the building trades, we're in this together," said Mr. Pepe, whose trade organization represents about 500 businesses. "We're coming out of a recession, and a setback now would be devastating."
The no-net-gain policy for the amount of nitrogen going into the Sound could mean a moratorium on new construction, Mr. Pepe said. Specific recommendations for plant upgrades, on the other hand, will mean new jobs and allow for construction of new homes and buildings.
On Thursday in Stamford, the proposals in the Sound Study's management report will be reviewed and possibly modified to include some of the recent recommendations made by environmentalists, Mr. Tedesco said. Once the study's policy committee authorizes release of the plan, probably later this month, it will be open to public comment at a series of meetings.

HEADLINE: Three Very Rare Generations

BYLINE: By Eric Foner; Eric Foner, the DeWitt Clinton Professor of History at Columbia University, taught in 1990 at Moscow State University as Fulbright Lecturer in American History.

 BODY:

SOUL TO SOUL
A Black Russian American Family 1865-1992.
By Yelena Khanga with Susan Jacoby.
Illustrated. 318 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $22.95. 
 AMONG its other consequences, the demise of the Soviet Union has released an emigration of foreign-born leftists and their descendants. Along with Spanish Loyalists and exiled third-world socialists now returning to their countries of origin, this little-noticed diaspora includes Yelena Khanga, the granddaughter of a black American who had moved to the Soviet Union in 1931, along with his Polish-Jewish-American wife. "Soul to Soul: A Black Russian American Family 1865-1992" tells the remarkable story of Ms. Khanga's family, shedding light into unfamiliar corners of both the Soviet and American pasts. Its title derives from a Russian expression for close friendship. In an American context, it also suggests encounters among blacks, and the book's most interesting chapters recount the story of the black side of Ms. Khanga's family tree.
Her great-grandfather, Hilliard Golden, born a slave, served on the board of supervisors in Yazoo County, Miss., during Reconstruction, and managed to become one of the areas's largest black landowners (Ms. Khanga is not sure how). The restoration of white supremacy abruptly ended his political career, but Golden clung tenaciously to his property until 1909, when, like many other farmers in the New South, he succumbed to debt and lost his land.
Golden's son Oliver, the author's grandfather, studied agronomy at Tuskegee Institute, and served in the Army during World War I. Disillusioned by his experience in the military (like most black soldiers, he was kept far from the front lines, working as a cook), and by the fact that the only job he could find in postwar America was as a railway waiter, he gravitated to the Communist Party. Defying the powerful social stigma attached to interracial relationships, Oliver Golden entered a common-law marriage with Bertha Bialek, a young garment worker who had emigrated from Poland and had become a Communist while working in the sweatshops of New York's garment center in the 1920's.
In 1931, with 15 other Americans -- black agricultural specialists and their families -- Ms. Khanga's grandparents sailed for the Soviet Union to help develop cotton cultivation in Uzbekistan. The poverty and backwardness of the region, where polygamy still flourished, reinforced the Goldens' sense of socialist mission. When their daughter, Lily, was born, they decided to remain in the Soviet Union "because they did not want to raise a racially mixed child in America." The agricultural experiments succeeded, and Stalin then decreed that Uzbekistan should concentrate exclusively on cotton, transforming the area, ironically, into a one-crop economy bearing some resemblance to the South of Golden's youth.
Oliver Golden died in 1940. Bertha survived to 1985, supporting herself by teaching English, and never abandoning her Communist convictions. Lily Golden, the author's mother, became a scholar at the African Institute in Moscow, and married Abdullah Khanga, a political leader from Zanzibar studying in the Soviet Union. Their marriage was ill starred, for Khanga expected his wife to behave like an African Muslim woman of the most traditional sort -- for example, she was forbidden to speak when other men were present.
Yelena Khanga was born in Moscow in 1962. Her father was bitterly disappointed that she was not a son, and did not even pick up his wife and daughter at the hospital. When he returned to Africa a few months later, Lily declined to follow. Like her own parents, although for different reasons, Lily Khanga did not want her daughter to be raised in a land that could not accord her a semblance of equality. In 1965, Abdullah Khanga was murdered by political opponents.
Thus Ms. Khanga grew up in a three-generation female household, a situation not uncommon, she notes, either in black America or in Russia, where divorce is prevalent and child raising a female duty. She was brought up to take pride in her black heritage and to rely on her own talents. She studied journalism at Moscow State University and worked for a time as a singer at the Cosmos Hotel (where she was billed as "Lolita from America"). In 1984 she landed a job at Moscow News, shortly before glasnost transformed it from a dull party organ into a muckraking journal exposing the underside of Soviet life.
Ms. Khanga is a bit older than the students I encountered in 1990, when I taught American history at Moscow State, but her book reflects many attitudes of the generation that came of age in the 1980's. Like my students, she was shocked by the revelations about Soviet society that glasnost made possible (as a reporter, she discovered grinding rural poverty on the outskirts of Moscow and found entrenched corruption in institutions like Intourist). Like them, she is fascinated by history, but prone to nostalgia for the prerevolutionary past, as if Stalin had invented Russian poverty, and neither prison camps nor stifling bureaucracy had existed under the czars.
In one respect, however, Ms. Khanga's outlook differs from that of the young people I encountered, who, along with Moscow News itself during glasnost's heyday, adopted the United States as a substitute utopia. Her friends, she notes, were unable to understand how anyone could leave the American paradise for the Soviet Union, even during the Depression. Ms. Khanga's background allowed her to appreciate that the Communist Party was then virtually the only predominantly white organization actively recruiting black members, and to empathize with her grandparents' exhilaration at living in a land where blacks could order a meal in any restaurant and enter a hotel through the front door.
Unlike many young Russians today, even those who have visited the United States, Ms. Khanga is fully aware of the less attractive features of American life. Seeing firsthand the black poverty in the Mississippi Delta in 1991 while searching for her family on a Rockefeller Foundation grant was, in a way, as disillusioning as her first glimpse of living conditions in rural Russia. She was pained to discover that the Jewish side of her family had rejected her grandmother for marrying a black man. (When Lily was born, Bertha Bialek sent a snapshot to her mother. "Is the child a shvartse?" Ms. Khanga's great-grandmother asked. When the answer was positive, she tore up the photo without looking at it.)
Ms. Khanga is careful to distinguish racism from the prejudices she encountered while growing up in the Soviet Union. Although sometimes treated as an exotic, she says she did not suffer overt discrimination. Her family's problems stemmed from the system's repressiveness (like many scholars before glasnost, her mother was unable to travel abroad) and from a general suspicion of foreigners, which led many Russians to distrust her family. Indeed, one of Ms. Khanga's more original observations is that racism, which she rarely encountered as a child, is now growing in Russia not only because of conflicts among the former Soviet Union's many nationalities, but also as a byproduct of increased contacts with the United States.
Such unexpected reflections, however, are not typical of "Soul to Soul." Too often, where thoughtful insights are called for, she falls back on familiar cliches ("individual initiative comes hard when it has always been discouraged") or meaningless bromides ("Africa isn't Eden, it's a vast, complicated continent"). Then too, the book's breezy style (presumably the contribution of the co-author, Susan Jacoby) tends to trivialize the events Ms. Khanga recounts.
IN the end, despite her family's unusual and fascinating odyssey, "Soul to Soul" somehow adds up to less than the sum of its component parts. Perhaps the problem lies in the genre itself. As in many family histories, the story seems to lose energy when it reaches the present generation. Ms. Khanga has witnessed momentous changes in the past few years, but the lives of her ancestors -- slaves seizing freedom, immigrants crossing the Atlantic, men and women moved by injustice and hoping to build a new society -- seem to have occupied a larger stage than her own. The problems of finding an understanding hairdresser in Moscow, or dealing with various Soviet lovers, pale before the challenges surmounted by her forebears.
In the course of her research, Ms. Khanga unexpectedly discovered that her mother had already been born when her grandparents renounced their American citizenship during the Stalin purges in 1936. As a result, while reared in the Soviet Union, both Lily Golden Khanga and her daughter Yelena, the author, retained a claim to American citizenship. However Yelena Khanga reconciles the complex strands of her ancestry in the future, she has, in "Soul to Soul," already made a contribution to retrieving a piece of the Soviet Union's unknown history.

LENGTH: 941 words

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Hollywood's Tree Gets the Spartan Look

BYLINE: By Anne Thompson; Anne Thompson is a Los Angeles-based writer.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
"THOSE were the days," laments Russell Schwartz, an independent film distributor with fond memories of Hollywood Christmases past. During the 1980's boom, he recalls, "we used to get 10-cup coffee makers, big thick argyle sweaters and big boxes of frozen steaks."
Not so now. The trend in the recession-hit entertainment industry -- once the epitome of holiday largesse -- is toward cheaper gifts, or none at all, or, for the politically correct, a card announcing a contribution to charity. 
 One Hollywood press agent says she's so poor, she won't be sending out any Christmas presents this season. Nancy Nigrosh, a literary agent, says: "It's going to be a lean year. Everybody has already spent their money."
Last year, Universal Pictures made one of its production vice presidents fork over $1,500, or half the cost of the 150 or so presents he was sending out to business friends. Also starting last year, Sony Entertainment requested that its divisions not send out holiday gifts at all -- unless to charity.
Much of Hollywood, in fact, now prefers to share with the less fortunate. Rather than ordering gift baskets full of Mrs. Beaseley's muffins, Trader Joe's wine or Godiva chocolates, they send season's greetings -- preferably on recycled paper -- with a gift to charity.
"Somewhere in the Reagan era, Hollywood OD'd on the arcane ritual exchange of needless foodstuffs," says Sean Daniel, the producer ("American Me"). "There's been an ever-increasing and welcome change to charitable donations and worthy causes, thanks to a combination of conscience, belt-tightening and some shred of decency." Among the industry's favorite charities: AIDS Project L.A., the Pediatric AIDS Foundation and the Hunger Project.
When serious spending goes on -- and some still does -- it is at the top of the Hollywood pyramid. "People give gifts to thank someone for something," says Marvin Antonowsky, executive vice president at Columbia Pictures, "or to build up future favors."
One director recalls a December visit in the late 80's to the office of Mark Canton, Warner Brothers production president at the time: "It was wall-to-wall gifts, hundreds of gifts people sent him and stuff going out the door."
"Mark is in a powerful position," explains one TriStar production executive. "He can make movies. He's likable. People want him to like them. Isn't that why you give people presents?"
"It's obeisance," says Jack Brodsky, the producer ("King Ralph"). "It's like what they do to the sultans."
Now chairman of Columbia Pictures, a unit of Sony, Mr. Canton "receives but doesn't send," a Columbia spokesman said. "He gives to charity."
In the "thank you" vein, when the Oscar-winning "Rain Man" was on its way to grossing $180 million, the director Barry Levinson's Baltimore Pictures sent out fresh seafood dinners -- lobster, crab, clams and potatoes -- on dry ice from Baltimore to those included on a lucky gift list.
Martin Ransohoff, the producer ("Jagged Edge"), recalls his favorite Christmas surprise: a nicely framed photograph of the actor Peter Sellers impersonating Adolf Hitler, signed "To Marty, with deep regards, Adolf Sellers." A bemused Mr. Ransohoff called Mr. Sellers and asked if he had done something to offend him. "I thought it would amuse you," came the reply.
Last Christmas, the director Richard Donner ("Lethal Weapon") gave his producer, Joel Silver, a custom-designed pinball machine featuring sounds and images from Mr. Silver's career. One year, Mr. Silver gave pairs of Frank Lloyd Wright candlesticks to key personnel on his HBO series "Tales from the Crypt."
The producers of television shows often make up a special Christmas gift for crew members. Allan Arkush, the director, said he still prizes his "St. Elsewhere" hospital bathrobe and "Shannon's Deal" key-chain. Because Mr. Arkush is in a position to hire people, he also receives gifts and cards from sound labs and production and costume designers and the like. "Companies tend to send the Fruit-of-the-Month club," he says. "It's all about the food chain."
Besides his best friends, Mr. Arkush, a music maven, sends gifts to the executive producers of his TV shows, his assistant directors and both his agents. "I don't buy a generic gift, like a case of wine," he says. "Buying laser-discs and CD's is the easiest way to personalize gifts. Thank Godfor boxed sets. But you can't go out and buy CD's for everyone; you'd go broke. This year I ordered some neat-looking unique cards with the covers of trashy novels on them, which may end up on some office coffee tables."
One independent film producer has a more strictly tiered gift-giving strategy, and so wants to remain anonymous: "For the 25 to 30 top people, I pick out something special," he says. "I send Mrs. Grace's cakes to a wider group. And the rest get Christmas cards. My assistant has become very proficient at gift-wrapping."
Many executives agree that gift-giving probably has very little real impact. Agents gave gifts every Christmas, one development executive said, so that they would "be remembered favorably and we'd pay more attention to their scripts." But it's not very effective, he said: "People forget instantly as soon as the season is over."
The owner of one top entertainment public relations firm admits that while its staff once dedicated much time and money toward putting together gifts each holiday season, "it didn't make people pay their bills any faster."
"I'm Scrooge," he says, when it comes to widespread giving. "What's important is to take care of our own: we give our staff a bonus. We sent out cards last year."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1432 words

HEADLINE: INVESTMENT NEEDS FOR A NEW RUSSIA ARE MOSTLY UNMET

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
Large-scale foreign economic and financial aid to Russia, which many economists still believe is essential for a transformation to a market economy, has been pushed off the international agenda by political uncertainties here and by a global recession that affects potential donors.
The political struggle in Russia between pro-market forces, led by President Boris N. Yeltsin, and legislators who resist the painful aspects of change leaves many Western investors and diplomats skeptical about investing large amounts. 
 Crucially, Western governments also say that they have run out of money to give Mr. Yeltsin, and that private investment will have to do the job.
 
German Cupboard Is Bare
 Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, whose country has provided nearly $50 billion in aid, loans and credit guarantees to Russia since 1989, will have little to offer other than export guarantees when he arrives Monday night, according to German officials, who say Mr. Kohl is coming mainly to show moral support for Mr. Yeltsin.
"Let other countries make a contribution now," said one German diplomat, echoing statements Mr. Kohl himself has made about Germany's having done more than its share.
Germany has also provided $11 billion in aid to the formerly Communist countries of Eastern Europe, more than a quarter of the assistance there.
 
Major Western Goal
 No goal of Western foreign policy is more important, in the view of many policymakers, than assuring the success of political and economic freedom in the former Soviet bloc. The Germans in particular say failure would be a disaster, and they fear mass social disorder and migration on a scale that would dwarf anything seen in the Balkans so far.
But the Germans' European partners have so far not answered the calls for more aid. Japanese aid and private investment have been held up by a political dispute with Moscow over sovereignty in the four southernmost Kurile Islands, in the Sea of Japan.
As with the Marshall Plan that led to the economic recovery of Europe after World War II, only the United States seems capable of leading an effective effort to put Russia back on its feet.
The Marshall Plan involved about $10 billion in 1948-1949 dollars, which at the time amounted to more than 2.5 percent of the United States gross national product. But the United States made the investment unhesitatingly because it had full confidence that the Europeans knew how to put the money to good use.
There is no such confidence about the Russians. And though some studies estimate that far less money, proportionately, would be required for a successful Marshall Plan for Russia in the 1990's, there appears little prospect that the United States, Europe or Japan is thinking about starting a comparable effort.
 
Private Investors Cautious
 Private investors from abroad appear to be waiting cautiously for the wrangling between Mr. Yeltsin and the Russian Parliament to end, and for the Russian state to create the clear legal basis they need to sink large amounts of capital into private ventures here.
"There are scores of letters of intent, protocols of intent and draft contracts, but nothing ever happens," said Suzana Matyushkina, an interpreter who has tried to help a group of American real estate investors get started here. They finally found more fruitful fields in Turkmenistan, where, she said, the bureaucratic obstacles were more tractable than in Moscow.
In Russia, as Dr. Lorenz Schomerus, an official of the German Economics Ministry said in Bonn recently, "a lot of business people plunged in enthusiastically, but there's more caution now."
[On Thursday, Mr. Yeltsin denounced his opponents in the legislature for attempting a "creeping coup" after the Congress of People's Deputies refused to confirm his Acting Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar, in office. A compromise between Mr. Yeltsin was announced two days later, reopening the issue of choosing a Prime Minister and calling for a referendum in April on constitutional questions.]
 
A Stunned Population
 The "shock therapy" for economic change that has been pushed vigorously by the Acting Prime Minister, Yegor T. Gaidar, is widely feared and little understood among Russians.
For most, Mr. Gaidar's program has meant a surge in prices of 25 percent a month and the loss of most of their savings. It has also brought forth a class of shady black-market speculators, loan sharks and petty thieves.
Bureaucratic and political arguments about property, investment and bankruptcy laws have been going on since mid-1991. Some foreign investors have taken the plunge anyway, but the amount of capital they have brought is far below the estimated needs for outside investment: at least $40 billion to $50 billion a year.
While the Soviet Union still stood, many Russians depended on the Germans, who provided huge amounts of money to secure Moscow's assent to German reunification two years ago.
 
Estimating the Needs
 But now Germany's hands are full rebuilding the economy of its eastern states, which have about 16.5 million people. A leading German economic institute recently suggested that rebuilding eastern Germany would require nearly $85 billion in investment in 1993 alone, 20 percent more than this year, plus almost as much in Government subsidies.
So far, because of the uncertainties, very few foreign companies have invested much in Russia. German net direct investment in Russia and the other former Soviet republics ammounted to under $10 million last year, while German companies made a net transfer of $300 million to Hungary, the German Economics Ministry in Bonn said.
In the first quarter of this year, according to East European Investment Magazine, United States companies invested $131.5 million in Russia, compared to $485.2 million in Poland.
"Eastern European countries have 40 years more experience with capitalism than the Russians have," said one United States official, attempting to explain the greater attractiveness.
"Net German private investment in Russia has not been very great," a German diplomat here said, "because there isn't a sound legal basis for anything. There's a decree by Yeltsin that says that if you build a factory, the land under it belongs to you, but there's also a law from the Parliament that says it can be taken away from you."
And much of the foreign investment has gone to service industries, not to the manufacturing base the Russians need. Some investors who have put money into production have been surprised by unexpected obstacles.
Phibro Energy, a United States company that put $116 million into a Siberian oil-producing venture, was later informed of an export tax of $6 on every barrel of oil shipped abroad, adding more than 25 percent to the market price and making the venture economically unfeasible. Phibro has appealed, but the matter is still unresolved.
"New taxes are imposed out of the blue, making nonsense of economic plans and forecasts by the investor," Brian Lavers, chairman of the company, said in London recently.
"Foreign direct investment has been the neglected child of Russian economic reform so far," said Alexander Papachristou, a lawyer with White & Case, which has been advising the Government on how to privatize industry. "If the reforms continue, there will be real opportunities for foreign investment. These things have to start small."
 
Russians Get Their Shares
 In the first broad step toward privatization, Russians are being issued vouchers with a face value of 10,000 rubles (worth about $25 at the current rate of exchange), which they can invest in companies that are being put up for sale. Privatization started with retail shops and small businesses, but in the next year, 60 to 70 percent of Russian medium and large factories are to become joint stock companies.
Mr. Yeltsin cannot be surprised by the lack of investor interest in Russia. Last summer he went to a meeting of the leading Western economic democracies in Munich hoping for help, but he left with little more than confirmation of previously agreed aid programs that the donors say amounted to $24 billion, some of which is conditional on further change here.
The International Monetary Fund also provided a $1 billion credit to Russia last summer, but another $3 billion has been delayed because of the lack of an agreement on monetary and budget policies. A planned $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble is not feasible now, I.M.F. officials here said, as long as the value of the ruble continues to fluctuate wildly.

SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1066 words

HEADLINE: Europe's 2 Faces: Economic Skill, Political Inertia

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EDINBURGH, Dec. 13

 BODY:
After this weekend's meeting of European leaders here in the Scottish capital, the 12-nation European Community seems more than ever fated to remain a political dwarf, even as it becomes an economic giant.
At the turn of the year, the Europeans will establish and begin expanding a free-trade single market now with 340 million people. But when it comes to making decisions on common foreign and military policy, many of the Europeans still profess helplessness and look to the United Nations and to the United States, notably to the soon-to-be Clinton administration. 
 The European leaders saved an ambitious treaty on political and monetary union this weekend by granting concessions that they hope will enable Denmark and Britain to ratify it next year.
 
When to Become European?
 But many of them concede that some of the treaty's most important provisions may remain dead letters. Economic strains have effectively pushed the goal of a common European currency past the turn of the century, and an effective European foreign policy to deal with the growing threat of widening disorder in the Balkans and other areas of the east is nowhere in reach.
Warning that Serbian aggression against former Yugoslav republics had created "a serious threat to peace and stability in the region," the European leaders blustered but stopped short of threatening military intervention to stop it.
They sent a team headed by Dame Anne Warburton, a former British United Nations representative, to Bosnia to investigate reports of systematic detention and rape of Muslim women by the Serbs. They also condemned what they called "acts of unspeakable brutality" that were part of the strategy of "ethnic cleansing" in the substantially Muslim republic.
"It is true that the statements we have made in the past about Yugoslavia have only been of marginal significance," the German Foreign Minister, Klaus Kinkel, said after the meeting ended late Saturday night. "We acknowledged that unfortunately, up to now, we have not been able to bring the situation under control."
Mr. Kinkel and other European colleagues warned, as some American officials have done, against the dangers of sending Western troops into a Balkan quagmire that could take years, and thousands of lives, to clear out.
This attitude could change. President Bush's decision to dispatch Americans to Somalia as part of a United Nations force to save a starving people from feuding warlords has made European officials acutely conscious of their impotence.
"I just think it's scandalous that we can do it in Somalia and not in Yugoslavia," Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers of the Netherlands said a few days ago, reflecting sentiments that would be heard from others at the talks here.
 
Another Look at the Balkans
 A series of meetings in Europe this coming week may shed further light on whether a turning point has been reached.
Foreign ministers from more than 50 countries, including Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger, will discuss violence in the Balkans and in ethnically disputed regions of the former Soviet Union at a meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in Stockholm on Monday and Tuesday.
On Wednesday, many of them, along with leaders from some Muslim countries, will meet in Geneva with Serbian, Bosnian and other officials from the former Yugoslavia to see what, if anything, they can do about the failure of this summer's London conference to stop the Yugoslav war.
And on Thursday and Friday, Mr. Eagleburger will meet with NATO ministers in Brussels to see whether the alliance, which helped prevent war with the Soviet Union for 40 years but has been powerless against the threat of communal violence in the formerly Communist countries, can play a more effective role.
Prime Minister John Major of Britain, who holds the rotating presidency of the European Community, will also meet in that capacity in Washington this week with President Bush, though President-elect Bill Clinton said he would be unable to receive him.
"We thought this was going to be the time when the Europeans took over dealing with these problems," said a senior American diplomat who will be involved this week. "It hasn't turned out that way. But we aren't going to replace one set of U.S.-dominated institutions with another set."
The difficulty is that none of the European institutions effective during the cold war have yet found an effective political or strategic way to deal with resurgent ethnic nationalism.
The European Community, for example, would like to prevent the spread of fighting to the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia, which most community members would like to recognize formally. Greece, which fears for its province of the same name, successfully prevented that here again this weekend, but did not block a plan to provide $124 million in relief and technical aid in the meantime.
Most of this weekend's wrangling was about trying to make Western European countries richer, not about helping to prevent social and economic misery in the east from spilling over into war and disorder that could affect them, too.
Spain led a fight, partly successful, to get richer countries like Germany and France to increase their contributions to the community's budget so that more development aid could be given to poorer members like Ireland, Portugal and Greece.
The main problem before all 12 European Community nations, the spreading recession, seems to stymie them. They were able to agree to establish a $2.5 billion European Investment Fund, and a temporary $6.25 billion line of credit to finance investments in bridges, roads, gas pipelines and electricity networks.
They also decided to start negotiating next month with Austria, Sweden, Finland and Norway about joining the community in 1995. All are relatively well-off countries that are expected to be net contributors.
As for Eastern Europe, Poland, the Czech republic and Hungary may have hope of joining after the turn of the century, but, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany said, it was "absurd" to even think of including Russia in the new Europe in the foreseeable future.
Some Europeans may still think of themselves as members of a rich club with protection provided mainly by a trans-Atlantic security force. This, the meetings this week may make clear, is no longer a realistic view.

HEADLINE: SALVADOR REBELS DELAY DISARMING

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Just before the ceremony to bring a formal end to the civil war here, the toughest fighting sector of the Salvadoran guerrilla movement is resisting demobilization and has turned to the United States to resolve concerns about its safety and economic security.
After a meeting on Friday of leaders of one guerrilla movement with an official of the United States Embassy, it was not clear whether the ceremony would take place as planned on Tuesday, or would be further delayed. 
 Officials and legislators were working throughout the weekend to push forward many of the uncompleted items of the broad, complicated peace package, and President Alfredo Cristiani was holding meetings with ex-guerrilla leaders to assess progress.
 
Last Major Hurdle
 However, the question of the demobilization of the People's Revolutionary Army appeared to be the most difficult roadblock to overcome.
More than 35 field commanders from the , group, one of five represented in the guerrilla front, held an unannounced meeting in the capital on Friday with Peter Romero, the charge d'affaires of the United States Embassy, to discuss their fears and frustrations.
Mr. Romero said today that the field commanders had returned to their rural zones to discuss possible next steps with their followers. The group is led by Joaquin Villalobos, the master guerrilla tactician who fought the army to a draw.
Mr. Romero said none of the participants in the meeting gave any indication that they intended to return to war, but he said they expressed "a lot of apprehensions" about some of the Government promises.
 
Worry Over Committments
 Mr. Romero said the commanders were worried that, once the formal peace is declared, promises to reduce the size of the army and continue a land distribution program might be broken. They also said they feared the army might be sent into former conflict zones after the peace is made formal.
"I found that they were not very well informed about what has been happening during these months," Mr. Romero said. "I can't say that there has been bad faith on either side, but they seemed to have little understanding of the details.
"They were concerned about whether the United States would be here to guarantee implementation," he added, "and seemed surprised when I told them that our aid is linked to compliance with the peace accords by both sides."
"I told them that we realize we are the major aid giver and that we are here to provide guarantees," he said, adding that he had told the commanders the incoming Clinton Administration would continue to give El Salvador "high priority."
 
Transition Period
 The Government and the rebels in the Salvadoran civil war signed a United Nations-mediated peace agreement on Jan. 16, and on Feb. 1 began a cease-fire, or period of "armed peace," during which they committed themselves to carry out a series of steps leading to formal peace, originally scheduled for Oct. 31.
Delays in fulfilling the agreement led to a renegotiation of the timetable and establishment of the new date of Dec. 15 for the ceremony. Vice President Dan Quayle, United Nations Secretary-General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and other foreign leaders are scheduled to attend.
Under the agreement, the members of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front were to demobilize and disarm so the front could be reorganized as a political party. Also stipulated was a reduction of the army and a purge of officers accountable for the most serious crimes against civilians. The agreement also called for the adoption of legislation dealing with electoral and judicial reform, and the provision of land and other benefits for former combatants on both sides and to guerrilla followers.
 
Demobilization in Phases
 The entire guerrilla front has been carrying out a phased demobilization of its 8,000 combatants since the end of June, with 20 per cent disarming in each step, handing in their weapons to United Nations peacekeepers. The fourth phase of the demobilization occurred at the beginning of this month, which was supposed to leave just the final 20 per cent to disarm immediately before Tuesday's ceremony.
However, diplomats and peacekeepers made known in recent days that the People's Revolutionary Army did not take part in the fourth phase and wanted to delay full demobilization for a couple of months.
Since most of those demobilized in the earlier stages were support personnel and part-time fighters, the heart of the group's fighting force remains intact at various points around the country.
The group's leaders said that since the cease-fire began, their rank and file members had not had contact with aid officials from the United States and the Salvadoran Government, and that this had contributed to the unrest, Mr. Romero said.
By contrast, he said, other guerrilla factions had allowed aid workers easy access to discuss benefits available to fighters for demobilizing.

 BODY:

The Economy
A politically explosive proposal lies at the heart of a plan for health care reform that is gaining momentum: taxing the health benefits that employers give workers. Under some proposals, workers would pay taxes on part of the money employers spend on health care benefits -- anything over what it costs to buy the least expensive plan. Or employers may lose tax deductions on what they pay. Supporters say the idea makes economic sense, since it would force consumers to choose more carefully. [Page A1.]
Manufacturers were elated during the Presidential campaign by the prospect of an additional $80 billion for public works projects. Now, with Bill Clinton shifting from campaign oratory to policy-making, many manufacturing executives express doubts about how much of the money will materialize and how much such a program will increase employment. [D1.] 
 The economic summit meeting in Little Rock is shaping up as a nationally televised gabfest about just how bad the economy is and what to do about it. [B6.] There are plenty of skeptics over the President-elect's plan for an investment tax credit, but many executives and economists favor it. [D1.]
A Federal study of energy industry subsidies concluded that the amounts involved were small and didn't affect consumption much. But an evaluation by a prominent electricity analyst finds enormous subsidies for the nuclear industry. [D2.]
 
Companies

But behind the jokes and cartoon characters are shrewd decisions that say a lot about sports as a business, how merchandise is sold and how executives try to build goodwill in their home communities. International
Large-scale economic and financial aid to Russia has been pushed off the international agenda by political uncertainties in that country and by a global recession affecting potential donors. [A1.]
Russia has begun the first public sale of a state-owned enterprise in which shares in a company can be bought only with "privatization checks," the vouchers issued to all citizens in the last two months. Each voucher represents a nominal 10,000 rubles' worth of state property. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Doubts On Funds For Roads

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The additional $80 billion that Bill Clinton promised to spend during the next four years on public works elated many manufacturers during the Presidential race. Now, as campaign oratory shifts to policy-making, many executives of manufacturing companies say they have doubts about how much of the money will actually materialize and how much such a program will increase employment.
The President-elect's plan is straightforward: Stepped-up spending on refurbishing the nation's highways and bridges will swell companies' workloads, quickly creating tens of thousands of jobs and giving a jolt to the economy. But many executives of manufacturing companies -- even those whose core business centers on products essential to any program to rebuild the infrastructure -- say that the money will come slowly, at best, and that the impact on their companies will probably be modest. 
 "I think Mr. Clinton will come up with a real program for infrastructure spending," said James A. Todd Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Birmingham Steel Corporation, a leading maker of the reinforcing bar steel, often called rebar, used in highways and light construction. "But I doubt it will make an impact on our business, or the steel business for that matter, for the near future."
 
 
Reaction of States
 Many executives of companies that produce products ranging from steel to asphalt and concrete said their doubts were based on the fact that few state transportation departments were ready to begin major construction projects. Moreover, they explained, far too much time would be needed to put such projects in place to result in large-scale hiring within the next year.
"Even if Mr. Clinton raises the amount of spending that will be available under the Surface Transportation Act -- that was $26 billion for fiscal 1992 -- the impact on our company will be slight to moderate," Mr. Todd said.
But that level of infrastructure spending would help to raise Birmingham Steel's earnings, he added, since even a slight increase in demand for its products would cause prices to climb. "We do expect that rebar consumption will be up about 10 percent in 1993 over 1992, but we expect it will hold to that level for much of the next five years," he said.
 For many companies, there is mostly uncertainty, not only about how much public works spending will increase, but how their businesses will be affected. "There is no way to predict with any amount of accuracy how much equipment will be sold over the next few years as a result of the action by the new Administration," Gordon D. Tjelmeland, a spokesman for Deere & Company, a maker of construction equipment, said.
Mr. Tjelmeland said Deere would probably sell more of its smaller construction equipment, based on Mr. Clinton's emphasis on highway repair and renovation. But he added that "much depends" on the weight that states give to programs involving mass transit versus highway and road construction.
F. Kenneth Iverson, the chairman and chief executive of the Nucor Corporation, the nation's leading mini-mill steel company, said Mr. Clinton's plans for infrastructure spending would probably "affect our company modestly in that it will increase steel demand." Nucor is a leading maker of bar and structural steel, which is used in bridges and heavy construction. Mr. Iverson added that an increase was not likely to lead to higher employment at Nucor.
Some manufacturers do anticipate a need for more hiring. Edward L. Flom, chairman of the Florida Steel Corporation, said a modest increase in infrastructure spending could well lead to an employment increase of as much as 8 percent in the next few years. "If this increase in spending occurs, employment will increase here," Mr. Flom said. "It's hard to say, but it could increase our employment between 5 and 8 percent."
 
 
A Skeptical Executive
 But Mr. Flom, whose company is a leading maker of bar steel products, said he remained unconvinced that significantly higher public works spending would necessarily materialize. "I don't take anything any elected official says as the truth until it happens," he said. "But something has got to happen, because our infrastructure is either obsolete or deteriorating."
John E. Jacobson, president of Jacobson & Associates, a steel industry consulting firm, said the impact of higher spending on steel companies' hiring would depend on whether the spending was sustained.
"If it's something that steel companies can depend on for a number of years, they will do more hiring," Mr. Jacobson said. "But steel companies, like most other manufacturing companies, have learned hard lessons in the last few years on having to do more with fewer people. It will take sustained spending by the government to break them of that habit."
Although executives of steel companies have doubts about the impact of a public works program, officials of concrete and asphalt companies are somewhat more optimistic about how the Clinton plans will affect their hiring.
 
 
'Not So Confident'
 Jon I. Mullarky, vice president of the National Ready Mixed Concrete Association, said higher spending on roads and bridges would increase employment in the industry.
"It will obviously have an impact on the hiring in our business, although I'm not so confident that the pace is going to be anything near quick," he said. "We should not look for any big highway program to begin in January, that's for sure."
Mr. Mullarky said his doubts over the pace of the Clinton Administration's infrastructure spending were based on the fact that in many cases, Federal funds must be matched by state and local money. Many states and municipalities do not have money to spend on such projects, he noted, adding that environmental reviews "can take a considerable amount of time on any construction project."
Environmental issues are at the heart of the concerns of several executives, including Gary B. Sauer, president of the Commercial Asphalt Company, a large asphalt producer in Minneapolis. "The highway bill last year had so many regulations that resulted in so much environmental impact study," Mr. Sauer said. "It's not easy to get things started, to get them going. If Mr. Clinton gets the dollars out of Congress, it will create jobs. But I have my doubts as to whether he can do that."

HEADLINE: U.S. Finds Energy Industry Subsidies Are Small

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
An Energy Department study of Government subsidies to the energy industry has concluded that the amounts involved are small and do not affect consumption much. But an evaluation by a prominent electricity analyst finds enormous subsidies for the nuclear industry, along with enormous costs incurred directly by the utilities.
The question of which energy forms the Government should support is drawing increased attention with the change of administrations. President Jimmy Carter won huge increases in Federal support for renewable energy resources and plans to replace oil with fuels derived from coal and other sources. As Presidents, Ronald Reagan and George Bush vigorously backed nuclear power. President-elect Bill Clinton and Vice President-elect Al Gore have talked about returning to renewable fuels and promoting natural gas and conservation.
 
A Contrarian View
 The Government study, released Wednesday, contradicts some conventional thinking about Washington's role in energy prices. It found, for example, that the oil industry, thought of as pampered with Government support, paid more in taxes than it got in benefits. 
 The study says a shift to conservation and use of renewable sources of energy, which the Clinton team advocates, has to a large extent already occurred.
The study, ordered by Congress last year, concludes that Government subsidies to the energy industry are equal to 1 to 3 percent of the value of all energy consumed, or $5 billion to $13 billion a year, depending on how a subsidy is defined.
The nation's total yearly energy bill is $475 billion, the study found.
"Contrary to what might be the popular impression, energy is not heavily subsidized," said Calvin A. Kent, administrator of the Energy Information Administration, an independent statistical agency within the Energy Department.
But the study did find that some energy sources, like gasohol and natural gas recovery from coal seams, existed only because of subsidies.
In contrast, a separate study to be released in a few days by Greenpeace, the environmental group, concludes that taxpayers have spent nearly $100 billion to promote nuclear power. The total, stated in 1990 dollars to account for inflation since the first expenditures in the early 1950's, said the subsidy amounted to 1.6 cents for every kilowatt-hour of electricity produced with nuclear power from 1968, when the first large plants began operating, until 1990.
 
'An Official Technology'
 The Greenpeace study was written by Charles Komanoff, a New York-based electricity analyst who has been comparing the costs of competing sources for 20 years, and an associate, Cora Roelofs. It excludes benefits received from Washington by the nuclear industry like "the ideological support which crowned nuclear power an 'official technology' and won investor confidence."
The study puts the total cost of a nuclear kilowatt-hour at just over 10 cents. The figure includes $347 billion spent to build, fuel and operate reactors and to begin programs to tear them down when they retire. The utilities have spent $48 billion on indirect costs, including waste disposal and investments in plants that were canceled. Both numbers were stated in 1990 dollars.
In contrast to the 10-cent figure, which is a wholesale figure, the average cost of a kilowatt hour to all customers in the first eight months of this year was 6.6 cents, according to the Energy Department.
Mr. Komanoff said the investments in nuclear power had not been worthwhile, adding that they were a warning "to be more tolerant of teething costs for renewables and energy efficiency."
"I don't mean that I or anyone else wants to spend half a trillion dollars on solar energy or wind," he said. "But when you see eyebrows being raised because a couple of hundred million is going to photovoltaic solar cells or a wind farm, you have to put it in perspective."
The Government study also found a heavy subsidy for nuclear power but did not compare the figure with the cost per kilowatt hour. It found that for fiscal 1992, direct appropriations for nuclear power were $890 million for research and development and $9 million in regulatory costs borne by taxpayers.
But nuclear power also has benefits separate from Congressional appropriations: it enjoys a partial exemption from liability for reactor accidents, which the study valued at $3 billion a year in reduced insurance costs.
The sector getting the most help, through subsidized loans and Government sales at below-market prices, is electricity, at $1.8 billion, the study found. In contrast, it said the oil industry lost nearly $2.2 billion to the Government, when comparing the value of its tax breaks with the Federal excise taxes on fuel.
Dr. Kent said the study did not rank sectors of the energy industry by size of subsidy because many different assumptions went into the counting. But if subsidies were counted on the basis of quantity of energy produced compared with subsidies received, renewable sources, which include solar power, hydroelectricity, wood, wind and other technologies that do not consume fossil fuels, would get $847 million in the current fiscal year. This includes $244 million in research and development funds plus $540 million in tax exemptions and $63 million for help to low-income people.
The coal industry is subsidized with $1.1 billion, the study said, with the largest item being $551 million for research into cleaner ways to burn the fuel.
Taxpayers will spend $635 million this year to subsidize conservation, the department said. The natural gas industry gets $1.7 billion.

HEADLINE: Health-Care Planners Urge A Tax on Workers' Benefits

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

 BODY:
A plan for health care reform that is gathering momentum around the country has at its heart a little-known but politically explosive proposal: taxing the health benefits employers give their workers.
Under current rules, workers do not pay taxes on health insurance provided by employers. And the employer can write off the cost, often thousands of dollars, from the company's taxable income. 
 But in what is emerging as the most likely model for national health care reform next year, an approach called "managed competition," much of that could change.
 
Tax on Workers
 Under some proposals, workers would pay taxes on part of the money employers now spend to provide health care benefits -- anything over what it costs to buy the least expensive basic health plan, like membership in a health maintenance organization. Or employers might lose their tax deductions on what they pay. Or possibly both.
Supporters say the idea makes perfect economic sense: it would force the 150 million Americans who enjoy such benefits to choose more carefully among health plans, by making them pay for more expensive plans out of their pockets. And that selective shopping, in theory, would drive down medical costs by rewarding the most efficient companies. As a bonus, the new taxes would provide billions of dollars that could buy insurance for the 37 million people currently without insurance.
 
Will Voters Approve?
 "The idea is to get businesses to cut prices to attract customers," said Alain Enthoven, a professor at Stanford University and a principal architect of managed competition. "With health plans competing to provide you more for your money, in the long run you are going to save a great deal."
But even the most ardent supporters of managed competition cringe at the prospect of breaking the news to American voters. The last thing voters expect when they say they favor health care reform, Democratic strategists say, is to be forced to pay taxes on something they never even regarded as income.
"It is one of those ideas that goes over great with the policy wonks," said a top Democratic strategist who insisted on anonymity. "But people in the middle class believe they are being done in by big insurance companies and the medical bureaucracy. It's going to be pretty hard to tell them the solution is to tax them."
Opponents of managed competition say greater Government intervention, not just competition, is needed to make health insurance available to all Americans. Organized labor, in particular, is likely to oppose steadfastly any plan to tax or limit health care benefits.
Nonetheless, in recent months managed competition in various forms has gained extraordinary political momentum, picking up support from groups as diverse as the insurance industry, the Business Roundtable and the National Governors' Conference. Policy experts from the conservative Heritage Foundation to California's Insurance Commissioner, John Garamendi, a liberal Democrat, have embraced it. So did Bill Clinton, in broad terms, on the campaign trail.
 
 
A New Intermediary
 Under managed competition, consumers would be represented in buying their health insurance by large "sponsors," which might represent thousands, even hundreds of thousands of customers. A sponsor, for example, might represent all the residents of a county. The sponsors are often referred to as health insurance purchasing corporations.
The sponsor would negotiate with insurance companies for high-quality and cost-effective health plans, then would give its members a choice of plans, from relatively inexpensive ones, those provided by health maintenance organizations, to more lavish coverage that costs more. Any insurance company signing up with a sponsor would have to take the business of anyone represented by that sponsor, whether sick or healthy.
Professor Enthoven suggested that under current rules insurers are rewarded not for keeping prices low but for raising them. He is one of the group of health care experts known as the Jackson Hole Group, whose influential writings on managed competition come from meetings in Jackson Hole, Wyo. As long as employers pay most of consumers' premiums and the employers get to deduct the costs from their taxes, they say, neither consumers nor employers have enough of a motivation to shop around for the least expensive health insurers.
"Changing the tax status of health benefits is the glue that holds managed competition together, said Dr. Paul Ellwood, another leading expert with the Jackson Hole Group. "This is the principal lever that government has, short of price controls, over the private sector."
 
 
Encouraging Cheaper Options
 Under the Jackson Hole plan, for example, consumers who choose more expensive health coverage -- any coverage more expensive than the least expensive plan offered by the sponsor -- would have to pay for it from after-tax dollars. That would encourage many workers to choose cheaper plans.
Employers would be required to pay for some health care coverage by making a contribution to the sponsor. Employers would not be allowed to contribute more than the cost of the cheapest basic standard health care package.
Professor Enthoven estimates that the cost to the Government of tax breaks for employees and employers now totals more than $66 billion.
Proponents argue that changing those tax breaks would hit the rich more than the poor; tax deductions are worth twice as much to families in the 31 percent bracket as they are to families in the 15 percent bracket. By closing such exemptions and exclusions, they say, the Government could find the money to pay for insurance coverage for those who are now uninsured, including the poor.
A more modest proposal for managed competition introduced in Congress this session by Representative Jim Cooper, Democrat of Tennessee, and Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma, would limit only the tax deduction of employers. Employers under that bill would be taxed whenever they chose to pay for more than the basic lowest cost health plan in their area.
"You are just telling them that the deduction is a limited privilege," Mr. Cooper said. "Everybody gets to deduct a Ford or Chevrolet. But if you want a Ferrari or a Mercedes, you have to pay for the difference."
 
 
No Comment From Clinton
 President-elect Clinton so far has not commented on proposals to cap or tax benefits for health care.
But Representative Cooper acknowledged that any such attempt is likely to draw heavy fire. Repeated proposals by the Reagan Administration to cap health benefits brought a vehement and fatal response from the Democratic majority in Congress, labor and business groups. The Bush Administration considered, then rejected, the idea as part of the health care reform plan it proposed last January.
Democratic leaders also recall what is considered the watershed campaign in 1991 of Harris Wofford, the Democrat who upset former Attorney General Dick Thornburgh for a Senate seat in Pennsylvania. The Wofford campaign used Mr. Thornburgh's apparent support of a health benefits tax as an opportunity to pummel him on the airwaves.
"Tax health care benefits?" ran one television commercial. "Thornburgh. He's been in Washington too long."
A poll of 1,445 manufacturers released last week by the National Association of Manufacturers in Washington found that 54 percent of the companies said they were opposed to ending the tax deduction, compared with 27 percent who said they would favor such a proposal if it would expand access to health care for the uninsured. Four percent said they favored the proposal regardless of how the money was used.
 
 
Strong Opposition Arises
 Opposition is also strong among health care experts who say that greater Government intervention is necessary to bring health costs under control.
"They are right that the tax issue is pretty central to their managed competition proposals," said Dr. David Himmelstein, an assistant professor at Harvard Medical School and advocate of a Government-run health insurance system like Canada's. "If you don't have strong penalties to drive people into cut-rate plans, they don't have incentives to go to what is lower-quality care. And the bottom tier of this system could be very poor."
Even more passionate opposition may come from organized labor, which has devoted much of its energy since World War II to fighting for liberal health benefits. While some economists argue that expensive health benefits have reduced the salaries workers receive, labor leaders have described recent proposals as a new tax on those who can afford it least.
"There is no rhyme or reason to tax health care benefits," said Robert M. McGlotten, the director of legislation for the A.F.L.-C.I.O in Washington. "The fact of the matter is that I have a health care program that my employer pays for. We essentially realized as a nation long ago that it was important for employers to help employees."
