HEADLINE: Promises, Promises: Transit Funds in Peril

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 13

 BODY:
When is a promise not a promise?
When it is made by the State of New York. Or more precisely, when it is made by the State of New York in times of fiscal distress. 
 That in essence has become the position taken by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in an intriguing new battle with lawmakers over transportation financing. And it has set off a lively, if somewhat incongruous, debate within the Legislature about high-minded principles like integrity, trust and credibility.
What has instigated the dispute is Mr. Cuomo's proposal to seize $516 million from a fund that just last year was dedicated to transportation needs so that the money can be used instead to balance the 1993-94 budget.
For two weeks, legislators have been arguing that it would violate a sacred trust with the public to divert the money. After all, they say, Mr. Cuomo joined them in approving legislation in 1991 stipulating that all of the money generated by that year's increase in the petroleum business tax would be spent solely to improve roads, bridges and mass transit.
 
A 'Locked Box'
 The dedicated fund was supposed to be so secure from budgetary predators that it was labeled the "locked box." That was then, says Mr. Cuomo. This is now.
With a tone that many legislators say is cavalier at best and cynical at worst, Mr. Cuomo is campaigning for his plan by asserting that the state's commitments, even when enshrined in legislation, become meaningless when financial conditions change.
He has argued that this year's broken promise would be no different from those broken in the past, including laws to cut personal income-tax rates and to provide education aid to the poor in the form of Liberty Scholarships.
When asked at a news conference last week what assurance the public has that the locked box will ever be used for transportation, Mr. Cuomo responded: "None, unless it's in the Constitution. The public at large doesn't have any assurance of any bill not being repealed or changed next year. They never did. For over 200 years, they haven't had any such assurance. Never, ever."
Legalistically, of course, Mr. Cuomo is right. And the state's recent fiscal record is replete with cases of programs not financed, tax cuts not granted, trust funds raided and temporary taxes made permanent.
But for the time being, both Democratic and Republican lawmakers are drawing a distinction when it comes to the transportation fund.
Some, like Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat, distinguish between a broken promise that would delay an expected benefit, like a tax cut, and one that would undercut the rationale for a new burden, like a tax increase.
Others, like State Senator John B. Daly, a Niagara County Republican, believe that unlocking the locked box would set a terrible precedent at a time when voters are cynical enough about government. "You live by your credibility up here," he said.
 
'Offending People'
 And then there are those who simply resent Mr. Cuomo's attitude.
"This is the guy that's moralized about government for 20 years," said one Democratic lawmaker, who insisted on anonymity lest he draw the wrath of Mr. Cuomo. "Now that he gets in a bind, he says promises don't matter. That's the heart and soul of what's offending people."
Mr. Cuomo argues, without using so many words, that the legislators are hypocrites. They are happy to break promises when the abrogation helps their political standing, he has suggested, but they become indignant when a broken pledge would mean less pork for their districts.
"You can't have it both ways," he said. "They want what they can get for themselves, not the state."
 
Bottom Line Is Last Word
 As the debate rolls along, most likely into next year, fiscal reality will weigh increasingly on Mr. Cuomo's side.
Administration and legislative budget analysts believe the state will have to close a gap of up to $4 billion, and possibly more, in the budget that begins on April 1. Because a precise number may not be made public by Mr. Cuomo until mid-January, legislators are reluctant to agree on a painful solution before knowing the depth of the problem.
But if most of the money in the locked box remains dedicated to transportation, legislators will have to look elsewhere to balance the budget. There are few alternatives: education aid, which is sacrosanct to the Republican majority in the Senate; social-service programs, which have already suffered deep cuts and are protected by the Democratic majority in the Assembly, and broad-based tax increases, which are abhorred by the Governor, the Republicans and many Democrats.
Close observers of state government said the debate reflected a larger problem: the continuing inability of the Governor and the Legislature to make the difficult choices needed to address the state's structural financial problems.
The state's patchwork fiscal practices, they say, are vividly illustrated by the measure that created the locked box in the first place: the 1991 increase in the petroleum business tax, which is levied on petroleum importers and which cost consumers about 12 cents a gallon at the pump.
As the tax law was designed, the revenue generated by the increase was to flow directly to the state's general fund in the 1991-92 fiscal year, when the budget gap was $6.5 billion, and in fiscal 1992-93, with the gap at $4.8 billion. But the political price of winning approval from the Senate Republicans was an agreement to devote the revenues to transportation starting in 1993-94.
It was assumed -- incorrectly as it turned out -- that the state's economy would have recovered enough by then to compensate for the lost revenue to the general fund. Now, the Governor is making a similar assumption about the next two years by proposing to divert $516 million from the $701 million in the locked box next year, but only $200 million in 1994-95, and nothing in 1995-96.
"All these things are bets on the future being better economically," said Eric Lane, a Hofstra law professor and former aide to the Senate Democrats. "And they pay a political price for it because when it doesn't work out, they do look cynical and they do look stupid."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
The Mixed Outlook on Municipals

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
There are a lot of reasons to be positive about the outlook for tax-exempt municipal bonds, including the prospect of a decline next year in new issues, which reduces supply, and a jump in Federal tax rates, which makes tax-exempt securities even more attractive. But analysts warn that there is also an issue to worry about: credit quality.
"The quality of municipal risk has been deteriorating because of the deteriorating condition of state and local governments," said Peter B. Coffin, a senior vice president and municipal bond portfolio manager at Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston. "You simply cannot take it for granted that because it is a municipal bond you are going to get paid." 
 William T. Reynolds, director of the municipal bond division at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore, said the yield spread between bonds with top credit ratings and those with medium ratings was narrow "and can only widen in the next few years."
The credit problem has several facets. One is seen in Brevard County, Fla., the home not only of Cape Canaveral but also of a taxpayer revolt that could lead the county to refuse to pay the interest and principal on bonds, called certificates of participation, that it used to finance a county office building.
 
Possibly Widespread Impact
 The impact of such a refusal could be felt well beyond Brevard County because this is not a case of being unable to pay; the county has the money, but may refuse to pay because it is caught in a political battle.
Another site of concern is California, where the state's fiscal problems, which led to a prolonged budget crisis this year, are expected to continue, resulting in a further downgrading of the state's credit ratings.
A third area is hospital bonds, especially for big city hospitals, whose credit quality could be damaged by cost-containment programs that will accompany President-elect Bill Clinton's effort to revamp the American health-care system.
In Brevard County, the Board of Commissioners plans to vote this week on a referendum that would let voters decide if the county should continue paying what it owes on the $23.9 million it borrowed for the new government center in Viera.
 
Payments Derive From Income
 These certificates of participation, or lease-obligation bonds, are different from general-obligation bonds in that they are not backed by the full faith and credit and taxing authority of the local government. Instead, payments of interest and principal come from income earned by the project built with the bonds, and the payments must be appropriated by the government every year. In this case, the income comes from rent the county pays for the office building.
The reason the bonds are popular with local governments cuts to the heart of the issue in Brevard County. Because the interest and principal payments have to be appropriated each year, courts have ruled that unlike a general-obligation bond, a certificate of participation is not long-term debt and does not have to be approved by voters before it is sold.
The government operations center in Viera has become a big political issue since the certificates were sold in 1989, in part because there was no vote on the bond issue first. The move for a referendum on whether to continue appropriating the payments of interest and principal has gained such momentum that in November two new commissioners, who promised to support a public vote, were elected to the board, giving it a 4-to-1 margin in favor of a referendum.
Robert J. Froelich, director of municipal research and investment strategy at Van Kampen Merritt in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., said the ramifications of a vote against honoring the certificates of participation "could be absolutely overwhelming." The bondholders would not be hurt, because the issue is insured.
 
Higher Rates Held Likely
 Mr. Froelich said Brevard County could be denied access for some time to the municipal market for general- obligation or other bonds. And when it could borrow again, it would be at a much higher interest rate than it now pays.
In addition, he argued, all other certificates of participation and lease-obligation bonds around the country would be affected, with their prices falling as investors wondered if another community would take the same route.
The Public Securities Association says about $65 billion of certificates of participation and lease-obligation bonds are outstanding, accounting for about 5.8 percent of the $1.1 trillion municipal bond market. About $10 billion were issued in 1991, and $8 billion have been sold so far this year.
Neil Budnick, a senior vice president of the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, the company that has insured the Brevard issue, is less worried about the consequences. He said that the impact would fall mostly on Brevard County and that he would expect investors to judge other issues on their own merits.
As for California, Mr. Reynolds of T. Rowe Price noted that the economy there was still being hammered by cuts in military spending and was having trouble creating jobs. These and other factors, he said, will mean the state's budget crisis will continue, making the credit of the nation's largest single issuer of municipal bonds riskier and not very attractive.
In general, Mr. Reynolds said he thinks that although the national economy is beginning to grow again, there are still signs that fiscal strains in states and local governments will continue, especially as the Federal Government pushes costs on to states and the states push them to the local level.
Mr. Reynolds said hospitals had enjoyed a stable period for several years, adding that interest rates on hospital bonds are not "dramatically higher" than on other sectors of the municipal bond market. But he says this situation will probably change as the Federal Government seeks to cut the costs of medical care, resulting in revenue declines at hospitals.
"You will see the weaker hospitals show the strain and become greater credit risks than they are today," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Haute Couture Is Set Aside For an Entire Issue of Vogue

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
With a toss of its imperial head and a clear-eyed look at where fashion is headed, Vogue will devote its entire April issue to clothes and other items that cost less than $500. The magazine, which is better known for showcasing designer clothes with price tags in the high four figures, says it is making a major fashion statement.
"This is about style," said Anne Sutherland Fuchs, the publisher. "There has never been this much fashion at this price. We will make it chic by doing this." 
 But it is also about business. The magazine will have a major tie-in with Neiman Marcus in April. The Dallas-based chain will take as many as 12 ad pages in the April Vogue, as well as running in-store promotions, videos and window displays in its 27 stores across the country touting Vogue's message.
This is also about maintaining the No. 1 position in the fashion-magazine field. Although Vogue is comfortably ahead of its competitors in circulation and advertising, Harper's Bazaar threw down the gauntlet this fall when it named Elizabeth Tilberis editor in chief and said it would take on Vogue coiffed head to coiffed head.
"This is a very good counterpunch to Harper's proclaiming "The Return of Elegance,' " said Theodore V. Kruckel 3d, vice president of Mc,inc., a magazine consulting firm, and former group marketing director of the Elle Publishing Company. "It's less that Vogue has set the agenda; it's that they have taken back the agenda."
Advertisers love to appear in what they perceive as a hot issue. The April 1992 Vogue, for instance, was the 100th anniversary issue. It was highly promoted by Vogue and its 379 ad pages represented a 64 percent increase from the 1991 issue. Similarly, in the September 1992 Harper's Bazaar, introduced in a blitz of publicity as Ms. Tilberis's first issue, ad pages nearly doubled, to 251, from 131 in September 1991 and newsstand sales jumped to an estimated 450,000 from 250,000.
"I think it's very smart of Vogue to do this," said Kalman Ruttenstein, senior vice president in charge of fashion at Bloomingdale's. Anna Wintour, Vogue's editor in chief, "really has her hand on the pulse of America, and it's exciting that she is doing it."
Although advertisers have not yet been approached, the fact that Vogue has rarely, if ever, devoted a whole issue to a single topic and that it normally positions itself as a high-end fashion publication should give this issue the kind of buzz that advertisers love. Nonetheless, Vogue is toeing a delicate line. It cannot afford to offend the designers whose couture and high-priced clothes are essentially the magazine's bread and butter.
"The true luxury advertisers are always going to be very hesitant about an issue with a dollar cap, so it is going to have to be positioned very, very carefully to the Escadas and the Chanels of the world," Mr. Kruckel said.
Ms. Fuchs would say only that "some of them are not going to make the issue."
 
'Dress for Less' Section
 The idea for the one-topic issue came from Ms. Wintour, who regularly runs a "dress for less" section in Vogue. Many of the other high-end fashion magazines also include this kind of dash-instead-of-cash fashion.
"It has to do with the whole change in the marketplace," Ms. Wintour said. "The economic realities being what they really are, this is timely. It will include bathing suits, what to wear to work, a lot of accessories. It's less about a total look, less top to toe; it's everything thrown together, mixed up, more fluid and personal. The issue will also include fitness at a price, theater tickets at a price, beauty at a price."
Vogue is not backing away from designer clothes. March is the traditional Paris couture issue. And the designers are expected back, full force, in May to retake their place. In fact, many women who buy designer clothes like to mix them with less expensive clothing -- the Chanel jacket worn with a pair of jeans from the Gap.
Less expensive stylish clothing has been gaining on the designers in the $60-billion-a-year fashion market since Donna Karan exploded onto the scene with her DKNY line in 1989 and, in a sense, changed fashion. A DKNY jacket now averages about $450, while one in the Donna Karan collection costs $1,100 or $1,200.
"We did $63 million the first year DKNY opened," said Christy Hood, a spokeswoman for the Donna Karan Company. "In 1992, our sales will be $185 million."
 
Bridge Lines of Clothing
 An increasing number of designers now have these so-called bridge lines. These include Anne Klein II, who in the early 1980's became the first to introduce a bridge line; CK Sport by Calvin Klein; KORS from Michael Kors and Giorgio Armani's A/X Armani Exchange. Mr. Ruttenstein said bridge lines were a major thrust in Bloomingdale's stores nationwide. An entire floor devoted to this fashion opened at Bloomingdale's flagship store on Lexington Avenue in September.
"Bridge will be roughly $350 to $500 retail for spring clothes," Mr. Ruttenstein said. "It's no longer fashionable to spend a lot of money on clothes. We thought it might be a passing fancy, but we think now that this is the 90's."
If devoting an issue to this kind of fashion is a departure for Vogue, promoting it is even more of a departure for Neiman Marcus, whose 27 stores are known for their high-end fashion and have a retail volume exceeding $1.3 billion.
The store's marketing strategy has been largely limited to direct mail, but Terry Lundgren, president and chief executive, said it was time to reach out to a broader audience. The Neiman Marcus bridge clothes that appear in the April Vogue may well also appear later in the Neiman catalogue.
"We are embarking on a new long-term strategy for Neiman," Mr. Lundgren said. "We are going to make a big deal out of this. We want to get full credit from our existing Neiman Marcus customer as well as the new audience that we are speaking to through Vogue magazine."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anna Wintour, editor in chief of Vogue, selecting clothes for the April 1993 issue, devoted to clothes and accessories costing less than $500. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times) (pg. D8)

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
Debating What to Do About the Deficit

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
With President-elect Bill Clinton's television special on the economy beginning today, tonight's two-hour "Firing Line" debate at 9 on PBS could not be smacker on the news. Viewers who stay with it -- not as arduous an obligation as it might seem from the proposition "Resolved: Reducing the Federal Deficit in the Next Four Years Is a Top Priority" -- should come out better equipped to assess the new Administration's approach to the overriding issue of the campaign.
As talk-show fans must know by now, the problem facing Mr. Clinton is whether to give priority to reducing the $4 trillion Federal debt, which could mean prolonging the recession, or promptly trying to stimulate the economy, which would mean a continuing increase in the deficit for a while at least. 
 Tonight's cadre of deficit fighters, led by William F. Buckley Jr., the "Firing Line" proprietor, argue that the debt is already costing too much (half of all income taxes must go to pay the interest), is scaring off investors and is threatening to be an intolerable burden to future generations.
The stimulators, led by Lester Thurow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who dismisses the evening's subject as "an irrelevancy," respond that reducing the deficit precipitously will make things worse; they want new investment right away. The exchanges are spirited, with all parties tossing around enormous figures that defy most people's imaginations.
The program's punch-counter-punch format, which compels the participants to answer opponents' points directly, is entertaining as well as illuminating. The panelists -- white males, every one! -- expound their positions with the sort of confidence that nothing in the dismal history of economists' predictions can shake. In true academic spirit, on some points, like tax increases, there is disagreement among allies and agreement between opponents.
Mr. Buckley is abetted by Clive Crook, of The Economist; James D. Davidson, the chairman of the National Taxpayers Union, and Senator Warren B. Rudman, the New Hampshire Republican who has announced his retirement but still seems to be campaigning and is chided by the evening's amiable host, Michael Kinsley, for feeding "applause lines" to the audience at Bard College, in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.
Joining Mr. Thurow are three other economists, Robert Eisner, David Levy and Robert Kuttner. All welcome the new Administration, and not even Mr. Buckley goes out of his way to defend the Reagan-Bush era, for which he is sometimes given some responsibility. Referring to his vote for Ronald Reagan, he quotes a French witticism: "If there are no alternatives, you've got to sleep with your wife." The new political age is upon us.
 
3-2-1 Contact Extra
Brainstorm: The Truth About Your Brain on Drugs
PBS, tonight at 8
(Channel 13 in New York)
"Brainstorm: The Truth About Your Brain on Drugs" is an easy-to-understand explanation for youngsters of why they should just say no. Tonight's offering from the Children's Television Workshop uses graphics, cartoons, models, quizzes, interviews with doctors, testimonials from sometime addicts and pictures of a brain operation (not for the squeamish) to show how the workings of the brain are disrupted by drugs.
The agreeable young hosts of "3-2-1 Contact," Stephanie Yu and Z Wright, though clearly straight arrows, avoid moralizing as they explain how drugs can take control of the nervous system. The images are strong and clear: at first the kick of crack or LSD may provide the thrill of a theme-park ride, but after a while, you can't get off the roller coaster. Alcohol is not neglected, and the zippy anti-smoking commercial that ends the lesson pointedly uses romantic pictures of movie stars lighting up to a rock song called "A Pack of Lies."

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
A Big Grant for Russian Science

 BODY:
One good way to curb the proliferation of nuclear arms is to keep talented Russian scientists at home in Russia doing research rather than selling their knowledge and their services to renegade states bent on acquiring nuclear arsenals.
With Russia's economy tottering and its research budgets cut to the bone, the only hope is for the West to provide research grants to keep the scientists gainfully employed on civilian projects. That would help Russia through a difficult time and make the world a bit safer for everyone. 
 Efforts to persuade Washington to come up with the needed money seem destined to take longer than the half-life of plutonium. So a few Western foundations have offered small-scale funding as a stopgap measure.
Now George Soros, who made a fortune on Wall Street, will put a hefty $100 million to work supporting basic research in Russia over the next two years.
The reaction of Washington's chief diplomat in Moscow says it all: "I certainly think he has given the U.S. Government a standard to live by."

HEADLINE: It's Rough, but It's Democracy

 BODY:
To Westerners, the news out of Moscow in the last few days has sounded ominous. The Russian Congress rebuffed President Boris Yeltsin and economic reform by refusing to confirm his choice for Prime Minister. Angrily, he resolved to appeal directly to the Russian people. The two sides then compromised because neither was certain of winning a national vote or prepared to face a complete collapse of government.
It's politics of the coarsest kind, and it may retard the development of a market economy. But for all the rough and tumble, Russia is evolving into a crude parliamentary democracy. 
 Production is still slipping, and so is the living standard of most Russians. Many wrongly blame economic reforms, rather than the collapse of the Communist command economy. And political responsibility remains murky. The Congress, like Mr. Yeltsin, was elected before the August 1991 coup. It won't adopt a new constitution, separating executive and legislative powers, until April.
Under these trying circumstances it is remarkable that Russia's political system functions at all. America's overriding interest lies in assuring that it continues to function. A modicum of political stability will keep Russian chauvinists out of power and nuclear proliferation under control. That is worthy of America's engagement and support.
Intolerance and paranoia still cloud the climate, impeding the compromises needed to make democracy work. And many deputies would rather denounce the Government's reform policies than propose their own. To avoid responsibility, they even voted by secret ballot to deny Yegor Gaidar the Prime Minister's post.
But Mr. Yeltsin has reached a compromise with the centrist coalition in Congress that would give the legislature a say in the choice of prime minister and cabinet. That's one of the foundations of parliamentary democracy. But the Congress has balked at a second -- giving the president the power to dissolve Congress and call elections.
That's why Mr. Yeltsin tried over the Congress's objections to do the next best thing. He called for a national vote of confidence. If voters had supported him, he intended to call parliamentary elections in March. That threat worked.
Mr. Gaidar can soldier on for now as Acting Prime Minister. And President Yeltsin can try to enact important reforms by executive decree. But after the events of last week, those decrees will carry less force than ever. The Government's popular mandate urgently needs renewal.
Last week's events are a sign of the tortuous path that probably lies ahead for Russia. The democratic possibility there challenges the West: How should America and other countries sustain engagement with Russia over the long haul?
The task for President-elect Clinton will be to mobilize sagging support, at home and abroad, for aid to Russia -- financing to reschedule its foreign debt, to provide a safety net for pensioners and the unemployed, technical assistance, a Democracy Corps. Democracy in Russia won't advance without setbacks, or take hold overnight. The task for America is to do what it can to help nurture it.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Working the Room

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

 BODY:
"These occasions have value," said Katharine Graham of The Washington Post Company, in a toast at her dinner party for the Clintons and Gores last week. "They create relationships beyond the office."
Because she was generous enough to invite some of the journalistic competition to the party for 100 at her Georgetown home, I set about creating relationships. Transition time is a very sensitive moment for pundits; you cannot appear eager to make contact, lest you be accused of sucking up, but neither should you allow your precious independence to be construed as aloofness or hostility, lest you miss out on a news-rich phone call from the highest authority. 
 The first trick is to position yourself along a cocktail reception's corridor of power. Never work the room; let the room-worker work you. I stood in the center of the tent outside the dining room, where it would require a conscious dodge by the President-elect and his wife (who has eclipsed Mrs. Graham as "the most powerful woman in America") to avoid me. To appear short and unimposing, I positioned myself between Paul Volcker and Senator John Rockefeller, together more than 13 feet of the Washington Establishment.
Kay brought the guest of honor past other experienced reception-positioners like Tom Johnson of CNN, Eric Breindel of The New York Post, and Judy Woodruff of PBS and her attractive husband, all of whom pretended to be talking to connected Clintonites Ron Brown, Warren Christopher and Vernon Jordan.
Sure enough, Bill Clinton, working the room, came my way. I knew him only by telephone; Kay introduced us, and the President-elect promptly said what goes over well with Republicans who reluctantly voted for him: "I hope you won't be disappointed."
Nice line, humble but not obsequious, followed by: "I hope to get good advice in the papers. You write it, I'll read it."
Rooted to the spot that had proved so well situated, I awaited Hillary Clinton. Along came Tmpwa herself, who quickly took up the Clintonian theme of appreciation for counseling: "You gave me some good advice early in the campaign. I took it."
That was a reference to a column after a couple of her gaffes, suggesting she stop defining herself by what she was not -- not a man-bystander, not a cookie pusher -- and start defining herself by what she was. Here she was saying she could take constructive criticism and remembered its source, the mark of a good politician.
So far so good; deferential in the first flush of power, they showed they know how to work a high-powered room. But could he -- the blowhard of a thousand stumps -- deliver a suitably brief toast? Would he have to work from notes? Would he act like a rube on a roll or say the graceful thing? At such an occasion, taste will tell; if you can do it at Kay Graham's, you can do it anywhere.
His hostess recalled having met Calvin Coolidge in her childhood and quipped: "When people say how nice it is to have children in the White House again, I have to remind myself they're talking about Chelsea."
He rose without notes (whew!), said a few standard things about generational change leading to generational reconciliation, and then, head on, addressed the secret fear of the guests: that he would keep running against Washington, Carter-style.
"Washington is a better place than most Americans think it is," its new leader said, softening up the set that hopes to take him into camp, and added deftly: "I hope to bring more of the country to the capital and more of the capital to the country." That Kennedyesque sugar-coating of rhetorical antithesis helped his centralist medicine go down: enough outsiders would be coming inside to make the Federal presence felt more on the outside.
Governor Clinton recalled how capitals have been places of intrigue, with plots and secret calculations, and then hoped that this capital's residents would ask for the space "to calculate less what is best for us here, and more what is best for all those who sent us here." Such gentle reproof of power-brokerage -- as he was preparing to appoint a set of seasoned economic power brokers -- rated high in the Establishment's calculation.
It was only a high-tension dinner party, not a great test of inner strength or judgment. But such occasions do have value: it was instructive to watch the young pros work a roomful of old pros.

HEADLINE: Rioting Threatens India's Secular Foundation;
Economic Frustration

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Pulling Down India's Temple" (editorial, Dec. 8) and your front-page news article of the same day fail to recognize the economic frustration of quotas and other mechanisms developed by political leaders to woo minorities in India. You overlook the influence of invisible political manipulations of "divide-and-rule" that have governed this other major democracy for five decades. 
 In pre- and post-British India, Hindus and Muslims have cohabited peacefully for centuries, except when incited by politicians who have exploited the masses for their own glorification.
In the 1940's, despite promises of secularism, the British partitioned and created a Muslim state of Pakistan as a result of nurturing this rift. Since India's independence in 1947, the Congress party has ruled by wooing and favoring the minorities with preferential treatment and quotas for the society's historically disadvantaged segments.
But such quotas have a strange way of becoming permanent and escalating, a fear some Americans share in the United States. The sad result is that India's regions receiving preferential status and maximum state support or subsidies seek further insurgence from the state.
A lasting solution lies in preventing politicians from exploiting religious differences by emulating an American-style separation of church and state. Mere inclusion in the state's constitution does not suffice; this secularism must become a legislated, mandatory practice in day-to-day decision making in areas of public life: public schools, higher education, jobs and so on.
The current Hindu outburst is not based just on religious differences. It was born in the average majority citizen's mounting economic frustration. This is the frustration of a Hindu parent whose young son or daughter cannot gain admission to an engineering or medical school because there is a cumulative quota for minorities.
If a reserved job is not taken by a minority in a particular year, it is added to the quota for the next year. As a result, in many walks of public life, more than 90 percent of jobs are reserved for the 10 percent minority in a given year. What we see now is the frustration of young, unemployed graduates who cannot get a decent job in government because these jobs have been reserved for minorities.
Beneath the surface, the riots in India are the people's mammoth economic frustration; the religious differences are merely the visible tip of the iceberg.
 
R. RAY GEHANI
Rochester, Dec. 9, 1992
The writer is a professor of international business at the Rochester Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Experts Gather For Conference On the Economy

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 13

 BODY:
Business leaders, economists, public interest advocates and labor organizers began to gather here today for an economic conference that is shaping up as a nationally televised gabfest about just how bad the economy is and what to do about it.
At last count close to 400 people had been invited by President-elect Bill Clinton to the two-day conference, which starts Monday. But no one is sure of the number because Mr. Clinton keeps wanting to add more people. 
 The President-elect will be the moderator, and the audience, for the economic diagnoses and the cures that are expected to be discussed during 12 hours of meetings here at the neoclassical Robinson Auditorium, the city's largest hall.
Clinton advisers make clear, though, that they have at least three other audiences in mind besides Mr. Clinton. They are the Congress, business leaders and the public, who will watching the conference, and Mr. Clinton, on television.
 
Expect No Miracles
 In a way the conferees will be the props for Mr. Clinton's first real exchange with the American people since being elected -- a discussion intended to convince the the public of Mr. Clinton's contention that the economy is in a structural decline and needs painful medicine. The Clinton team also seems to be seeking to tell voters that no one should expect the President-elect to work miracles.
"It is important for the American people to know that their next President is rolling up his sleeves and getting to work on the economy," said his communications director, George Stephanopoulos. "But it is also important that we understand where the economy is now."
In that vein, the Clinton team continued today to dismiss recent reports of improvement in the unemployment rate and the gross domestic product as misleading. Aides fear that favorable short-term data could slow momentum for Mr. Clinton's proposals.
As Vice President-elect Al Gore contended today in an interview on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," "None of the figures released thus far give any reason to believe that there's been a turnaround."
 
Don't Worry, Be Chatty
 The second audience is American business, which Mr. Clinton is seeking to reassure that there is nothing to fear from a Democratic President. Indeed, the President-elect's intention to listen to business leaders for 12 hours over two days is meant to demonstrate that he will pay attention to their concerns.
The third audience is Congress. While the conference will include some Republicans, participants as a whole tend to be in favor of Mr. Clinton's economic agenda, a way for the Clinton team to signal Congress that the economic experts support the President-elect's programs and share his sense of urgency.
This conference will also showcase Mr. Clinton's intent generally to operate his Presidency as a nonstop campaign for his agenda. As moderator, Mr. Clinton will be able to step into Americans' living rooms.
"Bill Clinton loves the discussion," said Vernon E. Jordan, Mr. Clinton's transition board chairman. "If there is one result to look for, it is that the American people should feel tuned in and part of the process of dealing with the economy."
There will be seven discussion sessions over the two days. Thirty-two conferees will take part in each session and the rest will be the audience.
The opening session on Monday, for instance, will be devoted to an "Assessment of the Domestic Economy," and will include presentations by the economist Robert M. Solow, a Nobel laureate; John Sculley, chairman and chief executive of Apple Computers, and Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, of which Mr. Clinton's wife, Hillary, was once chairwoman.
The afternoon session will be an "Assessment of the International Economy," with presenters including Glen Fukushima, director of A.T.&T. Japan; Larry Summers, chief economist of the World Bank, and Paula Stern, a trade lawyer.
These will be followed by working sessions on "Lifetime Learning," "Investment for Short-Term and Long-Term Growth," "Deficit Reduction," "Environment" and "Government Reform." There will be a closing news conference Tuesday afternoon.

HEADLINE: Tax Breaks Ahead, But How Big and for Whom?

SERIES: Tax Politics; Third of four articles.

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
For the makers of corporate jets, President-elect Bill Clinton's promise to restore an investment tax credit could not come at a better time.
As corporate America suffered in the recession, its jet makers suffered even more. They are just winding up their worst year in memory and are pining for investment credits, which they say increased their annual orders by up to 50 percent in some years. 
 But the way the Clinton plan is shaping up, a tax break for businesses investing in new equipment may not be as generous as in the past. And the structuring of the investment credit, which allows companies to subtract part of the cost of equipment from their tax bills, will determine not only whether it helps one industry or another but whether it increases the Federal deficit -- or makes any difference to the economy at all.
 
Saving an Industry
 The corporate jet builders say they expect the credit, a linchpin of the economic stimulus package Mr. Clinton is weighing, to salvage their industry. Companies like Gulfstream Aerospace of Savannah, Ga., and Beech Aircraft and Learjet Inc., both of Wichita, Kan., would probably respond by hiring thousands of workers to fill the orders they expect to receive, their chief executives told Mr. Clinton in a letter recently.
They are not alone. The National Association of Manufacturers and similar groups are generally in favor of an investment tax credit, and although opinions are not unanimous, many corporate leaders are likely to say so at Mr. Clinton's economic conference that opens Monday in Little Rock, Ark.
The widespread drumbeat of corporate enthusiasm is backed by a chorus of economists.
"I think the investment tax credit has a good history of being an effective economic stimulus," said Joseph W. Duncan, chief economist for the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, who urged the Clinton Administration to formulate it "to give a special benefit to smaller companies" -- those with fewer than 50 employees.
But skeptics abound. They say nobody can prove any benefit to economic growth from investment credits, which have been granted, altered and repealed again and again in the last 30 years.
 
Rules Not Known
 And of course nobody can yet say just what rules will apply this time.
"It is not clear that it will have all that much of an effect," said Jane G. Gravelle, a senior specialist in economic policy at the Congressional Research Service.
Robert S. McIntyre of Citizens for Tax Justice, which is financed largely by labor unions, said the credit would be acceptable only if paid for by raising other corporate taxes, just as corporate income tax rates were lowered when the investment credit was abandoned in 1986.
The Clinton economic program does in fact call for a range of tax increases on businesses as well as a range of tax breaks. The increases, by some estimates, could bring in nearly $60 billion, although other estimates cast doubt on that figure, saying Mr. Clinton's ideas would not raise as much revenue as he projects.
Still, some economists present the investment credit as a miracle cure, a tonic with no deficit hangover.
In a widely circulated simulation of the Clinton economic program that was published just after the election, the economic consultants Lawrence H. Meyer & Associates said that even though a credit might cost the Treasury billions in subsidies for corporate jets, machine tools, bulldozers and the like, the builders of all that equipment would end up paying back billions in payroll, excise and corporate taxes.
The Meyers model assumed that corporations would be given a 10 percent credit for all equipment purchases above 80 percent of the 1992 level. That would prevent a windfall for many companies that would have invested in new equipment anyway.
For at least the first two years, the model showed, the economic boost would funnel enough revenues into Federal tax coffers to offset almost completely the costs of the credit.
Without the "incremental" feature, many economists figure that the investment credit would be far too expensive to justify. The WEFA Group of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said an unconditional 10 percent credit on equipment, like the one favored by jet builders, would drive the nation's production up $60 billion by 1996, with about 500,000 jobs added. But the cumulative budget deficit would be about $55 billion higher than without the credit, or $110,000 per job, the report said.
And Allen Sinai of the Boston Company Economic Advisers Inc. said his projections showed that even a limited investment credit would substantially drive up the deficit. "There is no free ride on tax subsidies," he said.
Many other uncertainties remain.
For example, it is impossible to predict what types of equipment would qualify for the equipment credit. Computers might be excluded, for example, especially if they were used, say, for bookkeeping and word processing rather than for factory-line production. A publisher's presses might qualify, but not its telephones; corporate jets but not fleet automobiles, and so on. Without question there will be tough lobbying to get the credit structured to benefit individual industries.
 
Would Be Retroactive
 To counter fears that industry would defer capital spending while waiting for the tax credit to take hold, Congressional leaders, including Mr. Clinton's Treasury Secretary-designate, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, have said that whatever formula they approve will be retroactively effective to Dec. 3.
Another question is whether companies subject to the alternative minimum tax, which limits their deductions and credits, should be able to take advantage of an investment tax credit.
By one estimate, as many as 60 percent of major corporations are alternative minimum taxpayers; if they cannot use the credit, its utility would be considerably limited. But if they can, some of their tax bills might disappear, defeating the purpose of the minimum tax.
And it is not clear whether the tax credit would be refundable -- that is, whether companies that lose money, and therefore have no tax bills, could receive a refund check from the I.R.S. These might be the very companies that need to invest most to stay competitive.
The stimulative effects of the tax credit, its main justification, come not from its benefits to those who buy equipment and claim the credit, but from those who sell the equipment and hire new workers.
But a rarely mentioned feature of the investment tax is that it helps stimulate foreign suppliers as much as domestic ones. Probably more than a third of the capital equipment purchased by American industry comes from abroad, and it would be very difficult to exclude foreign suppliers from the program. Tight rules that discriminate against foreign companies would put the United States in conflict with world trade agreements.
 
Questions Abound
 There are also thorny administrative difficulties inherent in the most likely approach for an investment tax credit, an incremental tax credit that would reward only investments above a certain base.
Ms. Gravelle of the Congressional Research Service, one of the credit's critics, gives several examples:
*What about newly formed companies? If all their investments qualify for the credit, they would be at a huge advantage over established competitors.
*What about foreign-owned companies, whose capital spending is growing faster than well-established domestic-owned companies?
*How should companies that have been divested from parent corporations be treated? How about companies that merge?
*How should leasing companies be treated? If they qualify for the investment credit, would companies that do not qualify because their investments are declining simply decide to lease equipment instead? If they do not qualify, how would that affect, for example, the airlines, which typically lease about half of their fleets?
*What happens when companies sell old equipment and buy new? Could sharp managers take advantage of the credit by selling like equipment to each other?
*When partnerships apply for the tax credit, are past investments calculated for the partnership as a whole or for individual partners? It would make a big difference, and it would be hard to devise a system that prevented partnerships from reorganizing to get around any restrictions.
"These are only the problems that I can think of," Ms. Gravelle said. "I'm sure the lawyers will be able to think of others."
Unfortunately for both boosters and detractors of the investment credit, its chaotic history provides no solid lesson.
First put into effect in 1962, during the Kennedy Administration, the credit was switched off and on sporadically for decades, then was abandoned in the Reagan Administration's sweeping tax changes of 1986.
When first enacted, the credit was worth 7 percent (but just 3 percent for electric utilities). In October 1966, in an attempt to restrain inflation, the tax credit was temporarily suspended. After second thoughts, it was restored early in 1967. The credit was then repealed in 1969, once again to fight inflation.
In 1971, it once more was restored in an attempt to stimulate economic growth, and in 1975 it was increased to 10 percent. It was extended in 1976 and again in 1977, and Congress made it permanent in 1978.
 
Credit Somewhat Diluted
 The record is further clouded because the size of the credit was open to tinkering. When first enacted its effect was somewhat diluted by a provision that prevented companies from taking any depreciation on the portion of an investment that was refunded by the credit. That provision was repealed in 1964. From 1982 to 1986, depreciation was forbidden on half the credit's value.
The incremental tax the Clinton team is considering is also somewhat diluted in value. If a company that invested $100 million in 1992 raised investments to $120 million in 1993, a 10 percent credit on the increment above 80 percent of the previous year would be worth $4 million. That is just 3.3 percent of the company's total investment for the year. And if spending went up to $140 million the next year, the relative worth of the tax credit would be even less.
To economists, that is not much, especially if the stimulative effects of a tax credit and other fiscal policies drive inflation up sharply.
"Getting 4 points off the inflation rate is roughly 70 percent of the bang of a 5 percent investment tax credit," said Lawrence Lindsey, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board. "That's quite significant."

CORRECTION-DATE: December 15, 1992, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about proposals to change the tax treatment of health benefits misstated the provisions of the plan in the House of Representatives. It would limit a tax deduction for employers to the cost of a minimum standard package of benefits. For employees, all employer-provided benefits would remain tax-free.

HEADLINE: Hispanic Pragmatism Seen in Survey

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO

 BODY:
An overwhelming majority of the Hispanic population in the United States says there is too much immigration, according to a nationwide public opinion survey being made public today in Washington.
And in another response that poll takers said was likely to confound expectations in an era when ethnic identity has been emphasized, a large proportion of Hispanic citizens and residents say people who live in this country should learn to speak English. 
 The Latino National Political Survey, the most extensive effort to measure Hispanic attitudes to date, concludes that on these issues, as well as on other social and political questions, economic self-interest and a driving commitment to be part of American society shape attitudes among Hispanic groups more than a sense of ethnic identity.
And members of a team of scholars who directed the survey, of people of Mexican, Puerto Rican and Cuban origin, said that the results should dispel any notions that their political attitudes separate them from the majority of the American population or define them as a monolithic interest group.
"Overall, these groups do not constitute a political community," the report on the survey said.
Referring to the survey's respondents, the authors of the report, "Latino Voices," added, "Their positive views on their experiences with government and their optimism about their future suggest that the relationship between these groups and mainstream society is not so harsh as to isolate the 'Hispanic' community and make it easily mobilized around narrow ethnic appeals."
The survey was directed by a team of academic experts and consisted of face-to-face interviews with 2,817 people in 40 metropolitan areas from August 1989 to April 1990.
 
Detailed Questions Asked
 Unlike previous polls, the survey asked detailed questions touching on many issues, including discrimination, language and ethnic identity, and separated the responses by national group and citizenship status. The researchers said the survey was meant to fill a major void in the knowledge of attitudes among Hispanic residents and citizens.
Only a minority of the people surveyed said they had personally experienced bias based on their national origins. But clear majorities said they believed some discrimination existed against their national groups.
The survey, which assessed the language abilities of respondents to determine which language to use in interviews, found that a large majority of Hispanic people born in the United States speak English better than Spanish, and it said there were high levels of English literacy even among foreign-born immigrants who prefer to speak Spanish.
But though the poll's authors said there was strong support for bilingual education among all Hispanic groups, an overwhelming majority of those who said they were American citizens indicated that its goal should be to teach English or both languages rather than to preserve the Spanish language and culture.
"The results of this survey will prove surprising to people who have generalized from the most distinctive and visible part of the Latino population, which tends to be poor and Spanish-speaking," said Rodolfo O. de la Garza, a professor of government at the University of Texas who was the survey's principal researcher. "Even among those on the margins of society we found a desire to gain access to mainstream America. And there is a large population, especially among the native born, who are much less visible because they have already incorporated themselves."
Majorities as high as 80 percent among some Hispanic groups said there was too much immigration. And further, among Hispanic citizens in all groups, clear majorities disagreed with the notion that special preferences should be given to prospective immigrants from Latin American countries over those from other regions. "The explanation for this is simply that Latinos are the people who feel the greatest economic competition from immigrants," Professor de la Garza said.
F. Chris Garcia, a co-researcher on the survey who is a professor of political science at the University of New Mexico, said: "Latinos are much more pragmatic than we give them credit for in academic and activist circles. They are, after all, subject to the same pressures for accommodation as any other groups in the same socioeconomic conditions, and regardless of their national origins they have the same concerns as other similarly situated Americans."
In fact, clearly rejecting labels like "Hispanic" or "Latino," which tend to lump all national groups together, members of each group said in overwhelmingly large numbers that they believed they had little in common with the others.
The survey also found some deep social bonds within each national group, but it exposed a surprising lack of interest among respondents for most Hispanic groups, leaders or causes.
Angelo Falcon, another co-researcher on the study and the president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy in New York, noted that a majority of respondents in each national group described themselves as moderate to conservative ideologically. In other surveys, Mexican-American and Puerto Rican political leaders describe themselves as primarily liberal.
"The implication is that there is a growing gulf between the Latino leadership and the community," said Mr. Falcon. "The degree of assimilation illustrates that for many years, even as the leadership has identified itself ethnically, there has been no real Latino political movement that might have encouraged distinctively Latino views."
Hispanic citizens in the survey readily identified themselves by their national groups and said they were most likely to socialize with other members of their group. But responses were nearly evenly split when people were asked whether or not public officials from their own national groups were more helpful than others.
More than 90 percent of the respondents in each group said they did not belong to any ethnic organizations, and less than 13 percent said they had participated in any political activities organized around their national groups.
 
Some Contrasting Attitudes
 Several contrasting attitudes and values among the various Hispanic groups emerged in the survey.
Puerto Ricans, who are United States citizens by birth, nonetheless expressed greater concern with events in their ethnic homeland. And Puerto Ricans were the only group in which a clear majority said the history of their ethnic homeland should be taught in schools along with American history.
American citizens of Mexican origin showed the least concern of any group with the politics of their ethnic homeland, and were the least likely to support increased government spending on programs for refugees and immigrants.
The three national Hispanic groups surveyed represent almost 80 percent of the total Hispanic population of the United States. The survey sample is representative of 90 percent of the members of those groups. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Conducted with financing from the Ford, Rockefeller, Spencer and Tinker Foundations, the survey asked as many as 200 questions of individual respondents, who were given the choice of being interviewed in English or Spanish. About 60 percent of the respondents chose Spanish.

HEADLINE: Clinton Picks Arkansas Official To Be New U.S. Surgeon General

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Dec. 14

 BODY:
The top Arkansas health official, Dr. Joycelyn Elders, has been asked by President-elect Bill Clinton to be the new surgeon general, a transition official said today.
Dr. Elders, a 59-year-old pediatrician here and the director of the State Health Department, was offered the position over the weekend and accepted it immediately, the official said. She would become the second black and fifth woman to be named to a top post in the Clinton Administration. 
 The transition team had not expected to announce Dr. Elders's appointment before Wednesday, but now may announce it on Tuesday because of the disclosure tonight, first reported by The Associated Press.
 
'Conscience of Health Care'
 Dr. Harry Ward, chancellor for medical sciences at the University of Arkansas, said tonight of Dr. Elders, "She has become the conscience of health care in our state, speaking out in a very candid way on every major health-care issue from teen-age pregnancy to poverty to violence."
If confirmed, Dr. Elders would replace Dr. Antonia Novello as head of the Government's Public Health Service.
Dr. Elders has battled with conservative groups in Arkansas for her advocacy of distributing contraceptives at school health clinics to combat AIDS and pregnancy.
She has said when confronted on the issue, "I really feel we must put our children first and I'm willing to do whatever we have to do to save the children."
Dr. Elders is the first black and first women to head the Arkansas Health Department. She came to the job in 1987 after a 26-year career in pediatrics at the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences.
She is a 1952 honors graduate of Philander Smith College, a mostly black college in Little Rock. She earned a master's degree in biochemistry and her medical degree from the University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences and did pediatric training at the University of Minnesota.
Dr. Elders and her husband, Oliver, a high school basketball coach, have two sons, Eric, 29, and Kevin, 27.
According to an article in The New York Times Magazine in 1989, Dr. Elders is the author or co-author of 138 published monographs, many of them dealing with growth problems and diabetes, the treatment of which first brought her to the attention of the state's medical community. Her level of expertise was such that doctors around the state routinely began to refer their juvenile patients with insulin-dependent diabetes to her.
On Saturday, Mr. Clinton named another black, Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic Party chairman, as his Commerce Secretary. The other women Mr. Clinton has named so far are Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency; Alice M. Rivlin, deputy budget director; Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services.

HEADLINE: THE TRANSITION;
Gore Bringing Environmental Policy to Fore

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 14

 BODY:
With a month to go before the Clinton Administration takes office, Vice President-elect Al Gore has already had unusual influence on a broad range of appointments and is supervising the development of new policies on the environment, natural resources, technology and the economy, transition aides say.
The most immediate example of Mr. Gore's influence with Mr. Clinton occurred last Friday when a former senior Senate aide was chosen by Mr. Clinton to be Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. 
 Another example will come Tuesday, the second day of the economic conference in Little Rock, Ark., when Mr. Gore is to lead a panel he organized on the connection between economic growth, environmental safeguards and new technology.
But such visible signs of Mr. Gore's authority are viewed by transition aides as merely the prelude to a much larger vision that Mr. Gore and Mr. Clinton have for the Government: how to make environmental and economic goals equal in virtually every decision the new Administration makes.
 
Counterweight to Quayle
 "A heavy majority of the American people understand that our future depends on maintaining a sustainable environment, on conserving our resources, on solving our problems and that in doing that we can create economic opportunity," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference on Friday.
Indeed, scholars of the American Presidency say that Mr. Gore's influence will apparently exceed the considerable power wielded by Vice President Walter F. Mondale early in President Jimmy Carter's Administration.
Some said the only comparable example is the commanding role that Vice President Dan Quayle has played on environmental and economic issues in the last two years of President Bush's Administration. Mr. Quayle and a group of aides, through his Council on Competitiveness, developed the White House program for stalling regulations deemed unfriendly to business and speeding those considered helpful.
Aides to the Clinton transition said the process of gaining economic benefits from environmental safeguards begins by dismantling the barriers that have long existed between the agencies that regulate the environment, natural resources, research and economy.
 
Traditional Bureau Battles
 For example, the head of the United States Forest Service historically battled the Environmental Protection Agency over decisions on barring defoliants. Nor was the Department of the Interior often in contact with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration on offshore drilling.
Transition aides said the new Administration goal is to have concern for environmental protection permeate the entire range of public policy, an idea Mr. Gore has long advocated.
In one indication of such goals, Mr. Clinton named his boyhood friend, Thomas F. McLarty 3d to be chief of staff. Mr. McLarty is a member of the Business Council for a Sustainable Energy Future, which has called for creating thousands of jobs and reducing environmental damage by sharply increasing the use of natural gas and renewable energy sources.
Mr. Gore declined to be interviewed. But on Sunday on the CBS News program "Face the Nation," Mr. Gore said he did not have any "line responsibilities for the environment." He added, though, that Mr. Clinton had "been very generous in asking for my advice on the decisions that he faces."
Some evidence for Mr. Gore's clout has been highly public. On Friday, Carol M. Browner, the Secretary of Environmental Regulation in Florida and a former senior aide to Senator Gore, was chosen to be Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency.
A week ago, Mr. Gore announced he would block the opening of the nation's newest hazardous-waste incinerator in Ohio pending the outcome of a Congressional investigation into its safety and how its permits had been issued.
Other examples of Mr. Gore's authority have been less public. Mr. Gore helped scuttle the nomination of Lawrence H. Summers, the chief economist at the World Bank, as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers after environmentalists criticized his views on protecting natural resources.
